large language models and improving reliability and trustworthiness.

AI.tldr: ExpertAgent is an intelligent agent framework for personalized education that adaptively plans learning content and strategies in real time using a continually updated student model and a validated curriculum repository, reducing LLM hallucinations and improving reliability.
AI.motivation: Generative AI in education often lacks real-time adaptability, personalization, and reliable, non-hallucinatory content, limiting its practical effectiveness and trustworthiness.
AI.method: Design an intelligent learning agent (ExpertAgent) that: (1) maintains a continuously updated student model; (2) dynamically plans content and pedagogy based on that model; (3) grounds all instructional outputs in a validated curriculum repository; and (4) delivers proactive, personalized learning experiences.
AI.result: The abstract claims ExpertAgent overcomes static-content limitations, delivers optimized teaching strategies with real-time adaptivity, and reduces hallucination risk, thereby improving reliability and trust. No quantitative results or benchmarks are reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: A grounded, student-model-driven agent can provide reliable, highly adaptive personalized learning; ExpertAgent is proposed to address key shortcomings of current AI tools in education by coupling dynamic planning with curriculum-grounded content.

title: ParsTranslit: Truly Versatile Tajik-Farsi Transliteration
summary:
As a digraphic language, the Persian language utilizes two written standards:
Perso-Arabic in Afghanistan and Iran, and Tajik-Cyrillic in Tajikistan. Despite
the significant similarity between the dialects of each country, script
differences prevent simple one-to-one mapping, hindering written communication
and interaction between Tajikistan and its Persian-speaking ``siblings''. To
overcome this, previously-published efforts have investigated machine
transliteration models to convert between the two scripts. Unfortunately, most
efforts did not use datasets other than those they created, limiting these
models to certain domains of text such as archaic poetry or word lists. A truly
usable transliteration system must be capable of handling varied domains,
meaning that suck models lack the versatility required for real-world usage.
The contrast in domain between data also obscures the task's true difficulty.
We present a new state-of-the-art sequence-to-sequence model for Tajik-Farsi
transliteration trained across all available datasets, and present two datasets
of our own. Our results across domains provide clearer understanding of the
task, and set comprehensive comparable leading benchmarks. Overall, our model
achieves chrF++ and Normalized CER scores of 87.91 and 0.05 from Farsi to Tajik
and 92.28 and 0.04 from Tajik to Farsi. Our model, data, and code are available
at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/ParsTranslit-FB30/.

AI.tldr: They build a cross-domain, state-of-the-art seq2seq transliteration system between Tajik (Cyrillic) and Farsi (Perso‑Arabic), train it on all available corpora plus two new datasets, and report strong bidirectional scores, establishing comprehensive benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Persian is written in two scripts across countries; script mismatch blocks straightforward communication. Prior transliteration work relied on narrow, self-collected datasets (e.g., poetry, word lists), limiting generalization and obscuring the true task difficulty. A practical system must work across varied domains and needs clear, comparable evaluation.
AI.method: Develop a sequence-to-sequence transliteration model trained jointly on all available datasets and two newly introduced datasets. Evaluate bidirectionally (Farsi→Tajik and Tajik→Farsi) across multiple domains using chrF++ and Normalized CER to provide comparable, cross-domain benchmarks.
AI.result: New state-of-the-art performance with chrF++/Normalized CER: 87.91/0.05 (Farsi→Tajik) and 92.28/0.04 (Tajik→Farsi). The cross-domain evaluation clarifies difficulty and shows robustness beyond prior domain-limited systems.
AI.conclusion: A unified, data-aggregated seq2seq approach yields robust, practical Tajik–Farsi transliteration in both directions, sets strong, comparable benchmarks, and releases model, data, and code for reproducibility and future work.

title: Cross-Modal Attention Guided Unlearning in Vision-Language Models
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have demonstrated immense capabilities in
multi-modal understanding and inference tasks such as Visual Question Answering
(VQA), which requires models to infer outputs based on visual and textual
context simultaneously. Such inference abilities of large-scale pretrained
models are often attributed to the massive scale of pre-training data collected
across several domains. However, the models may memorize private and/or
sensitive information during training and regurgitate it in inference.
Recently, machine unlearning has been leveraged to address the leakage of
private data in LLMs. VLMs add a layer of complexity to this process, as the
visual context in the query may also contain sensitive information in addition
to the text. To address this issue, we explore unlearning for vision-language
models, specifically for the VQA task. We explore the role of visual tokens for
output generation in VLMs using cross-modal attention and utilize it to
formulate Cross-Modal Attention Guided Unlearning (CAGUL), a lightweight and
efficient VLM unlearning framework. In contrast to computationally expensive
model finetuning methods, CAGUL utilizes external modules to encode unlearning
information in visual tokens of low importance for relevant queries. We find
that the transformed visual tokens not only prevent leakage but also retain
reference model behavior. Experimental results show that our method performs
better or on par with finetuning-based baselines without altering the
pre-trained model parameters or incurring retraining costs, making it a
practical and effective unlearning solution for VLMs.

AI.tldr: Proposes CAGUL, a lightweight unlearning framework for VLMs (VQA) that uses cross‑modal attention to target low-importance visual tokens and encode unlearning signals via external modules, preventing sensitive information leakage without finetuning or retraining, while preserving model behavior and matching/exceeding finetuning baselines.
AI.motivation: Large VLMs can memorize and leak private/sensitive information during inference. Unlike text-only LLMs, VLM queries may also contain sensitive visual content, making unlearning more complex. There is a need for practical, low-cost unlearning that avoids retraining/finetuning and preserves utility.
AI.method: Analyze cross‑modal attention to quantify each visual token’s contribution to output generation in VQA. Introduce Cross‑Modal Attention Guided Unlearning (CAGUL), which employs external modules to inject unlearning information into visual tokens deemed low-importance for the query, thereby suppressing leakage while keeping high-importance tokens intact. Crucially, pretrained model parameters are not modified, avoiding expensive finetuning.
AI.result: Transformed visual tokens block private data leakage yet maintain the reference model’s behavior. Empirically, CAGUL performs on par with or better than finetuning-based unlearning baselines, with no changes to pretrained parameters and no retraining cost.
AI.conclusion: CAGUL offers a practical, efficient, and effective unlearning approach for VLMs (particularly VQA): it mitigates sensitive information leakage via token-level interventions guided by cross-modal attention, preserves task performance, and eliminates the need for model finetuning or retraining.

title: Evaluation of LLMs for Process Model Analysis and Optimization
comment:
15 pages, 5 tables, 4 figures; full research paper currently under
  review for the Workshop on Information Technologies and Systems (WITS) 2025.
  The paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of large language models (LLMs)
  for business process model analysis and optimization, including error
  detection, reasoning, and scenario-based redesign
summary:
In this paper, we report our experience with several LLMs for their ability
to understand a process model in an interactive, conversational style, find
syntactical and logical errors in it, and reason with it in depth through a
natural language (NL) interface. Our findings show that a vanilla, untrained
LLM like ChatGPT (model o3) in a zero-shot setting is effective in
understanding BPMN process models from images and answering queries about them
intelligently at syntactic, logic, and semantic levels of depth. Further,
different LLMs vary in performance in terms of their accuracy and
effectiveness. Nevertheless, our empirical analysis shows that LLMs can play a
valuable role as assistants for business process designers and users. We also
study the LLM's "thought process" and ability to perform deeper reasoning in
the context of process analysis and optimization. We find that the LLMs seem to
exhibit anthropomorphic properties.

AI.tldr: Empirical study shows that zero-shot, multimodal LLMs (notably ChatGPT o3) can read BPMN diagrams from images, detect syntactic/logical issues, and answer deep queries; performance varies across models, but they appear useful as assistants and sometimes exhibit seemingly anthropomorphic reasoning patterns.
AI.motivation: Assess whether general-purpose LLMs can practically support business process modeling by understanding BPMN diagrams, catching errors, and reasoning about processes via natural language—potentially lowering barriers for designers and analysts.
AI.method: Interactive, conversational evaluation of several LLMs on BPMN process models presented as images. Tasks include comprehension, syntactic/logic error detection, and deeper semantic reasoning for analysis/optimization. Zero-shot prompts are used; models’ responses and apparent reasoning (“thought process”) are compared for accuracy and effectiveness.
AI.result: ChatGPT (o3) performs effectively in zero-shot image-to-text understanding of BPMN and handles syntactic, logical, and semantic questions. Other LLMs show varying accuracy/effectiveness. LLMs can assist designers/users in practice. Observations suggest models display anthropomorphic-seeming behaviors during deeper reasoning.
AI.conclusion: LLMs, even without task-specific fine-tuning, can aid business process analysis and design from visual BPMN inputs. Their capabilities differ across models; while promising as assistants, claims of deeper reasoning/anthropomorphism warrant careful, rigorous validation in future work.

title: OWL: Overcoming Window Length-Dependence in Speculative Decoding for Long-Context Inputs
summary:
Speculative decoding promises faster inference for large language models
(LLMs), yet existing methods fail to generalize to real-world settings.
Benchmarks typically assume short contexts (e.g., 2K tokens), whereas practical
workloads involve long contexts. We find current approaches degrade severely
with long contexts; for instance, EAGLE3 even slows down the generation speed
by 0.81x. We address these limitations by releasing a new long-context
benchmark (LongSpecBench) and introducing a novel model (OWL). OWL achieves
about 5x higher acceptance length than EAGLE3 on long-context inputs through
three innovations: (1) an LSTM-based drafter conditioned only on the last-token
state, making it generalize to various lengths, (2) a special token [SPEC] in
the verifier that produces richer representation for drafter, and (3) a hybrid
algorithm combining both tree and non-tree decoding methods. We release all
code and datasets to advance future research.

AI.tldr: Speculative decoding methods that speed up LLM inference break down on long contexts. The authors introduce a long-context benchmark (LongSpecBench) and a new speculative decoder (OWL) that generalizes across sequence lengths and yields much higher token acceptance in long contexts (≈5× over EAGLE3).
AI.motivation: Real-world LLM workloads often use long contexts, but popular speculative decoding benchmarks and methods are tuned for short inputs (~2K tokens). Existing approaches degrade severely as context length grows, sometimes becoming slower than baseline decoding. There is a need for both a realistic benchmark and an approach that remains efficient on long sequences.
AI.method: 1) Create LongSpecBench to evaluate speculative decoding under long-context conditions. 2) Propose OWL: (a) an LSTM-based drafter conditioned only on the last-token state to enable length-agnostic generalization; (b) introduce a special verifier token [SPEC] to produce richer conditioning signals for the drafter; (c) employ a hybrid speculative decoding algorithm that combines tree and non-tree strategies to improve acceptance and stability.
AI.result: On long-context inputs, prior systems (e.g., EAGLE3) can even slow generation (0.81× of baseline). OWL achieves about 5× higher acceptance length than EAGLE3, implying substantially greater speedups in long-context inference. Code and datasets are released.
AI.conclusion: Speculative decoding must be rethought for long-context scenarios. The proposed benchmark and OWL’s architecture/algorithmic changes improve acceptance rates and practical efficiency, offering a more robust path to fast LLM inference at long sequence lengths.

title: MaizeStandCounting (MaSC): Automated and Accurate Maize Stand Counting from UAV Imagery Using Image Processing and Deep Learning
comment:
10 pages, 11 figures. Submitted to IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in
  Signal Processing (JSTSP) Special Series on Artificial Intelligence for Smart
  Agriculture
summary:
Accurate maize stand counts are essential for crop management and research,
informing yield prediction, planting density optimization, and early detection
of germination issues. Manual counting is labor-intensive, slow, and
error-prone, especially across large or variable fields. We present
MaizeStandCounting (MaSC), a robust algorithm for automated maize seedling
stand counting from RGB imagery captured by low-cost UAVs and processed on
affordable hardware. MaSC operates in two modes: (1) mosaic images divided into
patches, and (2) raw video frames aligned using homography matrices. Both modes
use a lightweight YOLOv9 model trained to detect maize seedlings from V2-V10
growth stages. MaSC distinguishes maize from weeds and other vegetation, then
performs row and range segmentation based on the spatial distribution of
detections to produce precise row-wise stand counts. Evaluation against
in-field manual counts from our 2024 summer nursery showed strong agreement
with ground truth (R^2= 0.616 for mosaics, R^2 = 0.906 for raw frames). MaSC
processed 83 full-resolution frames in 60.63 s, including inference and
post-processing, highlighting its potential for real-time operation. These
results demonstrate MaSC's effectiveness as a scalable, low-cost, and accurate
tool for automated maize stand counting in both research and production
environments.

AI.tldr: MaSC is a low-cost, UAV RGB–based pipeline that detects maize seedlings with a lightweight YOLOv9, segments rows/ranges, and outputs row-wise stand counts. It supports mosaic patches and homography-aligned raw frames, achieving strong agreement with manual counts (especially on raw frames) and near–real-time throughput.
AI.motivation: Manual maize stand counts are laborious, slow, and error-prone, yet they are critical for yield prediction, planting density optimization, and early detection of emergence issues. There is a need for scalable, affordable automation that works in real field conditions.
AI.method: Two operating modes: (1) mosaic images split into patches; (2) raw video frames aligned via homographies. A lightweight YOLOv9 detects maize seedlings from V2–V10 and distinguishes them from weeds. Spatial clustering is then used for row and range segmentation to produce row-wise counts. Processing is designed for affordable hardware and aims at real-time operation.
AI.result: Against in-field manual counts from a 2024 nursery, the system achieved R^2=0.616 on mosaics and R^2=0.906 on raw frames. Throughput was 83 full-resolution frames in 60.63 s including inference and post-processing, indicating near real-time potential.
AI.conclusion: MaSC provides an accurate, scalable, and low-cost solution for automated maize stand counting; the raw-frame pipeline notably outperforms mosaics. It is promising for both research and production use given accuracy and processing speed.

title: Optimizing Ethical Risk Reduction for Medical Intelligent Systems with Constraint Programming
summary:
Medical Intelligent Systems (MIS) are increasingly integrated into healthcare
workflows, offering significant benefits but also raising critical safety and
ethical concerns. According to the European Union AI Act, most MIS will be
classified as high-risk systems, requiring a formal risk management process to
ensure compliance with the ethical requirements of trust- worthy AI. In this
context, we focus on risk reduction optimization problems, which aim to reduce
risks with ethical considerations by finding the best balanced assignment of
risk assessment values according to their coverage of trustworthy AI ethical
requirements. We formalize this problem as a constrained optimization task and
investigate three resolution paradigms: Mixed Integer Programming (MIP),
Satisfiability (SAT), and Constraint Pro- gramming(CP).Our contributions
include the mathematical formulation of this optimization problem, its modeling
with the Minizinc constraint modeling language, and a comparative experimental
study that analyzes the performance, expressiveness, and scalability of each
ap- proach to solving. From the identified limits of the methodology, we draw
some perspectives of this work regarding the integration of the Minizinc model
into a complete trustworthy AI ethical risk management process for MIS.

AI.tldr: They formalize ethical risk-reduction for Medical Intelligent Systems as a constrained optimization problem aligned with EU AI Act/Trustworthy AI requirements, implement it in MiniZinc, and empirically compare MIP, SAT, and CP approaches, discussing trade-offs, scalability, and integration into a full risk management workflow.
AI.motivation: MIS are deemed high-risk under the EU AI Act and must meet Trustworthy AI ethical requirements. Current risk management lacks a principled, optimized way to allocate mitigations/assessments across ethical dimensions. The paper seeks a formal, systematic approach to reduce risk while respecting ethical coverage and regulatory constraints.
AI.method: Define risk-reduction as a constrained optimization task that balances risk assessment values across ethical requirements. Encode the problem in MiniZinc and solve it using three paradigms—Mixed Integer Programming, SAT/Max-SAT-style encodings, and Constraint Programming—then run a comparative experimental study on performance, expressiveness, and scalability, noting modeling trade-offs and methodological limits.
AI.result: A portable MiniZinc model and mathematical formulation of the problem; empirical comparison showing differing strengths/limitations of MIP, SAT, and CP in performance, scalability, and modeling expressiveness; identification of methodological limits and integration considerations. No single universal winner is claimed in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: Optimization-based ethical risk reduction for MIS is feasible and practically modelable in MiniZinc. Each solving paradigm offers trade-offs; selecting one depends on problem structure and constraints. The work points toward integrating the MiniZinc model within a comprehensive, trustworthy AI risk management process for MIS and outlines next steps to overcome identified limitations.

title: Deploying Tiny LVLM Judges for Real-World Evaluation of Chart Models: Lessons Learned and Best Practices
comment: Accepted to the EMNLP 2025 Industry Track
summary:
Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) with only 7B parameters have shown
promise as automated judges in chart comprehension tasks. However, tiny models
(<=2B parameters) still perform poorly as judges, limiting their real-world use
in resource-constrained settings. To address this, we propose two approaches to
ensure cost-efficient evaluation: (i) multi-criteria prompting, which combines
separate evaluation criteria into a single query, and (ii) domain-adaptive
transfer learning, in which we fine-tune a 2B-parameter LVLM on synthetic
judgments in a chart dataset to create the ChartJudge. Experiments show that
multi-criteria prompting exposes robustness gaps, which led to a huge drop in
performance for 7B models, including specialized LVLM judges like LLaVA-Critic.
In addition, we find that our tiny LVLM (ChartJudge) can effectively transfer
knowledge from one dataset to another to make it a more specialized model. Our
fine-grained analysis across chart types and query complexities offers
actionable insights into trade-offs between model size, prompt design, and
transferability, enabling scalable, low-cost evaluation for chart reasoning
tasks. Our code and the data will be made publicly available.

AI.tldr: They introduce multi-criteria prompting and a domain-adaptively fine-tuned 2B LVLM (ChartJudge) to enable low-cost, scalable judging for chart reasoning. Multi-criteria prompts reveal robustness gaps in 7B judges, while the tiny ChartJudge transfers well across datasets.
AI.motivation: Existing ~7B LVLM judges work but are costly; ≤2B models perform poorly, limiting use in resource-constrained settings. The authors aim to create a robust, low-cost evaluator and examine how prompt design affects judge reliability.
AI.method: (i) Multi-criteria prompting: merge separate evaluation criteria into a single query to stress-test robustness. (ii) Domain-adaptive transfer learning: fine-tune a 2B-parameter LVLM on synthetic judgment data from a chart dataset to build ChartJudge. They evaluate across chart types and query complexities and study cross-dataset transfer.
AI.result: Multi-criteria prompting causes large performance drops for 7B LVLM judges, including specialized ones like LLaVA-Critic, exposing robustness gaps. The fine-tuned 2B model (ChartJudge) effectively transfers knowledge between datasets and becomes a more specialized judge. Fine-grained analysis highlights trade-offs among model size, prompt design, and transferability.
AI.conclusion: Tiny LVLMs, when domain-adaptively trained, can serve as effective, low-cost chart-judging models. Prompt design critically affects robustness; combining criteria can degrade larger judges. ChartJudge offers a scalable alternative, with released code and data to support adoption.

title: Quick-CapsNet (QCN): A fast alternative to Capsule Networks
summary:
The basic computational unit in Capsule Network (CapsNet) is a capsule (vs.
neurons in Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)). A capsule is a set of
neurons, which form a vector. CapsNet is used for supervised classification of
data and has achieved state-of-the-art accuracy on MNIST digit recognition
dataset, outperforming conventional CNNs in detecting overlapping digits.
Moreover, CapsNet shows higher robustness towards affine transformation when
compared to CNNs for MNIST datasets. One of the drawbacks of CapsNet, however,
is slow training and testing. This can be a bottleneck for applications that
require a fast network, especially during inference. In this work, we introduce
Quick-CapsNet (QCN) as a fast alternative to CapsNet, which can be a starting
point to develop CapsNet for fast real-time applications. QCN builds on
producing a fewer number of capsules, which results in a faster network. QCN
achieves this at the cost of marginal loss in accuracy. Inference is 5x faster
on MNIST, F-MNIST, SVHN and Cifar-10 datasets. We also further enhanced QCN by
employing a more powerful decoder instead of the default decoder to further
improve QCN.

AI.tldr: Proposes Quick-CapsNet (QCN), a streamlined Capsule Network that reduces the number of capsules to achieve ~5x faster inference on MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, SVHN, and CIFAR-10, with only marginal accuracy loss; performance further improved by a stronger decoder.
AI.motivation: CapsNets outperform CNNs on tasks like overlapping digits and show robustness to affine transforms, but their slow training and inference hinder deployment in latency-sensitive, real-time applications.
AI.method: Design a faster CapsNet by producing fewer capsules to cut computation; replace the default decoder with a more powerful one to compensate for accuracy loss and improve representations.
AI.result: On MNIST, F-MNIST, SVHN, and CIFAR-10, QCN attains approximately 5x faster inference with only a small drop in classification accuracy; the enhanced decoder further improves results (details not quantified in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: QCN serves as a practical, fast alternative to standard CapsNet for scenarios where inference speed is critical, offering a favorable speed–accuracy trade-off and a base for real-time applications.

title: CompassLLM: A Multi-Agent Approach toward Geo-Spatial Reasoning for Popular Path Query
summary:
The popular path query - identifying the most frequented routes between
locations from historical trajectory data - has important applications in urban
planning, navigation optimization, and travel recommendations. While
traditional algorithms and machine learning approaches have achieved success in
this domain, they typically require model training, parameter tuning, and
retraining when accommodating data updates. As Large Language Models (LLMs)
demonstrate increasing capabilities in spatial and graph-based reasoning, there
is growing interest in exploring how these models can be applied to geo-spatial
problems.
  We introduce CompassLLM, a novel multi-agent framework that intelligently
leverages the reasoning capabilities of LLMs into the geo-spatial domain to
solve the popular path query. CompassLLM employs its agents in a two-stage
pipeline: the SEARCH stage that identifies popular paths, and a GENERATE stage
that synthesizes novel paths in the absence of an existing one in the
historical trajectory data. Experiments on real and synthetic datasets show
that CompassLLM demonstrates superior accuracy in SEARCH and competitive
performance in GENERATE while being cost-effective.

AI.tldr: CompassLLM is a multi-agent LLM framework that finds and, when needed, synthesizes popular paths from trajectory data, achieving strong accuracy and cost-efficiency.
AI.motivation: Popular path queries are valuable for urban planning and navigation, but traditional/ML methods need training, parameter tuning, and retraining as data changes. With LLMs showing promise in spatial and graph reasoning, there is interest in using them to reduce these overheads and increase adaptability.
AI.method: A two-stage multi-agent pipeline: (1) SEARCH agents identify popular paths from historical trajectories; (2) GENERATE agents synthesize plausible new paths when no suitable historical path exists, leveraging LLM reasoning over geo-spatial/graph structures.
AI.result: On real and synthetic datasets, CompassLLM attains superior accuracy for the SEARCH task and competitive performance for GENERATE, while remaining cost-effective.
AI.conclusion: LLM-driven, multi-agent reasoning is an effective and economical alternative for popular path queries, handling both retrieval and novel path synthesis, and suggests broader applicability to geo-spatial problems.

title: Multi-Task Pre-Finetuning of Lightweight Transformer Encoders for Text Classification and NER
summary:
Deploying natural language processing (NLP) models on mobile platforms
requires models that can adapt across diverse applications while remaining
efficient in memory and computation. We investigate pre-finetuning strategies
to enhance the adaptability of lightweight BERT-like encoders for two
fundamental NLP task families: named entity recognition (NER) and text
classification. While pre-finetuning improves downstream performance for each
task family individually, we find that na\"ive multi-task pre-finetuning
introduces conflicting optimization signals that degrade overall performance.
To address this, we propose a simple yet effective multi-task pre-finetuning
framework based on task-primary LoRA modules, which enables a single shared
encoder backbone with modular adapters. Our approach achieves performance
comparable to individual pre-finetuning while meeting practical deployment
constraint. Experiments on 21 downstream tasks show average improvements of
+0.8% for NER and +8.8% for text classification, demonstrating the
effectiveness of our method for versatile mobile NLP applications.

AI.tldr: They show that naïve multi-task pre-finetuning harms lightweight BERT encoders, and propose task-primary LoRA adapters on a shared backbone to avoid optimization conflicts, yielding per-task-level performance with mobile-friendly efficiency.
AI.motivation: Mobile NLP needs models that are both efficient (memory/compute) and adaptable across apps. Pre-finetuning helps adaptability, but combining tasks naïvely causes conflicting gradients that degrade performance. The authors seek a way to get the benefits of multi-task pre-finetuning without interference.
AI.method: Introduce a simple multi-task pre-finetuning framework using task-primary Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) modules plugged into a single shared encoder. Each task family (NER, text classification) uses modular adapters so the backbone remains shared while optimization signals are disentangled across tasks.
AI.result: Across 21 downstream tasks, the method matches individual pre-finetuning while satisfying deployment constraints, yielding average gains of +0.8% for NER and +8.8% for text classification versus the baseline.
AI.conclusion: Task-primary LoRA on a shared lightweight encoder mitigates multi-task interference, enabling versatile, deployable mobile NLP models with competitive performance, especially for text classification; improvements for NER are modest but positive.

title: Rectified-CFG++ for Flow Based Models
summary:
Classifier-free guidance (CFG) is the workhorse for steering large diffusion
models toward text-conditioned targets, yet its native application to rectified
flow (RF) based models provokes severe off-manifold drift, yielding visual
artifacts, text misalignment, and brittle behaviour. We present
Rectified-CFG++, an adaptive predictor-corrector guidance that couples the
deterministic efficiency of rectified flows with a geometry-aware conditioning
rule. Each inference step first executes a conditional RF update that anchors
the sample near the learned transport path, then applies a weighted conditional
correction that interpolates between conditional and unconditional velocity
fields. We prove that the resulting velocity field is marginally consistent and
that its trajectories remain within a bounded tubular neighbourhood of the data
manifold, ensuring stability across a wide range of guidance strengths.
Extensive experiments on large-scale text-to-image models (Flux, Stable
Diffusion 3/3.5, Lumina) show that Rectified-CFG++ consistently outperforms
standard CFG on benchmark datasets such as MS-COCO, LAION-Aesthetic, and
T2I-CompBench. Project page: https://rectified-cfgpp.github.io/

AI.tldr: Rectified-CFG++ is a geometry-aware, predictor–corrector guidance method for rectified-flow (RF) text-to-image models that mitigates off-manifold drift from standard classifier-free guidance, offering provable stability and consistent quality gains across benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Standard classifier-free guidance works well for diffusion but causes off-manifold drift, artifacts, and text misalignment when naively applied to rectified flows. The authors seek a principled way to steer RF models while preserving their deterministic efficiency and staying near the learned data/transport manifold.
AI.method: An adaptive predictor–corrector scheme: (1) a conditional RF update anchors the sample near the learned transport trajectory; (2) a weighted conditional correction interpolates between conditional and unconditional velocity fields. The guidance rule is geometry-aware. They prove marginal consistency and that trajectories stay within a bounded tubular neighborhood of the data manifold, providing stability over a wide range of guidance strengths.
AI.result: Across large T2I models (Flux, Stable Diffusion 3/3.5, Lumina), the method consistently outperforms standard CFG on MS-COCO, LAION-Aesthetic, and T2I-CompBench, with improvements in visual quality and text alignment and fewer artifacts.
AI.conclusion: Rectified-CFG++ provides a theoretically grounded and practically effective guidance mechanism for RF models, maintaining manifold adherence and delivering better, more stable text-conditioned generation than standard CFG.

title: Measuring and Mitigating Identity Bias in Multi-Agent Debate via Anonymization
summary:
Multi-agent debate (MAD) aims to improve large language model (LLM) reasoning
by letting multiple agents exchange answers and then aggregate their opinions.
Yet recent studies reveal that agents are not neutral: they are prone to
identity-driven sycophancy and self-bias, uncritically adopting a peer's view
or stubbornly adhering to their own prior output, undermining the reliability
of debate. In this work, we present the first principled framework that joins
sycophancy and self-bias to mitigate and quantify identity bias in MAD. First,
we formalize the debate dynamics as an identity-weighted Bayesian update
process. Second, we propose response anonymization: by removing identity
markers from prompts, agents cannot distinguish "self" from "peer", which
forces equal weights on agent identity, thereby reducing bias. Third, we define
the Identity Bias Coefficient (IBC), a principled metric that measures how
often an agent follows a peer versus itself. Empirical studies across multiple
models, datasets and debate rounds confirm that identity bias is widespread,
with sycophancy far more common than self-bias. Our findings highlight the need
to "mask" identity to ensure that MAD systems reason based on content rather
than source identity. Code is released in
https://github.com/deeplearning-wisc/MAD-identity-bias.

AI.tldr: They show that multi-agent debate among LLMs is biased by agent identity (sycophancy and self-bias), formalize this as identity-weighted Bayesian updating, mitigate it via response anonymization, and quantify it with a new Identity Bias Coefficient (IBC). Empirically, sycophancy dominates self-bias and anonymization reduces identity-driven effects.
AI.motivation: Multi-agent debate is intended to improve reasoning, but agents often defer to perceived authoritative peers (sycophancy) or cling to their own prior answers (self-bias), degrading reliability. There is no principled, unified way to model, measure, and mitigate these identity effects.
AI.method: 1) Formalize debate as an identity-weighted Bayesian update, capturing how agent identity affects opinion aggregation. 2) Propose response anonymization that strips identity markers so agents cannot distinguish self vs. peer, enforcing equal identity weights. 3) Introduce the Identity Bias Coefficient (IBC) to quantify the tendency to follow peers vs. oneself. 4) Empirically evaluate across models, datasets, and debate rounds.
AI.result: Experiments show identity bias is pervasive in MAD, with sycophancy substantially more prevalent than self-bias. Anonymization reduces identity-driven following and encourages content-based reasoning; IBC captures these effects across settings.
AI.conclusion: Identity must be masked to make multi-agent debate rely on content rather than source identity. The proposed formalization and IBC enable quantification of bias, and anonymization is a simple, effective mitigation. Code is publicly available.

title: Linguistic Patterns in Pandemic-Related Content: A Comparative Analysis of COVID-19, Constraint, and Monkeypox Datasets
summary:
This study conducts a computational linguistic analysis of pandemic-related
online discourse to examine how language distinguishes health misinformation
from factual communication. Drawing on three corpora: COVID-19 false narratives
(n = 7588), general COVID-19 content (n = 10700), and Monkeypox-related posts
(n = 5787), we identify significant differences in readability, rhetorical
markers, and persuasive language use. COVID-19 misinformation exhibited
markedly lower readability scores and contained over twice the frequency of
fear-related or persuasive terms compared to the other datasets. It also showed
minimal use of exclamation marks, contrasting with the more emotive style of
Monkeypox content. These patterns suggest that misinformation employs a
deliberately complex rhetorical style embedded with emotional cues, a
combination that may enhance its perceived credibility. Our findings contribute
to the growing body of work on digital health misinformation by highlighting
linguistic indicators that may aid detection efforts. They also inform public
health messaging strategies and theoretical models of crisis communication in
networked media environments. At the same time, the study acknowledges
limitations, including reliance on traditional readability indices, use of a
deliberately narrow persuasive lexicon, and reliance on static aggregate
analysis. Future research should therefore incorporate longitudinal designs,
broader emotion lexicons, and platform-sensitive approaches to strengthen
robustness.

AI.tldr: Comparative computational linguistics reveals that COVID-19 misinformation differs systematically from other pandemic discourse: it is harder to read, uses over twice as many fear/persuasive terms, and employs fewer overt emotive markers (e.g., exclamation points). These cues may help detect misinformation and shape public health messaging, though the analysis relies on limited indices and static snapshots.
AI.motivation: To understand how linguistic features distinguish health misinformation from factual communication online, enabling better detection, informing crisis communication strategies, and advancing theory on misinformation dynamics in networked media.
AI.method: Assemble three corpora (COVID-19 false narratives, general COVID-19 content, Monkeypox posts). Apply computational linguistic measures: readability indices, counts of rhetorical markers (including exclamation marks), and frequency of fear-related/persuasive lexicon terms. Compare distributions across corpora using aggregate, cross-sectional analysis.
AI.result: COVID-19 misinformation texts have substantially lower readability scores and more than double the rate of fear/persuasive lexicon usage relative to general COVID-19 and Monkeypox corpora. They show minimal exclamation mark use, whereas Monkeypox content displays a more overtly emotive style. These differences are statistically meaningful patterns across datasets.
AI.conclusion: Health misinformation appears to use a more complex rhetorical style infused with emotional cues, potentially boosting perceived credibility. Linguistic indicators identified here can aid automated detection and guide public health messaging, but conclusions are constrained by traditional readability metrics, a narrow persuasive lexicon, and non-longitudinal, platform-agnostic analysis; future work should be longitudinal, lexically broader, and platform-sensitive.

title: PIT-QMM: A Large Multimodal Model For No-Reference Point Cloud Quality Assessment
summary:
Large Multimodal Models (LMMs) have recently enabled considerable advances in
the realm of image and video quality assessment, but this progress has yet to
be fully explored in the domain of 3D assets. We are interested in using these
models to conduct No-Reference Point Cloud Quality Assessment (NR-PCQA), where
the aim is to automatically evaluate the perceptual quality of a point cloud in
absence of a reference. We begin with the observation that different modalities
of data - text descriptions, 2D projections, and 3D point cloud views - provide
complementary information about point cloud quality. We then construct PIT-QMM,
a novel LMM for NR-PCQA that is capable of consuming text, images and point
clouds end-to-end to predict quality scores. Extensive experimentation shows
that our proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art by significant
margins on popular benchmarks with fewer training iterations. We also
demonstrate that our framework enables distortion localization and
identification, which paves a new way forward for model explainability and
interactivity. Code and datasets are available at
https://www.github.com/shngt/pit-qmm.

AI.tldr: PIT-QMM is a large multimodal model that fuses text, 2D images, and 3D point-cloud inputs to perform no-reference point-cloud quality assessment, outperforming prior methods and enabling distortion localization/explainability.
AI.motivation: While LMMs have advanced quality assessment for images/videos, their potential in 3D asset evaluation remains underexplored. There is a need for automatic, reference-free assessment of point-cloud perceptual quality and better explainability/localization of distortions.
AI.method: Design a novel LMM (PIT-QMM) that ingests three complementary modalities—textual descriptions/prompts, 2D projections, and 3D point-cloud views—end-to-end to regress quality scores. The multimodal fusion leverages complementary cues from each modality to improve NR-PCQA and supports localization/identification of distortions.
AI.result: On popular NR-PCQA benchmarks, PIT-QMM achieves significant performance gains over state-of-the-art methods and requires fewer training iterations. It also provides distortion localization and identification outputs that enhance interpretability and interactivity.
AI.conclusion: Multimodal LMMs can effectively address NR-PCQA, offering higher accuracy, better data efficiency, and built-in explainability. The released code/datasets facilitate adoption and further research, pointing to a new direction for interpretable 3D quality assessment.

title: An Evaluation Study of Hybrid Methods for Multilingual PII Detection
summary:
The detection of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) is critical for
privacy compliance but remains challenging in low-resource languages due to
linguistic diversity and limited annotated data. We present RECAP, a hybrid
framework that combines deterministic regular expressions with context-aware
large language models (LLMs) for scalable PII detection across 13 low-resource
locales. RECAP's modular design supports over 300 entity types without
retraining, using a three-phase refinement pipeline for disambiguation and
filtering. Benchmarked with nervaluate, our system outperforms fine-tuned NER
models by 82% and zero-shot LLMs by 17% in weighted F1-score. This work offers
a scalable and adaptable solution for efficient PII detection in
compliance-focused applications.

AI.tldr: RECAP is a hybrid regex + LLM framework for multilingual PII detection that scales to 300+ entity types and 13 low‑resource locales, achieving substantially higher weighted F1 than fine‑tuned NER (+82%) and zero‑shot LLMs (+17%).
AI.motivation: PII detection is essential for privacy compliance, yet low‑resource languages suffer from scarce annotations and high linguistic variability, making conventional supervised NER or pure LLM approaches unreliable or costly to adapt.
AI.method: A modular, hybrid system that combines deterministic regular expressions with context‑aware LLM reasoning. It uses a three‑phase refinement pipeline for disambiguation and filtering, enabling support for 300+ PII entity types across 13 locales without retraining.
AI.result: Evaluated (with nervaluate) across 13 low‑resource locales, RECAP delivers weighted F1 gains of 82% over fine‑tuned NER models and 17% over zero‑shot LLM baselines, while maintaining scalability to hundreds of entity types without retraining.
AI.conclusion: Hybrid, modular PII detection—grounding with regexes plus LLM context—yields state‑of‑the‑art accuracy and practical scalability for compliance workflows in low‑resource settings.

title: IASC: Interactive Agentic System for ConLangs
summary:
We present a system that uses LLMs as a tool in the development of
Constructed Languages. The system is modular in that one first creates a target
phonology for the language using an agentic approach that refines its output at
each step with commentary feedback on its previous attempt. Next, a set of
sentences is 'translated' from their English original into a morphosyntactic
markup that reflects the word order and morphosyntactic feature specifications
of the desired target language, with affixes represented as morphosyntactic
feature bundles. From this translated corpus, a lexicon is constructed using
the phonological model and the set of morphemes (stems and affixes) extracted
from the 'translated' sentences. The system is then instructed to provide an
orthography for the language, using an existing script such as Latin or
Cyrillic. Finally, the system writes a brief grammatical handbook of the
language. The system can also translate further sentences into the target
language.
  Our goal is twofold. First, we hope that these tools will be fun to use for
creating artificially constructed languages. Second, we are interested in
exploring what LLMs 'know' about language-not what they know about any
particular language or linguistic phenomenon, but how much they know about and
understand language and linguistic concepts. As we shall see, there is a fairly
wide gulf in capabilities both among different LLMs and among different
linguistic specifications, with it being notably easier for systems to deal
with more common patterns than rarer ones. An additional avenue that we explore
is the application of our approach to translating from high-resource into
low-resource languages. While the results so far are mostly negative, we
provide some evidence that an improved version of the present system could
afford some real gains in such tasks.
  https://github.com/SakanaAI/IASC

AI.tldr: A modular, agentic LLM-driven pipeline generates full constructed languages—phonology, morphosyntax, lexicon, orthography, and a mini-grammar—and can translate into the conlang; it also probes what LLMs know about general linguistic structure, finding strong performance on common patterns and weak on rare ones, with tentative, mostly negative results for aiding low-resource translation.
AI.motivation: Provide an engaging tool for conlang creation and use the process as a probe of LLMs’ general linguistic knowledge, beyond specific languages. Additionally, explore whether such a pipeline can help translate from high-resource to low-resource languages.
AI.method: Build a stepwise system: (1) agentic refinement to design a target phonology; (2) translate seed English sentences into morphosyntactic markup encoding word order and feature bundles; (3) derive stems/affixes to form a lexicon using the phonological model; (4) define an orthography (e.g., Latin/Cyrillic mapping); (5) auto-generate a brief grammar; (6) optionally translate new sentences into the target language. Compare performance across LLMs and linguistic specifications.
AI.result: The pipeline works for common linguistic patterns but degrades on rarer morphosyntactic/phonological structures; significant variability exists across different LLMs. For high-to-low resource translation, current outcomes are mostly negative, though hints suggest potential gains with improved versions.
AI.conclusion: LLMs possess useful, generalizable linguistic knowledge sufficient to synthesize plausible conlangs under typical patterns, yet struggle with rare or typologically marked phenomena. The modular, agentic approach is promising for both creative tooling and as a diagnostic probe, with future work needed to strengthen robustness and explore practical benefits for low-resource translation.

title: Dual-Stream Alignment for Action Segmentation
summary:
Action segmentation is a challenging yet active research area that involves
identifying when and where specific actions occur in continuous video streams.
Most existing work has focused on single-stream approaches that model the
spatio- temporal aspects of frame sequences. However, recent research has
shifted toward two-stream methods that learn action-wise features to enhance
action segmentation performance. In this work, we propose the Dual-Stream
Alignment Network (DSA Net) and investigate the impact of incorporating a
second stream of learned action features to guide segmentation by capturing
both action and action-transition cues. Communication between the two streams
is facilitated by a Temporal Context (TC) block, which fuses complementary
information using cross- attention and Quantum-based Action-Guided Modulation
(Q- ActGM), enhancing the expressive power of the fused features. To the best
of our knowledge, this is the first study to introduce a hybrid
quantum-classical machine learning framework for action segmentation. Our
primary objective is for the two streams (frame-wise and action-wise) to learn
a shared feature space through feature alignment. This is encouraged by the
proposed Dual-Stream Alignment Loss, which comprises three components:
relational consistency, cross-level contrastive, and cycle-consistency
reconstruction losses. Following prior work, we evaluate DSA Net on several
diverse benchmark datasets: GTEA, Breakfast, 50Salads, and EgoProcel. We
further demonstrate the effectiveness of each component through extensive
ablation studies. Notably, DSA Net achieves state-of-the-art performance,
significantly outperforming existing

AI.tldr: DSA Net proposes a dual-stream alignment framework for action segmentation that aligns frame-wise and action-wise features via a Temporal Context block with cross-attention and a Quantum-based Action-Guided Modulation module, optimized by a multi-term alignment loss; it achieves state-of-the-art results on GTEA, Breakfast, 50Salads, and EgoProcel.
AI.motivation: Single-stream spatiotemporal models underuse action-wise and transition cues. Two-stream approaches can provide complementary, higher-level action structure to guide per-frame segmentation. The authors aim to learn a shared feature space between frame-wise and action-wise representations and to increase fusion expressiveness (via a hybrid quantum-classical module) to improve segmentation accuracy and robustness.
AI.method: Two coordinated streams: (1) a frame-wise stream and (2) an action-wise stream. A Temporal Context (TC) block mediates cross-stream communication using cross-attention and a Quantum-based Action-Guided Modulation (Q-ActGM) mechanism to enhance fused features. Training uses a Dual-Stream Alignment Loss with three parts: relational consistency, cross-level contrastive alignment, and cycle-consistency reconstruction to encourage a shared feature space and alignment between streams.
AI.result: Evaluated on GTEA, Breakfast, 50Salads, and EgoProcel, DSA Net achieves state-of-the-art performance; ablation studies indicate that each component (TC, Q-ActGM, and each loss term) contributes to the gains.
AI.conclusion: Learning and aligning complementary frame-wise and action-wise representations, coupled with enhanced cross-stream fusion, yields superior action segmentation. The hybrid quantum-classical module further boosts expressiveness, and the approach generalizes across diverse benchmarks.

title: Benchmarking is Broken - Don't Let AI be its Own Judge
comment:
12 pages; Accepted to NeurIPS 2025. Link to poster:
  https://neurips.cc/virtual/2025/poster/121919
summary:
The meteoric rise of Artificial Intelligence (AI), with its rapidly expanding
market capitalization, presents both transformative opportunities and critical
challenges. Chief among these is the urgent need for a new, unified paradigm
for trustworthy evaluation, as current benchmarks increasingly reveal critical
vulnerabilities. Issues like data contamination and selective reporting by
model developers fuel hype, while inadequate data quality control can lead to
biased evaluations that, even if unintentionally, may favor specific
approaches. As a flood of participants enters the AI space, this "Wild West" of
assessment makes distinguishing genuine progress from exaggerated claims
exceptionally difficult. Such ambiguity blurs scientific signals and erodes
public confidence, much as unchecked claims would destabilize financial markets
reliant on credible oversight from agencies like Moody's.
  In high-stakes human examinations (e.g., SAT, GRE), substantial effort is
devoted to ensuring fairness and credibility; why settle for less in evaluating
AI, especially given its profound societal impact? This position paper argues
that the current laissez-faire approach is unsustainable. We contend that true,
sustainable AI advancement demands a paradigm shift: a unified, live, and
quality-controlled benchmarking framework robust by construction, not by mere
courtesy and goodwill. To this end, we dissect the systemic flaws undermining
today's AI evaluation, distill the essential requirements for a new generation
of assessments, and introduce PeerBench, a community-governed, proctored
evaluation blueprint that embodies this paradigm through sealed execution, item
banking with rolling renewal, and delayed transparency. Our goal is to pave the
way for evaluations that can restore integrity and deliver genuinely
trustworthy measures of AI progress.

AI.tldr: Current AI evaluations are unreliable due to contamination, selective reporting, and weak quality controls. The paper proposes PeerBench—a unified, community-governed, proctored benchmarking framework with sealed execution, rolling item banks, and delayed transparency—to produce trustworthy, robust-by-construction assessments of AI progress.
AI.motivation: Explosive AI growth and market hype outpace the rigor of existing benchmarks, which suffer from data leakage, biased curation, and incentives for selective reporting. This creates a "Wild West" where genuine advances are hard to distinguish from marketing, eroding scientific signals and public trust. The authors argue that, as with high-stakes human exams (SAT/GRE), AI evaluation requires fairness, credibility, and oversight. Without reform, the current laissez-faire approach risks systemic distortion of progress claims.
AI.method: This is a position/blueprint paper. The authors first analyze systemic flaws in today’s evaluation ecosystem (contamination, gaming, inadequate controls, reporting bias). They then distill requirements for next-generation assessments and introduce PeerBench, a community-governed, proctored framework featuring: (1) sealed execution to prevent interference and tampering, (2) item banking with rolling renewal to curb memorization/overfitting, and (3) delayed transparency to reduce benchmark gaming. The framework aims to be unified, live, and quality-controlled by design.
AI.result: No empirical leaderboard is reported; instead, the core contribution is a specification and governance blueprint. The paper delineates mechanisms and processes intended to yield more trustworthy and durable evaluations, positioning PeerBench as a practical path to robust-by-construction benchmarking.
AI.conclusion: The current evaluation status quo is untenable. A shift to a unified, proctored, and quality-controlled benchmarking regime is necessary for sustainable AI progress. PeerBench is proposed as a community-led architecture to restore integrity, mitigate hype, and produce credible measures of capability over time.

title: Vocabulary embeddings organize linguistic structure early in language model training
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) work by manipulating the geometry of input
embedding vectors over multiple layers. Here, we ask: how are the input
vocabulary representations of language models structured, and how and when does
this structure evolve over training? To answer this question, we use
representational similarity analysis, running a suite of experiments that
correlate the geometric structure of the input embeddings and output embeddings
of two open-source models (Pythia 12B and OLMo 7B) with semantic, syntactic,
and frequency-based metrics over the course of training. Our key findings are
as follows: 1) During training, the vocabulary embedding geometry quickly
converges to high correlations with a suite of semantic and syntactic features;
2) Embeddings of high-frequency and function words (e.g., "the," "of") converge
to their final vectors faster than lexical and low-frequency words, which
retain some alignment with the bias in their random initializations. These
findings help map the dynamic trajectory by which input embeddings organize
around linguistic structure, revealing distinct roles for word frequency and
function. Our findings motivate a deeper study of how the evolution of
vocabulary geometry may facilitate specific capability gains during model
training.

AI.tldr: They track how LLM token embeddings organize during training and find that embedding geometry rapidly aligns with linguistic structure, with high‑frequency/function words stabilizing fastest while rare/lexical words retain more initialization bias for longer.
AI.motivation: To understand when and how vocabulary embeddings in LLMs acquire linguistic structure, and how word frequency/function shape this process—both for interpretability and for linking training dynamics to capability emergence.
AI.method: Representational similarity analysis across training checkpoints of Pythia‑12B and OLMo‑7B, correlating input/output embedding geometries with semantic, syntactic, and frequency-based metrics to quantify alignment and its evolution.
AI.result: (1) Rapid rise to high correlations between embedding geometry and semantic/syntactic features; (2) high‑frequency/function words converge to stable vectors earlier; (3) low‑frequency/lexical words keep detectable alignment with their random initializations longer.
AI.conclusion: LLM vocabulary embeddings quickly organize around linguistic structure, with frequency and word function governing convergence rates. This dynamics likely contributes to staged capability gains, motivating deeper study of how evolving vocabulary geometry supports downstream behaviors.

title: Once Is Enough: Lightweight DiT-Based Video Virtual Try-On via One-Time Garment Appearance Injection
comment:
5 pages (including references), 4 figures. Code and models will be
  released upon publication
summary:
Video virtual try-on aims to replace the clothing of a person in a video with
a target garment. Current dual-branch architectures have achieved significant
success in diffusion models based on the U-Net; however, adapting them to
diffusion models built upon the Diffusion Transformer remains challenging.
Initially, introducing latent space features from the garment reference branch
requires adding or modifying the backbone network, leading to a large number of
trainable parameters. Subsequently, the latent space features of garments lack
inherent temporal characteristics and thus require additional learning. To
address these challenges, we propose a novel approach, OIE (Once is Enough), a
virtual try-on strategy based on first-frame clothing replacement:
specifically, we employ an image-based clothing transfer model to replace the
clothing in the initial frame, and then, under the content control of the
edited first frame, utilize pose and mask information to guide the temporal
prior of the video generation model in synthesizing the remaining frames
sequentially. Experiments show that our method achieves superior parameter
efficiency and computational efficiency while still maintaining leading
performance under these constraints.

AI.tldr: OIE (Once is Enough) performs clothing replacement only on the first video frame using an image try‑on model, then leverages that edited frame plus pose and mask guidance to sequentially synthesize the rest of the video with a Diffusion Transformer, achieving leading quality with far fewer parameters and lower compute.
AI.motivation: Dual‑branch U‑Net–style video try‑on methods don’t transfer cleanly to Diffusion Transformers: injecting garment features typically requires altering the backbone and adding many trainable parameters, and garment latent features lack temporal cues, demanding extra temporal learning. The goal is a parameter‑ and compute‑efficient video try‑on that avoids heavy architectural changes while preserving quality.
AI.method: First, replace clothing in the initial frame via an image‑based try‑on model. Then, use the edited first frame as content control and guide a video diffusion model with pose and mask information to impose a temporal prior, synthesizing subsequent frames sequentially without modifying the DiT backbone.
AI.result: Experiments indicate superior parameter and computational efficiency compared to prior approaches, while maintaining state‑of‑the‑art/leading performance under these constraints.
AI.conclusion: Conditioning video generation on a single edited frame plus pose/mask guidance is sufficient to propagate realistic clothing across time, enabling practical, efficient Diffusion Transformer–based video virtual try‑on without expanding or altering the backbone.

title: AgentAsk: Multi-Agent Systems Need to Ask
summary:
Multi-agent systems built on large language models (LLMs) promise enhanced
problem-solving capabilities through collaborative division of labor. However,
they frequently underperform single-agent baselines due to edge-level error
cascades: minor inaccuracies at one message handoff propagate across the entire
chain. We propose AgentAsk, a lightweight and plug-and-play clarification
module that treats every inter-agent message as a potential failure point and
inserts minimally necessary questions to arrest error propagation. AgentAsk
follows a three-stage pipeline: (i) distilling edge-level judgments from
curated failure traces into a compact policy, (ii) supervising the policy to
determine when/what/whom/how to ask, and (iii) optimizing online with E-GRPO, a
reinforcement learning objective that balances accuracy, latency, and cost. The
module is architecture-agnostic and easy to integrate into existing
orchestration. Across math, reasoning, and coding benchmarks, AgentAsk
consistently improves accuracy and robustness over public multi-agent
implementations while keeping overhead minimal, with latency and extra cost all
less than 5%, approaching the performance of a strong evaluator. Beyond
empirical improvements, we contribute a principled taxonomy of edge-level
errors and a practical recipe for link-local intervention, offering a scalable
pathway toward more reliable LLM-based multi-agent systems.

AI.tldr: AgentAsk is a plug-and-play clarification module for multi-agent LLM systems that inserts minimal questions at message handoffs to prevent error cascades, improving accuracy and robustness with <5% latency and cost overhead.
AI.motivation: Multi-agent LLMs should outperform single agents via division of labor, but often underperform because small mistakes at one handoff propagate across the chain (edge-level error cascades). A lightweight, general mechanism is needed to detect and correct uncertainties at each inter-agent message without heavy evaluators or large latency/cost penalties.
AI.method: Introduce AgentAsk, which treats every inter-agent edge as a potential failure point and injects minimal clarification questions. The pipeline: (i) distill edge-level judgments from curated failure traces into a compact policy; (ii) supervise that policy to decide when to ask, what to ask, whom to ask, and how to ask; (iii) optimize online via E-GRPO, a reinforcement learning objective that balances accuracy, latency, and monetary cost. The module is architecture-agnostic and integrates into existing orchestration.
AI.result: On math, reasoning, and coding benchmarks, AgentAsk consistently improves accuracy and robustness over public multi-agent implementations while keeping additional latency and monetary cost under 5%, approaching the performance of a strong evaluator.
AI.conclusion: Targeted, link-local clarification guided by a taxonomy of edge-level errors can reliably curb error propagation in multi-agent LLM systems. AgentAsk offers a scalable, low-overhead path to more dependable multi-agent orchestration and provides a practical recipe for integrating such interventions.

title: Toward Reliable Clinical Coding with Language Models: Verification and Lightweight Adaptation
summary:
Accurate clinical coding is essential for healthcare documentation, billing,
and decision-making. While prior work shows that off-the-shelf LLMs struggle
with this task, evaluations based on exact match metrics often overlook errors
where predicted codes are hierarchically close but incorrect. Our analysis
reveals that such hierarchical misalignments account for a substantial portion
of LLM failures. We show that lightweight interventions, including prompt
engineering and small-scale fine-tuning, can improve accuracy without the
computational overhead of search-based methods. To address hierarchically
near-miss errors, we introduce clinical code verification as both a standalone
task and a pipeline component. To mitigate the limitations in existing
datasets, such as incomplete evidence and inpatient bias in MIMIC, we release
an expert double-annotated benchmark of outpatient clinical notes with ICD-10
codes. Our results highlight verification as an effective and reliable step
toward improving LLM-based medical coding.

AI.tldr: LLMs often miss ICD-10 codes by hierarchically “near-miss” errors; lightweight prompting and small-scale fine-tuning plus a new verification step substantially improve reliability, and a new expert double-annotated outpatient dataset enables better benchmarking.
AI.motivation: Clinical coding drives billing, documentation, and decisions, but off-the-shelf LLMs underperform. Standard exact-match metrics hide clinically close-but-wrong predictions, and widely used datasets (e.g., MIMIC) have incomplete evidence and inpatient bias. The authors aim to close this evaluation gap and improve accuracy without heavy, search-based computation.
AI.method: (1) Error analysis showing many failures are hierarchical misalignments in the ICD-10 ontology. (2) Lightweight interventions: prompt engineering and small-scale fine-tuning. (3) Introduction of clinical code verification as a standalone task and as a pipeline component to catch near-miss errors. (4) Release of an expert double-annotated outpatient clinical-notes benchmark with ICD-10 codes to address dataset limitations.
AI.result: Prompting and small-scale fine-tuning improve accuracy without the cost of search-based methods; a verification step effectively identifies/corrects hierarchically close errors, improving reliability. The new outpatient benchmark mitigates evidence gaps and inpatient bias, facilitating fairer evaluation. The analysis quantifies hierarchical misalignments as a major source of LLM failures.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating a verification stage and lightweight model adaptations is an effective, practical path to more accurate LLM-based medical coding. Evaluations should account for ICD-10 hierarchy, and the new outpatient dataset supports more representative assessment and development.

title: MONKEY: Masking ON KEY-Value Activation Adapter for Personalization
summary:
Personalizing diffusion models allows users to generate new images that
incorporate a given subject, allowing more control than a text prompt. These
models often suffer somewhat when they end up just recreating the subject
image, and ignoring the text prompt. We observe that one popular method for
personalization, the IP-Adapter automatically generates masks that we
definitively segment the subject from the background during inference. We
propose to use this automatically generated mask on a second pass to mask the
image tokens, thus restricting them to the subject, not the background,
allowing the text prompt to attend to the rest of the image. For text prompts
describing locations and places, this produces images that accurately depict
the subject while definitively matching the prompt. We compare our method to a
few other test time personalization methods, and find our method displays high
prompt and source image alignment.

AI.tldr: Use the IP-Adapter’s automatically generated subject mask to run a second masked pass that constrains image tokens to the subject, letting the text prompt control the background—improving prompt adherence while preserving subject identity.
AI.motivation: Personalized diffusion often overfits to the reference image, recreating it and ignoring the text prompt, especially for backgrounds/locations. The goal is to decouple subject identity from background generation so prompts can meaningfully steer the scene.
AI.method: During inference with IP-Adapter, reuse its auto-generated subject mask in a second pass to mask image tokens: restrict image-based conditioning to the subject region while freeing the background for text-driven synthesis. This is a test-time procedure with no retraining.
AI.result: For prompts describing locations/places, the approach yields images that both accurately depict the subject and closely match the textual prompt. Compared against several test-time personalization baselines, the method shows higher prompt alignment and source-image fidelity (qualitative claims; metrics not detailed).
AI.conclusion: A simple, test-time masking strategy improves the balance between subject fidelity and prompt control. Leveraging IP-Adapter’s own mask provides better prompt adherence without retraining, particularly for background/location prompts.

title: Traceability and Accountability in Role-Specialized Multi-Agent LLM Pipelines
summary:
Sequential multi-agent systems built with large language models (LLMs) can
automate complex software tasks, but they are hard to trust because errors
quietly pass from one stage to the next. We study a traceable and accountable
pipeline, meaning a system with clear roles, structured handoffs, and saved
records that let us trace who did what at each step and assign blame when
things go wrong. Our setting is a Planner -> Executor -> Critic pipeline. We
evaluate eight configurations of three state-of-the-art LLMs on three
benchmarks and analyze where errors start, how they spread, and how they can be
fixed. Our results show: (1) adding a structured, accountable handoff between
agents markedly improves accuracy and prevents the failures common in simple
pipelines; (2) models have clear role-specific strengths and risks (e.g.,
steady planning vs. high-variance critiquing), which we quantify with repair
and harm rates; and (3) accuracy-cost-latency trade-offs are task-dependent,
with heterogeneous pipelines often the most efficient. Overall, we provide a
practical, data-driven method for designing, tracing, and debugging reliable,
predictable, and accountable multi-agent systems.

AI.tldr: A traceable Planner→Executor→Critic LLM pipeline with structured handoffs and logging improves reliability, reveals role-specific risks/strengths, and yields better accuracy–cost–latency trade-offs, especially with heterogeneous model choices.
AI.motivation: Sequential LLM agent pipelines often fail silently as errors propagate across stages, making them hard to trust, debug, or attribute blame. There is a need for accountable designs that make decision paths inspectable and responsibilities clear.
AI.method: Implement a traceable, accountable multi-agent pipeline (Planner→Executor→Critic) with clear roles, structured handoffs, and saved records. Evaluate eight configurations using three state-of-the-art LLMs across three benchmarks. Analyze where errors originate, how they propagate, and how critiques repair or harm outputs; quantify with repair/harm rates and assess accuracy–cost–latency trade-offs, including homogeneous vs. heterogeneous pipelines.
AI.result: Structured, accountable handoffs significantly boost accuracy and reduce common failure modes. Different models excel in different roles (e.g., planners are steady; critics can be high variance). Repair and harm rates quantify these effects. Optimal pipelines are task-dependent, with heterogeneous configurations often delivering the best efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Adopting traceable, role-structured pipelines and choosing models per role provides a practical, data-driven path to designing, debugging, and operating reliable, predictable, and accountable multi-agent LLM systems.

title: Role-Conditioned Refusals: Evaluating Access Control Reasoning in Large Language Models
summary:
Access control is a cornerstone of secure computing, yet large language
models often blur role boundaries by producing unrestricted responses. We study
role-conditioned refusals, focusing on the LLM's ability to adhere to access
control policies by answering when authorized and refusing when not. To
evaluate this behavior, we created a novel dataset that extends the Spider and
BIRD text-to-SQL datasets, both of which have been modified with realistic
PostgreSQL role-based policies at the table and column levels. We compare three
designs: (i) zero or few-shot prompting, (ii) a two-step generator-verifier
pipeline that checks SQL against policy, and (iii) LoRA fine-tuned models that
learn permission awareness directly. Across multiple model families, explicit
verification (the two-step framework) improves refusal precision and lowers
false permits. At the same time, fine-tuning achieves a stronger balance
between safety and utility (i.e., when considering execution accuracy). Longer
and more complex policies consistently reduce the reliability of all systems.
We release RBAC-augmented datasets and code.

AI.tldr: They study role-conditioned refusals for LLMs in text-to-SQL, augment Spider and BIRD with realistic PostgreSQL RBAC policies, and compare prompting, a generator–verifier pipeline, and LoRA fine-tuning. Explicit verification best reduces false permits (improves refusal precision), while fine-tuning yields the best safety–utility balance (execution accuracy). More complex policies hurt all methods. Datasets and code are released.
AI.motivation: LLMs often ignore access boundaries, producing answers regardless of user permissions. In settings like text-to-SQL, this undermines access control. The goal is to make models respond when authorized and refuse when not—i.e., enforce RBAC through role-aware behavior.
AI.method: Create RBAC-augmented versions of Spider and BIRD by attaching realistic PostgreSQL table/column-level policies. Evaluate three designs across multiple model families: (i) zero/few-shot prompting with policy context, (ii) a two-step generator–verifier that checks produced SQL against the policy and refuses if noncompliant, and (iii) LoRA fine-tuning to internalize permission awareness. Measure refusal precision, false permits, and execution accuracy; analyze robustness under longer/more complex policies.
AI.result: The generator–verifier approach explicitly checking SQL against policy improves refusal precision and reduces false permits compared to prompting. LoRA fine-tuned models achieve a better overall trade-off between safety (refusals when required) and utility (accurate, executable SQL when allowed). Increased policy length/complexity consistently degrades performance for all approaches.
AI.conclusion: Explicit verification is effective for preventing unauthorized outputs, while fine-tuning offers the best balance of safety and utility. However, policy complexity remains a key challenge. The work provides RBAC-augmented datasets and code to spur further research on policy-aware LLMs for secure text-to-SQL.

title: Automatic Text Box Placement for Supporting Typographic Design
summary:
In layout design for advertisements and web pages, balancing visual appeal
and communication efficiency is crucial. This study examines automated text box
placement in incomplete layouts, comparing a standard Transformer-based method,
a small Vision and Language Model (Phi3.5-vision), a large pretrained VLM
(Gemini), and an extended Transformer that processes multiple images.
Evaluations on the Crello dataset show the standard Transformer-based models
generally outperform VLM-based approaches, particularly when incorporating
richer appearance information. However, all methods face challenges with very
small text or densely populated layouts. These findings highlight the benefits
of task-specific architectures and suggest avenues for further improvement in
automated layout design.

AI.tldr: Task-specific Transformer models outperform general-purpose VLMs for automated text box placement in incomplete layouts; richer appearance cues help, but all models struggle with tiny text and dense designs.
AI.motivation: Automate text box placement to balance aesthetics and communication in ads/web pages, and test whether general Vision-Language Models can replace specialized Transformer approaches, including whether multi-image context/appearance cues help.
AI.method: Compare four models: (1) standard Transformer-based placer, (2) small VLM (Phi3.5-vision), (3) large pretrained VLM (Gemini), and (4) an extended Transformer consuming multiple images/appearance features; evaluate on the Crello dataset.
AI.result: Transformer-based approaches generally beat VLMs, especially when enriched with appearance information; multi-image processing helps. All methods degrade with very small text or highly crowded layouts.
AI.conclusion: Task-specific architectures remain preferable for layout completion; incorporating richer visual cues and context improves performance. Future advances should target robustness to tiny text and dense layouts (e.g., multi-scale features, better local detail modeling).

title: A Case for Leveraging Generative AI to Expand and Enhance Training in the Provision of Mental Health Services
summary:
Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI) is transforming
healthcare. With this evolution comes optimism regarding the impact it will
have on mental health, as well as concern regarding the risks that come with
generative AI operating in the mental health domain. Much of the investment in,
and academic and public discourse about, AI-powered solutions for mental health
has focused on therapist chatbots. Despite the common assumption that chatbots
will be the most impactful application of GenAI to mental health, we make the
case here for a lower-risk, high impact use case: leveraging generative AI to
enhance and scale training in mental health service provision. We highlight key
benefits of using generative AI to help train people to provide mental health
services and present a real-world case study in which generative AI improved
the training of veterans to support one another's mental health. With numerous
potential applications of generative AI in mental health, we illustrate why we
should invest in using generative AI to support training people in mental
health service provision.
