AI.tldr: The paper argues that the most impactful and lower‑risk use of generative AI in mental health is not therapist chatbots but AI‑augmented training for people who deliver mental health services, illustrated by a case study training veterans to support peers.
AI.motivation: Public and investment focus on therapist chatbots overlooks safety risks and the urgent need to expand and upskill the mental‑health workforce. Training is a scalable, safer leverage point where GenAI can provide immediate, practical benefits.
AI.method: Conceptual position plus a real‑world case study. The authors outline benefits of GenAI for training (e.g., scalable practice scenarios, feedback, personalization) and describe deploying such tools to improve training for veteran peer supporters.
AI.result: In the case study, GenAI use reportedly improved the training process and preparedness of veterans to support one another’s mental health; specific quantitative outcomes are not provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: Prioritize investment in GenAI systems that enhance and scale training for mental‑health service provision as a lower‑risk, high‑impact alternative to therapist chatbots; such tools can help grow capacity and quality across the mental‑health ecosystem.

title: Banking Done Right: Redefining Retail Banking with Language-Centric AI
summary:
This paper presents Ryt AI, an LLM-native agentic framework that powers Ryt
Bank to enable customers to execute core financial transactions through natural
language conversation. This represents the first global regulator-approved
deployment worldwide where conversational AI functions as the primary banking
interface, in contrast to prior assistants that have been limited to advisory
or support roles. Built entirely in-house, Ryt AI is powered by ILMU, a
closed-source LLM developed internally, and replaces rigid multi-screen
workflows with a single dialogue orchestrated by four LLM-powered agents
(Guardrails, Intent, Payment, and FAQ). Each agent attaches a task-specific
LoRA adapter to ILMU, which is hosted within the bank's infrastructure to
ensure consistent behavior with minimal overhead. Deterministic guardrails,
human-in-the-loop confirmation, and a stateless audit architecture provide
defense-in-depth for security and compliance. The result is Banking Done Right:
demonstrating that regulator-approved natural-language interfaces can reliably
support core financial operations under strict governance.

AI.tldr: Ryt AI is an in-house, LLM-native, regulator-approved conversational banking interface powered by the internal ILMU model and four specialized agents (Guardrails, Intent, Payment, FAQ) using task-specific LoRA adapters, secured with deterministic guardrails, human-in-the-loop confirmations, and a stateless audit layer to enable core financial transactions via natural language.
AI.motivation: Transform banking UX from rigid, multi-screen workflows to a single natural-language dialogue while meeting strict regulatory, security, and compliance requirements—moving beyond prior AI assistants limited to advisory/support roles.
AI.method: An agentic architecture with four ILMU-based agents, each attaching a task-specific LoRA adapter. All models are hosted within the bank’s infrastructure for consistency and control. Safety/compliance is enforced via deterministic guardrails, human-in-the-loop confirmations for sensitive steps, and a stateless audit architecture, forming defense-in-depth.
AI.result: First reported global regulator-approved deployment where conversational AI serves as the primary banking interface, supporting core financial transactions reliably under governance at Ryt Bank.
AI.conclusion: LLM-native, agentic conversational interfaces—when augmented with modular LoRA specialization, strict guardrails, human oversight, and auditable operations—can meet regulatory standards and operate as primary channels for core banking transactions.

title: TCIP: Threshold-Controlled Iterative Pyramid Network for Deformable Medical Image Registration
summary:
Although pyramid networks have demonstrated superior performance in
deformable medical image registration, their decoder architectures are
inherently prone to propagating and accumulating anatomical structure
misalignments. Moreover, most existing models do not adaptively determine the
number of iterations for optimization under varying deformation requirements
across images, resulting in either premature termination or excessive
iterations that degrades registration accuracy. To effectively mitigate the
accumulation of anatomical misalignments, we propose the Feature-Enhanced
Residual Module (FERM) as the core component of each decoding layer in the
pyramid network. FERM comprises three sequential blocks that extract anatomical
semantic features, learn to suppress irrelevant features, and estimate the
final deformation field, respectively. To adaptively determine the number of
iterations for varying images, we propose the dual-stage Threshold-Controlled
Iterative (TCI) strategy. In the first stage, TCI assesses registration
stability and with asserted stability, it continues with the second stage to
evaluate convergence. We coin the model that integrates FERM and TCI as
Threshold-Controlled Iterative Pyramid (TCIP). Extensive experiments on three
public brain MRI datasets and one abdomen CT dataset demonstrate that TCIP
outperforms the state-of-the-art (SOTA) registration networks in terms of
accuracy, while maintaining comparable inference speed and a compact model
parameter size. Finally, we assess the generalizability of FERM and TCI by
integrating them with existing registration networks and further conduct
ablation studies to validate the effectiveness of these two proposed methods.

AI.tldr: They introduce TCIP, a pyramid registration network that adds a feature-enhanced residual decoder (FERM) to curb misalignment accumulation and a dual-stage Threshold-Controlled Iterative (TCI) stopping rule to adapt iterations per image, achieving higher accuracy than SOTA on multiple MRI/CT datasets without extra runtime or parameters.
AI.motivation: Pyramid-network decoders in deformable medical image registration can propagate and accumulate anatomical misalignments, and most methods use fixed iteration counts, causing premature stopping or excessive iterations that harm accuracy across images with different deformation demands.
AI.method: Embed a Feature-Enhanced Residual Module (FERM) into each decoder layer: (1) extract anatomical semantic features, (2) suppress irrelevant features, (3) estimate the deformation field. Add a dual-stage Threshold-Controlled Iterative (TCI) strategy: Stage 1 assesses registration stability; upon stability, Stage 2 evaluates convergence to adaptively determine the number of iterations. The integrated model is called Threshold-Controlled Iterative Pyramid (TCIP).
AI.result: Across three public brain MRI datasets and one abdomen CT dataset, TCIP surpasses state-of-the-art registration networks in accuracy, with comparable inference speed and compact model size. Integrating FERM and TCI into existing networks also improves their performance; ablation studies confirm both components’ contributions.
AI.conclusion: FERM mitigates decoder-induced misalignment accumulation, and TCI adaptively matches iteration counts to image-specific deformation needs. The combined TCIP framework improves registration accuracy without sacrificing efficiency and generalizes to other registration architectures.

title: Test-Time Matching: Unlocking Compositional Reasoning in Multimodal Models
summary:
Frontier AI models have achieved remarkable progress, yet recent studies
suggest they struggle with compositional reasoning, often performing at or
below random chance on established benchmarks. We revisit this problem and show
that widely used evaluation metrics systematically underestimate model
capability. To address this, we introduce a group matching score that better
exploits group structure and reveals substantial hidden capability in both
contrastive vision-language models (VLMs) and multimodal large language models
(MLLMs). Moreover, simply overfitting to the induced group matchings at test
time transfers this hidden capability into higher scores under standard
evaluation metrics, closing much of the reported gap. This adjustment enables
SigLIP-B16 to surpass all previous results and GPT-4.1 to yield the first
result surpassing estimated human performance on Winoground.
  Building on this insight, we propose Test-Time Matching (TTM), an iterative,
self-improving algorithm that further bootstraps model performance without any
external supervision. TTM delivers additional, non-trivial improvements: for
example, TTM enables SigLIP-B16 to surpass GPT-4.1 on MMVP-VLM, establishing a
new state of the art. Importantly, TTM remains broadly effective even on
benchmarks without metric-induced effects or group structures, achieving
relative gains up to 85.7% on challenging datasets such as WhatsUp. Across 16
dataset variants spanning diverse setups, our experiments demonstrate that TTM
consistently improves model performance and advances the frontier of
compositional reasoning.

AI.tldr: Benchmark metrics understate multimodal models’ compositional reasoning. A new group-matching score and a test-time matching (TTM) procedure expose and convert hidden capability into higher standard scores, setting new SOTA and even surpassing estimated human performance on Winoground.
AI.motivation: Recent claims that VLMs/MLLMs perform at or below chance on compositional reasoning may be artifacts of evaluation: common metrics ignore group structure and systematically underestimate capability. The authors seek fairer measurement and a way to harness latent competence at test time.
AI.method: 1) Define a group matching score that leverages group structure in benchmarks (e.g., sets of image–text pairs) to better reflect model ability. 2) Show that simply overfitting to the induced group matchings at test time lifts scores under standard metrics. 3) Propose Test-Time Matching (TTM), an unsupervised, iterative, self-improving procedure that bootstraps predictions; designed to work with or without explicit group structures.
AI.result: Group matching reveals substantial hidden capability in both contrastive VLMs and MLLMs. Test-time overfitting to these matchings boosts conventional scores: SigLIP-B16 surpasses all prior results; GPT-4.1 exceeds estimated human performance on Winoground. TTM provides additional gains, enabling SigLIP-B16 to beat GPT-4.1 on MMVP-VLM and yielding up to 85.7% relative improvement on WhatsUp. Improvements are consistent across 16 dataset variants.
AI.conclusion: A large fraction of the perceived compositional reasoning deficit is due to metric-induced effects. Accounting for group structure and applying unsupervised test-time matching reliably elevates performance and advances SOTA, implying current benchmarks and metrics need reevaluation.

title: OBCache: Optimal Brain KV Cache Pruning for Efficient Long-Context LLM Inference
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) with extended context windows enable powerful
downstream applications but impose significant memory overhead, as caching all
key-value (KV) states scales linearly with sequence length and batch size.
Existing cache eviction methods address this by exploiting attention sparsity,
yet they typically rank tokens heuristically using accumulated attention
weights without considering their true impact on attention outputs. We propose
Optimal Brain Cache (OBCache), a principled framework that formulates cache
eviction as a layer-wise structured pruning problem. Building upon the Optimal
Brain Damage (OBD) theory, OBCache quantifies token saliency by measuring the
perturbation in attention outputs induced by pruning tokens, with closed-form
scores derived for isolated keys, isolated values, and joint key-value pairs.
Our scores account not only for attention weights but also for information from
value states and attention outputs, thereby enhancing existing eviction
strategies with output-aware signals. Experiments on LLaMA and Qwen models
demonstrate that replacing the heuristic scores in existing works, which
estimate token saliency across different query positions, with OBCache's
output-aware scores consistently improves long-context accuracy.

AI.tldr: OBCache formulates KV-cache eviction in long-context LLMs as a principled, output-aware pruning problem using Optimal Brain Damage, yielding closed-form saliency scores for keys, values, and key–value pairs that improve long-context accuracy over heuristic attention-weight methods.
AI.motivation: Extended context windows require caching all KV states, causing memory to grow linearly with sequence length and batch size. Existing eviction strategies rank tokens via heuristic attention-weight statistics, which ignore their true effect on attention outputs and can mis-prioritize what to keep or drop.
AI.method: Treat KV-cache eviction as layer-wise structured pruning. Using Optimal Brain Damage theory, derive closed-form saliency scores that estimate the perturbation to attention outputs when pruning tokens: isolated key-only, value-only, and joint key–value scores. These scores incorporate attention weights, value states, and current attention outputs, producing output-aware importance estimates that can replace heuristic rankings in existing eviction algorithms.
AI.result: On LLaMA and Qwen families, swapping heuristic token-saliency scores with OBCache’s output-aware scores consistently improves long-context accuracy across query positions. (Abstract reports consistent gains; exact numbers not provided.)
AI.conclusion: A principled, output-aware scoring mechanism for KV-cache eviction leads to better retention decisions and improved long-context performance under memory constraints. The framework is general and can be plugged into existing eviction methods.

title: Controllable Video Synthesis via Variational Inference
summary:
Many video workflows benefit from a mixture of user controls with varying
granularity, from exact 4D object trajectories and camera paths to coarse text
prompts, while existing video generative models are typically trained for fixed
input formats. We develop a video synthesis method that addresses this need and
generates samples with high controllability for specified elements while
maintaining diversity for under-specified ones. We cast the task as variational
inference to approximate a composed distribution, leveraging multiple video
generation backbones to account for all task constraints collectively. To
address the optimization challenge, we break down the problem into step-wise KL
divergence minimization over an annealed sequence of distributions, and further
propose a context-conditioned factorization technique that reduces modes in the
solution space to circumvent local optima. Experiments suggest that our method
produces samples with improved controllability, diversity, and 3D consistency
compared to prior works.

AI.tldr: They propose a controllable video synthesis framework that composes multiple constraints (e.g., 4D object trajectories, camera paths, text) via variational inference, optimized with step-wise KL over an annealed sequence and a context-conditioned factorization to avoid local optima, yielding better controllability, diversity, and 3D consistency than prior methods.
AI.motivation: Real-world video workflows need mixed-granularity controls—precise spatiotemporal trajectories and camera paths together with coarse prompts—while existing generators are trained for fixed input formats and struggle to honor heterogeneous constraints without sacrificing diversity.
AI.method: Formulate video generation as approximating a composed distribution that integrates multiple constraint sources using variational inference; leverage multiple video-generation backbones jointly; optimize via step-wise KL divergence minimization along an annealed distribution path; introduce a context-conditioned factorization that reduces solution-space modes to mitigate local minima.
AI.result: Empirically improves controllability of specified elements, preserves diversity where under-specified, and increases 3D consistency compared to prior work (qualitative/quantitative details not provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Compositional, VI-based control across multiple backbones enables fine-to-coarse controllability in video generation with improved outcomes; the optimization strategy (annealed step-wise KL + context-conditioned factorization) is key to stability and avoiding local optima.

title: Safely Exploring Novel Actions in Recommender Systems via Deployment-Efficient Policy Learning
summary:
In many real recommender systems, novel items are added frequently over time.
The importance of sufficiently presenting novel actions has widely been
acknowledged for improving long-term user engagement. A recent work builds on
Off-Policy Learning (OPL), which trains a policy from only logged data,
however, the existing methods can be unsafe in the presence of novel actions.
Our goal is to develop a framework to enforce exploration of novel actions with
a guarantee for safety. To this end, we first develop Safe Off-Policy Policy
Gradient (Safe OPG), which is a model-free safe OPL method based on a high
confidence off-policy evaluation. In our first experiment, we observe that Safe
OPG almost always satisfies a safety requirement, even when existing methods
violate it greatly. However, the result also reveals that Safe OPG tends to be
too conservative, suggesting a difficult tradeoff between guaranteeing safety
and exploring novel actions. To overcome this tradeoff, we also propose a novel
framework called Deployment-Efficient Policy Learning for Safe User
Exploration, which leverages safety margin and gradually relaxes safety
regularization during multiple (not many) deployments. Our framework thus
enables exploration of novel actions while guaranteeing safe implementation of
recommender systems.

AI.tldr: They propose a safe off-policy learning approach for recommenders with novel items: Safe Off-Policy Policy Gradient (Safe OPG) ensures high-confidence safety but is conservative; then a deployment-efficient framework gradually relaxes safety constraints over a few deployments to safely explore novel actions.
AI.motivation: Recommender systems continually face novel items that need exploration to improve long-term engagement, but existing off-policy learning methods can be unsafe when acting on unseen actions. The authors seek a method that guarantees safety while still exploring new items.
AI.method: 1) Safe Off-Policy Policy Gradient (Safe OPG): a model-free safe OPL algorithm that uses high-confidence off-policy evaluation to enforce safety constraints during learning. 2) Deployment-Efficient Policy Learning for Safe User Exploration: introduces a safety margin and progressively relaxes safety regularization across multiple (few) real-world deployments to expand exploration safely.
AI.result: In experiments, Safe OPG almost always meets the safety requirement, whereas prior methods frequently violate it; however, Safe OPG is overly conservative. The proposed deployment-efficient framework overcomes this conservatism, enabling exploration of novel actions while preserving safety across deployments.
AI.conclusion: Safe OPL with high-confidence guarantees is feasible but conservative; combining it with staged relaxation of safety constraints yields a practical, deployment-efficient approach that safely explores novel items in recommender systems.

title: Textual Entailment and Token Probability as Bias Evaluation Metrics
summary:
Measurement of social bias in language models is typically by token
probability (TP) metrics, which are broadly applicable but have been criticized
for their distance from real-world langugage model use cases and harms. In this
work, we test natural language inference (NLI) as a more realistic alternative
bias metric. We show that, curiously, NLI and TP bias evaluation behave
substantially differently, with very low correlation among different NLI
metrics and between NLI and TP metrics. We find that NLI metrics are more
likely to detect "underdebiased" cases. However, NLI metrics seem to be more
brittle and sensitive to wording of counterstereotypical sentences than TP
approaches. We conclude that neither token probability nor natural language
inference is a "better" bias metric in all cases, and we recommend a
combination of TP, NLI, and downstream bias evaluations to ensure comprehensive
evaluation of language models.
  Content Warning: This paper contains examples of anti-LGBTQ+ stereotypes.

AI.tldr: They compare token-probability (TP) and natural language inference (NLI) metrics for measuring social bias in language models, finding low correlation between them; NLI can better catch underdebiased cases but is brittle to wording, so no single metric suffices. They recommend combining TP, NLI, and downstream evaluations.
AI.motivation: Prevailing TP-based bias metrics are easy to apply but criticized as being far from real-world harms and use. The authors explore whether NLI-based evaluation—closer to semantic judgments—offers a more realistic and reliable alternative.
AI.method: Evaluate multiple NLI-based bias metrics and compare them to standard TP-based metrics on bias detection tasks. Analyze correlations across metrics, examine sensitivity to counterstereotypical sentence wording, and assess each method’s ability to surface underdebiased cases.
AI.result: Very low correlation both among different NLI metrics and between NLI and TP metrics. NLI metrics more often detect underdebiased models/cases, but they are brittle—highly sensitive to phrasing of counterstereotypical sentences—relative to TP approaches.
AI.conclusion: Neither TP nor NLI is universally superior for bias measurement. Each captures different failure modes: NLI may reveal underdebiased cases but is fragile to wording; TP is more stable yet potentially less aligned with real-world harms. A combined evaluation suite using TP, NLI, and downstream bias tests is recommended.

authors: MD Zahin Muntaqim Hasan Muhammad Kafi
title: Hybrid CNN-BYOL Approach for Fault Detection in Induction Motors Using Thermal Images
summary:
Induction motors (IMs) are indispensable in industrial and daily life, but
they are susceptible to various faults that can lead to overheating, wasted
energy consumption, and service failure. Early detection of faults is essential
to protect the motor and prolong its lifespan. This paper presents a hybrid
method that integrates BYOL with CNNs for classifying thermal images of
induction motors for fault detection. The thermal dataset used in this work
includes different operating states of the motor, such as normal operation,
overload, and faults. We employed multiple deep learning (DL) models for the
BYOL technique, ranging from popular architectures such as ResNet-50,
DenseNet-121, DenseNet-169, EfficientNetB0, VGG16, and MobileNetV2.
Additionally, we introduced a new high-performance yet lightweight CNN model
named BYOL-IMNet, which comprises four custom-designed blocks tailored for
fault classification in thermal images. Our experimental results demonstrate
that the proposed BYOL-IMNet achieves 99.89\% test accuracy and an inference
time of 5.7 ms per image, outperforming state-of-the-art models. This study
highlights the promising performance of the CNN-BYOL hybrid method in enhancing
accuracy for detecting faults in induction motors, offering a robust
methodology for online monitoring in industrial settings.

AI.tldr: Hybrid self-supervised BYOL + CNN pipeline for thermal-image-based induction motor fault classification; introduces a lightweight BYOL-IMNet model achieving 99.89% accuracy with 5.7 ms inference, outperforming common backbones and enabling online monitoring.
AI.motivation: Induction motors are pervasive but prone to faults that cause overheating, energy waste, and failures. Early, accurate, and fast detection—ideally from non-invasive thermal imagery—is needed to protect equipment and extend lifespan. Self-supervised learning like BYOL can improve representation quality and robustness, especially when labeled data are limited.
AI.method: Use BYOL self-supervised representation learning with multiple CNN backbones (ResNet-50, DenseNet-121/169, EfficientNetB0, VGG16, MobileNetV2) and a new lightweight 4-block custom CNN (BYOL-IMNet) tailored to thermal fault features. Train on a thermal dataset covering normal, overload, and fault conditions; evaluate classification accuracy and per-image inference time.
AI.result: BYOL-IMNet achieves 99.89% test accuracy and 5.7 ms inference per image, outperforming state-of-the-art CNN backbones under the same BYOL framework on the given thermal dataset.
AI.conclusion: A CNN-BYOL hybrid, particularly the lightweight BYOL-IMNet, delivers high-accuracy, low-latency induction motor fault detection from thermal images, indicating suitability for robust online monitoring in industrial settings.

title: Multimodal Safety Evaluation in Generative Agent Social Simulations
summary:
Can generative agents be trusted in multimodal environments? Despite advances
in large language and vision-language models that enable agents to act
autonomously and pursue goals in rich settings, their ability to reason about
safety, coherence, and trust across modalities remains limited. We introduce a
reproducible simulation framework for evaluating agents along three dimensions:
(1) safety improvement over time, including iterative plan revisions in
text-visual scenarios; (2) detection of unsafe activities across multiple
categories of social situations; and (3) social dynamics, measured as
interaction counts and acceptance ratios of social exchanges. Agents are
equipped with layered memory, dynamic planning, multimodal perception, and are
instrumented with SocialMetrics, a suite of behavioral and structural metrics
that quantifies plan revisions, unsafe-to-safe conversions, and information
diffusion across networks. Experiments show that while agents can detect direct
multimodal contradictions, they often fail to align local revisions with global
safety, reaching only a 55 percent success rate in correcting unsafe plans.
Across eight simulation runs with three models - Claude, GPT-4o mini, and
Qwen-VL - five agents achieved average unsafe-to-safe conversion rates of 75,
55, and 58 percent, respectively. Overall performance ranged from 20 percent in
multi-risk scenarios with GPT-4o mini to 98 percent in localized contexts such
as fire/heat with Claude. Notably, 45 percent of unsafe actions were accepted
when paired with misleading visuals, showing a strong tendency to overtrust
images. These findings expose critical limitations in current architectures and
provide a reproducible platform for studying multimodal safety, coherence, and
social dynamics.

AI.tldr: They propose a reproducible simulation framework to evaluate multimodal agents’ safety, coherence, and social behavior, showing that while agents detect direct text–image contradictions, they often fail to globally correct unsafe plans and overtrust misleading visuals.
AI.motivation: LLMs and VLMs can autonomously act in rich environments but their cross-modal safety, coherence, and trustworthiness are poorly understood and lack standardized, reproducible evaluation. The work aims to systematically measure whether agents can improve safety over time, detect unsafe activities, and behave safely in social contexts.
AI.method: A simulation framework with text–visual scenarios evaluates agents along three axes: (1) safety improvement over time via iterative plan revisions; (2) detection of unsafe activities across diverse social situations; and (3) social dynamics using interaction counts and acceptance ratios. Agents use layered memory, dynamic planning, and multimodal perception, and are instrumented with SocialMetrics to quantify plan revisions, unsafe-to-safe conversions, and information diffusion. Experiments cover eight runs using three models (Claude, GPT-4o mini, Qwen-VL), with five-agent populations per run.
AI.result: Agents reliably spot direct multimodal contradictions but struggle to align local revisions with global safety, achieving only ~55% success in correcting unsafe plans. Average unsafe-to-safe conversion rates across five-agent populations: Claude 75%, GPT-4o mini 55%, Qwen-VL 58%. Overall performance varied widely—from 20% in multi-risk scenarios (GPT-4o mini) to 98% in localized contexts like fire/heat (Claude). 45% of unsafe actions were accepted when paired with misleading visuals, indicating substantial overtrust in images.
AI.conclusion: Current agent architectures have critical limitations in cross-modal safety reasoning and global plan alignment, especially under misleading visuals. The released framework provides a reproducible testbed for studying multimodal safety, coherence, and social dynamics, and highlights needs for better global planning, cross-modal consistency checks, and calibrated trust in visual inputs.

title: Stress-Testing Model Specs Reveals Character Differences among Language Models
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly trained from AI constitutions
and model specifications that establish behavioral guidelines and ethical
principles. However, these specifications face critical challenges, including
internal conflicts between principles and insufficient coverage of nuanced
scenarios. We present a systematic methodology for stress-testing model
character specifications, automatically identifying numerous cases of principle
contradictions and interpretive ambiguities in current model specs.
  We stress test current model specs by generating scenarios that force
explicit tradeoffs between competing value-based principles. Using a
comprehensive taxonomy we generate diverse value tradeoff scenarios where
models must choose between pairs of legitimate principles that cannot be
simultaneously satisfied. We evaluate responses from twelve frontier LLMs
across major providers (Anthropic, OpenAI, Google, xAI) and measure behavioral
disagreement through value classification scores. Among these scenarios, we
identify over 70,000 cases exhibiting significant behavioral divergence.
Empirically, we show this high divergence in model behavior strongly predicts
underlying problems in model specifications. Through qualitative analysis, we
provide numerous example issues in current model specs such as direct
contradiction and interpretive ambiguities of several principles. Additionally,
our generated dataset also reveals both clear misalignment cases and
false-positive refusals across all of the frontier models we study. Lastly, we
also provide value prioritization patterns and differences of these models.

AI.tldr: They propose a systematic stress-testing method to probe contradictions and ambiguities in LLM “constitutions”/model specs by generating value tradeoff scenarios, evaluate 12 frontier models, find 70k+ high-divergence cases, show divergence predicts spec flaws, and map models’ value prioritization patterns.
AI.motivation: LLM behavior is guided by written specifications that can contain internal conflicts and lack guidance for nuanced situations. There is a need to identify where such specs break down—contradicting themselves or leaving room for ambiguous interpretation—to improve safety, consistency, and alignment.
AI.method: Build a comprehensive taxonomy of value tradeoffs and automatically generate scenarios that force explicit choices between legitimate but competing principles. Evaluate 12 frontier LLMs (across Anthropic, OpenAI, Google, xAI) on these scenarios, compute value-classification–based disagreement scores to quantify behavioral divergence, and conduct qualitative analysis to surface contradictions and ambiguities in the underlying specs. Analyze misalignment and refusal errors and extract cross-model value prioritization patterns.
AI.result: Across generated scenarios, they detect over 70,000 cases with significant behavioral divergence among models. High divergence correlates with underlying problems in model specifications. They present qualitative evidence of direct contradictions and interpretive ambiguities, and document both clear misalignment cases and false-positive refusals across all studied models, along with distinct value prioritization patterns.
AI.conclusion: Current model specs contain nontrivial contradictions and ambiguities that manifest as inconsistent model behavior. The proposed stress-testing approach effectively pinpoints these weaknesses and can guide refinement of specifications and alignment practices. Models differ systematically in value prioritization, suggesting a need for clearer, more hierarchical or operationalized specs to reduce ambiguity-driven divergence.

title: Mutual Learning for Hashing: Unlocking Strong Hash Functions from Weak Supervision
summary:
Deep hashing has been widely adopted for large-scale image retrieval, with
numerous strategies proposed to optimize hash function learning. Pairwise-based
methods are effective in learning hash functions that preserve local similarity
relationships, whereas center-based methods typically achieve superior
performance by more effectively capturing global data distributions. However,
the strength of center-based methods in modeling global structures often comes
at the expense of underutilizing important local similarity information. To
address this limitation, we propose Mutual Learning for Hashing (MLH), a novel
weak-to-strong framework that enhances a center-based hashing branch by
transferring knowledge from a weaker pairwise-based branch. MLH consists of two
branches: a strong center-based branch and a weaker pairwise-based branch.
Through an iterative mutual learning process, the center-based branch leverages
local similarity cues learned by the pairwise-based branch. Furthermore,
inspired by the mixture-of-experts paradigm, we introduce a novel
mixture-of-hash-experts module that enables effective cross-branch interaction,
further enhancing the performance of both branches. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that MLH consistently outperforms state-of-the-art hashing methods
across multiple benchmark datasets.

AI.tldr: Proposes MLH, a dual-branch hashing framework where a strong center-based model is enhanced via mutual learning from a weaker pairwise-based model, plus a mixture-of-hash-experts module for cross-branch interaction; achieves state-of-the-art image retrieval performance.
AI.motivation: Pairwise-based hashing preserves local similarity but struggles with global structure; center-based methods model global distributions well but underuse local cues. The goal is to combine their strengths by transferring local similarity knowledge to a strong center-based branch without sacrificing global modeling.
AI.method: MLH has two branches: (1) a strong center-based hashing branch; (2) a weaker pairwise-based branch. Through iterative mutual learning, the center-based branch absorbs local similarity signals learned by the pairwise branch. A new mixture-of-hash-experts module enables effective cross-branch interaction and routing/combination of expertise, further improving both branches.
AI.result: Across multiple benchmark datasets, MLH consistently outperforms prior state-of-the-art hashing methods for large-scale image retrieval (no specific numbers provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Mutual learning from a weaker pairwise branch can strengthen a center-based hashing model by injecting local similarity information, and a mixture-of-hash-experts mechanism further boosts performance. The approach yields consistent SOTA gains in deep hashing for image retrieval.

title: Control Synthesis of Cyber-Physical Systems for Real-Time Specifications through Causation-Guided Reinforcement Learning
comment: 14 pages, 4 figures, 6 tables, accepted by RTSS 2025
summary:
In real-time and safety-critical cyber-physical systems (CPSs), control
synthesis must guarantee that generated policies meet stringent timing and
correctness requirements under uncertain and dynamic conditions. Signal
temporal logic (STL) has emerged as a powerful formalism of expressing
real-time constraints, with its semantics enabling quantitative assessment of
system behavior. Meanwhile, reinforcement learning (RL) has become an important
method for solving control synthesis problems in unknown environments. Recent
studies incorporate STL-based reward functions into RL to automatically
synthesize control policies. However, the automatically inferred rewards
obtained by these methods represent the global assessment of a whole or partial
path but do not accumulate the rewards of local changes accurately, so the
sparse global rewards may lead to non-convergence and unstable training
performances. In this paper, we propose an online reward generation method
guided by the online causation monitoring of STL. Our approach continuously
monitors system behavior against an STL specification at each control step,
computing the quantitative distance toward satisfaction or violation and
thereby producing rewards that reflect instantaneous state dynamics.
Additionally, we provide a smooth approximation of the causation semantics to
overcome the discontinuity of the causation semantics and make it
differentiable for using deep-RL methods. We have implemented a prototype tool
and evaluated it in the Gym environment on a variety of continuously controlled
benchmarks. Experimental results show that our proposed STL-guided RL method
with online causation semantics outperforms existing relevant STL-guided RL
methods, providing a more robust and efficient reward generation framework for
deep-RL.

AI.tldr: They introduce a differentiable, online STL-causation–guided reward shaping scheme for RL that yields dense, stepwise signals aligned with temporal logic constraints, improving stability and performance over prior STL-guided RL on continuous-control benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing STL-guided RL typically uses global/episode-level robustness signals that are sparse, non-additive, and poorly reflect local progress toward satisfying temporal logic specs, leading to non-convergence and unstable training in uncertain, real-time CPS settings.
AI.method: Continuously monitor system trajectories against an STL specification using causation semantics at every control step; compute quantitative distances to satisfaction/violation to emit instantaneous rewards. Provide a smooth (differentiable) approximation of the causation semantics to overcome discontinuities and enable deep-RL optimization.
AI.result: A prototype implementation evaluated on several Gym continuous-control tasks shows that the proposed online causation–based reward generation outperforms prior STL-guided RL baselines, yielding more robust and efficient learning (faster convergence and more stable training).
AI.conclusion: Online, differentiable STL-causation monitoring provides dense, informative rewards that better align RL with temporal logic objectives, resulting in improved performance for deep-RL in CPS-like settings and offering a practical framework for STL-constrained policy synthesis.

title: Large Language Models Meet Virtual Cell: A Survey
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are transforming cellular biology by enabling
the development of "virtual cells"--computational systems that represent,
predict, and reason about cellular states and behaviors. This work provides a
comprehensive review of LLMs for virtual cell modeling. We propose a unified
taxonomy that organizes existing methods into two paradigms: LLMs as Oracles,
for direct cellular modeling, and LLMs as Agents, for orchestrating complex
scientific tasks. We identify three core tasks--cellular representation,
perturbation prediction, and gene regulation inference--and review their
associated models, datasets, evaluation benchmarks, as well as the critical
challenges in scalability, generalizability, and interpretability.

AI.tldr: Survey of LLMs for “virtual cells,” proposing a two-paradigm taxonomy (LLMs as Oracles vs. LLMs as Agents), organizing three core tasks (cellular representation, perturbation prediction, gene regulation inference), and reviewing models, datasets, benchmarks, and key challenges (scalability, generalizability, interpretability).
AI.motivation: LLMs are rapidly entering computational cellular biology, but the field lacks a unified framework to clarify how they are used, what tasks they address, what resources exist, and where the major limitations and opportunities lie.
AI.method: Comprehensive literature review that introduces a unified taxonomy (Oracle vs. Agent), delineates three core task categories, and systematically catalogs associated models, datasets, and evaluation benchmarks, alongside an analysis of cross-cutting challenges.
AI.result: A structured map of the landscape: taxonomy, task definitions, and a curated inventory of methods/resources; identification of persistent bottlenecks in scaling to high-dimensional biology, achieving out-of-distribution generalization, and improving mechanistic interpretability.
AI.conclusion: LLMs can support virtual cell modeling both as direct predictors and as coordinators of scientific workflows, but realizing their potential requires better data and benchmarks, scalable architectures/training regimes, and methods that enhance reliability and biological interpretability.

title: RePainter: Empowering E-commerce Object Removal via Spatial-matting Reinforcement Learning
summary:
In web data, product images are central to boosting user engagement and
advertising efficacy on e-commerce platforms, yet the intrusive elements such
as watermarks and promotional text remain major obstacles to delivering clear
and appealing product visuals. Although diffusion-based inpainting methods have
advanced, they still face challenges in commercial settings due to unreliable
object removal and limited domain-specific adaptation. To tackle these
challenges, we propose Repainter, a reinforcement learning framework that
integrates spatial-matting trajectory refinement with Group Relative Policy
Optimization (GRPO). Our approach modulates attention mechanisms to emphasize
background context, generating higher-reward samples and reducing unwanted
object insertion. We also introduce a composite reward mechanism that balances
global, local, and semantic constraints, effectively reducing visual artifacts
and reward hacking. Additionally, we contribute EcomPaint-100K, a high-quality,
large-scale e-commerce inpainting dataset, and a standardized benchmark
EcomPaint-Bench for fair evaluation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
Repainter significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, especially in
challenging scenes with intricate compositions. We will release our code and
weights upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: Repainter is an RL-enhanced diffusion inpainting framework for e-commerce images that uses attention modulation, spatial-matting trajectory refinement, and a composite reward to remove watermarks/text reliably; it comes with a 100K-scale dataset and benchmark, and outperforms SOTA, especially on complex scenes.
AI.motivation: E-commerce product images often contain watermarks and promotional overlays that hurt visual clarity and ad performance. Existing diffusion inpainting works struggle in production due to unreliable removal, spurious object insertion, and weak domain adaptation.
AI.method: Introduce Repainter: (1) reinforcement learning with Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to fine-tune a diffusion inpainting policy; (2) spatial-matting trajectory refinement to guide the denoising toward background-consistent fills; (3) attention modulation to prioritize background context over foreground insertions; (4) a composite reward balancing global image quality, local mask fidelity, and semantic consistency to reduce artifacts and reward hacking; plus release of EcomPaint-100K dataset and EcomPaint-Bench benchmark.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, Repainter significantly outperforms state-of-the-art inpainting methods, with especially strong gains on complex, cluttered scenes and challenging compositions.
AI.conclusion: Reinforcement learning with attention modulation and composite rewards yields more reliable, domain-adapted inpainting for e-commerce imagery. The new dataset/benchmark standardize evaluation; code and weights to be released upon acceptance.

title: oMeBench: Towards Robust Benchmarking of LLMs in Organic Mechanism Elucidation and Reasoning
comment: Main Text: 8 pages, In total: 37 pages, 9 figures
summary:
Organic reaction mechanisms are the stepwise elementary reactions by which
reactants form intermediates and products, and are fundamental to understanding
chemical reactivity and designing new molecules and reactions. Although large
language models (LLMs) have shown promise in understanding chemical tasks such
as synthesis design, it is unclear to what extent this reflects genuine
chemical reasoning capabilities, i.e., the ability to generate valid
intermediates, maintain chemical consistency, and follow logically coherent
multi-step pathways. We address this by introducing oMeBench, the first
large-scale, expert-curated benchmark for organic mechanism reasoning in
organic chemistry. It comprises over 10,000 annotated mechanistic steps with
intermediates, type labels, and difficulty ratings. Furthermore, to evaluate
LLM capability more precisely and enable fine-grained scoring, we propose oMeS,
a dynamic evaluation framework that combines step-level logic and chemical
similarity. We analyze the performance of state-of-the-art LLMs, and our
results show that although current models display promising chemical intuition,
they struggle with correct and consistent multi-step reasoning. Notably, we
find that using prompting strategy and fine-tuning a specialist model on our
proposed dataset increases performance by 50% over the leading closed-source
model. We hope that oMeBench will serve as a rigorous foundation for advancing
AI systems toward genuine chemical reasoning.

AI.tldr: They introduce oMeBench, a 10k+ step, expert-annotated benchmark and a dynamic evaluation (oMeS) to test LLMs on organic reaction mechanism reasoning; current models show intuition but fail at consistent multi-step logic, while targeted prompting and fine-tuning on oMeBench yield substantial gains (~50% over a leading closed-source model).
AI.motivation: LLMs can propose syntheses, but it is unclear if they truly reason about reaction mechanisms—generating valid intermediates, preserving chemical consistency, and maintaining coherent multi-step pathways. The field lacks a rigorous, large-scale, expert-curated benchmark to measure such mechanistic reasoning.
AI.method: Create oMeBench: >10,000 mechanistic steps with intermediates, type labels, and difficulty ratings. Propose oMeS: a dynamic scoring framework combining step-level logical checks with chemical similarity metrics for fine-grained evaluation. Benchmark state-of-the-art LLMs; study the impact of prompting strategies and fine-tuning a specialist model on the new dataset.
AI.result: State-of-the-art LLMs display some chemical intuition but often fail to maintain correct, consistent multi-step mechanistic reasoning. Prompting strategies help, and fine-tuning a specialist model on oMeBench improves performance by about 50% versus a leading closed-source baseline.
AI.conclusion: oMeBench and oMeS offer a rigorous foundation for assessing and advancing genuine mechanistic reasoning in AI for organic chemistry, highlighting current limitations and a path forward through targeted training and evaluation.

title: Causality Guided Representation Learning for Cross-Style Hate Speech Detection
summary:
The proliferation of online hate speech poses a significant threat to the
harmony of the web. While explicit hate is easily recognized through overt
slurs, implicit hate speech is often conveyed through sarcasm, irony,
stereotypes, or coded language -- making it harder to detect. Existing hate
speech detection models, which predominantly rely on surface-level linguistic
cues, fail to generalize effectively across diverse stylistic variations.
Moreover, hate speech spread on different platforms often targets distinct
groups and adopts unique styles, potentially inducing spurious correlations
between them and labels, further challenging current detection approaches.
Motivated by these observations, we hypothesize that the generation of hate
speech can be modeled as a causal graph involving key factors: contextual
environment, creator motivation, target, and style. Guided by this graph, we
propose CADET, a causal representation learning framework that disentangles
hate speech into interpretable latent factors and then controls confounders,
thereby isolating genuine hate intent from superficial linguistic cues.
Furthermore, CADET allows counterfactual reasoning by intervening on style
within the latent space, naturally guiding the model to robustly identify hate
speech in varying forms. CADET demonstrates superior performance in
comprehensive experiments, highlighting the potential of causal priors in
advancing generalizable hate speech detection.

AI.tldr: CADET uses a causal, disentangled representation of hate speech—separating context, creator motivation, target, and style—and performs counterfactual style interventions to isolate true hateful intent, yielding more robust, generalizable detection, especially for implicit hate.
AI.motivation: Implicit hate speech (sarcasm, irony, stereotypes, coded language) evades detectors that rely on surface cues. Cross‑platform differences in targeted groups and stylistic norms induce spurious correlations between style and labels, hurting generalization. A causally grounded approach is needed to separate intent from superficial expression.
AI.method: Model hate speech generation via a causal graph with key factors: contextual environment, creator motivation, target, and style. Learn interpretable, disentangled latent variables for these factors; control confounders to isolate hate intent. Enable counterfactual reasoning by intervening on the style latent while holding other factors fixed, guiding the detector toward intent rather than surface form. The framework, CADET, embeds these causal priors into representation learning and prediction.
AI.result: Across comprehensive experiments, CADET outperforms prior hate speech detection systems and remains robust to stylistic variation, improving detection of implicit hate and cross‑setting generalization.
AI.conclusion: Causal priors plus disentangled, counterfactual reasoning substantially improve robustness and generalization in hate speech detection, indicating a promising direction for handling implicit, stylistically diverse hate online.

title: SyncHuman: Synchronizing 2D and 3D Generative Models for Single-view Human Reconstruction
summary:
Photorealistic 3D full-body human reconstruction from a single image is a
critical yet challenging task for applications in films and video games due to
inherent ambiguities and severe self-occlusions. While recent approaches
leverage SMPL estimation and SMPL-conditioned image generative models to
hallucinate novel views, they suffer from inaccurate 3D priors estimated from
SMPL meshes and have difficulty in handling difficult human poses and
reconstructing fine details. In this paper, we propose SyncHuman, a novel
framework that combines 2D multiview generative model and 3D native generative
model for the first time, enabling high-quality clothed human mesh
reconstruction from single-view images even under challenging human poses.
Multiview generative model excels at capturing fine 2D details but struggles
with structural consistency, whereas 3D native generative model generates
coarse yet structurally consistent 3D shapes. By integrating the complementary
strengths of these two approaches, we develop a more effective generation
framework. Specifically, we first jointly fine-tune the multiview generative
model and the 3D native generative model with proposed pixel-aligned 2D-3D
synchronization attention to produce geometrically aligned 3D shapes and 2D
multiview images. To further improve details, we introduce a feature injection
mechanism that lifts fine details from 2D multiview images onto the aligned 3D
shapes, enabling accurate and high-fidelity reconstruction. Extensive
experiments demonstrate that SyncHuman achieves robust and photo-realistic 3D
human reconstruction, even for images with challenging poses. Our method
outperforms baseline methods in geometric accuracy and visual fidelity,
demonstrating a promising direction for future 3D generation models.

AI.tldr: SyncHuman fuses a 2D multiview generative model with a 3D native generative model, synchronized via pixel-aligned attention and enhanced by feature injection, to reconstruct high-fidelity clothed human meshes from a single image, outperforming SMPL-based baselines—especially on challenging poses.
AI.motivation: Single-image full-body 3D human reconstruction is ill-posed due to ambiguities and self-occlusions. SMPL-conditioned methods often provide inaccurate 3D priors, struggle with hard poses, and miss fine details. A method that preserves 3D structural consistency while capturing rich 2D details is needed.
AI.method: Jointly fine-tune a 2D multiview generative model and a 3D native generative model. Introduce pixel-aligned 2D–3D synchronization attention to align generated multiview images and 3D shapes geometrically. Use a feature injection mechanism to transfer fine 2D details from multiview images onto the aligned 3D geometry, yielding accurate, detailed reconstructions from a single input image.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show robust, photorealistic reconstructions under challenging human poses. The method surpasses baselines in both geometric accuracy and visual fidelity.
AI.conclusion: Synchronizing complementary 2D and 3D generative pathways and injecting 2D detail into aligned 3D shapes is an effective recipe for single-image human reconstruction, pointing to a promising direction for future 3D generation models.

title: SurveyG: A Multi-Agent LLM Framework with Hierarchical Citation Graph for Automated Survey Generation
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly adopted for automating survey
paper generation \cite{wang2406autosurvey, liang2025surveyx,
yan2025surveyforge,su2025benchmarking,wen2025interactivesurvey}. Existing
approaches typically extract content from a large collection of related papers
and prompt LLMs to summarize them directly. However, such methods often
overlook the structural relationships among papers, resulting in generated
surveys that lack a coherent taxonomy and a deeper contextual understanding of
research progress. To address these shortcomings, we propose \textbf{SurveyG},
an LLM-based agent framework that integrates \textit{hierarchical citation
graph}, where nodes denote research papers and edges capture both citation
dependencies and semantic relatedness between their contents, thereby embedding
structural and contextual knowledge into the survey generation process. The
graph is organized into three layers: \textbf{Foundation},
\textbf{Development}, and \textbf{Frontier}, to capture the evolution of
research from seminal works to incremental advances and emerging directions. By
combining horizontal search within layers and vertical depth traversal across
layers, the agent produces multi-level summaries, which are consolidated into a
structured survey outline. A multi-agent validation stage then ensures
consistency, coverage, and factual accuracy in generating the final survey.
Experiments, including evaluations by human experts and LLM-as-a-judge,
demonstrate that SurveyG outperforms state-of-the-art frameworks, producing
surveys that are more comprehensive and better structured to the underlying
knowledge taxonomy of a field.

AI.tldr: SurveyG is an LLM-agent framework that builds and exploits a hierarchical citation graph—layered into Foundation, Development, and Frontier—to generate structured, taxonomy-aware surveys, with multi-agent validation for coverage, consistency, and factuality; it outperforms existing systems per human and LLM-judge evaluations.
AI.motivation: Prior LLM-based survey generators largely summarize retrieved papers without modeling structural relationships (citations, semantic ties) or the temporal/evolutionary context, leading to weak taxonomies and shallow understanding of research progress.
AI.method: Construct a hierarchical citation graph whose nodes are papers and edges encode citation dependencies and semantic relatedness. Organize nodes into three layers (Foundation/Development/Frontier). An agent performs horizontal exploration within layers and vertical traversal across layers to craft multi-level summaries that are consolidated into a structured outline. A multi-agent validation stage checks consistency, coverage, and factual accuracy. Evaluations include human experts and LLM-as-a-judge comparisons to prior frameworks.
AI.result: Across experiments, SurveyG produces surveys judged more comprehensive and better structured, aligning more closely with a field’s knowledge taxonomy than state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.conclusion: Embedding structural and contextual knowledge via a hierarchical citation graph, combined with agentic summarization and validation, substantially improves automated survey generation quality and organization.

title: MemWeaver: A Hierarchical Memory from Textual Interactive Behaviors for Personalized Generation
summary:
The primary form of user-internet engagement is shifting from leveraging
implicit feedback signals, such as browsing and clicks, to harnessing the rich
explicit feedback provided by textual interactive behaviors. This shift unlocks
a rich source of user textual history, presenting a profound opportunity for a
deeper form of personalization. However, prevailing approaches offer only a
shallow form of personalization, as they treat user history as a flat list of
texts for retrieval and fail to model the rich temporal and semantic structures
reflecting dynamic nature of user interests. In this work, we propose
\textbf{MemWeaver}, a framework that weaves the user's entire textual history
into a hierarchical memory to power deeply personalized generation. The core
innovation of our memory lies in its ability to capture both the temporal
evolution of interests and the semantic relationships between different
activities. To achieve this, MemWeaver builds two complementary memory
components that both integrate temporal and semantic information, but at
different levels of abstraction: behavioral memory, which captures specific
user actions, and cognitive memory, which represents long-term preferences.
This dual-component memory serves as a unified representation of the user,
allowing large language models (LLMs) to reason over both concrete behaviors
and abstracted traits. Experiments on the Language Model Personalization (LaMP)
benchmark validate the efficacy of MemWeaver. Our code is
available\footnote{https://github.com/fishsure/MemWeaver}.

AI.tldr: MemWeaver builds a hierarchical, temporally aware and semantically structured user memory (behavioral + cognitive) from textual histories to enable deeper LLM personalization, showing improved performance on the LaMP benchmark.
AI.motivation: User interaction is increasingly explicit and text-based, yielding rich histories. Existing personalization treats history as a flat list, missing temporal evolution and semantic relations of user interests; a richer structure is needed to capture dynamics and long-term preferences.
AI.method: Construct a dual-component hierarchical memory: (1) behavioral memory encoding concrete, time-stamped user actions; (2) cognitive memory abstracting long-term preferences. Both components integrate temporal and semantic signals. This unified memory is fed to LLMs to reason over concrete behaviors and abstract traits for personalized generation.
AI.result: On the Language Model Personalization (LaMP) benchmark, MemWeaver outperforms baselines (details not specified in the abstract), validating the approach’s effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: Hierarchical, temporally and semantically structured user memories enable deeper personalization for LLM generation. MemWeaver’s dual memory (behavioral + cognitive) offers a unified user representation and demonstrates empirical gains on LaMP; code is open-sourced.

title: ComGS: Efficient 3D Object-Scene Composition via Surface Octahedral Probes
summary:
Gaussian Splatting (GS) enables immersive rendering, but realistic 3D
object-scene composition remains challenging. Baked appearance and shadow
information in GS radiance fields cause inconsistencies when combining objects
and scenes. Addressing this requires relightable object reconstruction and
scene lighting estimation. For relightable object reconstruction, existing
Gaussian-based inverse rendering methods often rely on ray tracing, leading to
low efficiency. We introduce Surface Octahedral Probes (SOPs), which store
lighting and occlusion information and allow efficient 3D querying via
interpolation, avoiding expensive ray tracing. SOPs provide at least a 2x
speedup in reconstruction and enable real-time shadow computation in Gaussian
scenes. For lighting estimation, existing Gaussian-based inverse rendering
methods struggle to model intricate light transport and often fail in complex
scenes, while learning-based methods predict lighting from a single image and
are viewpoint-sensitive. We observe that 3D object-scene composition primarily
concerns the object's appearance and nearby shadows. Thus, we simplify the
challenging task of full scene lighting estimation by focusing on the
environment lighting at the object's placement. Specifically, we capture a 360
degrees reconstructed radiance field of the scene at the location and fine-tune
a diffusion model to complete the lighting. Building on these advances, we
propose ComGS, a novel 3D object-scene composition framework. Our method
achieves high-quality, real-time rendering at around 28 FPS, produces visually
harmonious results with vivid shadows, and requires only 36 seconds for
editing. Code and dataset are available at
https://nju-3dv.github.io/projects/ComGS/.

AI.tldr: ComGS is a 3D object–scene composition framework that makes Gaussian Splatting relightable and efficient by (1) replacing costly ray tracing with Surface Octahedral Probes (SOPs) for lighting/occlusion queries, and (2) estimating localized environment lighting via a 360° radiance capture and diffusion-based completion—yielding real-time (~28 FPS) rendering with vivid, coherent shadows and ~2× faster reconstruction.
AI.motivation: GS radiance fields bake appearance and shadows, causing inconsistencies when inserting new objects. Achieving realistic composition requires relightable object reconstruction and accurate lighting estimation. Existing Gaussian inverse-rendering methods rely on slow ray tracing and struggle with complex light transport; single-image learning methods are view-sensitive.
AI.method: Introduce Surface Octahedral Probes (SOPs) that store lighting and occlusion on surfaces and support fast 3D interpolation queries, avoiding ray tracing and enabling real-time shadow computation in Gaussian scenes. For lighting, focus on the object’s local environment: capture a 360° reconstructed radiance field at the intended placement and fine-tune a diffusion model to complete the lighting. Integrate both into the ComGS pipeline for composition.
AI.result: SOPs provide at least a 2× speedup in reconstruction and enable real-time shadowing. ComGS renders at ~28 FPS, produces visually harmonious compositions with vivid shadows, and supports interactive editing in ~36 seconds.
AI.conclusion: By localizing lighting estimation and using SOPs for efficient relightable reconstruction, ComGS achieves high-quality, real-time object–scene composition in Gaussian Splatting scenes, overcoming baked-shadow artifacts and inefficiencies of ray tracing-based inverse rendering.

title: Haibu Mathematical-Medical Intelligent Agent:Enhancing Large Language Model Reliability in Medical Tasks via Verifiable Reasoning Chains
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) show promise in medicine but are prone to
factual and logical errors, which is unacceptable in this high-stakes field. To
address this, we introduce the "Haibu Mathematical-Medical Intelligent Agent"
(MMIA), an LLM-driven architecture that ensures reliability through a formally
verifiable reasoning process. MMIA recursively breaks down complex medical
tasks into atomic, evidence-based steps. This entire reasoning chain is then
automatically audited for logical coherence and evidence traceability, similar
to theorem proving. A key innovation is MMIA's "bootstrapping" mode, which
stores validated reasoning chains as "theorems." Subsequent tasks can then be
efficiently solved using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), shifting from
costly first-principles reasoning to a low-cost verification model. We
validated MMIA across four healthcare administration domains, including DRG/DIP
audits and medical insurance adjudication, using expert-validated benchmarks.
Results showed MMIA achieved an error detection rate exceeding 98% with a false
positive rate below 1%, significantly outperforming baseline LLMs. Furthermore,
the RAG matching mode is projected to reduce average processing costs by
approximately 85% as the knowledge base matures. In conclusion, MMIA's
verifiable reasoning framework is a significant step toward creating
trustworthy, transparent, and cost-effective AI systems, making LLM technology
viable for critical applications in medicine.

AI.tldr: They propose MMIA, an LLM-based agent that decomposes medical tasks into auditable, evidence-backed steps, verifies the entire reasoning chain (theorem-proving style), and caches validated chains as “theorems” for RAG-based reuse. On four healthcare administration tasks, it reports >98% error detection with <1% false positives and projects ~85% cost reduction as the cache grows.
AI.motivation: LLMs make factual and logical mistakes that are unacceptable in high-stakes medical contexts. The authors aim to deliver trustworthy, transparent, and cost-effective AI by ensuring reasoning is formally verifiable and traceable to evidence.
AI.method: MMIA recursively breaks complex tasks into atomic, evidence-anchored steps; automatically audits chains for logical coherence and provenance (akin to theorem proving); stores validated chains as reusable “theorems”; and later solves similar tasks via Retrieval-Augmented Generation plus low-cost verification instead of expensive first-principles reasoning. Evaluated on four healthcare administration domains (e.g., DRG/DIP audits, insurance adjudication) using expert-validated benchmarks.
AI.result: MMIA outperforms baseline LLMs with an error detection rate >98% and false positive rate <1%. As the knowledge base matures, the RAG matching mode is projected to reduce average processing costs by ~85%.
AI.conclusion: A verifiable reasoning framework like MMIA can make LLMs more reliable, transparent, and economical for critical medical applications, moving from expensive open-ended reasoning to reusable, auditable verification workflows.

title: SUBQRAG: sub-question driven dynamic graph rag
summary:
Graph Retrieval-Augmented Generation (Graph RAG) effectively builds a
knowledge graph (KG) to connect disparate facts across a large document corpus.
However, this broad-view approach often lacks the deep structured reasoning
needed for complex multi-hop question answering (QA), leading to incomplete
evidence and error accumulation. To address these limitations, we propose
SubQRAG, a sub-question-driven framework that enhances reasoning depth. SubQRAG
decomposes a complex question into an ordered chain of verifiable
sub-questions. For each sub-question, it retrieves relevant triples from the
graph. When the existing graph is insufficient, the system dynamically expands
it by extracting new triples from source documents in real time. All triples
used in the reasoning process are aggregated into a "graph memory," forming a
structured and traceable evidence path for final answer generation. Experiments
on three multi-hop QA benchmarks demonstrate that SubQRAG achieves consistent
and significant improvements, especially in Exact Match scores.

AI.tldr: SubQRAG augments Graph RAG with sub-question decomposition, iterative triple retrieval/expansion, and a graph memory to create a traceable evidence path, yielding higher Exact Match on multi-hop QA benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Standard Graph RAG connects facts across corpora but lacks sufficiently deep, structured, multi-step reasoning, leading to incomplete evidence gathering and error accumulation on complex multi-hop questions.
AI.method: Decompose each complex query into an ordered chain of verifiable sub-questions. For each sub-question, retrieve relevant triples from the existing KG; if coverage is insufficient, dynamically expand the KG by extracting new triples from the source documents in real time. Aggregate all used triples into a persistent "graph memory" to form a structured, auditable evidence path for final answer generation.
AI.result: Across three multi-hop QA benchmarks, SubQRAG delivers consistent and significant gains over baselines, notably improving Exact Match scores.
AI.conclusion: Driving retrieval and KG expansion with sub-questions and maintaining a graph memory deepens reasoning and strengthens evidence completeness and traceability, translating into state-of-the-art performance on multi-hop QA tasks.

title: UltraLED: Learning to See Everything in Ultra-High Dynamic Range Scenes
summary:
Ultra-high dynamic range (UHDR) scenes exhibit significant exposure
disparities between bright and dark regions. Such conditions are commonly
encountered in nighttime scenes with light sources. Even with standard exposure
settings, a bimodal intensity distribution with boundary peaks often emerges,
making it difficult to preserve both highlight and shadow details
simultaneously. RGB-based bracketing methods can capture details at both ends
using short-long exposure pairs, but are susceptible to misalignment and
ghosting artifacts. We found that a short-exposure image already retains
sufficient highlight detail. The main challenge of UHDR reconstruction lies in
denoising and recovering information in dark regions. In comparison to the RGB
images, RAW images, thanks to their higher bit depth and more predictable noise
characteristics, offer greater potential for addressing this challenge. This
raises a key question: can we learn to see everything in UHDR scenes using only
a single short-exposure RAW image? In this study, we rely solely on a single
short-exposure frame, which inherently avoids ghosting and motion blur, making
it particularly robust in dynamic scenes. To achieve that, we introduce
UltraLED, a two-stage framework that performs exposure correction via a ratio
map to balance dynamic range, followed by a brightness-aware RAW denoiser to
enhance detail recovery in dark regions. To support this setting, we design a
9-stop bracketing pipeline to synthesize realistic UHDR images and contribute a
corresponding dataset based on diverse scenes, using only the shortest exposure
as input for reconstruction. Extensive experiments show that UltraLED
significantly outperforms existing single-frame approaches. Our code and
dataset are made publicly available at
https://srameo.github.io/projects/ultraled.

AI.tldr: UltraLED reconstructs ultra-high dynamic range images from a single short‑exposure RAW by first correcting exposure with a learned ratio map, then denoising with a brightness‑aware RAW model—avoiding ghosting and recovering shadows better than prior single‑frame methods.
AI.motivation: UHDR scenes (e.g., night with bright lights) have bimodal intensity distributions that make it hard to preserve both highlights and shadows. RGB bracketing can capture both but suffers from misalignment/ghosting. Short exposures already retain highlights; the core challenge is denoising and recovering dark‑region details. RAW offers higher bit depth and more predictable noise, making it better suited for this task.
AI.method: Use only a single short‑exposure RAW frame. A two‑stage framework (UltraLED): (1) exposure correction via a learned ratio map to balance dynamic range, (2) a brightness‑aware RAW denoiser to restore dark details. To train/evaluate, a 9‑stop bracketing pipeline synthesizes realistic UHDR targets; the shortest exposure serves as the sole input. Code and dataset are released.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, UltraLED significantly outperforms existing single‑frame approaches, especially in dark‑region recovery, while inherently avoiding ghosting and motion blur. Public code and dataset support reproducibility.
AI.conclusion: A single short‑exposure RAW image can be sufficient for high‑quality UHDR reconstruction when coupled with ratio‑map exposure correction and brightness‑aware RAW denoising. The approach is practical for dynamic scenes, and the provided dataset enables further research.

title: From Noisy to Native: LLM-driven Graph Restoration for Test-Time Graph Domain Adaptation
summary:
Graph domain adaptation (GDA) has achieved great attention due to its
effectiveness in addressing the domain shift between train and test data. A
significant bottleneck in existing graph domain adaptation methods is their
reliance on source-domain data, which is often unavailable due to privacy or
security concerns. This limitation has driven the development of Test-Time
Graph Domain Adaptation (TT-GDA), which aims to transfer knowledge without
accessing the source examples. Inspired by the generative power of large
language models (LLMs), we introduce a novel framework that reframes TT-GDA as
a generative graph restoration problem, "restoring the target graph to its
pristine, source-domain-like state". There are two key challenges: (1) We need
to construct a reasonable graph restoration process and design an effective
encoding scheme that an LLM can understand, bridging the modality gap. (2) We
need to devise a mechanism to ensure the restored graph acquires the intrinsic
features of the source domain, even without access to the source data. To
ensure the effectiveness of graph restoration, we propose GRAIL, that restores
the target graph into a state that is well-aligned with the source domain.
Specifically, we first compress the node representations into compact latent
features and then use a graph diffusion process to model the graph restoration
process. Then a quantization module encodes the restored features into discrete
tokens. Building on this, an LLM is fine-tuned as a generative restorer to
transform a "noisy" target graph into a "native" one. To further improve
restoration quality, we introduce a reinforcement learning process guided by
specialized alignment and confidence rewards. Extensive experiments demonstrate
the effectiveness of our approach across various datasets.

AI.tldr: GRAIL reframes test-time graph domain adaptation as an LLM-driven generative graph restoration task that converts a “noisy” target graph into a source-like one via diffusion-based restoration, tokenization, LLM fine-tuning, and RL with alignment/confidence rewards, achieving strong empirical results without access to source data.
AI.motivation: Conventional graph domain adaptation relies on source-domain data, which can be unavailable due to privacy/security. Test-time GDA must adapt with only target data, raising two challenges: (1) defining a restoration process and encoding that an LLM can understand (bridging the graph–text modality gap), and (2) ensuring restored graphs capture source-domain intrinsic properties without seeing any source examples.
AI.method: GRAIL: (i) compress node representations into compact latent features; (ii) use a graph diffusion process to model restoration from noisy target to native/source-like states; (iii) quantize restored features into discrete tokens; (iv) fine-tune an LLM as a generative restorer to map noisy graphs to native ones; (v) further optimize with reinforcement learning guided by alignment and confidence rewards.
AI.result: Across multiple datasets, experiments show GRAIL effectively aligns target graphs to source-like representations and improves TT-GDA performance, demonstrating its practicality and robustness in source-free settings.
AI.conclusion: Casting TT-GDA as generative graph restoration and leveraging LLMs with diffusion, quantization, and RL enables source-free alignment of target graphs to source-domain characteristics, leading to improved test-time adaptation performance.

title: Multilingual Knowledge Graph Completion via Efficient Multilingual Knowledge Sharing
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) based Multilingual Knowledge Graph Completion
(MKGC) aim to predict missing facts by leveraging LLMs' multilingual
understanding capabilities, improving the completeness of multilingual
knowledge graphs (KGs). However, existing MKGC research underutilizes the
multilingual capabilities of LLMs and ignores the shareability of cross-lingual
knowledge. In this paper, we propose a novel MKGC framework that leverages
multilingual shared knowledge to significantly enhance performance through two
components: Knowledge-level Grouped Mixture of Experts (KL-GMoE) and Iterative
Entity Reranking (IER). KL-GMoE efficiently models shared knowledge, while IER
significantly enhances its utilization. To evaluate our framework, we
constructed a mKG dataset containing 5 languages and conducted comprehensive
comparative experiments with existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) MKGC method. The
experimental results demonstrate that our framework achieves improvements of
5.47%, 3.27%, and 1.01% in the Hits@1, Hits@3, and Hits@10 metrics,
respectively, compared with SOTA MKGC method. Further experimental analysis
revealed the properties of knowledge sharing in settings of unseen and
unbalanced languages. We have released the dataset and code for our work on
https://github.com/gaoxiaofei07/KL-GMoE.

AI.tldr: Proposes a multilingual KG completion framework that exploits cross-lingual shared knowledge using a Knowledge-level Grouped Mixture of Experts (KL-GMoE) and Iterative Entity Reranking (IER), yielding notable gains over SOTA on a new 5-language dataset; code and data released.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM-based MKGC methods underuse LLMs’ multilingual capabilities and overlook shareability of knowledge across languages, limiting completion quality—especially in low-resource or unseen-language settings.
AI.method: Introduce two components: (1) KL-GMoE to model and route shared knowledge across languages via grouped experts at the knowledge level, and (2) IER to iteratively rerank candidate entities to better utilize shared knowledge in prediction. Build an mKG dataset (5 languages) and compare against a SOTA MKGC baseline.
AI.result: On the mKG dataset, the framework improves Hits@1 by 5.47%, Hits@3 by 3.27%, and Hits@10 by 1.01% over the SOTA MKGC method. Additional analyses examine knowledge sharing in unseen and unbalanced language scenarios. Code and dataset are publicly released.
