as a bounded stochastic process with restoring forces and controllable
interventions. We instantiate this framework in both synthetic long-horizon
rewriting tasks and realistic user-agent simulations such as in $\tau$-Bench,
measuring drift for several open-weight LLMs that are used as user simulators.
Our experiments consistently reveal stable, noise-limited equilibria rather
than runaway degradation, and demonstrate that simple reminder interventions
reliably reduce divergence in line with theoretical predictions. Together,
these results suggest that multi-turn drift can be understood as a controllable
equilibrium phenomenon rather than as inevitable decay, providing a foundation
for studying and mitigating context drift in extended interactions.

AI.tldr: They formalize and measure multi-turn “context drift” in LLMs, model its dynamics, and show it reaches a stable, controllable equilibrium that simple reminders can improve—rather than inexorable degradation.
AI.motivation: LLMs often perform well on single-turn tasks, but real-world use involves sustained, multi-turn interactions where goals and context persist. Models can drift from the user’s goals over time, and existing static metrics miss this temporally unfolding error. A principled way to quantify, interpret, and mitigate drift is needed.
AI.method: Define drift at each turn as the KL divergence between the test model’s token-level predictive distribution and that of a goal-consistent reference model. Propose a recurrence (dynamical) model treating drift as a bounded stochastic process with restoring forces and controllable interventions. Instantiate and evaluate this on synthetic long-horizon rewriting tasks and realistic user–agent simulations (e.g., τ-Bench), using several open-weight LLMs as user simulators, and test simple reminder interventions.
AI.result: Across tasks and models, drift exhibits stable, noise-limited equilibria rather than runaway error accumulation. Reminder-style interventions reliably reduce divergence in accordance with the theoretical predictions of the dynamical model.
AI.conclusion: Multi-turn drift is best viewed as a controllable equilibrium phenomenon, not inevitable decay. The proposed framework offers a basis to analyze, predict, and mitigate drift in extended interactions via simple, effective interventions.

title: AlignGS: Aligning Geometry and Semantics for Robust Indoor Reconstruction from Sparse Views
summary:
The demand for semantically rich 3D models of indoor scenes is rapidly
growing, driven by applications in augmented reality, virtual reality, and
robotics. However, creating them from sparse views remains a challenge due to
geometric ambiguity. Existing methods often treat semantics as a passive
feature painted on an already-formed, and potentially flawed, geometry. We
posit that for robust sparse-view reconstruction, semantic understanding
instead be an active, guiding force. This paper introduces AlignGS, a novel
framework that actualizes this vision by pioneering a synergistic, end-to-end
optimization of geometry and semantics. Our method distills rich priors from 2D
foundation models and uses them to directly regularize the 3D representation
through a set of novel semantic-to-geometry guidance mechanisms, including
depth consistency and multi-faceted normal regularization. Extensive
evaluations on standard benchmarks demonstrate that our approach achieves
state-of-the-art results in novel view synthesis and produces reconstructions
with superior geometric accuracy. The results validate that leveraging semantic
priors as a geometric regularizer leads to more coherent and complete 3D models
from limited input views. Our code is avaliable at
https://github.com/MediaX-SJTU/AlignGS .

AI.tldr: AlignGS jointly optimizes geometry and semantics for sparse-view indoor 3D reconstruction by distilling 2D foundation-model priors to guide 3D shape, achieving state-of-the-art novel view synthesis and more accurate geometry.
AI.motivation: Sparse-view reconstruction suffers from geometric ambiguity; prior work treats semantics as an afterthought painted onto imperfect geometry. The authors argue semantics should actively constrain geometry to yield robust, coherent 3D scenes from few views.
AI.method: Introduce AlignGS, an end-to-end framework that synergistically optimizes geometry and semantics. It distills rich priors from 2D foundation models and directly regularizes the 3D representation via semantic-to-geometry guidance, including depth consistency and multi-faceted surface normal regularization.
AI.result: On standard benchmarks, AlignGS attains state-of-the-art performance in novel view synthesis and produces reconstructions with superior geometric accuracy and completeness under sparse inputs.
AI.conclusion: Using semantic priors as a geometric regularizer effectively resolves ambiguities in sparse-view settings, leading to more coherent, complete 3D indoor models. The approach validates the value of semantics-as-guidance and is released as open-source (AlignGS).

title: Enabling Personalized Long-term Interactions in LLM-based Agents through Persistent Memory and User Profiles
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) increasingly serve as the central control unit
of AI agents, yet current approaches remain limited in their ability to deliver
personalized interactions. While Retrieval Augmented Generation enhances LLM
capabilities by improving context-awareness, it lacks mechanisms to combine
contextual information with user-specific data. Although personalization has
been studied in fields such as human-computer interaction or cognitive science,
existing perspectives largely remain conceptual, with limited focus on
technical implementation. To address these gaps, we build on a unified
definition of personalization as a conceptual foundation to derive technical
requirements for adaptive, user-centered LLM-based agents. Combined with
established agentic AI patterns such as multi-agent collaboration or
multi-source retrieval, we present a framework that integrates persistent
memory, dynamic coordination, self-validation, and evolving user profiles to
enable personalized long-term interactions. We evaluate our approach on three
public datasets using metrics such as retrieval accuracy, response correctness,
or BertScore. We complement these results with a five-day pilot user study
providing initial insights into user feedback on perceived personalization. The
study provides early indications that guide future work and highlights the
potential of integrating persistent memory and user profiles to improve the
adaptivity and perceived personalization of LLM-based agents.

AI.tldr: Proposes a practical framework for personalized LLM-based agents that unifies a definition of personalization with an architecture featuring persistent memory, evolving user profiles, dynamic coordination, and self-validation; evaluated on three datasets and a short user study, suggesting improved adaptivity and perceived personalization.
AI.motivation: Current LLM-based agents struggle to deliver truly personalized interactions. RAG improves context use but lacks mechanisms to fuse retrieved context with durable, user-specific knowledge. Prior work on personalization is largely conceptual and not translated into implementable, agentic AI systems.
AI.method: Derive technical requirements from a unified definition of personalization and realize them via a framework that combines agentic patterns (multi-agent collaboration, multi-source retrieval) with persistent memory, dynamic coordination, self-validation, and evolving user profiles to enable long-term adaptive behavior. Evaluate on three public datasets using retrieval accuracy, response correctness, and BERTScore, and run a five-day pilot user study to gauge perceived personalization.
AI.result: Quantitative evaluations on three datasets are reported (metrics: retrieval accuracy, response correctness, BERTScore), and a five-day pilot user study provides initial positive indications of improved adaptivity and perceived personalization. The abstract does not specify exact numbers but suggests benefits from integrating persistent memory and user profiles.
AI.conclusion: Integrating persistent memory and evolving user profiles into LLM-based agent architectures is a promising path to sustained, user-centered personalization. The proposed framework supports long-term adaptivity and shows early encouraging signals, motivating more comprehensive empirical validation and refinement.

title: RCPU: Rotation-Constrained Error Compensation for Structured Pruning of a Large Language Model
summary:
In this paper, we propose a rotation-constrained compensation method to
address the errors introduced by structured pruning of large language models
(LLMs). LLMs are trained on massive datasets and accumulate rich semantic
knowledge in their representation space. In contrast, pruning is typically
carried out with only a small amount of calibration data, which makes output
mismatches unavoidable. Although direct least-squares fitting can reduce such
errors, it tends to overfit to the limited calibration set, destructively
modifying pretrained weights. To overcome this difficulty, we update the pruned
parameters under a rotation constraint. This constrained update preserves the
geometry of output representations (i.e., norms and inner products) and
simultaneously re-aligns the pruned subspace with the original outputs.
Furthermore, in rotation-constrained compensation, removing components that
strongly contribute to the principal directions of the output makes error
recovery difficult. Since input dimensions with large variance strongly affect
these principal directions, we design a variance-aware importance score that
ensures such dimensions are preferentially kept in the pruned model. By
combining this scoring rule with rotation-constrained updates, the proposed
method effectively compensates errors while retaining the components likely to
be more important in a geometry-preserving manner. In the experiments, we apply
the proposed method to LLaMA-7B and evaluate it on WikiText-2 and multiple
language understanding benchmarks. The results demonstrate consistently better
perplexity and task accuracy compared with existing baselines.

AI.tldr: They introduce a geometry-preserving, rotation-constrained compensation paired with a variance-aware importance score to make structured pruning of LLMs less destructive, yielding lower perplexity and higher task accuracy on LLaMA‑7B than baselines.
AI.motivation: Structured pruning uses limited calibration data, causing output mismatches. Direct least-squares fitting can reduce errors but overfits and distorts pretrained weights. The goal is to compensate pruning errors while preserving the pretrained representation geometry and avoiding removal of components vital to principal directions.
AI.method: After pruning, update pruned parameters under a rotation constraint so norms and inner products of output representations are preserved while re-aligning the pruned subspace with the original outputs. Complement this with a variance-aware importance score that prioritizes retaining input dimensions with high variance (i.e., those heavily influencing principal directions), then combine this scoring with the rotation-constrained updates.
AI.result: On LLaMA‑7B, across WikiText‑2 and multiple language understanding benchmarks, the approach consistently improves perplexity and task accuracy compared with existing pruning baselines.
AI.conclusion: Rotation-constrained compensation plus variance-aware scoring effectively mitigates pruning-induced errors without overfitting, preserves representation geometry, and retains important components, offering a practical, stronger baseline for structured LLM pruning.

title: Self-Supervised Learning Strategies for a Platform to Test the Toxicity of New Chemicals and Materials
summary:
High-throughput toxicity testing offers a fast and cost-effective way to test
large amounts of compounds. A key component for such systems is the automated
evaluation via machine learning models. In this paper, we address critical
challenges in this domain and demonstrate how representations learned via
self-supervised learning can effectively identify toxicant-induced changes. We
provide a proof-of-concept that utilizes the publicly available EmbryoNet
dataset, which contains ten zebrafish embryo phenotypes elicited by various
chemical compounds targeting different processes in early embryonic
development. Our analysis shows that the learned representations using
self-supervised learning are suitable for effectively distinguishing between
the modes-of-action of different compounds. Finally, we discuss the integration
of machine learning models in a physical toxicity testing device in the context
of the TOXBOX project.

AI.tldr: Proof-of-concept: self-supervised representations learned from EmbryoNet zebrafish embryo images can detect toxicant-induced phenotypes and separate compounds by mode of action; outlines integration into a TOXBOX testing device.
AI.motivation: High-throughput toxicity screens require fast, scalable, and label-efficient analysis. Supervised models depend on extensive labels and may not generalize across compounds or mechanisms. The goal is to learn robust representations that capture toxicant-induced changes and differentiate modes of action to enable automated evaluation.
AI.method: Apply self-supervised learning to the EmbryoNet dataset (10 zebrafish embryo phenotypes induced by diverse compounds) to learn image representations. Assess whether these embeddings effectively separate phenotypes and modes of action. Provide a discussion on embedding such models in a physical testing device (TOXBOX).
AI.result: Self-supervised embeddings effectively identify toxicant-induced changes and distinguish between modes of action for different compounds within EmbryoNet.
AI.conclusion: Self-supervised learning yields suitable representations for automated high-throughput toxicity testing and shows promise for integration into practical devices like TOXBOX.

title: Agent-Based Genetic Algorithm for Crypto Trading Strategy Optimization
summary:
Cryptocurrency markets present formidable challenges for trading strategy
optimization due to extreme volatility, non-stationary dynamics, and complex
microstructure patterns that render conventional parameter optimization methods
fundamentally inadequate. We introduce Cypto Genetic Algorithm Agent
(CGA-Agent), a pioneering hybrid framework that synergistically integrates
genetic algorithms with intelligent multi-agent coordination mechanisms for
adaptive trading strategy parameter optimization in dynamic financial
environments. The framework uniquely incorporates real-time market
microstructure intelligence and adaptive strategy performance feedback through
intelligent mechanisms that dynamically guide evolutionary processes,
transcending the limitations of static optimization approaches. Comprehensive
empirical evaluation across three cryptocurrencies demonstrates systematic and
statistically significant performance improvements on both total returns and
risk-adjusted metrics.

AI.tldr: CGA-Agent is a hybrid genetic-algorithm plus multi-agent coordination framework that uses real-time market microstructure signals and adaptive performance feedback to dynamically optimize trading strategy parameters in crypto, yielding statistically significant gains in returns and risk-adjusted metrics across three coins.
AI.motivation: Conventional (static) parameter optimization fails in crypto due to extreme volatility, non-stationarity, and complex microstructure. The authors seek an adaptive optimizer that can continuously adjust strategy parameters to shifting market regimes.
AI.method: Introduce CGA-Agent, which couples evolutionary search (genetic algorithms) with intelligent multi-agent coordination. Agents ingest real-time market microstructure intelligence and strategy performance feedback to steer mutation/selection and guide the evolutionary process toward robust, regime-adaptive parameter sets.
AI.result: On three cryptocurrencies, the framework delivers systematic and statistically significant improvements versus baselines on total return and risk-adjusted measures (e.g., Sharpe-like metrics).
AI.conclusion: Embedding microstructure-aware, feedback-driven guidance into evolutionary optimization can overcome the limitations of static tuning, enhancing adaptability and robustness of trading strategies in dynamic crypto markets. The approach appears generalizable to other volatile, non-stationary financial environments.

title: LLM4Cell: A Survey of Large Language and Agentic Models for Single-Cell Biology
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) and emerging agentic frameworks are beginning to
transform single-cell biology by enabling natural-language reasoning,
generative annotation, and multimodal data integration. However, progress
remains fragmented across data modalities, architectures, and evaluation
standards. LLM4Cell presents the first unified survey of 58 foundation and
agentic models developed for single-cell research, spanning RNA, ATAC,
multi-omic, and spatial modalities. We categorize these methods into five
families-foundation, text-bridge, spatial, multimodal, epigenomic, and
agentic-and map them to eight key analytical tasks including annotation,
trajectory and perturbation modeling, and drug-response prediction. Drawing on
over 40 public datasets, we analyze benchmark suitability, data diversity, and
ethical or scalability constraints, and evaluate models across 10 domain
dimensions covering biological grounding, multi-omics alignment, fairness,
privacy, and explainability. By linking datasets, models, and evaluation
domains, LLM4Cell provides the first integrated view of language-driven
single-cell intelligence and outlines open challenges in interpretability,
standardization, and trustworthy model development.

AI.tldr: LLM4Cell is a unified survey of 58 LLM-based and agentic methods for single-cell biology across RNA, ATAC, multi-omic, and spatial data, offering a taxonomy, task mapping, dataset review, and a 10-dimension evaluation framework, and identifying gaps in interpretability, standardization, and trustworthiness.
AI.motivation: Progress in applying LLMs and agentic systems to single-cell biology is fragmented across modalities, architectures, datasets, and evaluation practices. The field lacks a consolidated taxonomy, standardized benchmarks, and a holistic view of ethical and scalability constraints.
AI.method: Systematic review of 58 models spanning single-cell modalities; categorization into families (foundation, text-bridge, spatial, multimodal, epigenomic, agentic); mapping to eight analytical tasks (e.g., cell-type annotation, trajectory/perturbation modeling, drug-response prediction); analysis of 40+ public datasets for benchmark suitability and diversity; evaluation across 10 domain dimensions (biological grounding, multi-omics alignment, fairness, privacy, explainability, etc.).
AI.result: A cross-modal taxonomy and task-model map; a curated view of datasets and their limitations; an evaluation framework covering 10 domain dimensions; identification of ethical/scalability constraints and gaps in interpretability and standardization.
AI.conclusion: The survey provides the first integrated perspective on language-driven single-cell intelligence, linking datasets, models, and evaluation axes, and outlines a roadmap toward interpretable, standardized, and trustworthy model development for the field.

title: XYZCylinder: Feedforward Reconstruction for Driving Scenes Based on A Unified Cylinder Lifting Method
summary:
Recently, more attention has been paid to feedforward reconstruction
paradigms, which mainly learn a fixed view transformation implicitly and
reconstruct the scene with a single representation. However, their
generalization capability and reconstruction accuracy are still limited while
reconstructing driving scenes, which results from two aspects: (1) The fixed
view transformation fails when the camera configuration changes, limiting the
generalization capability across different driving scenes equipped with
different camera configurations. (2) The small overlapping regions between
sparse views of the $360^\circ$ panorama and the complexity of driving scenes
increase the learning difficulty, reducing the reconstruction accuracy. To
handle these difficulties, we propose \textbf{XYZCylinder}, a feedforward model
based on a unified cylinder lifting method which involves camera modeling and
feature lifting. Specifically, to improve the generalization capability, we
design a Unified Cylinder Camera Modeling (UCCM) strategy, which avoids the
learning of viewpoint-dependent spatial correspondence and unifies different
camera configurations with adjustable parameters. To improve the reconstruction
accuracy, we propose a hybrid representation with several dedicated modules
based on newly designed Cylinder Plane Feature Group (CPFG) to lift 2D image
features to 3D space. Experimental results show that XYZCylinder achieves
state-of-the-art performance under different evaluation settings, and can be
generalized to other driving scenes in a zero-shot manner. Project page:
\href{https://yuyuyu223.github.io/XYZCYlinder-projectpage/}{here}.

AI.tldr: XYZCylinder is a feedforward 3D reconstruction model for driving scenes that uses a unified cylindrical camera model and cylinder-plane feature lifting to improve cross-rig generalization and accuracy with sparse 360° inputs, achieving state-of-the-art results and zero-shot transfer.
AI.motivation: Feedforward reconstruction methods that implicitly learn a fixed view transform struggle to generalize across varying multi-camera rigs and to accurately reconstruct complex driving scenes with minimal overlap among sparse panoramic views.
AI.method: Introduce a unified cylinder lifting pipeline: (1) Unified Cylinder Camera Modeling (UCCM) uses adjustable parameters to normalize diverse camera configurations and avoids learning viewpoint-dependent correspondences; (2) Cylinder Plane Feature Group (CPFG) lifts 2D image features onto cylindrical 3D structures with a hybrid representation and dedicated modules to better handle sparse overlaps and scene complexity; overall a feedforward architecture reconstructs scenes from multi-view inputs.
AI.result: Across multiple evaluation settings, XYZCylinder attains state-of-the-art reconstruction performance and demonstrates zero-shot generalization to unseen driving scenes and camera setups.
AI.conclusion: Unifying camera geometry via a cylindrical model and explicitly lifting features to 3D cylinders reduces viewpoint dependence and improves accuracy in sparse 360° driving scenarios, making feedforward reconstruction more robust and transferable to diverse rigs.

title: TaoSR-SHE: Stepwise Hybrid Examination Reinforcement Learning Framework for E-commerce Search Relevance
summary:
Query-product relevance analysis is a foundational technology in e-commerce
search engines and has become increasingly important in AI-driven e-commerce.
The recent emergence of large language models (LLMs), particularly their
chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning capabilities, offers promising opportunities
for developing relevance systems that are both more interpretable and more
robust. However, existing training paradigms have notable limitations: SFT and
DPO suffer from poor generalization on long-tail queries and from a lack of
fine-grained, stepwise supervision to enforce rule-aligned reasoning. In
contrast, reinforcement learning with verification rewards (RLVR) suffers from
sparse feedback, which provides insufficient signal to correct erroneous
intermediate steps, thereby undermining logical consistency and limiting
performance in complex inference scenarios.
  To address these challenges, we introduce the Stepwise Hybrid Examination
Reinforcement Learning framework for Taobao Search Relevance (TaoSR-SHE). At
its core is Stepwise Reward Policy Optimization (SRPO), a reinforcement
learning algorithm that leverages step-level rewards generated by a hybrid of a
high-quality generative stepwise reward model and a human-annotated offline
verifier, prioritizing learning from critical correct and incorrect reasoning
steps. TaoSR-SHE further incorporates two key techniques: diversified data
filtering to encourage exploration across varied reasoning paths and mitigate
policy entropy collapse, and multi-stage curriculum learning to foster
progressive capability growth. Extensive experiments on real-world search
benchmarks show that TaoSR-SHE improves both reasoning quality and
relevance-prediction accuracy in large-scale e-commerce settings, outperforming
SFT, DPO, GRPO, and other baselines, while also enhancing interpretability and
robustness.

AI.tldr: TaoSR-SHE introduces stepwise, hybrid-verified reinforcement learning to improve LLM chain-of-thought reasoning and query–product relevance in e-commerce search, outperforming SFT/DPO/GRPO baselines while increasing interpretability and robustness.
AI.motivation: SFT/DPO lack fine-grained, step-level supervision and generalize poorly on long-tail queries; RL with sparse verification rewards cannot correct intermediate reasoning errors. The goal is to enforce rule-aligned, interpretable reasoning with richer feedback to handle complex inference in e-commerce relevance.
AI.method: Stepwise Reward Policy Optimization (SRPO) uses step-level rewards from a hybrid source: a high-quality generative stepwise reward model plus a human-annotated offline verifier. Learning prioritizes critical correct/incorrect steps. The framework adds diversified data filtering to sustain exploration and avoid entropy collapse, and multi-stage curriculum learning for progressive capability building.
AI.result: On real-world Taobao search benchmarks, TaoSR-SHE improves reasoning quality and relevance prediction accuracy over SFT, DPO, GRPO, and other baselines, and yields better interpretability and robustness.
AI.conclusion: Hybrid, stepwise reward RL effectively guides LLM reasoning for e-commerce relevance, overcoming sparse-feedback limitations and extending beyond SFT/DPO approaches; it offers a scalable path to more accurate, consistent, and interpretable search relevance systems.

title: HiPRAG: Hierarchical Process Rewards for Efficient Agentic Retrieval Augmented Generation
summary:
Agentic RAG is a powerful technique for incorporating external information
that LLMs lack, enabling better problem solving and question answering.
However, suboptimal search behaviors exist widely, such as over-search
(retrieving information already known) and under-search (failing to search when
necessary), which leads to unnecessary overhead and unreliable outputs. Current
training methods, which typically rely on outcome-based rewards in a RL
framework, lack the fine-grained control needed to address these
inefficiencies. To overcome this, we introduce Hierarchical Process Rewards for
Efficient agentic RAG (HiPRAG), a training methodology that incorporates a
fine-grained, knowledge-grounded process reward into the RL training. Our
approach evaluates the necessity of each search decision on-the-fly by
decomposing the agent's reasoning trajectory into discrete, parsable steps. We
then apply a hierarchical reward function that provides an additional bonus
based on the proportion of optimal search and non-search steps, on top of
commonly used outcome and format rewards. Experiments on the Qwen2.5 and
Llama-3.2 models across seven diverse QA benchmarks show that our method
achieves average accuracies of 65.4% (3B) and 67.2% (7B). This is accomplished
while improving search efficiency, reducing the over-search rate to just 2.3%
and concurrently lowering the under-search rate. These results demonstrate the
efficacy of optimizing the reasoning process itself, not just the final
outcome. Further experiments and analysis demonstrate that HiPRAG shows good
generalizability across a wide range of RL algorithms, model families, sizes,
and types. This work demonstrates the importance and potential of fine-grained
control through RL, for improving the efficiency and optimality of reasoning
for search agents.

AI.tldr: HiPRAG adds hierarchical, knowledge-grounded process rewards to train agentic RAG to make only necessary search steps, cutting over-/under-search and improving QA accuracy and efficiency across models and benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Agentic RAG often wastes effort (over-search) or misses needed retrieval (under-search). Outcome-only RL rewards lack fine-grained control over when to search, leading to inefficiency and unreliable outputs. The authors seek to optimize the decision process itself, not just final correctness.
AI.method: Decompose the agent’s reasoning into discrete, parsable steps and assess, on-the-fly, whether each step should trigger a search. Introduce a hierarchical reward that adds process bonuses proportional to the fraction of optimal search and non-search decisions, layered on top of standard outcome and format rewards. Train with RL and show compatibility across different algorithms, model families, and sizes.
AI.result: Across seven QA benchmarks with Qwen2.5 and Llama-3.2, HiPRAG attains average accuracies of 65.4% (3B) and 67.2% (7B), reduces over-search to 2.3%, and simultaneously lowers under-search, improving search efficiency without sacrificing performance.
AI.conclusion: Fine-grained, hierarchical process rewards improve the efficiency and optimality of agentic RAG by aligning the reasoning process with necessary retrieval decisions. The approach generalizes across models and RL algorithms, highlighting the value of process-level control in RL for search agents.

title: MARC: Memory-Augmented RL Token Compression for Efficient Video Understanding
summary:
The rapid progress of large language models (LLMs) has laid the foundation
for multimodal models. However, visual language models (VLMs) still face heavy
computational costs when extended from images to videos due to high frame rates
and long durations. Token compression is a promising solution, yet most
existing training-free methods cause information loss and performance
degradation. To overcome this, we propose \textbf{Memory-Augmented
Reinforcement Learning-based Token Compression (MARC)}, which integrates
structured retrieval and RL-based distillation. MARC adopts a
\textit{retrieve-then-compress} strategy using a \textbf{Visual Memory
Retriever (VMR)} to select key clips and a \textbf{Compression Group Relative
Policy Optimization (C-GRPO)} framework to distil reasoning ability from a
teacher to a student model. Experiments on six video benchmarks show that MARC
achieves near-baseline accuracy using only one frame's tokens -- reducing
visual tokens by \textbf{95\%}, GPU memory by \textbf{72\%}, and latency by
\textbf{23.9\%}. This demonstrates its potential for efficient, real-time video
understanding in resource-constrained settings such as video QA, surveillance,
and autonomous driving.

AI.tldr: MARC compresses video tokens for VLMs via memory-guided retrieval and RL distillation, preserving near-baseline accuracy while cutting 95% visual tokens, 72% GPU memory, and 23.9% latency.
AI.motivation: Video understanding with VLMs is computationally heavy due to many frames and long durations; training-free compression often loses information and hurts accuracy. The goal is to reduce tokens efficiently without sacrificing reasoning performance.
AI.method: A retrieve-then-compress pipeline: (1) Visual Memory Retriever (VMR) constructs/queries a structured memory to pick key clips; (2) Compression Group Relative Policy Optimization (C-GRPO), an RL-based distillation framework, transfers reasoning ability from a teacher to a student so the student learns to compress tokens while retaining task-relevant information.
AI.result: On six video benchmarks, MARC achieves near-baseline accuracy using tokens equivalent to one frame, reducing visual tokens by 95%, GPU memory by 72%, and latency by 23.9%.
AI.conclusion: Combining structured retrieval with RL-based compression enables efficient, real-time video understanding for resource-limited scenarios (e.g., video QA, surveillance, autonomous driving) with minimal accuracy loss.

title: VoiceAgentBench: Are Voice Assistants ready for agentic tasks?
summary:
Large-scale Speech Language Models (SpeechLMs) have enabled voice assistants
capable of understanding natural spoken queries and performing complex tasks.
However, existing speech benchmarks primarily focus on isolated capabilities
such as transcription, or question-answering, and do not systematically
evaluate agentic scenarios encompassing multilingual and cultural
understanding, as well as adversarial robustness. To address this, we introduce
VoiceAgentBench, a comprehensive benchmark designed to evaluate SpeechLMs in
realistic spoken agentic settings. It comprises over 5,500 synthetic spoken
queries, including dialogues grounded in Indian context, covering single-tool
invocations, multi-tool workflows, multi-turn interactions, and safety
evaluations. The benchmark supports English, Hindi, and 5 other Indian
languages, reflecting real-world linguistic and cultural diversity. We simulate
speaker variability using a novel sampling algorithm that selects audios for
TTS voice conversion based on its speaker embeddings, maximizing acoustic and
speaker diversity. Our evaluation measures tool selection accuracy, structural
consistency, and the correctness of tool invocations, including adversarial
robustness. Our experiments reveal significant gaps in contextual tool
orchestration tasks, Indic generalization, and adversarial robustness, exposing
critical limitations of current SpeechLMs.

AI.tldr: VoiceAgentBench is a comprehensive benchmark to evaluate Speech Language Models as voice agents across multilingual, culturally grounded, multi-tool, multi-turn, and adversarial scenarios, revealing major weaknesses in current systems—especially for Indic languages, tool orchestration, and robustness.
AI.motivation: Current speech benchmarks test narrow skills (e.g., ASR, QA) and miss realistic, agentic use cases that require multilingual and cultural competence and robustness against adversarial inputs. There is a need for a realistic, diverse, and systematic evaluation suite for SpeechLMs acting as tool-using agents.
AI.method: Construct a 5,500+ utterance synthetic spoken benchmark with dialogues grounded in Indian context. Cover single-tool invocations, multi-tool workflows, multi-turn interactions, and safety checks. Support English, Hindi, and five additional Indian languages. Simulate speaker variability via a new sampling algorithm that picks TTS voice-conversion audios using speaker embeddings to maximize acoustic and speaker diversity. Evaluate models on tool selection accuracy, structural consistency, correctness of tool calls, and adversarial robustness.
AI.result: Across evaluated SpeechLMs, performance degrades notably in contextual tool orchestration, generalization to Indic languages, and under adversarial conditions, indicating substantial gaps beyond simple ASR/QA capabilities.
AI.conclusion: VoiceAgentBench exposes critical limitations of current SpeechLMs in realistic agentic settings and provides a structured path to measure and improve multilingual, culturally grounded, and robust voice-agent behaviors.

title: Dynamic Generation of Multi-LLM Agents Communication Topologies with Graph Diffusion Models
summary:
The efficiency of multi-agent systems driven by large language models (LLMs)
largely hinges on their communication topology. However, designing an optimal
topology is a non-trivial challenge, as it requires balancing competing
objectives such as task performance, communication cost, and robustness.
Existing frameworks often rely on static or hand-crafted topologies, which
inherently fail to adapt to diverse task requirements, leading to either
excessive token consumption for simple problems or performance bottlenecks for
complex ones. To address this challenge, we introduce a novel generative
framework called \textit{Guided Topology Diffusion (GTD)}. Inspired by
conditional discrete graph diffusion models, GTD formulates topology synthesis
as an iterative construction process. At each step, the generation is steered
by a lightweight proxy model that predicts multi-objective rewards (e.g.,
accuracy, utility, cost), enabling real-time, gradient-free optimization
towards task-adaptive topologies. This iterative, guided synthesis process
distinguishes GTD from single-step generative frameworks, enabling it to better
navigate complex design trade-offs. We validated GTD across multiple
benchmarks, and experiments show that this framework can generate highly
task-adaptive, sparse, and efficient communication topologies, significantly
outperforming existing methods in LLM agent collaboration.

AI.tldr: They propose Guided Topology Diffusion (GTD), an iterative, proxy-guided discrete graph diffusion method that generates task-adaptive, sparse communication topologies for LLM multi-agent systems, optimizing accuracy/utility vs. token cost/robustness and outperforming static or one-shot designs.
AI.motivation: Communication topology critically affects performance, cost, and robustness in LLM-based multi-agent systems. Static or hand-crafted topologies cannot adapt across task difficulty, causing waste on simple tasks and bottlenecks on complex ones. A principled way to synthesize topologies that balance competing objectives per task is needed.
AI.method: GTD frames topology design as iterative construction via conditional discrete graph diffusion. At each iteration, a lightweight proxy predicts multi-objective rewards (accuracy, utility, cost), which guide the diffusion steps to bias generation toward better trade-offs. This enables gradient-free, real-time, task-adaptive topology synthesis distinct from single-step generators.
AI.result: Across multiple benchmarks, GTD produces sparse, efficient, and task-tailored communication graphs for LLM agents, yielding significant improvements over existing methods in collaboration performance while reducing token/communication overhead.
AI.conclusion: Iterative, proxy-guided diffusion is an effective mechanism to navigate multi-objective trade-offs in LLM multi-agent topology design, enabling adaptive, efficient, and robust communication structures that outperform static or one-shot baselines.

title: ASBench: Image Anomalies Synthesis Benchmark for Anomaly Detection
summary:
Anomaly detection plays a pivotal role in manufacturing quality control, yet
its application is constrained by limited abnormal samples and high manual
annotation costs. While anomaly synthesis offers a promising solution, existing
studies predominantly treat anomaly synthesis as an auxiliary component within
anomaly detection frameworks, lacking systematic evaluation of anomaly
synthesis algorithms. Current research also overlook crucial factors specific
to anomaly synthesis, such as decoupling its impact from detection,
quantitative analysis of synthetic data and adaptability across different
scenarios. To address these limitations, we propose ASBench, the first
comprehensive benchmarking framework dedicated to evaluating anomaly synthesis
methods. Our framework introduces four critical evaluation dimensions: (i) the
generalization performance across different datasets and pipelines (ii) the
ratio of synthetic to real data (iii) the correlation between intrinsic metrics
of synthesis images and anomaly detection performance metrics , and (iv)
strategies for hybrid anomaly synthesis methods. Through extensive experiments,
ASBench not only reveals limitations in current anomaly synthesis methods but
also provides actionable insights for future research directions in anomaly
synthesis

AI.tldr: ASBench is a dedicated benchmark for evaluating anomaly synthesis, offering four evaluation axes (generalization, synthetic-to-real ratio, metric–performance correlation, and hybrid strategies) and exposing current methods’ limitations while guiding future research.
AI.motivation: Manufacturing anomaly detection suffers from scarce abnormal samples and costly labels. Existing work uses synthesis only as an auxiliary add-on and lacks a principled, decoupled, and quantitative evaluation of synthesis itself across scenarios.
AI.method: Propose ASBench, a comprehensive benchmarking framework focused on anomaly synthesis. It evaluates methods along four dimensions: (i) generalization across datasets and detection pipelines, (ii) varying proportions of synthetic vs. real data, (iii) correlation between intrinsic image-level synthesis metrics and downstream detection performance, and (iv) design/evaluation of hybrid synthesis strategies. Extensive experiments are conducted under these protocols.
AI.result: Experiments reveal limitations of current synthesis approaches, characterize how performance varies with data ratios and pipelines, and identify relationships between synthesis quality metrics and detection outcomes. The benchmark yields practical insights for method design and use, though specific quantitative gains are not detailed in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: ASBench establishes the first comprehensive, standardized evaluation for anomaly synthesis, decoupling it from detection and enabling fair, cross-scenario comparisons. It provides actionable guidance and a basis for future algorithmic improvements and integration strategies.

title: ReInAgent: A Context-Aware GUI Agent Enabling Human-in-the-Loop Mobile Task Navigation
summary:
Mobile GUI agents exhibit substantial potential to facilitate and automate
the execution of user tasks on mobile phones. However, exist mobile GUI agents
predominantly privilege autonomous operation and neglect the necessity of
active user engagement during task execution. This omission undermines their
adaptability to information dilemmas including ambiguous, dynamically evolving,
and conflicting task scenarios, leading to execution outcomes that deviate from
genuine user requirements and preferences. To address these shortcomings, we
propose ReInAgent, a context-aware multi-agent framework that leverages dynamic
information management to enable human-in-the-loop mobile task navigation.
ReInAgent integrates three specialized agents around a shared memory module: an
information-managing agent for slot-based information management and proactive
interaction with the user, a decision-making agent for conflict-aware planning,
and a reflecting agent for task reflection and information consistency
validation. Through continuous contextual information analysis and sustained
user-agent collaboration, ReInAgent overcomes the limitation of existing
approaches that rely on clear and static task assumptions. Consequently, it
enables more adaptive and reliable mobile task navigation in complex,
real-world scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that ReInAgent
effectively resolves information dilemmas and produces outcomes that are more
closely aligned with genuine user preferences. Notably, on complex tasks
involving information dilemmas, ReInAgent achieves a 25% higher success rate
than Mobile-Agent-v2.

AI.tldr: ReInAgent is a human-in-the-loop, context-aware multi-agent system for mobile GUI task execution that manages ambiguous, evolving, and conflicting information via shared memory and proactive user interaction, yielding a 25% higher success rate than Mobile-Agent-v2 on complex tasks.
AI.motivation: Current mobile GUI agents overemphasize full autonomy and underuse active user engagement, which hurts performance when tasks contain ambiguity, changing requirements, or conflicting constraints—leading to outcomes misaligned with true user preferences.
AI.method: Introduce ReInAgent, a multi-agent framework centered on a shared memory. It comprises: (1) an information-managing agent that performs slot-based information tracking and proactively queries the user; (2) a decision-making agent that plans while accounting for information conflicts; and (3) a reflecting agent that conducts task reflection and validates information consistency. The system continuously analyzes context and maintains user-in-the-loop collaboration to navigate tasks adaptively.
AI.result: Experiments show ReInAgent effectively resolves information dilemmas and produces outcomes closer to user preferences. On complex tasks with information dilemmas, it achieves a 25% higher success rate than Mobile-Agent-v2.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating dynamic information management and human-in-the-loop collaboration within a context-aware multi-agent architecture improves adaptability and reliability of mobile task navigation in complex, real-world scenarios.

title: Multilingual Generative Retrieval via Cross-lingual Semantic Compression
summary:
Generative Information Retrieval is an emerging retrieval paradigm that
exhibits remarkable performance in monolingual scenarios.However, applying
these methods to multilingual retrieval still encounters two primary
challenges, cross-lingual identifier misalignment and identifier inflation. To
address these limitations, we propose Multilingual Generative Retrieval via
Cross-lingual Semantic Compression (MGR-CSC), a novel framework that unifies
semantically equivalent multilingual keywords into shared atoms to align
semantics and compresses the identifier space, and we propose a dynamic
multi-step constrained decoding strategy during retrieval. MGR-CSC improves
cross-lingual alignment by assigning consistent identifiers and enhances
decoding efficiency by reducing redundancy. Experiments demonstrate that
MGR-CSC achieves outstanding retrieval accuracy, improving by 6.83% on
mMarco100k and 4.77% on mNQ320k, while reducing document identifiers length by
74.51% and 78.2%, respectively.

AI.tldr: MGR-CSC is a multilingual generative retrieval framework that compresses and aligns cross-lingual identifiers via shared semantic atoms and uses dynamic constrained decoding, yielding higher accuracy and shorter identifier sequences.
AI.motivation: Generative IR works well in monolingual settings but struggles in multilingual scenarios due to cross-lingual identifier misalignment (same concept mapped to different tokens across languages) and identifier inflation (large, redundant identifier spaces), which hurt alignment and decoding efficiency.
AI.method: Introduce Multilingual Generative Retrieval via Cross-lingual Semantic Compression (MGR-CSC). It unifies semantically equivalent multilingual keywords into shared atoms to align semantics and compress the identifier space, and applies a dynamic multi-step constrained decoding strategy during retrieval to enforce consistent, efficient generation.
AI.result: On mMarco100k and mNQ320k, MGR-CSC improves retrieval accuracy by 6.83% and 4.77%, respectively, and reduces document identifier lengths by 74.51% and 78.2%.
AI.conclusion: By compressing and aligning cross-lingual semantics and guiding generation with constrained decoding, MGR-CSC enhances both effectiveness and efficiency for multilingual generative retrieval.

title: TTOM: Test-Time Optimization and Memorization for Compositional Video Generation
summary:
Video Foundation Models (VFMs) exhibit remarkable visual generation
performance, but struggle in compositional scenarios (e.g., motion, numeracy,
and spatial relation). In this work, we introduce Test-Time Optimization and
Memorization (TTOM), a training-free framework that aligns VFM outputs with
spatiotemporal layouts during inference for better text-image alignment. Rather
than direct intervention to latents or attention per-sample in existing work,
we integrate and optimize new parameters guided by a general layout-attention
objective. Furthermore, we formulate video generation within a streaming
setting, and maintain historical optimization contexts with a parametric memory
mechanism that supports flexible operations, such as insert, read, update, and
delete. Notably, we found that TTOM disentangles compositional world knowledge,
showing powerful transferability and generalization. Experimental results on
the T2V-CompBench and Vbench benchmarks establish TTOM as an effective,
practical, scalable, and efficient framework to achieve cross-modal alignment
for compositional video generation on the fly.

AI.tldr: TTOM is a training-free, test-time optimization and memory framework that aligns video foundation models’ generations to spatiotemporal layouts via a layout-attention objective, enabling streaming generation with a parametric memory and improving compositional text–video alignment on T2V-CompBench and VBench.
AI.motivation: Despite strong visual quality, VFMs often fail at compositional reasoning (motion consistency, numeracy, spatial relations). The goal is to enhance cross-modal alignment without retraining and to operate in streaming settings where historical context matters.
AI.method: Instead of per-sample latent/attention editing, TTOM injects and optimizes additional inference-time parameters guided by a general layout-attention objective to enforce spatiotemporal layout adherence. It frames video generation as streaming and maintains historical optimization context with a parametric memory supporting insert/read/update/delete, enabling on-the-fly alignment across time.
AI.result: TTOM disentangles compositional world knowledge, shows transferability and generalization across prompts, and yields improved alignment and performance on T2V-CompBench and VBench. It is presented as practical, scalable, and efficient.
AI.conclusion: A training-free, inference-time optimization with memory can reliably improve compositional alignment in video generation on the fly, making VFMs more controllable in streaming scenarios without model retraining.

title: Language Models Do Not Embed Numbers Continuously
summary:
Recent research has extensively studied how large language models manipulate
integers in specific arithmetic tasks, and on a more fundamental level, how
they represent numeric values. These previous works have found that language
model embeddings can be used to reconstruct the original values, however, they
do not evaluate whether language models actually model continuous values as
continuous. Using expected properties of the embedding space, including linear
reconstruction and principal component analysis, we show that language models
not only represent numeric spaces as non-continuous but also introduce
significant noise. Using models from three major providers (OpenAI, Google
Gemini and Voyage AI), we show that while reconstruction is possible with high
fidelity ($R^2 \geq 0.95$), principal components only explain a minor share of
variation within the embedding space. This indicates that many components
within the embedding space are orthogonal to the simple numeric input space.
Further, both linear reconstruction and explained variance suffer with
increasing decimal precision, despite the ordinal nature of the input space
being fundamentally unchanged. The findings of this work therefore have
implications for the many areas where embedding models are used, in-particular
where high numerical precision, large magnitudes or mixed-sign values are
common.

AI.tldr: Embeddings from major LLM providers allow accurate numeric value reconstruction, but they do not form a clean, low-dimensional, continuous representation of numbers; much variance is orthogonal noise and worsens with higher decimal precision.
AI.motivation: Prior work showed numeric values can be decoded from language model embeddings, but did not test whether those embeddings respect the continuity and geometry expected of numeric spaces. This matters for applications relying on distances and directions in embedding space to reflect numeric relationships.
AI.method: Embed numeric inputs using APIs from OpenAI, Google Gemini, and Voyage AI. Evaluate (1) linear reconstruction accuracy (e.g., regression R^2) from embeddings back to numbers; and (2) the fraction of variance explained by principal components to assess whether a small set of directions captures the numeric manifold. Vary decimal precision, magnitudes, and signs.
AI.result: Despite high linear reconstruction fidelity (R^2 ≥ 0.95), principal components capture only a small fraction of total embedding variance, implying most embedding dimensions are not aligned with the simple numeric axis. Both reconstruction quality and explained variance deteriorate as decimal precision increases; mixed signs and large magnitudes further challenge representation.
AI.conclusion: LLM embeddings represent numeric inputs in a noisy, largely non-continuous manner, with many orthogonal components unrelated to the numeric axis. This undermines assumptions that embedding distances capture numeric relations and raises caution for applications demanding high numerical precision, large ranges, or mixed-sign values.

title: AdaSwitch: Adaptive Switching Generation for Knowledge Distillation
summary:
Small language models (SLMs) are crucial for applications with strict latency
and computational constraints, yet achieving high performance remains
challenging. Knowledge distillation (KD) can transfer capabilities from large
teacher models, but existing methods involve trade-offs: off-policy
distillation provides high-quality supervision but introduces a
training-inference mismatch, while on-policy approaches maintain consistency
but rely on low-quality student outputs. To address these issues, we propose
AdaSwitch, a novel approach that dynamically combines on-policy and off-policy
generation at the token level. AdaSwitch allows the student to first explore
its own predictions and then selectively integrate teacher guidance based on
real-time quality assessment. This approach simultaneously preserves
consistency and maintains supervision quality. Experiments on three datasets
with two teacher-student LLM pairs demonstrate that AdaSwitch consistently
improves accuracy, offering a practical and effective method for distilling
SLMs with acceptable additional overhead.

AI.tldr: AdaSwitch is a token-level adaptive distillation method that mixes on-policy (student) and off-policy (teacher) generation using real-time quality checks, improving SLM accuracy with modest overhead.
AI.motivation: Small language models are needed for latency/compute-limited applications but underperform. Standard KD faces a trade-off: off-policy supervision is high quality but causes training–inference mismatch; on-policy is consistent but fed by low-quality student outputs. A mechanism is needed to leverage teacher quality without losing policy consistency.
AI.method: During distillation, the student first proposes tokens (on-policy). A real-time quality assessment then decides per token whether to keep the student’s choice or to integrate teacher guidance, effectively switching between student- and teacher-driven trajectories at the token level. This maintains on-policy exposure while injecting high-quality supervision. Evaluated on three datasets with two teacher–student pairs.
AI.result: Across all tested datasets and model pairs, AdaSwitch yields consistent accuracy gains over baselines, with acceptable additional computational overhead.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive token-level switching balances supervision quality and exposure consistency, providing a practical, effective way to distill stronger performance into SLMs under resource constraints.

title: CVD-STORM: Cross-View Video Diffusion with Spatial-Temporal Reconstruction Model for Autonomous Driving
summary:
Generative models have been widely applied to world modeling for environment
simulation and future state prediction. With advancements in autonomous
driving, there is a growing demand not only for high-fidelity video generation
under various controls, but also for producing diverse and meaningful
information such as depth estimation. To address this, we propose CVD-STORM, a
cross-view video diffusion model utilizing a spatial-temporal reconstruction
Variational Autoencoder (VAE) that generates long-term, multi-view videos with
4D reconstruction capabilities under various control inputs. Our approach first
fine-tunes the VAE with an auxiliary 4D reconstruction task, enhancing its
ability to encode 3D structures and temporal dynamics. Subsequently, we
integrate this VAE into the video diffusion process to significantly improve
generation quality. Experimental results demonstrate that our model achieves
substantial improvements in both FID and FVD metrics. Additionally, the
jointly-trained Gaussian Splatting Decoder effectively reconstructs dynamic
scenes, providing valuable geometric information for comprehensive scene
understanding.

AI.tldr: CVD-STORM is a cross-view video diffusion framework augmented with a spatial-temporal reconstruction VAE to generate long-horizon, multi-view videos while enabling 4D (dynamic 3D) scene reconstruction under various controls.
AI.motivation: Autonomous driving requires not only controllable, high-fidelity video simulation for world modeling but also geometric signals like depth for robust scene understanding. Existing generators often lack strong 3D/temporal consistency and explicit 4D reconstruction.
AI.method: (1) Fine-tune a video VAE with an auxiliary 4D reconstruction objective to better encode 3D structure and temporal dynamics. (2) Plug this VAE into a video diffusion model to improve generation quality and controllability across views and time. (3) Jointly train a Gaussian Splatting Decoder to reconstruct dynamic scenes and expose geometric information.
AI.result: The approach yields significant improvements on FID and FVD for generated videos, and the Gaussian Splatting Decoder successfully reconstructs dynamic scenes, producing useful geometric outputs (e.g., depth/structure).
AI.conclusion: By coupling a 4D-aware VAE with diffusion and a Gaussian splatting decoder, CVD-STORM advances controllable, multi-view video generation and delivers explicit geometric reconstructions that enhance comprehensive scene understanding.

title: PEAR: Phase Entropy Aware Reward for Efficient Reasoning
summary:
Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) have achieved impressive performance on complex
reasoning tasks by generating detailed chain-of-thought (CoT) explanations.
However, these responses are often excessively long, containing redundant
reasoning steps that inflate inference cost and reduce usability. Controlling
the length of generated reasoning without sacrificing accuracy remains an open
challenge. Through a systematic empirical analysis, we reveal a consistent
positive correlation between model entropy and response length at different
reasoning stages across diverse LRMs: the thinking phase exhibits higher
entropy, reflecting exploratory behavior of longer responses, while the final
answer phase shows lower entropy, indicating a more deterministic solution.This
observation suggests that entropy at different reasoning stages can serve as a
control knob for balancing conciseness and performance. Based on this insight,
this paper introduces Phase Entropy Aware Reward (PEAR), a reward mechanism
that incorporating phase-dependent entropy into the reward design. Instead of
treating all tokens uniformly, PEAR penalize excessive entropy during the
thinking phase and allowing moderate exploration at the final answer phase,
which encourages models to generate concise reasoning traces that retain
sufficient flexibility to solve the task correctly. This enables adaptive
control of response length without relying on explicit length targets or rigid
truncation rules. Extensive experiments across four benchmarks demonstrate that
PEAR consistently reduces response length while sustaining competitive accuracy
across model scales. In addition, PEAR demonstrates strong out-of-distribution
(OOD) robustness beyond the training distribution. Our code is available at:
https://github.com/iNLP-Lab/PEAR.

AI.tldr: They observe a strong link between stage-wise entropy and response length in chain-of-thought reasoning and propose PEAR, a phase-entropy–aware reward that shortens thinking traces while preserving accuracy and robustness.
AI.motivation: Chain-of-thought outputs from large reasoning models are often unnecessarily long, increasing inference cost and hurting usability. Existing controls (e.g., explicit length targets, truncation) can harm accuracy. The authors seek a principled, model-intrinsic signal to control conciseness without degrading performance.
AI.method: Empirically analyze entropy across reasoning stages and find: higher entropy during the thinking phase (exploratory, longer traces) and lower entropy at the final answer (more deterministic). They design PEAR (Phase Entropy Aware Reward), which incorporates phase-dependent entropy into the RL reward: penalize excessive entropy in the thinking phase while allowing moderate entropy at the final answer. This guides the model to generate concise yet sufficiently flexible reasoning without explicit length constraints.
AI.result: Across four benchmarks and multiple model scales, PEAR consistently reduces response length while maintaining competitive accuracy. It further shows strong out-of-distribution robustness beyond the training distribution.
AI.conclusion: Stage-dependent entropy is an effective control knob for the conciseness–performance trade-off. PEAR enables adaptive length control of chain-of-thought reasoning without rigid targets or truncation and generalizes well across tasks and distributions.

title: Ready to Translate, Not to Represent? Bias and Performance Gaps in Multilingual LLMs Across Language Families and Domains
summary:
The rise of Large Language Models (LLMs) has redefined Machine Translation
(MT), enabling context-aware and fluent translations across hundreds of
languages and textual domains. Despite their remarkable capabilities, LLMs
often exhibit uneven performance across language families and specialized
domains. Moreover, recent evidence reveals that these models can encode and
amplify different biases present in their training data, posing serious
concerns for fairness, especially in low-resource languages. To address these
gaps, we introduce Translation Tangles, a unified framework and dataset for
evaluating the translation quality and fairness of open-source LLMs. Our
approach benchmarks 24 bidirectional language pairs across multiple domains
using different metrics. We further propose a hybrid bias detection pipeline
that integrates rule-based heuristics, semantic similarity filtering, and
LLM-based validation. We also introduce a high-quality, bias-annotated dataset
based on human evaluations of 1,439 translation-reference pairs. The code and
dataset are accessible on GitHub:
https://github.com/faiyazabdullah/TranslationTangles

AI.tldr: Presents Translation Tangles, a unified benchmark, pipeline, and bias-annotated dataset to assess both translation quality and fairness of open-source LLMs across 24 bidirectional language pairs and multiple domains.
AI.motivation: LLM-based MT shows uneven quality across languages/domains and can encode/amplify biases, raising fairness concerns—especially for low-resource languages. A consistent, fairness-aware evaluation framework is missing.
AI.method: Build a unified evaluation suite that benchmarks 24 bidirectional language pairs over multiple domains with varied quality metrics. Propose a hybrid bias-detection pipeline combining rule-based heuristics, semantic similarity filtering, and LLM-based validation. Create a human-evaluated, bias-annotated dataset of 1,439 translation–reference pairs; release code and data.
AI.result: Deliver a public framework, metrics coverage, and a high-quality bias-annotated dataset enabling assessment of translation quality and bias. Provide a practical bias-identification pipeline validated with human judgments; resources are released on GitHub.
AI.conclusion: Translation Tangles enables systematic, fairness-aware evaluation of open-source LLM translation, particularly benefiting analysis in low-resource settings and supporting future research on mitigating bias and improving cross-lingual performance.

title: A Large-scale Dataset for Robust Complex Anime Scene Text Detection
summary:
Current text detection datasets primarily target natural or document scenes,
where text typically appear in regular font and shapes, monotonous colors, and
orderly layouts. The text usually arranged along straight or curved lines.
However, these characteristics differ significantly from anime scenes, where
text is often diverse in style, irregularly arranged, and easily confused with
complex visual elements such as symbols and decorative patterns. Text in anime
scene also includes a large number of handwritten and stylized fonts. Motivated
by this gap, we introduce AnimeText, a large-scale dataset containing 735K
images and 4.2M annotated text blocks. It features hierarchical annotations and
hard negative samples tailored for anime scenarios. %Cross-dataset evaluations
using state-of-the-art methods demonstrate that models trained on AnimeText
achieve superior performance in anime text detection tasks compared to existing
datasets. To evaluate the robustness of AnimeText in complex anime scenes, we
conducted cross-dataset benchmarking using state-of-the-art text detection
methods. Experimental results demonstrate that models trained on AnimeText
outperform those trained on existing datasets in anime scene text detection
tasks. AnimeText on HuggingFace:
https://huggingface.co/datasets/deepghs/AnimeText

AI.tldr: AnimeText is a large-scale, anime-focused text detection dataset (735K images, 4.2M text blocks) with hierarchical annotations and hard negatives; models trained on it outperform those trained on general text datasets for anime scenes.
AI.motivation: Existing text detection datasets target natural/document scenes with regular fonts, colors, and layouts, which differ markedly from anime scenes that feature stylized, handwritten, irregularly arranged text easily confused with decorative elements. A domain-specific dataset is needed.
AI.method: Construct AnimeText with 735K images and 4.2M annotated text blocks, providing hierarchical annotations and hard negative samples tailored to anime. Assess robustness via cross-dataset benchmarking using state-of-the-art text detection methods.
AI.result: Cross-dataset evaluations show that models trained on AnimeText achieve superior performance for anime scene text detection compared to models trained on existing datasets.
AI.conclusion: AnimeText offers a robust benchmark and training resource for anime text detection, improving performance in complex anime scenes; it is released on HuggingFace to facilitate research and application.

title: AILoRA: Function-Aware Asymmetric Initialization for Low-Rank Adaptation of Large Language Models
summary:
Parameter-efficient finetuning (PEFT) aims to mitigate the substantial
computational and memory overhead involved in adapting large-scale pretrained
models to diverse downstream tasks. Among numerous PEFT strategies, Low-Rank
Adaptation (LoRA) has emerged as one of the most widely adopted approaches due
to its robust empirical performance and low implementation complexity. In
practical deployment, LoRA is typically applied to the $W^Q$ and $W^V$
projection matrices of self-attention modules, enabling an effective trade-off
between model performance and parameter efficiency. While LoRA has achieved
considerable empirical success, it still encounters challenges such as
suboptimal performance and slow convergence. To address these limitations, we
introduce \textbf{AILoRA}, a novel parameter-efficient method that incorporates
function-aware asymmetric low-rank priors. Our empirical analysis reveals that
the projection matrices $W^Q$ and $W^V$ in the self-attention mechanism exhibit
distinct parameter characteristics, stemming from their functional differences.
Specifically, $W^Q$ captures task-specific semantic space knowledge essential
for attention distributions computation, making its parameters highly sensitive
to downstream task variations. In contrast, $W^V$ encodes token-level feature
representations that tend to remain stable across tasks and layers. Leveraging
these insights, AILoRA performs a function-aware initialization by injecting
the principal components of $W^Q$ to retain task-adaptive capacity, and the
minor components of $W^V$ to preserve generalizable feature representations.
This asymmetric initialization strategy enables LoRA modules to better capture
the specialized roles of attention parameters, thereby enhancing both
finetuning performance and convergence efficiency.

AI.tldr: AILoRA is a LoRA-style PEFT variant that exploits the different roles of attention’s Q and V projections by using asymmetric, function-aware low‑rank priors, yielding better fine‑tuning performance and faster convergence.
AI.motivation: Standard LoRA, typically applied to W^Q and W^V, can be suboptimal and slow to converge because it treats both projections similarly despite their distinct functions. Empirically, W^Q is task-sensitive (drives attention distributions), while W^V encodes more stable token features. The paper aims to leverage this asymmetry to improve parameter efficiency and adaptation quality.
AI.method: Introduce AILoRA, which performs function-aware asymmetric initialization of LoRA adapters: inject principal components of W^Q to preserve task-adaptive capacity for queries, and inject minor components of W^V to maintain generalizable, stable feature representations for values. This yields different low-rank priors for Q vs. V within standard LoRA modules.
AI.result: Empirically, AILoRA enhances fine-tuning performance and accelerates convergence relative to conventional LoRA (no specific metrics provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Encoding the functional asymmetry between W^Q and W^V into low-rank priors enables LoRA modules to better capture their specialized roles, improving both effectiveness and efficiency of PEFT during fine-tuning.

title: Do LLMs Really Need 10+ Thoughts for "Find the Time 1000 Days Later"? Towards Structural Understanding of LLM Overthinking
summary:
Models employing long chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning have shown superior
performance on complex reasoning tasks. Yet, this capability introduces a
critical and often overlooked inefficiency -- overthinking -- models often
engage in unnecessarily extensive reasoning even for simple queries, incurring
significant computations without accuracy improvements. While prior work has
explored solutions to mitigate overthinking, a fundamental gap remains in our
understanding of its underlying causes. Most existing analyses are limited to
superficial, profiling-based observations, failing to delve into LLMs' inner
workings. This study introduces a systematic, fine-grained analyzer of LLMs'
thought process to bridge the gap, TRACE. We first benchmark the overthinking
issue, confirming that long-thinking models are five to twenty times slower on
simple tasks with no substantial gains. We then use TRACE to first decompose
the thought process into minimally complete sub-thoughts. Next, by inferring
discourse relationships among sub-thoughts, we construct granular thought
progression graphs and subsequently identify common thinking patterns for
topically similar queries. Our analysis reveals two major patterns for
open-weight thinking models -- Explorer and Late Landing. This finding provides
evidence that over-verification and over-exploration are the primary drivers of
overthinking in LLMs. Grounded in thought structures, we propose a
utility-based definition of overthinking, which moves beyond length-based
metrics. This revised definition offers a more insightful understanding of
LLMs' thought progression, as well as practical guidelines for principled
overthinking management.

AI.tldr: TRACE introduces a fine-grained analyzer for LLM chains-of-thought, showing long-CoT models often overthink (5–20× slower on simple tasks without accuracy gains) due to two dominant patterns—Explorer and Late Landing—driven by over-exploration and over-verification; it proposes a utility-based definition of overthinking that goes beyond length-based metrics and informs mitigation.
AI.motivation: Long chain-of-thought improves complex reasoning but wastes compute on simple queries; prior work largely profiles surface behavior without exposing internal reasoning structure, leaving causes of overthinking unclear. The authors seek a principled, structural understanding of why and how overthinking occurs.
AI.method: Benchmark overthinking on simple tasks; introduce TRACE to decompose chains into minimally complete sub-thoughts; infer discourse relations among sub-thoughts; build granular thought progression graphs; cluster similar queries to find common patterns; and formalize a utility-based notion of overthinking grounded in these thought structures.
AI.result: Confirm that long-thinking models are 5–20× slower on simple tasks with no accuracy gains; discover two dominant patterns in open-weight thinking models—Explorer and Late Landing—implicating over-exploration and over-verification as the main drivers of overthinking.
AI.conclusion: A utility-based, structure-aware view of thought progression is more informative than raw length for diagnosing and managing overthinking, and it yields practical guidance for principled mitigation in long-CoT LLMs.

title: SimCast: Enhancing Precipitation Nowcasting with Short-to-Long Term Knowledge Distillation
summary:
Precipitation nowcasting predicts future radar sequences based on current
observations, which is a highly challenging task driven by the inherent
complexity of the Earth system. Accurate nowcasting is of utmost importance for
addressing various societal needs, including disaster management, agriculture,
transportation, and energy optimization. As a complementary to existing
non-autoregressive nowcasting approaches, we investigate the impact of
prediction horizons on nowcasting models and propose SimCast, a novel training
pipeline featuring a short-to-long term knowledge distillation technique
coupled with a weighted MSE loss to prioritize heavy rainfall regions. Improved
nowcasting predictions can be obtained without introducing additional overhead
during inference. As SimCast generates deterministic predictions, we further
integrate it into a diffusion-based framework named CasCast, leveraging the
strengths from probabilistic models to overcome limitations such as blurriness
and distribution shift in deterministic outputs. Extensive experimental results
on three benchmark datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed
framework, achieving mean CSI scores of 0.452 on SEVIR, 0.474 on HKO-7, and
0.361 on MeteoNet, which outperforms existing approaches by a significant
margin.

AI.tldr: They introduce SimCast, a training pipeline for radar precipitation nowcasting that distills short-horizon knowledge into longer horizons and uses a weighted MSE to emphasize heavy rainfall; then extend it with a diffusion-based probabilistic wrapper (CasCast) to mitigate blur and distribution shift, achieving state-of-the-art CSI on SEVIR, HKO-7, and MeteoNet.
AI.motivation: Accurate precipitation nowcasting is crucial for disaster response, agriculture, transport, and energy. Existing non-autoregressive models struggle with longer prediction horizons and produce blurry, distribution-shifted deterministic forecasts, especially failing to capture heavy rainfall that matters most operationally.
AI.method: 1) SimCast: a short-to-long term knowledge distillation training pipeline that transfers predictive skill from short horizons to longer horizons; coupled with a weighted MSE loss to prioritize heavy-rain regions. It remains deterministic and adds no inference-time overhead. 2) CasCast: integrates SimCast within a diffusion-based (probabilistic) framework to reduce blurriness and handle distribution shift, producing sharper, calibrated forecasts.
AI.result: On three benchmarks, the framework attains mean CSI of 0.452 (SEVIR), 0.474 (HKO-7), and 0.361 (MeteoNet), outperforming prior methods by a significant margin.
AI.conclusion: Horizon-aware distillation plus heavy-rain weighting improves deterministic nowcasting without extra runtime, and augmenting with diffusion further mitigates blur/shift, delivering state-of-the-art precipitation nowcasting across multiple datasets.

title: LinguaSim: Interactive Multi-Vehicle Testing Scenario Generation via Natural Language Instruction Based on Large Language Models
summary:
The generation of testing and training scenarios for autonomous vehicles has
drawn significant attention. While Large Language Models (LLMs) have enabled
new scenario generation methods, current methods struggle to balance command
adherence accuracy with the realism of real-world driving environments. To
reduce scenario description complexity, these methods often compromise realism
by limiting scenarios to 2D, or open-loop simulations where background vehicles
follow predefined, non-interactive behaviors. We propose LinguaSim, an
LLM-based framework that converts natural language into realistic, interactive
3D scenarios, ensuring both dynamic vehicle interactions and faithful alignment
between the input descriptions and the generated scenarios. A feedback
calibration module further refines the generation precision, improving fidelity
to user intent. By bridging the gap between natural language and closed-loop,
interactive simulations, LinguaSim constrains adversarial vehicle behaviors
using both the scenario description and the autonomous driving model guiding
them. This framework facilitates the creation of high-fidelity scenarios that
enhance safety testing and training. Experiments show LinguaSim can generate
scenarios with varying criticality aligned with different natural language
descriptions (ACT: 0.072 s for dangerous vs. 3.532 s for safe descriptions;
comfortability: 0.654 vs. 0.764), and its refinement module effectively reduces
excessive aggressiveness in LinguaSim's initial outputs, lowering the crash
rate from 46.9% to 6.3% to better match user intentions.

AI.tldr: LinguaSim is an LLM-driven system that converts natural-language instructions into realistic, closed-loop, interactive 3D driving scenarios, with a feedback calibration module that improves adherence to user intent and reduces over-aggressive behaviors, yielding controllable scenario criticality and lower crash rates.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM-based scenario generators for autonomous vehicles often trade realism for simplicity, restricting to 2D or open-loop settings with non-interactive traffic, which undermines faithful command adherence and realistic safety testing. There is a need for natural-language-controllable, high-fidelity, interactive scenarios.
AI.method: Parse natural-language descriptions with an LLM to synthesize 3D, closed-loop simulations with dynamic interactions. Constrain adversarial vehicle behaviors using both the textual scenario specification and the autonomous driving model under test. Introduce a feedback calibration module that iteratively refines scenarios to better match user intent and mitigate excessive aggressiveness.
AI.result: Generated scenarios exhibit controllable criticality aligned with prompts (e.g., ACT: 0.072 s for dangerous vs. 3.532 s for safe; comfortability: 0.654 vs. 0.764).
