The refinement module substantially lowers crash rate from 46.9% to 6.3%, indicating improved fidelity to intended difficulty/safety levels.
AI.conclusion: By bridging natural language and closed-loop, interactive simulation, LinguaSim produces high-fidelity, intent-aligned scenarios that enhance AV safety testing and training. The feedback calibration improves precision and realism, enabling controllable scenario difficulty while avoiding overly aggressive behaviors.

title: CS3-Bench: Evaluating and Enhancing Speech-to-Speech LLMs for Mandarin-English Code-Switching
summary:
The advancement of multimodal large language models has accelerated the
development of speech-to-speech interaction systems. While natural monolingual
interaction has been achieved, we find existing models exhibit deficiencies in
language alignment. In our proposed Code-Switching Speech-to-Speech Benchmark
(CS3-Bench), experiments on 7 mainstream models demonstrate a relative
performance drop of up to 66% in knowledge-intensive question answering and
varying degrees of misunderstanding in open-ended conversations. Starting from
a model with severe performance deterioration, we propose both data
constructions and training approaches to improve the language alignment
capabilities, specifically employing Chain of Recognition (CoR) to enhance
understanding and Keyword Highlighting (KH) to guide generation. Our approach
improves the knowledge accuracy from 25.14% to 46.13%, with open-ended
understanding rate from 64.5% to 86.5%, and significantly reduces pronunciation
errors in the secondary language. CS3-Bench is available at
https://huggingface.co/datasets/VocalNet/CS3-Bench.

AI.tldr: They introduce a code-switching speech-to-speech benchmark (CS3-Bench) and training strategies—Chain of Recognition and Keyword Highlighting—to fix language-alignment failures in multimodal LLM S2S systems, yielding sizable gains in knowledge QA, open-ended understanding, and pronunciation.
AI.motivation: Despite progress in speech-to-speech interaction, current models struggle when input/output spans multiple languages (code-switching), leading to large drops in factual QA and misunderstandings in conversation. There is a need to quantify these failures and develop methods that explicitly align languages during understanding and generation.
AI.method: 1) Build CS3-Bench to evaluate code-switching S2S performance; test 7 mainstream models. 2) From a poorly performing base model, construct targeted training data and apply two techniques: Chain of Recognition (CoR) to explicitly parse/recognize multilingual content for better comprehension, and Keyword Highlighting (KH) to steer generation toward salient multilingual cues. 3) Train and evaluate on knowledge-intensive QA and open-ended dialogue; assess pronunciation errors in the secondary language.
AI.result: Baseline models show up to a 66% relative drop in knowledge-intensive QA under code-switching and varying misunderstanding in open-ended dialogue. With CoR+KH, knowledge accuracy rises from 25.14% to 46.13%, open-ended understanding from 64.5% to 86.5%, and pronunciation errors in the secondary language are notably reduced.
AI.conclusion: Code-switching remains a critical failure mode for S2S MLLMs. CS3-Bench exposes these gaps, and CoR+KH substantially improve alignment and downstream performance. The benchmark is released to spur broader evaluation and progress.

title: Latent Harmony: Synergistic Unified UHD Image Restoration via Latent Space Regularization and Controllable Refinement
summary:
Ultra-High Definition (UHD) image restoration faces a trade-off between
computational efficiency and high-frequency detail retention. While Variational
Autoencoders (VAEs) improve efficiency via latent-space processing, their
Gaussian constraint often discards degradation-specific high-frequency
information, hurting reconstruction fidelity. To overcome this, we propose
Latent Harmony, a two-stage framework that redefines VAEs for UHD restoration
by jointly regularizing the latent space and enforcing high-frequency-aware
reconstruction.In Stage One, we introduce LH-VAE, which enhances semantic
robustness through visual semantic constraints and progressive degradation
perturbations, while latent equivariance strengthens high-frequency
reconstruction.Stage Two jointly trains this refined VAE with a restoration
model using High-Frequency Low-Rank Adaptation (HF-LoRA): an encoder LoRA
guided by a fidelity-oriented high-frequency alignment loss to recover
authentic details, and a decoder LoRA driven by a perception-oriented loss to
synthesize realistic textures. Both LoRA modules are trained via alternating
optimization with selective gradient propagation to preserve the pretrained
latent structure.At inference, a tunable parameter {\alpha} enables flexible
fidelity-perception trade-offs.Experiments show Latent Harmony achieves
state-of-the-art performance across UHD and standard-resolution tasks,
effectively balancing efficiency, perceptual quality, and reconstruction
accuracy.

AI.tldr: Latent Harmony is a two-stage VAE-based UHD image restoration framework that preserves efficiency while recovering high-frequency details via latent regularization and high-frequency-aware LoRA adaptations, achieving SOTA accuracy–perception trade-offs with an inference-time knob.
AI.motivation: UHD restoration must balance computational efficiency and retention of high-frequency, degradation-specific details. Standard VAEs enable efficient latent-space processing but their Gaussian prior blurs or discards high-frequency cues, degrading fidelity. The paper seeks to redesign VAEs and training to keep those details without sacrificing speed.
AI.method: Stage 1: Train LH-VAE with visual semantic constraints, progressive degradation perturbations, and latent equivariance to make the latent space robust yet detail-preserving. Stage 2: Jointly train the refined VAE and a restoration model using High-Frequency LoRA (HF-LoRA): an encoder LoRA guided by a fidelity-oriented high-frequency alignment loss to recover authentic details, and a decoder LoRA guided by a perception-oriented loss to synthesize realistic textures. Use alternating optimization with selective gradient propagation to retain pretrained latent structure. At inference, a tunable parameter alpha trades off fidelity vs. perceptual quality.
AI.result: The approach delivers state-of-the-art performance on UHD and standard-resolution restoration benchmarks, balancing computational efficiency, perceptual quality, and reconstruction accuracy.
AI.conclusion: By jointly regularizing the latent space and enforcing high-frequency-aware reconstruction with HF-LoRA, Latent Harmony retools VAEs for UHD restoration, preserving pretrained structure and enabling a controllable fidelity–perception trade-off, yielding SOTA results across tasks.

title: Multi-Condition Conformal Selection
summary:
Selecting high-quality candidates from large-scale datasets is critically
important in resource-constrained applications such as drug discovery,
precision medicine, and the alignment of large language models. While conformal
selection methods offer a rigorous solution with False Discovery Rate (FDR)
control, their applicability is confined to single-threshold scenarios (i.e., y
> c) and overlooks practical needs for multi-condition selection, such as
conjunctive or disjunctive conditions. In this work, we propose the
Multi-Condition Conformal Selection (MCCS) algorithm, which extends conformal
selection to scenarios with multiple conditions. In particular, we introduce a
novel nonconformity score with regional monotonicity for conjunctive conditions
and a global Benjamini-Hochberg (BH) procedure for disjunctive conditions,
thereby establishing finite-sample FDR control with theoretical guarantees. The
integration of these components enables the proposed method to achieve rigorous
FDR-controlled selection in various multi-condition environments. Extensive
experiments validate the superiority of MCCS over baselines, its
generalizability across diverse condition combinations, different real-world
modalities, and multi-task scalability.

AI.tldr: They introduce MCCS, a conformal selection framework that provides finite-sample FDR control for multi-condition (AND/OR) selection by designing a new monotone nonconformity score for conjunctions and a global BH procedure for disjunctions, showing superior empirical performance across tasks and modalities.
AI.motivation: Practical selection problems (drug discovery, precision medicine, LLM alignment) often require meeting multiple conditions under tight resource constraints. Existing conformal selection methods control FDR only for single-threshold rules, failing to address multi-condition (conjunctive/disjunctive) needs.
AI.method: MCCS extends conformal selection to multiple conditions. For conjunctive rules, it proposes a novel nonconformity score with regional monotonicity to enable valid calibration. For disjunctive rules, it applies a global Benjamini–Hochberg procedure across conditions. Together these yield finite-sample FDR control. The approach is evaluated across diverse condition combinations, modalities, and multi-task settings.
AI.result: Theoretically, MCCS guarantees finite-sample FDR control for multi-condition selection. Empirically, it outperforms baselines, generalizes across varied condition structures and data modalities, and scales to multi-task scenarios.
AI.conclusion: MCCS broadens conformal selection to realistic multi-condition environments, maintaining rigorous FDR guarantees and demonstrating superior performance and scalability in experiments.

title: Contrastive Weak-to-strong Generalization
summary:
Weak-to-strong generalization provides a promising paradigm for scaling large
language models (LLMs) by training stronger models on samples from aligned
weaker ones, without requiring human feedback or explicit reward modeling.
However, its robustness and generalization are hindered by the noise and biases
in weak-model outputs, which limit its applicability in practice. To address
this challenge, we leverage implicit rewards, which approximate explicit
rewards through log-likelihood ratios, and reveal their structural equivalence
with Contrastive Decoding (CD), a decoding strategy shown to reduce noise in
LLM generation. Building on this connection, we propose Contrastive
Weak-to-Strong Generalization (ConG), a framework that employs contrastive
decoding between pre- and post-alignment weak models to generate higher-quality
samples. This approach enables more reliable capability transfer, denoising,
and improved robustness, substantially mitigating the limitations of
traditional weak-to-strong methods. Empirical results across different model
families confirm consistent improvements, demonstrating the generality and
effectiveness of ConG. Taken together, our findings highlight the potential of
ConG to advance weak-to-strong generalization and provide a promising pathway
toward AGI.

AI.tldr: They introduce Contrastive Weak-to-Strong Generalization (ConG), which uses implicit rewards tied to contrastive decoding to denoise weak-model outputs, enabling more robust weak-to-strong training and showing consistent gains across model families.
AI.motivation: Weak-to-strong generalization can scale LLMs without human feedback or explicit reward models, but it is fragile because weak-model outputs are noisy and biased, which harms robustness and generalization.
AI.method: They connect implicit rewards (log-likelihood ratio proxies for explicit rewards) to Contrastive Decoding (CD), proving structural equivalence. Leveraging this, they propose ConG: generate higher-quality training samples via contrastive decoding between pre- and post-alignment weak models, then train stronger models on these denoised samples to transfer capability more reliably.
AI.result: Across multiple model families, ConG yields consistent improvements in robustness and generalization over traditional weak-to-strong methods, indicating better capability transfer and reduced noise sensitivity.
AI.conclusion: ConG mitigates the core limitations of weak-to-strong generalization by using contrastive, reward-free denoising mechanisms; its empirical generality suggests a practical path to scaling aligned models and a potential step toward AGI.

title: The impact of abstract and object tags on image privacy classification
comment: This work has been submitted to the ICASSP 2026
summary:
Object tags denote concrete entities and are central to many computer vision
tasks, whereas abstract tags capture higher-level information, which is
relevant for tasks that require a contextual, potentially subjective scene
understanding. Object and abstract tags extracted from images also facilitate
interpretability. In this paper, we explore which type of tags is more suitable
for the context-dependent and inherently subjective task of image privacy.
While object tags are generally used for privacy classification, we show that
abstract tags are more effective when the tag budget is limited. Conversely,
when a larger number of tags per image is available, object-related information
is as useful. We believe that these findings will guide future research in
developing more accurate image privacy classifiers, informed by the role of tag
types and quantity.

AI.tldr: Compares object vs. abstract (high-level) tags for image privacy classification; abstract tags win when only a few tags are available, while object tags catch up when many tags are available.
AI.motivation: Image privacy decisions are context-dependent and subjective; common object tags may miss higher-level context needed for privacy judgments. Understanding whether abstract tags provide better signals (and under what constraints) can improve interpretable, accurate privacy classifiers.
AI.method: Empirical comparison of tag types for image privacy classification under varying tag-budget constraints. Evaluate performance using object tags versus abstract, high-level semantic tags, analyzing how the number of available tags per image influences accuracy.
AI.result: When the tag budget is small, abstract tags are more effective for privacy prediction. With larger tag budgets, object-related information becomes as useful as abstract tags.
AI.conclusion: Tag type and quantity both matter for image privacy classification. Use abstract tags when only a few tags are available; with more tags, object tags suffice or can match performance. These insights should guide building better privacy classifiers and inform adaptive tag selection strategies.

title: AutoQual: An LLM Agent for Automated Discovery of Interpretable Features for Review Quality Assessment
summary:
Ranking online reviews by their intrinsic quality is a critical task for
e-commerce platforms and information services, impacting user experience and
business outcomes. However, quality is a domain-dependent and dynamic concept,
making its assessment a formidable challenge. Traditional methods relying on
hand-crafted features are unscalable across domains and fail to adapt to
evolving content patterns, while modern deep learning approaches often produce
black-box models that lack interpretability and may prioritize semantics over
quality. To address these challenges, we propose AutoQual, an LLM-based agent
framework that automates the discovery of interpretable features. While
demonstrated on review quality assessment, AutoQual is designed as a general
framework for transforming tacit knowledge embedded in data into explicit,
computable features. It mimics a human research process, iteratively generating
feature hypotheses through reflection, operationalizing them via autonomous
tool implementation, and accumulating experience in a persistent memory. We
deploy our method on a large-scale online platform with a billion-level user
base. Large-scale A/B testing confirms its effectiveness, increasing average
reviews viewed per user by 0.79% and the conversion rate of review readers by
0.27%.

AI.tldr: AutoQual is an LLM-driven agent that discovers and operationalizes interpretable features to rank online reviews by quality, yielding measurable engagement and conversion gains at billion-user scale.
AI.motivation: Assessing review quality is hard because “quality” varies by domain and shifts over time. Hand-crafted features don’t scale or adapt, and deep models are black boxes that may optimize semantics rather than quality, limiting trust and controllability.
AI.method: An iterative LLM-agent framework that mimics a human research workflow: (1) reflect to propose feature hypotheses, (2) autonomously implement tools to operationalize those features into computable signals, and (3) store and reuse experience in persistent memory. Applied to review-quality ranking but positioned as a general method to convert tacit knowledge in data into explicit, interpretable features.
AI.result: Deployed on a large-scale platform (billion-level users). Online A/B tests show +0.79% average reviews viewed per user and +0.27% conversion rate among review readers.
AI.conclusion: AutoQual delivers interpretable, adaptive feature discovery for quality ranking with real-world impact. It offers a scalable, transparent alternative to purely black-box models and is likely generalizable to other domains where quality is dynamic and hard to codify.

title: Standard-to-Dialect Transfer Trends Differ across Text and Speech: A Case Study on Intent and Topic Classification in German Dialects
summary:
Research on cross-dialectal transfer from a standard to a non-standard
dialect variety has typically focused on text data. However, dialects are
primarily spoken, and non-standard spellings are known to cause issues in text
processing. We compare standard-to-dialect transfer in three settings: text
models, speech models, and cascaded systems where speech first gets
automatically transcribed and then further processed by a text model. In our
experiments, we focus on German and multiple German dialects in the context of
written and spoken intent and topic classification. To that end, we release the
first dialectal audio intent classification dataset. We find that the
speech-only setup provides the best results on the dialect data while the
text-only setup works best on the standard data. While the cascaded systems lag
behind the text-only models for German, they perform relatively well on the
dialectal data if the transcription system generates normalized, standard-like
output.

AI.tldr: They compare text, speech, and ASR→text cascades for transferring from Standard German to German dialects on intent/topic classification, releasing the first dialectal audio intent dataset. Speech-only models work best on dialects; text-only works best on standard German; cascades help on dialects when ASR normalizes to standard-like text.
AI.motivation: Prior work on cross-dialect transfer has focused on text, but dialects are mainly spoken and non-standard spellings hurt text processing. There is a need to understand which modality (text vs. speech vs. cascaded) best handles dialectal variation and to provide appropriate datasets.
AI.method: Evaluate three setups—(1) text-only models, (2) speech-only models, (3) cascaded ASR followed by text models—on written and spoken intent/topic classification. The study targets Standard German and multiple German dialects, and introduces a new dialectal audio intent classification dataset. Performance is compared across modalities and varieties.
AI.result:
- Speech-only models achieve the best performance on dialectal data.
- Text-only models perform best on standard German data.
- Cascaded ASR→text systems underperform text-only on standard German but perform relatively well on dialectal data when ASR outputs normalized, standard-like transcripts.
AI.conclusion: For dialectal applications, directly modeling speech is most effective; for standard language, text modeling suffices. Cascaded approaches can be viable for dialects if the ASR normalizes output, highlighting the importance of ASR normalization. The work contributes a new dialectal audio intent dataset and empirical guidance on modality choice.

title: Is Architectural Complexity Always the Answer? A Case Study on SwinIR vs. an Efficient CNN
summary:
The simultaneous restoration of high-frequency details and suppression of
severe noise in low-light imagery presents a significant and persistent
challenge in computer vision. While large-scale Transformer models like SwinIR
have set the state of the art in performance, their high computational cost can
be a barrier for practical applications. This paper investigates the critical
trade-off between performance and efficiency by comparing the state-of-the-art
SwinIR model against a standard, lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)
on this challenging task. Our experimental results reveal a nuanced but
important finding. While the Transformer-based SwinIR model achieves a higher
peak performance, with a Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) of 39.03 dB, the
lightweight CNN delivers a surprisingly competitive PSNR of 37.4 dB. Crucially,
the CNN reached this performance after converging in only 10 epochs of
training, whereas the more complex SwinIR model required 132 epochs. This
efficiency is further underscored by the model's size; the CNN is over 55 times
smaller than SwinIR. This work demonstrates that a standard CNN can provide a
near state-of-the-art result with significantly lower computational overhead,
presenting a compelling case for its use in real-world scenarios where resource
constraints are a primary concern.

AI.tldr: Empirical study shows a lightweight CNN attains near–state-of-the-art low-light restoration (PSNR 37.4 dB) while being >55× smaller and converging far faster (10 vs 132 epochs) than SwinIR (39.03 dB), highlighting a strong efficiency–performance trade-off.
AI.motivation: Low-light image restoration must simultaneously recover high-frequency details and suppress heavy noise. While Transformer models like SwinIR lead in accuracy, their computational cost limits practical deployment. The paper seeks to quantify the trade-off between accuracy and efficiency for real-world, resource-constrained scenarios.
AI.method: Head-to-head comparison of a standard lightweight CNN against the Transformer-based SwinIR on low-light restoration. Metrics include PSNR, training epochs to convergence, and model size; convergence speed and model compactness are emphasized to assess practicality.
AI.result: SwinIR achieves higher peak PSNR (39.03 dB) but requires 132 training epochs. The lightweight CNN reaches 37.4 dB after only 10 epochs and is over 55× smaller, indicating substantial savings in training time and model footprint with modest accuracy loss.
AI.conclusion: A conventional lightweight CNN offers competitive image restoration performance at a fraction of the computational and memory cost, making it attractive for deployment under resource constraints. The paper underscores that near–state-of-the-art quality does not strictly require large Transformer models when efficiency is paramount.

title: From Ethical Declarations to Provable Independence: An Ontology-Driven Optimal-Transport Framework for Certifiably Fair AI Systems
summary:
This paper presents a framework for provably fair AI that overcomes the
limits of current bias mitigation methods by systematically removing all
sensitive information and its proxies. Using ontology engineering in OWL 2 QL,
it formally defines sensitive attributes and infers their proxies through
logical reasoning, constructing a sigma algebra G that captures the full
structure of biased patterns. Fair representations are then obtained via
Delbaen Majumdar optimal transport, which generates variables independent of G
while minimizing L2 distance to preserve accuracy. This guarantees true
independence rather than mere decorrelation. By modeling bias as dependence
between sigma algebras, compiling ontological knowledge into measurable
structures, and using optimal transport as the unique fair transformation, the
approach ensures complete fairness in tasks like loan approval, where proxies
such as ZIP code reveal race. The result is a certifiable and mathematically
grounded method for trustworthy AI.

AI.tldr: They use ontology engineering to formally define sensitive attributes and all their proxies, compile this knowledge into a sigma-algebra G, and then apply an optimal-transport mapping (Delbaen–Majumdar) that yields features independent of G while minimally distorting the data (L2), aiming for provable fairness via true independence rather than mere decorrelation.
AI.motivation: Conventional bias-mitigation methods often only reduce correlation with labeled sensitive attributes and fail to remove information leaked through proxies (e.g., ZIP code for race). The authors seek a mathematically certifiable approach that eliminates all sensitive information and its proxies, delivering fairness guarantees stronger than correlation-based criteria.
AI.method: 1) Build an OWL 2 QL ontology to formally declare sensitive attributes and infer their proxies via logical reasoning. 2) Translate this knowledge into a measurable structure: a sigma-algebra G representing all biased patterns. 3) Define bias as statistical dependence between sigma-algebras. 4) Use Delbaen–Majumdar optimal transport to transform features into variables independent of G while minimizing L2 distance to preserve task accuracy, claiming uniqueness of this fair transformation.
AI.result: The pipeline produces “fair representations” provably independent of the sensitive/proxy sigma-algebra G, thereby preventing leakage (e.g., ZIP code revealing race), with minimal distortion to the original data. The approach purportedly supports certifiable guarantees and remains accurate due to the L2-optimality of the transport.
AI.conclusion: By combining ontology-driven proxy discovery with a measurable-theoretic view of bias and an optimal-transport transformation, the method claims complete fairness (independence from G) and provides a certifiable, mathematically grounded procedure for trustworthy AI in applications like credit scoring.

title: Metric Calculating Benchmark: Code-Verifiable Complicate Instruction Following Benchmark for Large Language Models
summary:
Recent frontier-level LLMs have saturated many previously difficult
benchmarks, leaving little room for further differentiation. This progress
highlights the need for challenging benchmarks that provide objective
verification. In this paper, we introduce MCBench, a benchmark designed to
evaluate whether LLMs can execute string-matching NLP metrics by strictly
following step-by-step instructions. Unlike prior benchmarks that depend on
subjective judgments or general reasoning, MCBench offers an objective,
deterministic and codeverifiable evaluation. This setup allows us to
systematically test whether LLMs can maintain accurate step-by-step execution,
including instruction adherence, numerical computation, and long-range
consistency in handling intermediate results. To ensure objective evaluation of
these abilities, we provide a parallel reference code that can evaluate the
accuracy of LLM output. We provide three evaluative metrics and three benchmark
variants designed to measure the detailed instruction understanding capability
of LLMs. Our analyses show that MCBench serves as an effective and objective
tool for evaluating the capabilities of cutting-edge LLMs.

AI.tldr: MCBench is a deterministic, code-verifiable benchmark that tests whether LLMs can precisely follow step-by-step instructions to execute string-matching NLP metrics, revealing differences that saturated benchmarks miss.
AI.motivation: Frontier LLMs have maxed out many existing benchmarks, which often rely on subjective judgments or broad reasoning. The field needs harder, objective, and reproducible tests that specifically assess instruction adherence, exact computation, and consistency over multi-step procedures.
AI.method: Introduce MCBench: tasks that require models to compute string-matching NLP metrics strictly via step-by-step instructions. Provide parallel reference code for exact, deterministic verification. Include three evaluative metrics and three benchmark variants targeting instruction understanding, numerical correctness, and long-range consistency using intermediate results.
AI.result: Systematic evaluations indicate that MCBench objectively distinguishes LLM performance on instruction following and step-by-step execution, with code-based scoring ensuring reliable accuracy checks.
AI.conclusion: MCBench is an effective, objective tool to evaluate frontier LLMs’ procedural execution skills—especially instruction adherence, numerical computation, and consistent handling of intermediate results—addressing gaps left by saturated benchmarks.

title: GraphEnet: Event-driven Human Pose Estimation with a Graph Neural Network
summary:
Human Pose Estimation is a crucial module in human-machine interaction
applications and, especially since the rise in deep learning technology, robust
methods are available to consumers using RGB cameras and commercial GPUs. On
the other hand, event-based cameras have gained popularity in the vision
research community for their low latency and low energy advantages that make
them ideal for applications where those resources are constrained like portable
electronics and mobile robots. In this work we propose a Graph Neural Network,
GraphEnet, that leverages the sparse nature of event camera output, with an
intermediate line based event representation, to estimate 2D Human Pose of a
single person at a high frequency. The architecture incorporates a novel offset
vector learning paradigm with confidence based pooling to estimate the human
pose. This is the first work that applies Graph Neural Networks to event data
for Human Pose Estimation. The code is open-source at
https://github.com/event-driven-robotics/GraphEnet-NeVi-ICCV2025.

AI.tldr: GraphEnet is a Graph Neural Network that operates on a sparse, line-based event representation from event cameras to estimate single-person 2D human pose at high frequency, introducing offset-vector learning with confidence-based pooling; it is claimed to be the first GNN-based HPE on event data and the code is open-source.
AI.motivation: Conventional RGB-based pose estimators require substantial compute and have latency/energy costs unsuitable for constrained platforms. Event cameras provide low latency and low power, but their sparse, asynchronous output needs architectures that can exploit this structure to achieve fast, accurate pose estimation.
AI.method: Convert event streams into an intermediate line-based event representation and build a graph over these structures. Use a Graph Neural Network (GraphEnet) with a novel offset-vector learning paradigm and confidence-based pooling to infer keypoint locations for single-person 2D pose at high frequency.
AI.result: Demonstrates high-frequency, single-person 2D pose estimation from event data; introduces the first application of GNNs to event-based human pose estimation. Quantitative metrics are not provided in the abstract, but open-source code is available.
AI.conclusion: Event-driven GNNs can effectively leverage the sparsity of event cameras for low-latency, low-energy human pose estimation, suggesting a viable path for HPE on portable electronics and mobile robots; the released code enables reproduction and further research.

title: Can Risk-taking AI-Assistants suitably represent entities
summary:
Responsible AI demands systems whose behavioral tendencies can be effectively
measured, audited, and adjusted to prevent inadvertently nudging users toward
risky decisions or embedding hidden biases in risk aversion. As language models
(LMs) are increasingly incorporated into AI-driven decision support systems,
understanding their risk behaviors is crucial for their responsible deployment.
This study investigates the manipulability of risk aversion (MoRA) in LMs,
examining their ability to replicate human risk preferences across diverse
economic scenarios, with a focus on gender-specific attitudes, uncertainty,
role-based decision-making, and the manipulability of risk aversion. The
results indicate that while LMs such as DeepSeek Reasoner and
Gemini-2.0-flash-lite exhibit some alignment with human behaviors, notable
discrepancies highlight the need to refine bio-centric measures of
manipulability. These findings suggest directions for refining AI design to
better align human and AI risk preferences and enhance ethical decision-making.
The study calls for further advancements in model design to ensure that AI
systems more accurately replicate human risk preferences, thereby improving
their effectiveness in risk management contexts. This approach could enhance
the applicability of AI assistants in managing risk.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how manipulable risk aversion is in language models and how closely their risk-taking mirrors human preferences across economic scenarios, finding partial alignment but notable gaps, and calling for better measurement and model design to support ethical, risk-aware AI.
AI.motivation: As LMs are used in decision-support, unchecked risk behaviors can nudge users toward unsafe choices or encode biased risk aversion. The authors aim to quantify and adjust LM risk tendencies so AI systems can responsibly align with human risk preferences and avoid hidden biases.
AI.method: Behavioral evaluation of LMs on economic decision scenarios probing risk preferences, with dimensions including gender-specific attitudes, uncertainty, role-based decision-making, and explicit manipulability of risk aversion; comparison includes models like DeepSeek Reasoner and Gemini-2.0-flash-lite, assessing alignment to human data and divergences.
AI.result: LMs show some human-like risk behavior but with meaningful discrepancies across scenarios. DeepSeek Reasoner and Gemini-2.0-flash-lite partially align with human patterns, yet inconsistencies reveal limitations in current bio-centric manipulability measures and model behavior.
AI.conclusion: Better measurement frameworks and model design are needed to more faithfully reproduce human risk preferences, thereby improving ethical decision-making and the utility of AI assistants in risk management contexts.

title: ACE: Attribution-Controlled Knowledge Editing for Multi-hop Factual Recall
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) require efficient knowledge editing (KE) to
update factual information, yet existing methods exhibit significant
performance decay in multi-hop factual recall. This failure is particularly
acute when edits involve intermediate implicit subjects within reasoning
chains. Through causal analysis, we reveal that this limitation stems from an
oversight of how chained knowledge is dynamically represented and utilized at
the neuron level. We discover that during multi hop reasoning, implicit
subjects function as query neurons, which sequentially activate corresponding
value neurons across transformer layers to accumulate information toward the
final answer, a dynamic prior KE work has overlooked. Guided by this insight,
we propose ACE: Attribution-Controlled Knowledge Editing for Multi-hop Factual
Recall, a framework that leverages neuron-level attribution to identify and
edit these critical query-value (Q-V) pathways. ACE provides a mechanistically
grounded solution for multi-hop KE, empirically outperforming state-of-the-art
methods by 9.44% on GPT-J and 37.46% on Qwen3-8B. Our analysis further reveals
more fine-grained activation patterns in Qwen3 and demonstrates that the
semantic interpretability of value neurons is orchestrated by query-driven
accumulation. These findings establish a new pathway for advancing KE
capabilities based on the principled understanding of internal reasoning
mechanisms.

AI.tldr: ACE identifies and edits query–value neuron pathways that carry chained facts during multi-hop reasoning, leading to significantly better knowledge edits in LLMs.
AI.motivation: Existing knowledge editing methods degrade on multi-hop factual recall, especially when edits involve implicit intermediate subjects. This suggests current approaches overlook how chained knowledge is dynamically represented and used within networks.
AI.method: Using causal/attribution analysis, the authors show implicit subjects act as query neurons that sequentially activate value neurons across layers to accumulate information. They introduce ACE (Attribution-Controlled Editing), which leverages neuron-level attribution to localize and modify these critical query–value pathways to update facts without harming broader behavior.
AI.result: ACE outperforms state-of-the-art KE by 9.44% on GPT-J and 37.46% on Qwen3-8B for multi-hop recall. Analysis finds finer-grained activation patterns in Qwen3 and shows value-neuron semantics are organized by query-driven accumulation.
AI.conclusion: Mechanistically targeting Q–V pathways provides a principled route to reliable multi-hop knowledge editing in LLMs, improving recall and interpretability while highlighting the role of implicit-subject query neurons in reasoning chains.

title: CIR-CoT: Towards Interpretable Composed Image Retrieval via End-to-End Chain-of-Thought Reasoning
summary:
Composed Image Retrieval (CIR), which aims to find a target image from a
reference image and a modification text, presents the core challenge of
performing unified reasoning across visual and semantic modalities. While
current approaches based on Vision-Language Models (VLMs, e.g., CLIP) and more
recent Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs, e.g., Qwen-VL) have shown
progress, they predominantly function as ``black boxes." This inherent opacity
not only prevents users from understanding the retrieval rationale but also
restricts the models' ability to follow complex, fine-grained instructions. To
overcome these limitations, we introduce CIR-CoT, the first end-to-end
retrieval-oriented MLLM designed to integrate explicit Chain-of-Thought (CoT)
reasoning. By compelling the model to first generate an interpretable reasoning
chain, CIR-CoT enhances its ability to capture crucial cross-modal
interactions, leading to more accurate retrieval while making its decision
process transparent. Since existing datasets like FashionIQ and CIRR lack the
necessary reasoning data, a key contribution of our work is the creation of
structured CoT annotations using a three-stage process involving a caption,
reasoning, and conclusion. Our model is then fine-tuned to produce this
structured output before encoding its final retrieval intent into a dedicated
embedding. Comprehensive experiments show that CIR-CoT achieves highly
competitive performance on in-domain datasets (FashionIQ, CIRR) and
demonstrates remarkable generalization on the out-of-domain CIRCO dataset,
establishing a new path toward more effective and trustworthy retrieval
systems.

AI.tldr: They propose CIR-CoT, an end-to-end retrieval-oriented multimodal LLM that performs explicit chain-of-thought reasoning (caption → reasoning → conclusion) before encoding a retrieval embedding, yielding more accurate and interpretable composed image retrieval. They also create structured CoT annotations to train the model and show competitive in-domain and strong out-of-domain results.
AI.motivation: Composed Image Retrieval requires unified reasoning across visual and textual modalities, but existing VLM/MLLM methods act as black boxes—hindering interpretability and limiting adherence to complex, fine-grained instructions.
AI.method: Introduce CIR-CoT, an MLLM that is prompted/fine-tuned to produce a structured CoT (caption, reasoning, conclusion) for a given reference image and modification text; the final conclusion is encoded into a dedicated embedding for retrieval. They construct new structured CoT annotations for datasets (e.g., FashionIQ, CIRR) and fine-tune the model end-to-end to generate CoT and retrieve.
AI.result: CIR-CoT attains highly competitive performance on in-domain datasets (FashionIQ, CIRR) and exhibits strong generalization on the out-of-domain CIRCO benchmark, while providing transparent reasoning about retrieval decisions.
AI.conclusion: Embedding explicit CoT into retrieval-oriented MLLMs improves both retrieval accuracy and interpretability, suggesting a path to more effective and trustworthy CIR systems.

title: Prepared mind, fast response: A temporal decoupling framework for adaptive knowledge orchestration in open-domain dialogue
summary:
The latency-quality tradeoff is a fundamental constraint in open-domain
dialogue AI systems, since comprehensive knowledge access necessitates
prohibitive response delays. Contemporary approaches offer two inadequate
solutions: lightweight instruct models achieve sub-second latency but lack
reasoning depth, while tool-augmented ReAct agents enhance factuality through
external knowledge at the cost of synchronous execution that blocks interaction
during re- trieval processes. PMFR is thus proposed, with a tempo- ral
decoupling framework that fundamentally resolves the contradiction through
asynchronous knowledge orchestra- tion. PMFR employs three coordinated
components: (1) a Knowledge Adequacy Evaluator for real-time sufficiency
assessment, (2) a Lightweight Response Generator for imme- diate user
interaction, and (3) an Asynchronous Knowledge Refinement Agent for background
knowledge enhancement. This architecture maintains continuous conversational
flow while progressively enriching knowledge coverage through intelligent
triggering mechanisms. Evaluation results on Top- iOCQA demonstrate PMFR
outperforms brute-force scaling: PMFR achieves 95.3% latency reduction (23.38s
-> 1.09s) while preserving response quality comparable to heavyweight
synchronous baselines (GEval-C: 0.613 vs. 0.620).

AI.tldr: PMFR is an asynchronous, temporally decoupled dialogue framework that preserves response quality while cutting latency by ~95% by answering immediately with a lightweight model and refining knowledge in the background.
AI.motivation: Open-domain dialogue systems face a latency–quality tradeoff: fast lightweight models lack reasoning/factuality, while tool-augmented ReAct-style agents improve accuracy but incur blocking retrieval delays that harm user experience.
AI.method: Introduce PMFR, a temporal decoupling framework with three coordinated components: (1) a Knowledge Adequacy Evaluator to judge if current knowledge suffices, (2) a Lightweight Response Generator for immediate replies, and (3) an Asynchronous Knowledge Refinement Agent that performs background retrieval/updates. Intelligent triggers orchestrate when background knowledge is fetched and integrated without blocking the user interaction.
AI.result: On the TopiOCQA benchmark, PMFR reduces average latency from 23.38s to 1.09s (95.3% reduction) while maintaining nearly equal response quality compared to heavyweight synchronous baselines (GEval-C 0.613 vs 0.620).
AI.conclusion: Asynchronous knowledge orchestration via temporal decoupling can break the latency–quality tradeoff in open-domain dialogue, enabling smooth conversational flow with competitive quality relative to synchronous tool-augmented systems.

title: Towards Human-Like Grading: A Unified LLM-Enhanced Framework for Subjective Question Evaluation
summary:
Automatic grading of subjective questions remains a significant challenge in
examination assessment due to the diversity in question formats and the
open-ended nature of student responses. Existing works primarily focus on a
specific type of subjective question and lack the generality to support
comprehensive exams that contain diverse question types. In this paper, we
propose a unified Large Language Model (LLM)-enhanced auto-grading framework
that provides human-like evaluation for all types of subjective questions
across various domains. Our framework integrates four complementary modules to
holistically evaluate student answers. In addition to a basic text matching
module that provides a foundational assessment of content similarity, we
leverage the powerful reasoning and generative capabilities of LLMs to: (1)
compare key knowledge points extracted from both student and reference answers,
(2) generate a pseudo-question from the student answer to assess its relevance
to the original question, and (3) simulate human evaluation by identifying
content-related and non-content strengths and weaknesses. Extensive experiments
on both general-purpose and domain-specific datasets show that our framework
consistently outperforms traditional and LLM-based baselines across multiple
grading metrics. Moreover, the proposed system has been successfully deployed
in real-world training and certification exams at a major e-commerce
enterprise.

AI.tldr: They introduce a unified LLM-enhanced auto-grading system for diverse subjective questions that combines text matching, key-point comparison, pseudo-question generation, and human-like critique, outperforming baselines and deployed in production.
AI.motivation: Subjective question grading is hard because responses are open-ended and exams include many question types; prior methods target narrow formats and don’t generalize or mimic nuanced human evaluation.
AI.method: A four-module framework: (1) traditional text matching for baseline similarity; (2) LLM-extracted key knowledge points from reference and student answers for comparison; (3) LLM-generated pseudo-question from the student answer to test its relevance to the original question; (4) LLM-simulated human evaluation highlighting content and non-content strengths/weaknesses; combined for holistic scoring across domains.
AI.result: Across general-purpose and domain-specific datasets, the approach consistently beats traditional and LLM-only baselines on multiple grading metrics; it has been deployed in real training/certification exams at a major e-commerce company.
AI.conclusion: A general, human-like, and practically viable auto-grading framework for subjective questions that scales across domains and question types, demonstrating strong empirical performance and real-world readiness.

title: RayFusion: Ray Fusion Enhanced Collaborative Visual Perception
summary:
Collaborative visual perception methods have gained widespread attention in
the autonomous driving community in recent years due to their ability to
address sensor limitation problems. However, the absence of explicit depth
information often makes it difficult for camera-based perception systems, e.g.,
3D object detection, to generate accurate predictions. To alleviate the
ambiguity in depth estimation, we propose RayFusion, a ray-based fusion method
for collaborative visual perception. Using ray occupancy information from
collaborators, RayFusion reduces redundancy and false positive predictions
along camera rays, enhancing the detection performance of purely camera-based
collaborative perception systems. Comprehensive experiments show that our
method consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art models, substantially
advancing the performance of collaborative visual perception. The code is
available at https://github.com/wangsh0111/RayFusion.

AI.tldr: RayFusion is a ray-based multi-agent fusion method that injects collaborators’ ray occupancy cues into camera-only 3D detection to resolve depth ambiguity and suppress false positives, achieving state-of-the-art performance in collaborative visual perception.
AI.motivation: Camera-only 3D perception suffers from missing explicit depth, causing ambiguity and false positives. Collaborative perception can compensate for single-agent limitations, but needs an effective way to exploit partners’ information to disambiguate depth along camera rays.
AI.method: Introduce RayFusion, a ray-centric fusion scheme that aggregates collaborators’ ray occupancy information and projects it along each camera ray to prune redundant hypotheses and reduce false positives, thereby refining depth reasoning for camera-based 3D object detection in multi-agent settings.
AI.result: Across comprehensive experiments, RayFusion consistently surpasses prior state-of-the-art collaborative perception models and improves detection accuracy for purely camera-based systems.
AI.conclusion: Using collaborator-informed ray occupancy to constrain predictions along camera rays effectively mitigates depth ambiguity, advancing the performance frontier of camera-only collaborative visual perception. Open-source code is provided at the given repository.

title: R-Horizon: How Far Can Your Large Reasoning Model Really Go in Breadth and Depth?
summary:
Recent trends in test-time scaling for reasoning models (e.g., OpenAI o1,
DeepSeek-R1) have led to remarkable improvements through long Chain-of-Thought
(CoT). However, existing benchmarks mainly focus on immediate, single-horizon
tasks, failing to adequately evaluate models' ability to understand and respond
to complex, long-horizon scenarios. To address this incomplete evaluation of
Large Reasoning Models (LRMs), we propose R-HORIZON, a method designed to
stimulate long-horizon reasoning behaviors in LRMs through query composition.
Based on R-HORIZON, we construct a long-horizon reasoning benchmark, comprising
complex multi-step reasoning tasks with interdependent problems that span long
reasoning horizons. Through comprehensive evaluation of LRMs using the
R-HORIZON benchmark, we find that even the most advanced LRMs suffer
significant performance degradation. Our analysis reveals that LRMs exhibit
limited effective reasoning length and struggle to allocate thinking budget
across multiple problems appropriately. Recognizing these limitations, we use
R-HORIZON to construct long-horizon reasoning data for reinforcement learning
with verified rewards (RLVR). Compared to training with single-horizon data,
RLVR with R-HORIZON not only substantially improves performance on the
multi-horizon reasoning tasks, but also promotes accuracy on standard reasoning
tasks, with an increase of 7.5 on AIME2024. These results position R-HORIZON as
a scalable, controllable, and low-cost paradigm for enhancing and evaluating
the long-horizon reasoning capabilities of LRMs.

AI.tldr: R-HORIZON composes queries to induce long-horizon, interdependent reasoning, yielding a benchmark that exposes sharp performance drops in current Large Reasoning Models and a training recipe (RL with verified rewards) that improves both long-horizon performance and standard benchmarks (e.g., +7.5 on AIME2024).
AI.motivation: Current reasoning models benefit from long Chain-of-Thought at test time, but prevailing benchmarks are short, single-horizon, and fail to stress models’ ability to sustain and allocate reasoning over extended, interdependent tasks. The field lacks tools to both evaluate and systematically improve long-horizon reasoning.
AI.method: 1) Propose R-HORIZON, a query-composition scheme that stitches interdependent subproblems to form long-horizon tasks. 2) Build a benchmark of multi-step, dependency-rich problems to elicit extended reasoning. 3) Evaluate state-of-the-art LRMs on the benchmark and analyze failure modes (effective reasoning length and budget allocation). 4) Use R-HORIZON to generate long-horizon data with verifiable rewards and train via RL (RLVR).
AI.result: Across LRMs, performance degrades markedly on the R-HORIZON benchmark; models show limited effective reasoning length and poor allocation of thinking budget across subproblems. Training with RLVR on R-HORIZON data improves multi-horizon task performance and also boosts standard reasoning accuracy, reporting a +7.5 improvement on AIME2024.
AI.conclusion: R-HORIZON provides a scalable, controllable, and low-cost way to both evaluate and enhance long-horizon reasoning. It reveals current LRMs’ limited effective reasoning length and budget-allocation weaknesses, and demonstrates that RL with verified long-horizon data can transfer gains back to standard benchmarks.

title: STEPER: Step-wise Knowledge Distillation for Enhancing Reasoning Ability in Multi-Step Retrieval-Augmented Language Models
summary:
Answering complex real-world questions requires step-by-step retrieval and
integration of relevant information to generate well-grounded responses.
However, existing knowledge distillation methods overlook the need for
different reasoning abilities at different steps, hindering transfer in
multi-step retrieval-augmented frameworks. To address this, we propose Stepwise
Knowledge Distillation for Enhancing Reasoning Ability in Multi-Step
Retrieval-Augmented Language Models (StepER). StepER employs step-wise
supervision to align with evolving information and reasoning demands across
stages. Additionally, it incorporates difficulty-aware training to
progressively optimize learning by prioritizing suitable steps. Our method is
adaptable to various multi-step retrieval-augmented language models, including
those that use retrieval queries for reasoning paths or decomposed questions.
Extensive experiments show that StepER outperforms prior methods on multi-hop
QA benchmarks, with an 8B model achieving performance comparable to a 70B
teacher model.

AI.tldr: StepER introduces step-wise, difficulty-aware knowledge distillation tailored to multi-step retrieval-augmented reasoning, enabling small student models to approach large-teacher performance on multi-hop QA.
AI.motivation: Traditional knowledge distillation treats reasoning as a single stage and fails to align with the evolving information and reasoning needs across steps in multi-step retrieval-augmented frameworks, limiting transfer of complex reasoning abilities.
AI.method: StepER applies step-wise supervision that follows each stage’s retrieved evidence and reasoning demands, and adds difficulty-aware training to prioritize appropriately challenging steps over time. It is model-agnostic across multi-step RAG setups, including those using retrieval queries as reasoning paths or decomposed questions.
AI.result: Across multi-hop QA benchmarks, StepER outperforms prior distillation baselines; notably, an 8B student achieves performance comparable to a 70B teacher model.
AI.conclusion: Explicit, step-wise and difficulty-aware distillation better transfers multi-step reasoning and retrieval skills, boosting smaller models and generalizing across RAG variants.

title: RASALoRE: Region Aware Spatial Attention with Location-based Random Embeddings for Weakly Supervised Anomaly Detection in Brain MRI Scans
summary:
Weakly Supervised Anomaly detection (WSAD) in brain MRI scans is an important
challenge useful to obtain quick and accurate detection of brain anomalies when
precise pixel-level anomaly annotations are unavailable and only weak labels
(e.g., slice-level) are available. In this work, we propose RASALoRE: Region
Aware Spatial Attention with Location-based Random Embeddings, a novel
two-stage WSAD framework. In the first stage, we introduce a Discriminative
Dual Prompt Tuning (DDPT) mechanism that generates high-quality pseudo weak
masks based on slice-level labels, serving as coarse localization cues. In the
second stage, we propose a segmentation network with a region-aware spatial
attention mechanism that relies on fixed location-based random embeddings. This
design enables the model to effectively focus on anomalous regions. Our
approach achieves state-of-the-art anomaly detection performance, significantly
outperforming existing WSAD methods while utilizing less than 8 million
parameters. Extensive evaluations on the BraTS20, BraTS21, BraTS23, and MSD
datasets demonstrate a substantial performance improvement coupled with a
significant reduction in computational complexity. Code is available at:
https://github.com/BheeshmSharma/RASALoRE-BMVC-2025/.

AI.tldr: RASALoRE is a lightweight two‑stage weakly supervised anomaly detection framework for brain MRI that turns slice‑level labels into pseudo masks via Discriminative Dual Prompt Tuning and then segments anomalies using region‑aware spatial attention guided by fixed location‑based random embeddings, achieving state‑of‑the‑art results with <8M parameters.
AI.motivation: Precise pixel‑level annotations for brain anomalies are costly and scarce, yet accurate localization is needed for clinical utility. Existing WSAD methods struggle to localize reliably under weak labels and can be computationally heavy. The work aims to deliver accurate, efficient anomaly localization using only slice‑level supervision.
AI.method: Stage 1: Discriminative Dual Prompt Tuning (DDPT) produces high‑quality pseudo weak masks from slice‑level labels to provide coarse localization cues. Stage 2: A segmentation network employs a region‑aware spatial attention mechanism conditioned on fixed location‑based random embeddings to focus attention on anomalous regions. The overall model remains lightweight (<8M parameters).
AI.result: Across BraTS20/21/23 and MSD datasets, the method significantly outperforms prior WSAD approaches, reaching state‑of‑the‑art performance while substantially reducing computational complexity and parameter count (<8M).
AI.conclusion: Combining pseudo‑mask generation under weak supervision with region‑aware attention driven by location‑based random embeddings yields accurate and efficient anomaly localization in brain MRI. The approach is practical (compact model), generalizes across multiple datasets, and is reproducible (code available).

title: Measuring What Matters: The AI Pluralism Index
summary:
Artificial intelligence systems increasingly mediate knowledge,
communication, and decision making. Development and governance remain
concentrated within a small set of firms and states, raising concerns that
technologies may encode narrow interests and limit public agency. Capability
benchmarks for language, vision, and coding are common, yet public, auditable
measures of pluralistic governance are rare. We define AI pluralism as the
degree to which affected stakeholders can shape objectives, data practices,
safeguards, and deployment. We present the AI Pluralism Index (AIPI), a
transparent, evidence-based instrument that evaluates producers and system
families across four pillars: participatory governance, inclusivity and
diversity, transparency, and accountability. AIPI codes verifiable practices
from public artifacts and independent evaluations, explicitly handling
"Unknown" evidence to report both lower-bound ("evidence") and known-only
scores with coverage. We formalize the measurement model; implement a
reproducible pipeline that integrates structured web and repository analysis,
external assessments, and expert interviews; and assess reliability with
inter-rater agreement, coverage reporting, cross-index correlations, and
sensitivity analysis. The protocol, codebook, scoring scripts, and evidence
graph are maintained openly with versioned releases and a public adjudication
process. We report pilot provider results and situate AIPI relative to adjacent
transparency, safety, and governance frameworks. The index aims to steer
incentives toward pluralistic practice and to equip policymakers, procurers,
and the public with comparable evidence.

AI.tldr: Proposes the AI Pluralism Index (AIPI), an open, evidence-based benchmark that scores AI producers/systems on participatory governance, inclusivity/diversity, transparency, and accountability, with explicit handling of missing evidence and a reproducible, audited pipeline.
AI.motivation: AI development and governance are concentrated among few actors, risking narrow interests and reduced public agency. While capability benchmarks abound, auditable measures of pluralistic governance are lacking; the work aims to fill this gap.
AI.method: Define AI pluralism; design a four-pillar index. Code verifiable practices from public artifacts and independent evaluations; represent missing evidence as "Unknown" and compute lower-bound (evidence-based) and known-only scores with coverage. Formalize the measurement model; implement a reproducible pipeline combining structured web/repository analysis, external assessments, and expert interviews. Assess reliability via inter-rater agreement, coverage reporting, cross-index correlations, and sensitivity analysis. Maintain protocol, codebook, scoring scripts, and an evidence graph openly with versioned releases and public adjudication.
AI.result: Provide pilot provider/system scores; demonstrate reliability metrics and coverage; show correlations with related indices; publish the open protocol, codebook, scripts, and evidence graph to enable replication and adjudication.
AI.conclusion: AIPI offers a transparent way to compare and incentivize pluralistic governance in AI, aiming to inform policymakers, procurers, and the public while evolving through open maintenance and community oversight.

title: Comprehensiveness Metrics for Automatic Evaluation of Factual Recall in Text Generation
summary:
Despite demonstrating remarkable performance across a wide range of tasks,
large language models (LLMs) have also been found to frequently produce outputs
that are incomplete or selectively omit key information. In sensitive domains,
such omissions can result in significant harm comparable to that posed by
factual inaccuracies, including hallucinations. In this study, we address the
challenge of evaluating the comprehensiveness of LLM-generated texts, focusing
on the detection of missing information or underrepresented viewpoints. We
investigate three automated evaluation strategies: (1) an NLI-based method that
decomposes texts into atomic statements and uses natural language inference
(NLI) to identify missing links, (2) a Q&A-based approach that extracts
question-answer pairs and compares responses across sources, and (3) an
end-to-end method that directly identifies missing content using LLMs. Our
experiments demonstrate the surprising effectiveness of the simple end-to-end
approach compared to more complex methods, though at the cost of reduced
robustness, interpretability and result granularity. We further assess the
comprehensiveness of responses from several popular open-weight LLMs when
answering user queries based on multiple sources.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how to automatically evaluate whether LLM outputs omit important information; a simple end-to-end LLM-based judge performs surprisingly well versus more structured NLI and Q&A pipelines, but with losses in robustness, interpretability, and granularity. They also benchmark open-weight LLMs on multi-source queries for comprehensiveness.
AI.motivation: Omissions and underrepresented viewpoints in LLM outputs can be as harmful as factual errors. Current evaluation focuses on accuracy/hallucination, not on completeness. There is a need for automated ways to detect missing content to ensure safer, more reliable use in sensitive domains.
AI.method: They compare three automated strategies for detecting missing information: (1) NLI-based: decompose texts into atomic propositions and use NLI to find unsupported/missing links; (2) Q&A-based: generate question–answer pairs from sources and compare answers across systems; (3) End-to-end: prompt an LLM directly to identify missing content in a candidate response.
AI.result: The end-to-end LLM judge is surprisingly effective relative to the more structured NLI and Q&A pipelines, but it is less robust, less interpretable, and offers coarser-grained feedback. They also evaluate the comprehensiveness of several popular open-weight LLMs when answering multi-source queries.
AI.conclusion: A simple end-to-end LLM evaluator is a strong baseline for detecting omissions but has important trade-offs in reliability and transparency. More structured methods provide better robustness and interpretability at the cost of effectiveness. Comprehensive evaluation of LLM outputs should consider both completeness and accuracy, and benchmarking across models reveals gaps in multi-source comprehension.

title: RetouchLLM: Training-free White-box Image Retouching
summary:
Image retouching not only enhances visual quality but also serves as a means
of expressing personal preferences and emotions. However, existing
learning-based approaches require large-scale paired data and operate as black
boxes, making the retouching process opaque and limiting their adaptability to
handle diverse, user- or image-specific adjustments. In this work, we propose
RetouchLLM, a training-free white-box image retouching system, which requires
no training data and performs interpretable, code-based retouching directly on
high-resolution images. Our framework progressively enhances the image in a
manner similar to how humans perform multi-step retouching, allowing
exploration of diverse adjustment paths. It comprises of two main modules: a
visual critic that identifies differences between the input and reference
images, and a code generator that produces executable codes. Experiments
demonstrate that our approach generalizes well across diverse retouching
styles, while natural language-based user interaction enables interpretable and
controllable adjustments tailored to user intent.

AI.tldr: RetouchLLM is a training‑free, white‑box system that progressively retouches high‑resolution images by generating executable edit code guided by a visual critic; it supports natural‑language control and generalizes across styles.
AI.motivation: Existing learning‑based retouching methods require large paired datasets and act as black boxes, making the process opaque and hard to adapt to user‑ or image‑specific preferences. The goal is an interpretable, controllable approach that works without training data.
AI.method: A two‑module framework: (1) a visual critic identifies differences between the input and a reference image; (2) a code generator outputs executable retouching code. The system performs multi‑step, human‑like progressive enhancements, enabling exploration of diverse adjustment paths and natural‑language interactions, all directly on high‑resolution images and without training.
AI.result: Experiments indicate strong generalization across varied retouching styles, with interpretable and controllable adjustments that align with user intent via natural language, executed directly on high‑resolution images.
AI.conclusion: RetouchLLM offers a practical, transparent alternative to data‑hungry black‑box models: it enables code‑level, interpretable, multi‑step retouching guided by natural language, achieving adaptable results across styles without the need for training data.

title: The Tournament Tree Method for preference elicitation in Multi-criteria decision-making
summary:
Pairwise comparison methods, such as Fuzzy Preference Relations and Saaty's
Multiplicative Preference Relations, are widely used to model expert judgments
in multi-criteria decision-making. However, their application is limited by the
high cognitive load required to complete $m(m-1)/2$ comparisons, the risk of
inconsistency, and the computational complexity of deriving consistent value
scales. This paper proposes the Tournament Tree Method (TTM), a novel
elicitation and evaluation framework that overcomes these limitations. The TTM
requires only $m-1$ pairwise comparisons to obtain a complete, reciprocal, and
consistent comparison matrix. The method consists of three phases: (i)
elicitation of expert judgments using a reduced set of targeted comparisons,
(ii) construction of the consistent pairwise comparison matrix, and (iii)
derivation of a global value scale from the resulting matrix. The proposed
approach ensures consistency by design, minimizes cognitive effort, and reduces
the dimensionality of preference modeling from $m(m-1)/2$ to $m$ parameters.
Furthermore, it is compatible with the classical Deck of Cards method, and thus
it can handle interval and ratio scales. We have also developed a web-based
tool that demonstrates its practical applicability in real decision-making
scenarios.

AI.tldr: Introduces the Tournament Tree Method (TTM), which elicits only m−1 targeted pairwise comparisons to construct a complete, reciprocal, and perfectly consistent comparison matrix and derive a global value scale, thereby lowering cognitive load and parameter dimensionality; it supports interval and ratio scales and is implemented in a web tool.
AI.motivation: Classical pairwise comparison frameworks (e.g., Fuzzy Preference Relations, Saaty’s multiplicative relations) require m(m−1)/2 judgments, burdening experts, inducing inconsistency, and adding computational effort to enforce/measure consistency and compute value scales.
AI.method: Organize alternatives into a tournament-tree structure to query just m−1 informative pairwise comparisons. From these, algorithmically build a complete, reciprocal, and consistency-by-design pairwise comparison matrix and then derive a global value scale. The approach reduces the parameter space from quadratic to linear, and integrates with the Deck of Cards method to accommodate interval and ratio scales.
AI.result: With only m−1 elicited judgments, TTM produces a full, consistent comparison matrix and a global value scale, minimizing cognitive effort and dimensionality. A web-based tool demonstrates feasibility and usage in real decision contexts.
AI.conclusion: TTM is an efficient, scalable alternative to traditional pairwise comparison methods, ensuring consistency by construction while supporting interval and ratio scaling; its practicality is evidenced by an accompanying web application.

title: Vision-Enabled LLMs in Historical Lexicography: Digitising and Enriching Estonian-German Dictionaries from the 17th and 18th Centuries
summary:
This article presents research conducted at the Institute of the Estonian
Language between 2022 and 2025 on the application of large language models
(LLMs) to the study of 17th and 18th century Estonian dictionaries. The authors
address three main areas: enriching historical dictionaries with modern word
forms and meanings; using vision-enabled LLMs to perform text recognition on
sources printed in Gothic script (Fraktur); and preparing for the creation of a
unified, cross-source dataset. Initial experiments with J. Gutslaff's 1648
dictionary indicate that LLMs have significant potential for semi-automatic
enrichment of dictionary information. When provided with sufficient context,
Claude 3.7 Sonnet accurately provided meanings and modern equivalents for 81%
of headword entries. In a text recognition experiment with A. T. Helle's 1732
dictionary, a zero-shot method successfully identified and structured 41% of
headword entries into error-free JSON-formatted output. For digitising the
Estonian-German dictionary section of A. W. Hupel's 1780 grammar, overlapping
tiling of scanned image files is employed, with one LLM being used for text
recognition and a second for merging the structured output. These findings
demonstrate that even for minor languages LLMs have a significant potential for
saving time and financial resources.

AI.tldr: Applies modern and vision-enabled LLMs to enrich and digitize 17th–18th century Estonian dictionaries, reporting 81% accurate semantic enrichment and 41% error-free zero-shot structuring, plus a tiled OCR + merge pipeline—suggesting strong time/cost savings for a low-resource language.
AI.motivation: Digitize and semantically enrich historical Estonian lexicographic sources efficiently, overcoming challenges of Fraktur script, archaic spelling, and cross-source heterogeneity, to build a unified dataset while reducing human effort and cost.
AI.method: Three tracks: (1) Semiautomatic enrichment—using Claude 3.7 Sonnet with ample context to propose modern forms and meanings for headwords. (2) Vision-enabled LLM OCR/IE—zero-shot extraction of headwords and structured JSON from Fraktur-printed pages. (3) Digitization pipeline—overlapping tiling of page images; one LLM for text recognition and a second for merging/normalizing structured outputs; plans for cross-source unification.
AI.result: On Gutslaff (1648), 81% of headwords received accurate meanings/modern equivalents given sufficient context. On Helle (1732), a zero-shot approach yielded error-free JSON for 41% of headword entries. For Hupel (1780), a tiled, two-LLM pipeline is implemented for Estonian–German sections; results indicate feasibility though full metrics are not yet provided.
AI.conclusion: LLMs, including VLMs, can substantially accelerate historical lexicography and digitization for a minor language, enabling semi-automatic enrichment and structured extraction that promise notable time and financial savings, with a path toward a unified cross-source dataset.

title: A class-driven hierarchical ResNet for classification of multispectral remote sensing images
comment:
11 pages, 2 figures, accepted conference paper at SPIE REMOTE
  SENSING, 3-7 September 2023, Amsterdam, Netherlands
summary:
This work presents a multitemporal class-driven hierarchical Residual Neural
Network (ResNet) designed for modelling the classification of Time Series (TS)
of multispectral images at different semantical class levels. The architecture
consists of a modification of the ResNet where we introduce additional branches
to perform the classification at the different hierarchy levels and leverage on
hierarchy-penalty maps to discourage incoherent hierarchical transitions within
the classification. In this way, we improve the discrimination capabilities of
classes at different levels of semantic details and train a modular
architecture that can be used as a backbone network for introducing new
specific classes and additional tasks considering limited training samples
available. We exploit the class-hierarchy labels to train efficiently the
different layers of the architecture, allowing the first layers to train faster
on the first levels of the hierarchy modeling general classes (i.e., the
macro-classes) and the intermediate classes, while using the last ones to
discriminate more specific classes (i.e., the micro-classes). In this way, the
targets are constrained in following the hierarchy defined, improving the
classification of classes at the most detailed level. The proposed modular
network has intrinsic adaptation capability that can be obtained through fine
tuning. The experimental results, obtained on two tiles of the Amazonian Forest
on 12 monthly composites of Sentinel 2 images acquired during 2019, demonstrate
the effectiveness of the hierarchical approach in both generalizing over
different hierarchical levels and learning discriminant features for an
accurate classification at the micro-class level on a new target area, with a
better representation of the minoritarian classes.

AI.tldr: They propose a multitemporal, class-hierarchical ResNet with multi-level classification heads and hierarchy-penalty maps, enabling coherent predictions across macro-, intermediate-, and micro-classes and improving micro-class accuracy and minority-class representation on Sentinel-2 Amazon data.
AI.motivation: Remote sensing time-series classification must respect semantic class hierarchies, work with limited labels, and transfer to new areas. Flat classifiers often make inconsistent predictions across hierarchy levels and underperform on fine-grained and minority classes. A model that integrates hierarchy knowledge can improve discrimination, coherence, and data efficiency.
AI.method: Modify a ResNet backbone to add branch heads for multiple semantic levels (macro/intermediate/micro). Use class-hierarchy labels to supervise different depths (early layers for general classes, deeper layers for specific classes). Introduce hierarchy-penalty maps to discourage incoherent parent–child transitions. Train on multitemporal Sentinel-2 image series (12 monthly composites), yielding a modular network that can be fine-tuned and extended with new classes/tasks under limited samples.
AI.result: On two Amazon forest tiles (2019 Sentinel-2 monthly composites), the hierarchical approach generalizes across levels, improves micro-class classification on a new target area, and better represents minority classes; qualitative improvements are reported (no specific metrics provided).
AI.conclusion: Embedding class hierarchy into a multitemporal ResNet—with level-specific heads, hierarchical penalties, and depth-aligned supervision—produces coherent, transferable, and fine-grained land-cover classification, particularly benefiting micro- and minority classes and supporting modular adaptation via fine-tuning.

title: DODO: Causal Structure Learning with Budgeted Interventions
comment:
Under review. Supported by SoBigData\.it IR0000013, FAIR PE00000013,
  ICSC CN00000013
summary:
Artificial Intelligence has achieved remarkable advancements in recent years,
yet much of its progress relies on identifying increasingly complex
correlations. Enabling causality awareness in AI has the potential to enhance
its performance by enabling a deeper understanding of the underlying mechanisms
of the environment. In this paper, we introduce DODO, an algorithm defining how
an Agent can autonomously learn the causal structure of its environment through
repeated interventions. We assume a scenario where an Agent interacts with a
world governed by a causal Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG), which dictates the
system's dynamics but remains hidden from the Agent. The Agent's task is to
accurately infer the causal DAG, even in the presence of noise. To achieve
this, the Agent performs interventions, leveraging causal inference techniques
to analyze the statistical significance of observed changes. Results show
better performance for DODO, compared to observational approaches, in all but
the most limited resource conditions. DODO is often able to reconstruct with as
low as zero errors the structure of the causal graph. In the most challenging
configuration, DODO outperforms the best baseline by +0.25 F1 points.

AI.tldr: DODO is an intervention-driven algorithm that lets an agent autonomously discover a hidden causal DAG by experimenting and applying causal inference; it consistently outperforms observational baselines, often reconstructing the graph with zero errors and yielding up to +0.25 F1 in the hardest setting.
AI.motivation: Current AI often exploits correlations rather than true cause–effect relations. Equipping agents with causal awareness can improve understanding, generalization, and decision-making, motivating an algorithm that actively learns causal structure—even with noise—via purposeful interventions.
AI.method: An agent interacts with an environment governed by an unknown causal DAG. It performs repeated interventions on variables, then uses causal inference and statistical significance tests on observed post-intervention changes to infer edges and orientations. The approach targets robust structure learning under noise and compares against purely observational methods, considering resource constraints.
AI.result: Across conditions, DODO outperforms observational baselines. It frequently recovers the exact causal graph (zero structural errors). In the most challenging configuration, it still beats the strongest baseline by +0.25 F1; only under the most resource-limited settings does performance narrow.
AI.conclusion: Active intervention substantially improves causal structure discovery under noise. DODO demonstrates that autonomous experimentation enables accurate, data-efficient causal DAG recovery, offering consistent gains over observational approaches and a pathway to causally aware AI agents.
