title: A$^2$Search: Ambiguity-Aware Question Answering with Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) and Reinforcement Learning
(RL) have led to strong performance in open-domain question answering (QA).
However, existing models still struggle with questions that admit multiple
valid answers. Standard QA benchmarks, which typically assume a single gold
answer, overlook this reality and thus produce inappropriate training signals.
Existing attempts to handle ambiguity often rely on costly manual annotation,
which is difficult to scale to multi-hop datasets such as HotpotQA and MuSiQue.
In this paper, we present A$^2$Search, an annotation-free, end-to-end training
framework to recognize and handle ambiguity. At its core is an automated
pipeline that detects ambiguous questions and gathers alternative answers via
trajectory sampling and evidence verification. The model is then optimized with
RL using a carefully designed $\mathrm{AnsF1}$ reward, which naturally
accommodates multiple answers. Experiments on eight open-domain QA benchmarks
demonstrate that A$^2$Search achieves new state-of-the-art performance. With
only a single rollout, A$^2$Search-7B yields an average $\mathrm{AnsF1}@1$
score of $48.4\%$ across four multi-hop benchmarks, outperforming all strong
baselines, including the substantially larger ReSearch-32B ($46.2\%$).
Extensive analyses further show that A$^2$Search resolves ambiguity and
generalizes across benchmarks, highlighting that embracing ambiguity is
essential for building more reliable QA systems. Our code, data, and model
weights can be found at https://github.com/zfj1998/A2Search

AI.tldr: A^2Search is an annotation-free, RL-trained QA framework that detects ambiguity, collects valid alternative answers, and optimizes with a multi-answer-aware reward, achieving state-of-the-art results on multi-hop open-domain QA.
AI.motivation: Open-domain QA often has multiple valid answers, but standard benchmarks assume a single gold answer, producing misleading training signals. Manual ambiguity annotations are costly and don’t scale to multi-hop datasets like HotpotQA and MuSiQue.
AI.method: Introduce A^2Search: an end-to-end, annotation-free pipeline that (1) automatically detects ambiguous questions, (2) gathers alternative answers via trajectory sampling and evidence verification, and (3) optimizes the model with RL using an AnsF1 reward tailored to multiple valid answers. The approach supports single-rollout inference.
AI.result: Across eight open-domain QA benchmarks, A^2Search sets new SOTA. On four multi-hop datasets, A^2Search-7B achieves 48.4% AnsF1@1 with a single rollout, surpassing the larger ReSearch-32B (46.2%). Analyses show improved ambiguity resolution and cross-benchmark generalization.
AI.conclusion: Handling ambiguity during training leads to more reliable QA systems. A^2Search scales without manual annotations, effectively resolves ambiguous queries, and generalizes across benchmarks; code and models are publicly released.

title: Towards Real-World Deepfake Detection: A Diverse In-the-wild Dataset of Forgery Faces
summary:
Deepfakes, leveraging advanced AIGC (Artificial Intelligence-Generated
Content) techniques, create hyper-realistic synthetic images and videos of
human faces, posing a significant threat to the authenticity of social media.
While this real-world threat is increasingly prevalent, existing academic
evaluations and benchmarks for detecting deepfake forgery often fall short to
achieve effective application for their lack of specificity, limited deepfake
diversity, restricted manipulation techniques.To address these limitations, we
introduce RedFace (Real-world-oriented Deepfake Face), a specialized facial
deepfake dataset, comprising over 60,000 forged images and 1,000 manipulated
videos derived from authentic facial features, to bridge the gap between
academic evaluations and real-world necessity. Unlike prior benchmarks, which
typically rely on academic methods to generate deepfakes, RedFace utilizes 9
commercial online platforms to integrate the latest deepfake technologies found
"in the wild", effectively simulating real-world black-box scenarios.Moreover,
RedFace's deepfakes are synthesized using bespoke algorithms, allowing it to
capture diverse and evolving methods used by real-world deepfake creators.
Extensive experimental results on RedFace (including cross-domain,
intra-domain, and real-world social network dissemination simulations) verify
the limited practicality of existing deepfake detection schemes against
real-world applications. We further perform a detailed analysis of the RedFace
dataset, elucidating the reason of its impact on detection performance compared
to conventional datasets. Our dataset is available at:
https://github.com/kikyou-220/RedFace.

AI.tldr: RedFace is a real-world-oriented deepfake benchmark built from commercial, black-box AIGC services, showing that current academic detectors generalize poorly to practical scenarios.
AI.motivation: Existing deepfake detection benchmarks lack real-world specificity, diversity, and manipulation breadth, leading to inflated lab performance and weak field applicability. There is a need for a dataset that mirrors how deepfakes are actually produced and shared online.
AI.method: Construct RedFace using 9 commercial online deepfake platforms plus bespoke synthesis algorithms to gather >60k forged images and ~1k manipulated videos from authentic faces. Evaluate detectors under cross-domain, intra-domain, and social-network dissemination (compression/post-processing) settings, and analyze factors behind performance shifts versus conventional datasets.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, mainstream detection schemes show marked performance drops on RedFace, indicating limited real-world practicality. Analyses identify dataset characteristics and real-world artifacts that drive the degradation compared to academic benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: RedFace bridges the gap between academic evaluation and practical deployment by offering a diverse, evolving, black-box-oriented benchmark; results underscore the need for more robust, generalizable detectors and provide insights to guide future method design.

title: Selection, Reflection and Self-Refinement: Revisit Reasoning Tasks via a Causal Lens
summary:
Due to their inherent complexity, reasoning tasks have long been regarded as
rigorous benchmarks for assessing the capabilities of machine learning models,
especially large language models (LLMs). Although humans can solve these tasks
with ease, existing models, even after extensive pre-training and post-training
at scale, still fail to perform reasoning reliably. In this paper, we revisit
reasoning tasks from a causal perspective, seeking to understand their behavior
in latent space and to offer insights for addressing their challenges.
Specifically, we cast reasoning tasks as a selection mechanism, in which
high-level logical concepts function as selection operators on the given
observations, such as, identifying the correct answer in a math problem or
filling the appropriate entry in Sudoku. We emphasize two key properties of
this formulation that shed light on the difficulty of reasoning tasks. First,
the latent space exceeds the observation space in complexity, even when the
correct answer is fully determined by the observed input. Second, the latent
variables, corresponding to logical thought, are densely structured and exhibit
strong dependencies. Building on this formulation, we introduce a framework,
called SR$^2$, that incorporates the estimated latent variables as feedback
into the selection mechanism, thereby facilitating the learning of dense
dependencies among latent representations. The framework consists of three key
modules: reflective representation learning, dependency self-refinement, and
periodic intermediate alignment. Experimentally, we show that our approach
yields significant gains in reasoning accuracy, for example, attaining over
10$\%$ improvement in performance with 8$\times$ fewer parameters on the Sudoku
and Maze tasks over the recent advances.

AI.tldr: Proposes SR^2, a framework that views reasoning as a selection process over observations using latent logical variables; it feeds back estimated latent states to learn dense dependencies, yielding >10% accuracy gains on Sudoku and Maze with 8× fewer parameters than recent baselines.
AI.motivation: LLMs still struggle with reliable reasoning despite scale. The authors argue that reasoning difficulty arises because latent (thought) space is more complex than the observation space and its variables are densely interdependent. A causal, latent-space perspective could clarify and improve reasoning.
AI.method: Recast reasoning tasks as selection mechanisms where high-level logical concepts act as operators over observed inputs. Highlight two properties: (1) latent space complexity exceeds that of observations even when answers are determined, and (2) latent variables are densely structured with strong dependencies. Introduce SR^2, which feeds back estimated latent variables to shape the selection process and learn these dependencies via three modules: reflective representation learning, dependency self-refinement, and periodic intermediate alignment.
AI.result: Empirically, SR^2 significantly improves reasoning accuracy, e.g., achieving over 10% better performance on Sudoku and Maze while using 8× fewer parameters than recent methods.
AI.conclusion: Modeling and reinforcing dense dependencies among latent logical variables via feedback enables more reliable reasoning. The selection-based, causal view offers a principled path to make smaller models reason better, as demonstrated on structured tasks like Sudoku and Maze.

title: LightReasoner: Can Small Language Models Teach Large Language Models Reasoning?
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable progress in
reasoning, often through supervised fine-tuning (SFT). However, SFT is
resource-intensive, relying on large curated datasets, rejection-sampled
demonstrations, and uniform optimization across all tokens, even though only a
fraction carry meaningful learning value. In this work, we explore a
counterintuitive idea: can smaller language models (SLMs) teach larger language
models (LLMs) by revealing high-value reasoning moments that reflect the
latter's unique strength? We propose LightReasoner, a novel framework that
leverages the behavioral divergence between a stronger expert model (LLM) and a
weaker amateur model (SLM). LightReasoner operates in two stages: (1) a
sampling stage that pinpoints critical reasoning moments and constructs
supervision examples capturing the expert's advantage through expert-amateur
contrast, and (2) a fine-tuning stage that aligns the expert model with these
distilled examples, amplifying its reasoning strengths. Across seven
mathematical benchmarks, LightReasoner improves accuracy by up to 28.1%, while
reducing time consumption by 90%, sampled problems by 80%, and tuned token
usage by 99%, all without relying on ground-truth labels. By turning weaker
SLMs into effective teaching signals, LightReasoner offers a scalable and
resource-efficient approach for advancing LLM reasoning. Code is available at:
https://github.com/HKUDS/LightReasoner

AI.tldr: LightReasoner lets a weaker small model expose where a stronger LLM’s reasoning truly matters, then fine-tunes the LLM only on those high-value moments—boosting accuracy while slashing data, time, and tokens without ground-truth labels.
AI.motivation: Conventional supervised fine-tuning for reasoning is costly and inefficient: it needs large curated datasets, rejection sampling, and uniformly optimizes all tokens even though only a few contain useful learning signal. The goal is to find a label-free, resource-efficient way to target the most informative reasoning steps.
AI.method: Two-stage framework leveraging expert–amateur divergence. (1) Sampling: compare outputs/trajectories of a strong LLM (expert) and a weaker SLM (amateur) to identify critical reasoning moments where the expert outperforms the amateur; construct supervision from these contrasts. (2) Fine-tuning: align the expert model specifically on these distilled, high-value examples to amplify its reasoning strengths.
AI.result: On seven mathematical benchmarks, LightReasoner achieves up to +28.1% accuracy improvement while reducing time by ~90%, sampled problems by ~80%, and tuned token usage by ~99%, all without using ground-truth labels.
AI.conclusion: Smaller models can effectively teach larger ones by revealing high-value reasoning signals. LightReasoner provides a scalable, label-free, and resource-efficient path to improve LLM reasoning, focusing optimization where it matters most.

title: Physics-Driven Spatiotemporal Modeling for AI-Generated Video Detection
summary:
AI-generated videos have achieved near-perfect visual realism (e.g., Sora),
urgently necessitating reliable detection mechanisms. However, detecting such
videos faces significant challenges in modeling high-dimensional spatiotemporal
dynamics and identifying subtle anomalies that violate physical laws. In this
paper, we propose a physics-driven AI-generated video detection paradigm based
on probability flow conservation principles. Specifically, we propose a
statistic called Normalized Spatiotemporal Gradient (NSG), which quantifies the
ratio of spatial probability gradients to temporal density changes, explicitly
capturing deviations from natural video dynamics. Leveraging pre-trained
diffusion models, we develop an NSG estimator through spatial gradients
approximation and motion-aware temporal modeling without complex motion
decomposition while preserving physical constraints. Building on this, we
propose an NSG-based video detection method (NSG-VD) that computes the Maximum
Mean Discrepancy (MMD) between NSG features of the test and real videos as a
detection metric. Last, we derive an upper bound of NSG feature distances
between real and generated videos, proving that generated videos exhibit
amplified discrepancies due to distributional shifts. Extensive experiments
confirm that NSG-VD outperforms state-of-the-art baselines by 16.00% in Recall
and 10.75% in F1-Score, validating the superior performance of NSG-VD. The
source code is available at https://github.com/ZSHsh98/NSG-VD.

AI.tldr: Physics-driven detector for AI-generated videos that measures deviations from probability flow conservation via a new Normalized Spatiotemporal Gradient (NSG) statistic, estimated with pretrained diffusion models and compared using MMD; achieves sizable gains over prior methods with theoretical backing.
AI.motivation: Near-perfect visual realism of modern generative video (e.g., Sora) makes artifact-based or frame-only detectors unreliable. Detecting forgeries requires modeling high-dimensional spatiotemporal dynamics and finding subtle violations of physical/continuity laws in real videos that generators may not preserve.
AI.method: Define NSG as the ratio of spatial probability gradients to temporal density changes to capture conservation-law-consistent dynamics. Estimate NSG using pretrained diffusion models: approximate spatial gradients and perform motion-aware temporal modeling without explicit motion decomposition. For detection, compute NSG features for test and real videos and use Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD) between their NSG distributions as the decision metric. Provide a theoretical upper bound on NSG feature distances, showing distributional shifts in generated videos amplify discrepancies.
AI.result: On benchmarks, the proposed NSG-VD outperforms state-of-the-art detectors by +16.00% Recall and +10.75% F1-Score; extensive experiments validate robustness. Code is publicly released.
AI.conclusion: A physics-driven, diffusion-model-assisted approach to video forgery detection can better expose subtle, non-physical spatiotemporal dynamics in AI-generated videos. The NSG-VD method is theoretically motivated and empirically strong, suggesting conservation-law-based cues are effective for reliable deepfake video detection.

title: Chain-of-Trigger: An Agentic Backdoor that Paradoxically Enhances Agentic Robustness
summary:
The rapid deployment of large language model (LLM)-based agents in real-world
applications has raised serious concerns about their trustworthiness. In this
work, we reveal the security and robustness vulnerabilities of these agents
through backdoor attacks. Distinct from traditional backdoors limited to
single-step control, we propose the Chain-of-Trigger Backdoor (CoTri), a
multi-step backdoor attack designed for long-horizon agentic control. CoTri
relies on an ordered sequence. It starts with an initial trigger, and
subsequent ones are drawn from the environment, allowing multi-step
manipulation that diverts the agent from its intended task. Experimental
results show that CoTri achieves a near-perfect attack success rate (ASR) while
maintaining a near-zero false trigger rate (FTR). Due to training data modeling
the stochastic nature of the environment, the implantation of CoTri
paradoxically enhances the agent's performance on benign tasks and even
improves its robustness against environmental distractions. We further validate
CoTri on vision-language models (VLMs), confirming its scalability to
multimodal agents. Our work highlights that CoTri achieves stable, multi-step
control within agents, improving their inherent robustness and task
capabilities, which ultimately makes the attack more stealthy and raises
potential safty risks.

AI.tldr: CoTri is a chain-of-trigger backdoor that enables multi‑step, long‑horizon control of LLM/VLM agents with near‑perfect attack success and near‑zero false triggers, while paradoxically improving benign-task performance and robustness—making the attack stealthier and raising safety risks.
AI.motivation: LLM-based agents are rapidly deployed in real-world settings, but existing backdoor studies focus on single-step triggers and overlook long-horizon, agentic control. The authors aim to expose and analyze vulnerabilities specific to multi-step agent behaviors and understand how such attacks can remain stealthy in practice.
AI.method: Introduce Chain-of-Trigger Backdoor (CoTri): an ordered sequence of triggers where an initial trigger activates the backdoor and subsequent triggers are drawn from the environment to steer the agent over multiple steps. Train/evaluate on LLM agents (and VLMs) to measure attack success rate (ASR), false trigger rate (FTR), and side effects on benign-task performance and robustness to distractions; leverage environment stochasticity modeling during training.
AI.result: CoTri achieves near-perfect ASR with near-zero FTR. Surprisingly, due to modeling environmental stochasticity during training, implanting CoTri improves the agent’s performance on benign tasks and its robustness to environmental distractions. The approach scales to multimodal vision-language agents.
AI.conclusion: CoTri establishes stable, multi-step covert control over agents while enhancing their perceived capability and robustness, thus increasing stealth and elevating real-world safety risks. The work underscores an urgent need for defenses against long-horizon, environment-driven backdoors in LLM/VLM agents.

title: Active Confusion Expression in Large Language Models: Leveraging World Models toward Better Social Reasoning
summary:
While large language models (LLMs) excel in mathematical and code reasoning,
we observe they struggle with social reasoning tasks, exhibiting cognitive
confusion, logical inconsistencies, and conflation between objective world
states and subjective belief states. Through deteiled analysis of DeepSeek-R1's
reasoning trajectories, we find that LLMs frequently encounter reasoning
impasses and tend to output contradictory terms like "tricky" and "confused"
when processing scenarios with multiple participants and timelines, leading to
erroneous reasoning or infinite loops. The core issue is their inability to
disentangle objective reality from agents' subjective beliefs. To address this,
we propose an adaptive world model-enhanced reasoning mechanism that constructs
a dynamic textual world model to track entity states and temporal sequences. It
dynamically monitors reasoning trajectories for confusion indicators and
promptly intervenes by providing clear world state descriptions, helping models
navigate through cognitive dilemmas. The mechanism mimics how humans use
implicit world models to distinguish between external events and internal
beliefs. Evaluations on three social benchmarks demonstrate significant
improvements in accuracy (e.g., +10% in Hi-ToM) while reducing computational
costs (up to 33.8% token reduction), offering a simple yet effective solution
for deploying LLMs in social contexts.

AI.tldr: LLMs often conflate objective world states with agents’ beliefs in social reasoning; the authors build an adaptive textual world model that tracks entities and timelines and intervenes when confusion is detected, boosting accuracy (≈+10% on Hi-ToM) while cutting tokens (up to 33.8%).
AI.motivation: Despite strong math/code skills, LLMs perform poorly on social reasoning, showing cognitive confusion, contradictions, and looping—especially with multiple agents and timelines—because they fail to separate reality from belief states. The work seeks a lightweight, deployable fix.
AI.method: 1) Analyze DeepSeek-R1 reasoning traces to identify impasses and confusion markers (e.g., self-reports like “tricky,” “confused”). 2) Introduce an adaptive world-model-enhanced reasoning mechanism: construct a dynamic textual world model that tracks entities and temporal sequences; monitor the chain-of-thought for confusion indicators; when detected, inject concise, explicit world-state summaries to disentangle objective events from subjective beliefs, mimicking human mental models.
AI.result: Across three social reasoning benchmarks, the method yields higher accuracy (e.g., +10% on Hi-ToM) and efficiency gains (up to 33.8% token reduction), with fewer contradictions and fewer infinite loops.
AI.conclusion: Explicit, adaptive world-state modeling that separates reality from beliefs is a simple, effective way to stabilize LLM social reasoning, improving both accuracy and efficiency and facilitating practical deployment in social contexts.

title: DarkHash: A Data-Free Backdoor Attack Against Deep Hashing
summary:
Benefiting from its superior feature learning capabilities and efficiency,
deep hashing has achieved remarkable success in large-scale image retrieval.
Recent studies have demonstrated the vulnerability of deep hashing models to
backdoor attacks. Although these studies have shown promising attack results,
they rely on access to the training dataset to implant the backdoor. In the
real world, obtaining such data (e.g., identity information) is often
prohibited due to privacy protection and intellectual property concerns.
Embedding backdoors into deep hashing models without access to the training
data, while maintaining retrieval accuracy for the original task, presents a
novel and challenging problem. In this paper, we propose DarkHash, the first
data-free backdoor attack against deep hashing. Specifically, we design a novel
shadow backdoor attack framework with dual-semantic guidance. It embeds
backdoor functionality and maintains original retrieval accuracy by fine-tuning
only specific layers of the victim model using a surrogate dataset. We consider
leveraging the relationship between individual samples and their neighbors to
enhance backdoor attacks during training. By designing a topological alignment
loss, we optimize both individual and neighboring poisoned samples toward the
target sample, further enhancing the attack capability. Experimental results on
four image datasets, five model architectures, and two hashing methods
demonstrate the high effectiveness of DarkHash, outperforming existing
state-of-the-art backdoor attack methods. Defense experiments show that
DarkHash can withstand existing mainstream backdoor defense methods.

AI.tldr: DarkHash presents the first data-free backdoor attack on deep hashing for image retrieval, using surrogate data and a dual-semantic, topology-aware fine-tuning to implant robust triggers while preserving retrieval accuracy and evading common defenses.
AI.motivation: Prior backdoor attacks on deep hashing assume access to the original training data, which is often restricted due to privacy and IP concerns. The authors aim to show that an attacker can still implant an effective backdoor without the training dataset and without degrading retrieval utility.
AI.method: A shadow backdoor attack framework with dual-semantic guidance: the attacker fine-tunes only specific layers of a pretrained victim hashing model using a surrogate dataset. A topological alignment loss leverages instance-level features and neighborhood relations, optimizing both poisoned samples and their neighbors toward a target sample/code to strengthen the backdoor while maintaining the model’s original retrieval accuracy.
AI.result: On four image datasets, five architectures, and two hashing methods, DarkHash outperforms state-of-the-art backdoor baselines in attack effectiveness and maintains high retrieval accuracy. It also remains effective under mainstream backdoor defense techniques.
AI.conclusion: Data-free, topology-aware fine-tuning can embed strong backdoors into deep hashing models without sacrificing utility, posing practical risks for model reuse and distribution and signaling the need for more robust, hashing-specific defenses.

title: Co-TAP: Three-Layer Agent Interaction Protocol Technical Report
summary:
This paper proposes Co-TAP (T: Triple, A: Agent, P: Protocol), a three-layer
agent interaction protocol designed to address the challenges faced by
multi-agent systems across the three core dimensions of Interoperability,
Interaction and Collaboration, and Knowledge Sharing. We have designed and
proposed a layered solution composed of three core protocols: the Human-Agent
Interaction Protocol (HAI), the Unified Agent Protocol (UAP), and the
Memory-Extraction-Knowledge Protocol (MEK). HAI focuses on the interaction
layer, standardizing the flow of information between users, interfaces, and
agents by defining a standardized, event-driven communication paradigm. This
ensures the real-time performance, reliability, and synergy of interactions. As
the core of the infrastructure layer, UAP is designed to break down
communication barriers among heterogeneous agents through unified service
discovery and protocol conversion mechanisms, thereby enabling seamless
interconnection and interoperability of the underlying network. MEK, in turn,
operates at the cognitive layer. By establishing a standardized ''Memory (M) -
Extraction (E) - Knowledge (K)'' cognitive chain, it empowers agents with the
ability to learn from individual experiences and form shareable knowledge,
thereby laying the foundation for the realization of true collective
intelligence. We believe this protocol framework will provide a solid
engineering foundation and theoretical guidance for building the next
generation of efficient, scalable, and intelligent multi-agent applications.

AI.tldr: Co-TAP is a three-layer protocol stack (HAI, UAP, MEK) that standardizes human-agent interactions, unifies interoperability among heterogeneous agents, and systematizes memory-to-knowledge flows so agents can learn and share knowledge, aiming to enable scalable, real-time, collaborative multi-agent systems.
AI.motivation: Current multi-agent systems struggle with fragmented interfaces, siloed communication across heterogeneous agents, and poor mechanisms for learning and sharing knowledge—limiting real-time reliability, interoperability, and collective intelligence.
AI.method: Propose a layered protocol framework: (1) HAI (Human-Agent Interaction) defines an event-driven, standardized interface between users, UI components, and agents for reliable, real-time interaction; (2) UAP (Unified Agent Protocol) provides unified service discovery and protocol translation to interconnect heterogeneous agents; (3) MEK (Memory–Extraction–Knowledge) establishes a cognitive pipeline that converts experience (memory) into extracted insights and shareable knowledge.
AI.result: Design-level contribution: a protocol suite and architecture that purportedly ensures real-time, reliable interactions (HAI), seamless interconnection and interoperability (UAP), and agent learning plus knowledge sharing (MEK). No empirical benchmarks or case studies are reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: The authors argue Co-TAP offers a practical engineering foundation and theoretical guidance for building efficient, scalable, and intelligent multi-agent applications that exhibit collective intelligence.

title: Leveraging Author-Specific Context for Scientific Figure Caption Generation: 3rd SciCap Challenge
summary:
Scientific figure captions require both accuracy and stylistic consistency to
convey visual information. Here, we present a domain-specific caption
generation system for the 3rd SciCap Challenge that integrates figure-related
textual context with author-specific writing styles using the LaMP-Cap dataset.
Our approach uses a two-stage pipeline: Stage 1 combines context filtering,
category-specific prompt optimization via DSPy's MIPROv2 and SIMBA, and caption
candidate selection; Stage 2 applies few-shot prompting with profile figures
for stylistic refinement. Our experiments demonstrate that category-specific
prompts outperform both zero-shot and general optimized approaches, improving
ROUGE-1 recall by +8.3\% while limiting precision loss to -2.8\% and BLEU-4
reduction to -10.9\%. Profile-informed stylistic refinement yields 40--48\%
gains in BLEU scores and 25--27\% in ROUGE. Overall, our system demonstrates
that combining contextual understanding with author-specific stylistic
adaptation can generate captions that are both scientifically accurate and
stylistically faithful to the source paper.

AI.tldr: A two-stage, context- and style-aware captioning pipeline for SciCap that optimizes category-specific prompts and conditions on author profiles, yielding sizable gains in ROUGE/BLEU and more faithful scientific figure captions.
AI.motivation: Scientific figure captions must be both factually accurate (grounded in figure/context) and stylistically consistent with the paper’s author(s). Existing captioning often ignores author-specific style and uses generic prompting, leading to weaker recall and stylistic mismatch.
AI.method: Two-stage pipeline on LaMP-Cap for the 3rd SciCap Challenge: (1) Contextual grounding via context filtering, then category-specific prompt optimization using DSPy’s MIPROv2 and SIMBA, followed by candidate selection; (2) Stylistic refinement via few-shot prompting using author profile figures/examples to match writing style.
AI.result: Category-specific prompts outperform zero-shot and general optimized baselines: ROUGE-1 recall +8.3%, with trade-offs (precision −2.8%, BLEU-4 −10.9%). A second-stage, profile-informed stylistic refinement yields large gains: BLEU +40–48% and ROUGE +25–27%.
AI.conclusion: Jointly modeling figure-context and author-specific style improves both scientific accuracy and stylistic faithfulness. Category-specific prompt optimization and profile-based few-shot refinement are key to performance improvements.

title: Efficient Label Refinement for Face Parsing Under Extreme Poses Using 3D Gaussian Splatting
comment:
Accepted to VCIP 2025 (International Conference on Visual
  Communications and Image Processing 2025)
summary:
Accurate face parsing under extreme viewing angles remains a significant
challenge due to limited labeled data in such poses. Manual annotation is
costly and often impractical at scale. We propose a novel label refinement
pipeline that leverages 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) to generate accurate
segmentation masks from noisy multiview predictions. By jointly fitting two
3DGS models, one to RGB images and one to their initial segmentation maps, our
method enforces multiview consistency through shared geometry, enabling the
synthesis of pose-diverse training data with only minimal post-processing.
Fine-tuning a face parsing model on this refined dataset significantly improves
accuracy on challenging head poses, while maintaining strong performance on
standard views. Extensive experiments, including human evaluations, demonstrate
that our approach achieves superior results compared to state-of-the-art
methods, despite requiring no ground-truth 3D annotations and using only a
small set of initial images. Our method offers a scalable and effective
solution for improving face parsing robustness in real- world settings.

AI.tldr: They refine noisy multiview face segmentation labels by jointly fitting two 3D Gaussian Splatting models (one on RGB, one on segmentations) to enforce multiview-consistent geometry, synthesize pose-diverse masks, and fine-tune a parser, yielding large gains on extreme poses without needing 3D ground truth.
AI.motivation: Face parsing degrades at extreme head poses due to scarce, expensive-to-label data. The goal is a scalable way to obtain accurate, pose-diverse labels without manual 3D annotations, improving robustness in real-world conditions.
AI.method: Build a label refinement pipeline using 3D Gaussian Splatting: simultaneously fit one 3DGS to RGB images and another to initial (noisy) segmentation maps while sharing geometry, which enforces multiview consistency. Render novel views to create pose-diverse, refined masks with minimal post-processing, then fine-tune a face parsing network on this data.
AI.result: Fine-tuning on the refined dataset significantly boosts accuracy on challenging head poses and preserves strong performance on standard views. Across extensive experiments and human studies, the approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods despite using only a small set of initial images and no 3D ground-truth annotations.
AI.conclusion: A practical, scalable 3DGS-based label refinement pipeline can reliably produce consistent, pose-diverse segmentation masks, enabling more robust face parsing under extreme viewpoints in real-world applications.

title: Symmetry-Aware Fully-Amortized Optimization with Scale Equivariant Graph Metanetworks
summary:
Amortized optimization accelerates the solution of related optimization
problems by learning mappings that exploit shared structure across problem
instances. We explore the use of Scale Equivariant Graph Metanetworks
(ScaleGMNs) for this purpose. By operating directly in weight space, ScaleGMNs
enable single-shot fine-tuning of existing models, reducing the need for
iterative optimization. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach
empirically and provide a theoretical result: the gauge freedom induced by
scaling symmetries is strictly smaller in convolutional neural networks than in
multi-layer perceptrons. This insight helps explain the performance differences
observed between architectures in both our work and that of Kalogeropoulos et
al. (2024). Overall, our findings underscore the potential of symmetry-aware
metanetworks as a powerful approach for efficient and generalizable neural
network optimization. Open-source code:
https://github.com/daniuyter/scalegmn_amortization

AI.tldr: They introduce Scale Equivariant Graph Metanetworks (ScaleGMNs) that operate directly in weight space to perform single-shot fine-tuning, accelerating amortized optimization across related tasks, and prove that CNNs have less scaling-induced gauge freedom than MLPs, aligning with observed performance differences.
AI.motivation: Amortized optimization seeks to avoid costly iterative retraining across related problem instances. The authors aim to exploit shared structure and symmetries—particularly scaling—in neural networks to quickly adapt models while improving generalization and efficiency.
AI.method: Use scale-equivariant graph metanetworks defined over the parameter (weight) graphs of neural networks. The metanetwork maps a base model’s weights to adapted weights in one forward pass, leveraging scale symmetries (gauge freedom) for fast, architecture-aware fine-tuning. They compare architectures (CNNs vs MLPs) and analyze symmetry-induced gauge freedom.
AI.result: Empirically, single-shot weight-space adaptation with ScaleGMNs reduces or replaces iterative optimization and performs well across tasks. Theoretically, they show scaling gauge freedom is strictly smaller in CNNs than in MLPs, which helps explain why architectures behave differently in amortized optimization. Code is released.
AI.conclusion: Symmetry-aware metanetworks are promising for efficient, generalizable neural network adaptation. Architectural symmetries constrain gauge freedom, with CNNs offering more favorable properties than MLPs for this approach.

title: Learning on the Job: An Experience-Driven Self-Evolving Agent for Long-Horizon Tasks
summary:
Large Language Models have demonstrated remarkable capabilities across
diverse domains, yet significant challenges persist when deploying them as AI
agents for real-world long-horizon tasks. Existing LLM agents suffer from a
critical limitation: they are test-time static and cannot learn from
experience, lacking the ability to accumulate knowledge and continuously
improve on the job. To address this challenge, we propose MUSE, a novel agent
framework that introduces an experience-driven, self-evolving system centered
around a hierarchical Memory Module. MUSE organizes diverse levels of
experience and leverages them to plan and execute long-horizon tasks across
multiple applications. After each sub-task execution, the agent autonomously
reflects on its trajectory, converting the raw trajectory into structured
experience and integrating it back into the Memory Module. This mechanism
enables the agent to evolve beyond its static pretrained parameters, fostering
continuous learning and self-evolution. We evaluate MUSE on the long-horizon
productivity benchmark TAC. It achieves new SOTA performance by a significant
margin using only a lightweight Gemini-2.5 Flash model. Sufficient Experiments
demonstrate that as the agent autonomously accumulates experience, it exhibits
increasingly superior task completion capabilities, as well as robust
continuous learning and self-evolution capabilities. Moreover, the accumulated
experience from MUSE exhibits strong generalization properties, enabling
zero-shot improvement on new tasks. MUSE establishes a new paradigm for AI
agents capable of real-world productivity task automation.

AI.tldr: MUSE is an experience-driven, self-evolving LLM agent that uses a hierarchical memory and post-subtask reflection to convert trajectories into structured experience, enabling continuous improvement and achieving SOTA on the TAC long-horizon productivity benchmark with Gemini-2.5 Flash; accumulated experiences generalize zero-shot to new tasks.
AI.motivation: LLM agents are typically test-time static: they cannot learn from on-the-job experience for long-horizon tasks, limiting their ability to accumulate knowledge and improve performance over time.
AI.method: Introduce a framework centered on a hierarchical Memory Module that organizes experiences at multiple levels. After each subtask, the agent reflects on its trajectory, structures the experience, and integrates it back into memory. This closed-loop of plan–act–reflect–store allows the agent to leverage prior experience for future planning and execution without changing base model weights.
AI.result: On the TAC productivity benchmark, MUSE attains new state-of-the-art performance by a significant margin using the lightweight Gemini-2.5 Flash model. Experiments show monotonic improvement as experience accrues, robust continuous learning/self-evolution, and zero-shot gains on new tasks from transferred experiences.
AI.conclusion: MUSE demonstrates a practical path to agents that continuously learn at inference time via structured memory, moving beyond static LLM behavior toward real-world productivity automation.

title: Random Window Augmentations for Deep Learning Robustness in CT and Liver Tumor Segmentation
comment:
10 pages, 9 figures. This work has been submitted to the IEEE for
  possible publication
summary:
Contrast-enhanced Computed Tomography (CT) is important for diagnosis and
treatment planning for various medical conditions. Deep learning (DL) based
segmentation models may enable automated medical image analysis for detecting
and delineating tumors in CT images, thereby reducing clinicians' workload.
Achieving generalization capabilities in limited data domains, such as
radiology, requires modern DL models to be trained with image augmentation.
However, naively applying augmentation methods developed for natural images to
CT scans often disregards the nature of the CT modality, where the intensities
measure Hounsfield Units (HU) and have important physical meaning. This paper
challenges the use of such intensity augmentations for CT imaging and shows
that they may lead to artifacts and poor generalization. To mitigate this, we
propose a CT-specific augmentation technique, called Random windowing, that
exploits the available HU distribution of intensities in CT images. Random
windowing encourages robustness to contrast-enhancement and significantly
increases model performance on challenging images with poor contrast or timing.
We perform ablations and analysis of our method on multiple datasets, and
compare to, and outperform, state-of-the-art alternatives, while focusing on
the challenge of liver tumor segmentation.

AI.tldr: Natural-image intensity augmentations can hurt CT segmentation because HU values have physical meaning; the authors introduce a CT-specific “Random windowing” augmentation that varies HU window/level during training, yielding more robust, better-generalizing tumor segmentation, especially under contrast/timing variability, and outperforming SOTA baselines.
AI.motivation: Deep models for CT tumor segmentation need strong generalization, but labeled data are scarce. Standard intensity augmentations ignore the physics of Hounsfield Units, risking artifacts and degraded performance—especially across contrast phases and varying enhancement—so a modality-aware augmentation is needed.
AI.method: Propose Random windowing: during training, randomly sample clinically plausible HU window/level settings to remap intensities, leveraging the HU distribution and mimicking different contrast conditions. Conduct ablations and cross-dataset evaluations, focusing on liver tumor segmentation, and compare against common and state-of-the-art augmentation schemes.
AI.result: Random windowing improves robustness to contrast-enhancement variability and substantially boosts performance on difficult, low-contrast or mistimed scans; across multiple datasets it consistently outperforms standard and SOTA augmentation baselines. They also show naive intensity augmentations can introduce artifacts and harm generalization.
AI.conclusion: Augmentations for CT must respect HU physics. A simple, modality-aware random windowing strategy yields better generalization and segmentation accuracy, particularly under contrast/timing shifts, and is preferable to natural-image intensity augmentations for CT.

title: First Try Matters: Revisiting the Role of Reflection in Reasoning Models
summary:
Large language models have recently demonstrated significant gains in
reasoning ability, often attributed to their capacity to generate longer chains
of thought and engage in reflective reasoning. However, the contribution of
reflections to performance improvement remains unclear. In this paper, we
systematically analyze the rollouts of eight reasoning models on five
mathematical datasets. We focus on reflective behaviours where the model has
already produced an answer but continues reflecting before finalizing its
output. Our analysis reveals that reflections are predominantly confirmatory
and rarely alter the model's initial answer, a pattern consistent across models
and datasets. To understand the role of reflections in training, we construct
supervised fine-tuning (SFT) datasets with varying amounts of reflection steps.
We observe that training models on rollouts with more reflection steps
primarily enhances first-answer correctness rather than the ability to correct
initially wrong answers through reflections. This motivates us to propose a
question-aware early-stopping method that enhances inference-time token
efficiency by stopping the reasoning process once a few plausible candidate
answers are generated, thereby reducing unnecessary reflection steps. Motivated
by this, we further propose to dynamically truncate the reflections after a
candidate answer has appeared during generation, which reduces reasoning tokens
by 24.5% across five mathematical datasets, within a 2.9% drop in accuracy.

AI.tldr: Reflections in LLM math reasoning mostly confirm initial answers rather than fixing mistakes; training on more reflections boosts first-pass accuracy, not self-correction, motivating early stopping/truncation that cuts tokens ~24.5% with ~2.9% accuracy loss.
AI.motivation: Clarify whether reflective reasoning (continuing to think after proposing an answer) actually improves correctness, and how reflection-heavy training affects models. Additionally, seek ways to reduce unnecessary reasoning tokens without sacrificing much accuracy.
AI.method: Analyze rollouts from 8 reasoning models on 5 math datasets, focusing on steps after a first candidate answer appears. Construct SFT datasets varying the number of reflection steps to test training effects. Propose a question-aware early-stopping criterion that halts once a few plausible answers are generated, and a dynamic truncation strategy that cuts off reflections after a candidate answer emerges.
AI.result: Reflections are predominantly confirmatory and rarely change the initial answer across models/datasets. SFT with more reflection steps chiefly improves first-answer correctness, not the ability to overturn wrong answers via reflection. Dynamically truncating reflections reduces reasoning tokens by 24.5% across five math datasets with only a 2.9% absolute accuracy drop; early-stopping similarly improves token efficiency by avoiding redundant steps.
AI.conclusion: Extended reflections often add little beyond confirming the first answer. Emphasizing high-quality first-pass reasoning and using question-aware early stopping/truncation can substantially reduce token cost with minor accuracy trade-offs, challenging the premise that long reflections are key to self-correction.

title: ChatGPT as a Translation Engine: A Case Study on Japanese-English
summary:
This study investigates ChatGPT for Japanese-English translation, exploring
simple and enhanced prompts and comparing against commercially available
translation engines. Performing both automatic and MQM-based human evaluations,
we found that document-level translation outperforms sentence-level translation
for ChatGPT. On the other hand, we were not able to determine if enhanced
prompts performed better than simple prompts in our experiments. We also
discovered that ChatGPT-3.5 was preferred by automatic evaluation, but a
tradeoff exists between accuracy (ChatGPT-3.5) and fluency (ChatGPT-4). Lastly,
ChatGPT yields competitive results against two widely-known translation
systems.

AI.tldr: Evaluates ChatGPT (3.5 and 4) for Japanese→English translation across prompt types and translation granularity, using automatic and MQM human evaluations; document-level use helps, prompt enhancements are inconclusive, 3.5 scores higher on automatic accuracy while 4 is judged more fluent; overall performance is competitive with commercial MT.
AI.motivation: Assess whether ChatGPT is a viable Japanese–English MT system, how prompt design and translation scope (sentence vs document) affect quality, and how it compares to established commercial engines under both automatic and human (MQM) evaluation.
AI.method: Compare ChatGPT with simple vs enhanced prompts and sentence- vs document-level translation; evaluate both GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 using automatic metrics and MQM-based human assessments; benchmark against two commercial translation systems.
AI.result: Document-level translation outperforms sentence-level for ChatGPT; no clear advantage of enhanced prompts over simple prompts; automatic metrics prefer ChatGPT-3.5, while MQM reveals a tradeoff: 3.5 is more accurate and 4 is more fluent; overall, ChatGPT is competitive with two widely used MT systems.
AI.conclusion: Context aggregation (document-level) benefits ChatGPT’s JA→EN translation; elaborate prompt engineering yielded limited gains in this setup; evaluation choice shifts model ranking due to accuracy–fluency tradeoffs; both GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 are viable depending on priorities, and ChatGPT is competitive with commercial MT solutions.

title: Real-Time Motion-Controllable Autoregressive Video Diffusion
summary:
Real-time motion-controllable video generation remains challenging due to the
inherent latency of bidirectional diffusion models and the lack of effective
autoregressive (AR) approaches. Existing AR video diffusion models are limited
to simple control signals or text-to-video generation, and often suffer from
quality degradation and motion artifacts in few-step generation. To address
these challenges, we propose AR-Drag, the first RL-enhanced few-step AR video
diffusion model for real-time image-to-video generation with diverse motion
control. We first fine-tune a base I2V model to support basic motion control,
then further improve it via reinforcement learning with a trajectory-based
reward model. Our design preserves the Markov property through a Self-Rollout
mechanism and accelerates training by selectively introducing stochasticity in
denoising steps. Extensive experiments demonstrate that AR-Drag achieves high
visual fidelity and precise motion alignment, significantly reducing latency
compared with state-of-the-art motion-controllable VDMs, while using only 1.3B
parameters. Additional visualizations can be found on our project page:
https://kesenzhao.github.io/AR-Drag.github.io/.

AI.tldr: AR-Drag is an RL-enhanced, few-step autoregressive video diffusion model that delivers real-time, motion-controllable image-to-video generation with high visual fidelity and low latency.
AI.motivation: Real-time motion-controllable video generation is hindered by the latency of bidirectional diffusion models and the quality/motion artifacts of existing few-step autoregressive approaches, which are often limited to simple controls or text-only inputs.
AI.method: Start from a base image-to-video diffusion model and fine-tune it for basic motion control; then apply reinforcement learning with a trajectory-based reward to align motion and quality. Preserve the Markov property via a Self-Rollout mechanism and speed up training by selectively injecting stochasticity during denoising steps. The system targets few-step AR generation with a 1.3B-parameter model.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, AR-Drag achieves higher visual fidelity, tighter motion alignment, and significantly reduced latency versus state-of-the-art motion-controllable video diffusion methods, supporting diverse motion controls in real time with a compact (1.3B) model.
AI.conclusion: Combining RL with few-step autoregressive diffusion—augmented by Self-Rollout and selective denoising stochasticity—overcomes prior latency and artifact issues, enabling practical, real-time, motion-controllable image-to-video generation.

title: Beyond Pass@k: Breadth-Depth Metrics for Reasoning Boundaries
summary:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) has emerged as a
powerful paradigm to improve Large Language Models on reasoning tasks such as
coding, math or logic. To assess the reasoning boundary (the fraction of
problems a model can solve) researchers often report Pass@k at large sampling
budgets. Recent results reveal a crossover phenomenon: while RLVR models
outperform the base model at small k values, the base model usually outperforms
them when sampling a very large number of completions. This has been
interpreted as evidence that base models have a larger reasoning boundary. We
argue that on tasks with discrete answer spaces, such as math with numeric
outputs, Pass@k at large k reflects the increasingly higher chance of success
in the limit of the number of trials rather than genuine reasoning, and can
therefore be misleading. We propose Cover@tau, which measures the fraction of
problems that a model can solve for which at least a tau proportion of
completions are correct. Unlike Pass@k, Cover@tau captures reasoning under an
explicit reliability threshold: models that rely on random guessing degrade
rapidly as tau increases. We evaluate several RLVR models using Cover@tau-based
metrics and illustrate how the relative rankings of popular algorithms change
compared to Pass@1, offering a different perspective on reasoning boundaries.

AI.tldr: Pass@k at large sampling budgets can be misleading for discrete-answer tasks because it rewards chance success; the authors propose Cover@τ, a reliability-aware metric that measures the fraction of problems a model solves with at least τ proportion of correct completions, yielding different—and arguably more meaningful—rankings of RLVR models.
AI.motivation: RLVR models show a “crossover” where they beat base models at small k but lose at very large k under Pass@k. This has been read as base models having a larger reasoning boundary. The authors argue that, in discrete-output tasks (math, coding with exact checks), large-k Pass@k increasingly reflects random guessing rather than genuine reasoning, motivating a metric that captures reliable, not lucky, success.
AI.method: Define Cover@τ: for each task, estimate the share of correct generations; count a task as “covered” if this share ≥ τ; report the fraction of covered tasks across τ levels. Evaluate multiple RLVR models with Cover@τ-derived metrics and compare to Pass@1/Pass@k, analyzing how rankings shift and how performance decays as τ increases.
AI.result: Models that rely on stochastic guessing drop sharply as τ rises, while models with consistent reasoning maintain coverage. The previously observed crossover under large-k Pass@k is shown to be a sampling artifact. Relative rankings of popular RLVR algorithms change under Cover@τ, offering a different view of which models truly expand the reasoning boundary.
AI.conclusion: Pass@k at large k is not a reliable proxy for reasoning in discrete-output tasks; Cover@τ better captures robustness and reliability. Evaluations should include reliability-thresholded metrics like Cover@τ to assess true reasoning boundaries and avoid over-crediting models for chance success.

title: Climate Knowledge in Large Language Models
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed for climate-related
applications, where understanding internal climatological knowledge is crucial
for reliability and misinformation risk assessment. Despite growing adoption,
the capacity of LLMs to recall climate normals from parametric knowledge
remains largely uncharacterized. We investigate the capacity of contemporary
LLMs to recall climate normals without external retrieval, focusing on a
prototypical query: mean July 2-m air temperature 1991-2020 at specified
locations. We construct a global grid of queries at 1{\deg} resolution land
points, providing coordinates and location descriptors, and validate responses
against ERA5 reanalysis. Results show that LLMs encode non-trivial climate
structure, capturing latitudinal and topographic patterns, with
root-mean-square errors of 3-6 {\deg}C and biases of $\pm$1 {\deg}C. However,
spatially coherent errors remain, particularly in mountains and high latitudes.
Performance degrades sharply above 1500 m, where RMSE reaches 5-13 {\deg}C
compared to 2-4 {\deg}C at lower elevations. We find that including geographic
context (country, city, region) reduces errors by 27% on average, with larger
models being most sensitive to location descriptors. While models capture the
global mean magnitude of observed warming between 1950-1974 and 2000-2024, they
fail to reproduce spatial patterns of temperature change, which directly relate
to assessing climate change. This limitation highlights that while LLMs may
capture present-day climate distributions, they struggle to represent the
regional and local expression of long-term shifts in temperature essential for
understanding climate dynamics. Our evaluation framework provides a
reproducible benchmark for quantifying parametric climate knowledge in LLMs and
complements existing climate communication assessments.

AI.tldr: LLMs encode broad climatological normals in their parameters and can approximate present-day July 2‑m temperatures globally with RMSE ~3–6°C and ±1°C bias, but errors grow in mountains/high latitudes; adding geographic context cuts error ~27%. They reflect global mean warming magnitude but fail to reproduce its spatial pattern. The paper offers a reproducible benchmark for quantifying parametric climate knowledge.
AI.motivation: LLMs are being deployed for climate-related tasks where reliability and misinformation risks matter. The community lacks a clear characterization of how well LLMs, without external tools, recall climatological normals from their internal (parametric) knowledge.
AI.method: Construct a global 1° land-grid benchmark querying contemporary LLMs for mean July 2‑m air temperature (1991–2020) at specified coordinates and location descriptors, disallowing external retrieval. Validate responses against ERA5 reanalysis. Quantify RMSE/bias, spatial coherence of errors, elevation dependence (>1500 m vs lower), and the impact of providing geographic context (country/city/region). Assess whether models capture the magnitude and spatial pattern of warming between 1950–1974 and 2000–2024.
AI.result: LLMs capture non-trivial climate structure (latitudinal/topographic gradients). Overall RMSE ≈3–6°C; biases around ±1°C. Errors are spatially coherent and larger in mountains/high latitudes; RMSE rises to 5–13°C above 1500 m vs 2–4°C at lower elevations. Adding geographic context reduces errors by ~27% on average, with larger models most sensitive. Models match the global mean magnitude of observed warming but fail to reproduce its spatial distribution.
AI.conclusion: LLMs contain useful priors for present-day climate normals but are unreliable for regional/local expressions of long-term temperature change, especially at high elevations and latitudes. Geographic context helps but does not resolve core limitations. The proposed evaluation provides a reproducible benchmark that complements climate communication assessments and enables systematic measurement of parametric climate knowledge.

title: Improving Temporal Understanding Logic Consistency in Video-Language Models via Attention Enhancement
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) often generate self-contradictory outputs, which
severely impacts their reliability and hinders their adoption in practical
applications. In video-language models (Video-LLMs), this phenomenon recently
draws the attention of researchers. Specifically, these models fail to provide
logically consistent responses to rephrased questions based on their grounding
outputs. However, the underlying causes of this phenomenon remain
underexplored. In this work, we adopt an interpretability-driven approach to
analyze, statistically summarize, and intervention the potential factors of the
phenomenon. We find that one of the primary reasons for the inconsistency in
responses lies in the inability of cross-modal attention heads to effectively
distinguish video tokens across different timestamps. To address this, we
propose an attention enhancement method called Temporally Conditioned Attention
Sharpening (TCAS), which constructs an enhancement objective based on attention
distinctions to enhance the model's temporal resolution capability, thereby
improving its temporal understanding logic consistency. Experimental results
demonstrate that our method significantly enhances the temporal logic
consistency of Video-LLMs. Further interpretability analyses reveal that our
method indeed improves the temporal discriminability of attention heads,
validating our conclusions. Additionally, our method achieves performance
improvements in general video temporal grounding tasks, highlighting that
temporal logic consistency is a bottleneck in temporal understanding. By
enhancing consistency, our method drives significant progress in video temporal
understanding.

AI.tldr: An interpretability-driven study finds Video-LLMs’ inconsistencies stem from cross-modal attention heads failing to distinguish timestamps; proposes Temporally Conditioned Attention Sharpening (TCAS) to sharpen temporal attention, yielding markedly better temporal logic consistency and improved temporal grounding performance.
AI.motivation: Video-LLMs often answer rephrased, time-sensitive questions inconsistently. The root causes of this temporal logic inconsistency are unclear, limiting reliability and practical deployment. The work aims to diagnose the cause and remedy it.
AI.method: Analyze attention behavior in Video-LLMs via interpretability and statistical summaries; identify weak temporal discriminability in cross-modal attention. Introduce TCAS—an attention enhancement objective that conditions on time and increases attention separation across timestamps to improve temporal resolution and consistency.
AI.result: TCAS significantly increases temporal logic consistency in Video-LLMs; interpretability analyses show enhanced temporal discriminability of attention heads. It also improves results on general video temporal grounding tasks.
AI.conclusion: Temporal logic consistency is a key bottleneck in video understanding. Improving temporal discriminability in attention (via TCAS) both reduces contradictory responses and advances temporal grounding performance, validating the proposed diagnosis and intervention.

title: LLMs Reproduce Human Purchase Intent via Semantic Similarity Elicitation of Likert Ratings
summary:
Consumer research costs companies billions annually yet suffers from panel
biases and limited scale. Large language models (LLMs) offer an alternative by
simulating synthetic consumers, but produce unrealistic response distributions
when asked directly for numerical ratings. We present semantic similarity
rating (SSR), a method that elicits textual responses from LLMs and maps these
to Likert distributions using embedding similarity to reference statements.
Testing on an extensive dataset comprising 57 personal care product surveys
conducted by a leading corporation in that market (9,300 human responses), SSR
achieves 90% of human test-retest reliability while maintaining realistic
response distributions (KS similarity > 0.85). Additionally, these synthetic
respondents provide rich qualitative feedback explaining their ratings. This
framework enables scalable consumer research simulations while preserving
traditional survey metrics and interpretability.

AI.tldr: Introduces semantic similarity rating (SSR), which elicits textual answers from LLMs and maps them to Likert scores via embedding similarity to reference statements, yielding near-human reliability and realistic distributions on industry surveys while preserving qualitative insights.
AI.motivation: Traditional consumer research is expensive, slow, and biased due to panels and limited scale. Directly asking LLMs for numeric ratings gives unrealistic distributions, so there is a need for a scalable method that preserves human-like rating behavior and interpretability.
AI.method: Prompt LLMs for textual, rationale-rich responses; compute embeddings of these texts and compare them to curated reference statements aligned with Likert points; assign scores based on similarity. Evaluate against 57 real personal care product surveys (9,300 human responses) using test–retest reliability and Kolmogorov–Smirnov distribution similarity metrics.
AI.result: SSR attains 90% of human test–retest reliability and maintains realistic response distributions (KS similarity > 0.85). Synthetic respondents also produce qualitative feedback explaining their ratings.
AI.conclusion: SSR offers a scalable, interpretable alternative for consumer research that better matches human rating distributions than direct numeric prompts, preserves traditional survey metrics, and adds qualitative explanations, potentially reducing cost and panel biases.

title: A Survey of Process Reward Models: From Outcome Signals to Process Supervisions for Large Language Models
summary:
Although Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit advanced reasoning ability,
conventional alignment remains largely dominated by outcome reward models
(ORMs) that judge only final answers. Process Reward Models(PRMs) address this
gap by evaluating and guiding reasoning at the step or trajectory level. This
survey provides a systematic overview of PRMs through the full loop: how to
generate process data, build PRMs, and use PRMs for test-time scaling and
reinforcement learning. We summarize applications across math, code, text,
multimodal reasoning, robotics, and agents, and review emerging benchmarks. Our
goal is to clarify design spaces, reveal open challenges, and guide future
research toward fine-grained, robust reasoning alignment.

AI.tldr: Survey of Process Reward Models (PRMs) that score intermediate reasoning steps rather than only final answers, covering data generation, model construction, and deployment (test-time scaling, RL) across multiple domains, with benchmarks, taxonomy, and open challenges for fine-grained reasoning alignment.
AI.motivation: Outcome Reward Models focus on end answers and miss whether the reasoning process is correct, honest, or efficient. The field needs step-level supervision to better align LLM reasoning, reduce reward hacking, and improve reliability and controllability.
AI.method: A systematic literature review mapping the full PRM pipeline: (1) generating process-level data (traces, rationales, trajectories), (2) designing and training PRMs, and (3) using PRMs to guide inference (e.g., step scoring, tree search) and training (RL with process feedback). It synthesizes applications in math, code, text, multimodal reasoning, robotics, and agents, and surveys emerging benchmarks.
AI.result: Provides a taxonomy of PRM data/architectures/objectives, consolidates use cases (test-time scaling, RL), and compiles benchmarks and evaluations across domains. Identifies practical patterns and limitations observed in existing work rather than introducing new empirical results.
AI.conclusion: PRMs are a promising path to fine-grained, robust reasoning alignment, but require better process datasets, reliable evaluation protocols, scalable supervision, and domain transfer. The survey aims to orient research toward principled PRM design and deployment for step-aware, trustworthy reasoning.

title: UniMMVSR: A Unified Multi-Modal Framework for Cascaded Video Super-Resolution
summary:
Cascaded video super-resolution has emerged as a promising technique for
decoupling the computational burden associated with generating high-resolution
videos using large foundation models. Existing studies, however, are largely
confined to text-to-video tasks and fail to leverage additional generative
conditions beyond text, which are crucial for ensuring fidelity in multi-modal
video generation. We address this limitation by presenting UniMMVSR, the first
unified generative video super-resolution framework to incorporate hybrid-modal
conditions, including text, images, and videos. We conduct a comprehensive
exploration of condition injection strategies, training schemes, and data
mixture techniques within a latent video diffusion model. A key challenge was
designing distinct data construction and condition utilization methods to
enable the model to precisely utilize all condition types, given their varied
correlations with the target video. Our experiments demonstrate that UniMMVSR
significantly outperforms existing methods, producing videos with superior
detail and a higher degree of conformity to multi-modal conditions. We also
validate the feasibility of combining UniMMVSR with a base model to achieve
multi-modal guided generation of 4K video, a feat previously unattainable with
existing techniques.

AI.tldr: UniMMVSR is a unified cascaded video super‑resolution framework that conditions on text, images, and videos within a latent diffusion model, delivering sharper, condition‑faithful videos and enabling multi‑modal guided 4K generation when paired with a base model.
AI.motivation: Cascaded VSR can offload the heavy compute of high‑resolution video generation, but prior work mostly targets text‑to‑video and ignores additional generative conditions (e.g., reference images or videos) that are crucial for multi‑modal fidelity and control.
AI.method: Build a unified latent video diffusion VSR model that accepts hybrid‑modal conditions (text, images, videos). Systematically explore condition‑injection strategies, training schemes, and data‑mixture curricula. Devise distinct data construction and condition‑utilization mechanisms tailored to each condition type’s correlation with the target video, so the model can leverage them precisely.
AI.result: Across benchmarks, UniMMVSR surpasses existing methods in detail restoration and adherence to multi‑modal conditions. It also integrates with a base generator to achieve multi‑modal guided 4K video—a capability not attained by prior techniques.
AI.conclusion: A first unified generative VSR framework for hybrid modalities, UniMMVSR improves fidelity and detail while generalizing to high resolutions (4K) via cascaded integration with a base model, showing the viability of multi‑modal conditioned video super‑resolution at scale.

title: QAgent: A modular Search Agent with Interactive Query Understanding
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) excel at natural language tasks but are limited
by their static parametric knowledge, especially in knowledge-intensive task.
Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) mitigates this by integrating external
information. However, (1) traditional RAG struggles with complex query
understanding, and (2) even search agents trained with reinforcement learning
(RL), despite their promise, still face generalization and deployment
challenges. To address these limitations, we propose QAgent, a unified agentic
RAG framework that employs a search agent for adaptive retrieval. This agent
optimizes its understanding of the query through interactive reasoning and
retrieval. To facilitate real-world application, we focus on modular search
agent for query understanding that are plug-and-play in complex systems.
Secifically, the agent follows a multi-step decision process trained with RL to
maximize retrieval quality and support accurate downstream answers. We further
analyze the strengths and weaknesses of end-to-end RL and propose a strategy
that focuses on effective retrieval, thereby enhancing generalization in LLM
applications. Experiments show QAgent excels at QA and serves as a
plug-and-play module for real-world deployment.

AI.tldr: QAgent is a modular, RL-trained search agent for adaptive retrieval in RAG that improves complex query understanding and generalization, leading to stronger QA and practical plug-and-play deployment.
AI.motivation: LLMs have static parametric knowledge; RAG helps but struggles with complex query interpretation. RL-based search agents are promising yet suffer from generalization and deployment hurdles. There is a need for an agentic, modular retrieval component that can robustly understand queries and integrate into real systems.
AI.method: Introduce QAgent, a unified agentic RAG framework where a search agent performs multi-step interactive reasoning and retrieval. The agent is trained with reinforcement learning to maximize retrieval quality, thereby supporting accurate downstream answers. The design emphasizes modularity (plug-and-play) and focuses RL on the retrieval subtask rather than full end-to-end answer optimization. The paper analyzes end-to-end RL’s weaknesses and proposes a retrieval-centric RL strategy to enhance generalization.
AI.result: Across QA experiments, QAgent delivers superior retrieval and answer quality compared to baselines (details not specified in the abstract) and functions effectively as a plug-and-play module suitable for real-world deployment.
AI.conclusion: Focusing RL on adaptive retrieval within a modular agent improves complex query understanding and generalization in RAG systems. QAgent achieves strong QA performance and is practical for deployment as a reusable component.

title: FedDTRE: Federated Dialogue Generation Models Powered by Trustworthiness Evaluation
summary:
With the rapid development of artificial intelligence, dialogue systems have
become a prominent form of human-computer interaction. However, traditional
centralized or fully local training approaches face challenges in balancing
privacy preservation and personalization due to data privacy concerns and
heterogeneous device capabilities. Federated learning, as a representative
distributed paradigm, offers a promising solution. However, existing methods
often suffer from overfitting under limited client data and tend to forget
global information after multiple training rounds, leading to poor
generalization. To address these issues, we propose FedDTRE, a Federated
adaptive aggregation strategy for Dialogue generation based on Trustworthiness
Evaluation. Instead of directly replacing local models with the global model,
FedDTRE leverages trustworthiness scores of both global and local models on a
fairness-oriented evaluation dataset to dynamically regulate the global model's
contribution during local updates. Experimental results demonstrate that
FedDTRE can improve dialogue model performance and enhance the quality of
dialogue generation.

AI.tldr: FedDTRE is a federated learning strategy for dialogue generation that adaptively mixes global and local models using trustworthiness scores, mitigating overfitting and forgetting to improve generalization and response quality.
AI.motivation: Conventional centralized or fully local training for dialogue systems struggles to balance privacy with personalization. While federated learning preserves privacy, it often overfits on limited client data and forgets global knowledge across rounds, degrading generalization and dialogue quality.
AI.method: Introduce FedDTRE, an adaptive aggregation strategy guided by trustworthiness evaluation. Instead of replacing local models with the global model, clients compute trustworthiness scores for both global and local models on a fairness-oriented evaluation set and use these scores to dynamically regulate how much the global model influences local updates, preserving useful local personalization while retaining global knowledge.
AI.result: Experiments show that FedDTRE improves dialogue model performance and the quality of generated responses compared with standard FL baselines that suffer from overfitting and global information forgetting.
AI.conclusion: Trustworthiness-guided, adaptive aggregation in FL helps maintain a better balance between local personalization and global generalization for dialogue systems, leading to higher-quality outputs while respecting privacy constraints.

title: Beyond Textual CoT: Interleaved Text-Image Chains with Deep Confidence Reasoning for Image Editing
summary:
Image editing with natural language has gained significant popularity, yet
existing methods struggle with intricate object intersections and fine-grained
spatial relationships due to the lack of an explicit reasoning process. While
Chain-of-Thought (CoT) has been explored to enhance reasoning, purely textual
CoT or CoT augmented with coordinate information is fundamentally limited in
its ability to represent intricate visual layouts and lacks the necessary
visual cues to guide the generation of fine-grained, pixel-level details. To
address these challenges, we propose Multimodal Reasoning Edit (MURE), a novel
framework that shifts the visual editing process from purely text-based
reasoning to a series of interleaved textual and visual rationales. Our
framework performs image editing using a natively multimodal, interleaved
text-image CoT. This approach generates a step-by-step chain of reasoning where
a textual description is followed by a corresponding visual cue, such as a
positional mask that defined intended edited regions or a representation of new
content. Furthermore, to mitigate the hallucination phenomenon of large
language models, we introduce Multimodal Deep Confidence (MMDC) reasoning
paradigm. This paradigm explores a tree of visual reasoning paths at each step.
By pruning low-quality branches using a deep confidence score from a reward
model, it ensures the model consistently follows a high-quality trajectory
towards the final edited result. The proposed method decomposes complex editing
tasks into interdependent sub-tasks, achieving greater precision at each stage
and yielding high-fidelity edited results. We define the formulation for
interleaved text-image chains and release the first CoT-Edit-14K dataset,
comprising 14K high-quality editing examples. Extensive experiments show that
our method yields significant improvements across three image editing
benchmarks.

AI.tldr: MURE is a multimodal chain-of-thought image editing framework that interleaves textual steps with visual cues (e.g., masks/new content) and uses a tree-search with a reward-model “deep confidence” score to prune weak paths, yielding higher-fidelity edits and better spatial reasoning; it also releases the CoT-Edit-14K dataset and improves results on three benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Text-guided editing struggles with complex spatial relations and fine-grained details because existing methods lack explicit, grounded reasoning. Purely textual CoT (even with coordinates) cannot adequately represent visual layouts or provide pixel-level guidance, and LLM hallucinations further degrade edit quality.
AI.method: MURE formulates editing as an interleaved text-image CoT: each textual rationale is followed by a visual cue (e.g., positional mask or representation of new content) that constrains subsequent edits. To reduce hallucinations and guide decisions, the MMDC paradigm explores a tree of multimodal reasoning steps and uses a reward model to compute deep confidence scores that prune low-quality branches, maintaining a high-quality trajectory. The authors formalize this interleaved chain and train/evaluate with the new CoT-Edit-14K dataset (14K editing examples).
AI.result: Across three image-editing benchmarks, MURE delivers significant improvements in accuracy and fidelity versus prior methods, showing stronger handling of intricate object intersections, spatial relationships, and reduced hallucinations (numbers not specified in the abstract).
