AI.conclusion: Explicit, interleaved multimodal reasoning combined with confidence-guided tree search decomposes complex edits into manageable sub-tasks, improving precision and robustness in text-guided image editing; the formulation and dataset provide a foundation for further research.

title: Revisiting Hallucination Detection with Effective Rank-based Uncertainty
summary:
Detecting hallucinations in large language models (LLMs) remains a
fundamental challenge for their trustworthy deployment. Going beyond basic
uncertainty-driven hallucination detection frameworks, we propose a simple yet
powerful method that quantifies uncertainty by measuring the effective rank of
hidden states derived from multiple model outputs and different layers.
Grounded in the spectral analysis of representations, our approach provides
interpretable insights into the model's internal reasoning process through
semantic variations, while requiring no extra knowledge or additional modules,
thus offering a combination of theoretical elegance and practical efficiency.
Meanwhile, we theoretically demonstrate the necessity of quantifying
uncertainty both internally (representations of a single response) and
externally (different responses), providing a justification for using
representations among different layers and responses from LLMs to detect
hallucinations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method effectively
detects hallucinations and generalizes robustly across various scenarios,
contributing to a new paradigm of hallucination detection for LLM truthfulness.

AI.tldr: They detect LLM hallucinations by quantifying uncertainty via the effective rank of hidden-state representations across layers and multiple generated responses, using spectral analysis to capture semantic variation; theory motivates measuring both intra- and inter-response uncertainty; experiments show robust, efficient detection.
AI.motivation: Hallucinations undermine LLM trustworthiness. Prior uncertainty-driven detectors are limited or require extra knowledge/modules. The authors seek an interpretable, theoretically grounded, and efficient method that leverages internal model signals to assess when an answer is likely unfaithful.
AI.method: Perform spectral analysis of hidden-state representations from different layers and from multiple candidate outputs of the same prompt. Use the effective rank of these representation sets as an uncertainty measure, capturing semantic variation both within a single response (internal) and across different responses (external). The approach is plug-and-play, requiring no auxiliary models or external knowledge, and aims to provide interpretable cues about the model’s reasoning dynamics.
AI.result: They theoretically justify the need to quantify both internal and external uncertainty and empirically show that the effective-rank-based metric detects hallucinations well and generalizes across diverse settings. Experiments suggest strong performance and robustness without extra modules.
AI.conclusion: Measuring effective rank of layerwise and multi-output representations offers a simple, elegant, and practical way to detect hallucinations. The approach is interpretable, efficient, and broadly applicable, supporting a shift toward representation-spectral uncertainty as a paradigm for LLM truthfulness assessment.

title: Everything is Plausible: Investigating the Impact of LLM Rationales on Human Notions of Plausibility
summary:
We investigate the degree to which human plausibility judgments of
multiple-choice commonsense benchmark answers are subject to influence by
(im)plausibility arguments for or against an answer, in particular, using
rationales generated by LLMs. We collect 3,000 plausibility judgments from
humans and another 13,600 judgments from LLMs. Overall, we observe increases
and decreases in mean human plausibility ratings in the presence of
LLM-generated PRO and CON rationales, respectively, suggesting that, on the
whole, human judges find these rationales convincing. Experiments with LLMs
reveal similar patterns of influence. Our findings demonstrate a novel use of
LLMs for studying aspects of human cognition, while also raising practical
concerns that, even in domains where humans are ``experts'' (i.e., common
sense), LLMs have the potential to exert considerable influence on people's
beliefs.

AI.tldr: LLM-generated rationales measurably sway plausibility judgments on commonsense multiple-choice questions for both humans and LLMs: pro-rationales increase, con-rationales decrease perceived plausibility, indicating persuasive power and raising influence risks.
AI.motivation: Test whether LLM explanations can systematically influence human beliefs—even in domains where humans are presumed experts (commonsense)—and evaluate LLMs as instruments for probing human cognition and persuasion.
AI.method: Collect plausibility ratings for answers to commonsense multiple-choice benchmarks under different conditions: with LLM-generated PRO rationales, CON rationales, or no rationale. Obtain 3,000 human judgments and 13,600 LLM judgments; compare mean plausibility shifts across conditions and between humans and LLMs.
AI.result: Human plausibility ratings rise with PRO rationales and fall with CON rationales; LLMs show similar directional effects. The changes indicate that LLM-generated arguments are convincing to both people and models.
AI.conclusion: LLMs can be used to study cognitive influence mechanisms but also pose practical risks by shaping beliefs even in commonsense contexts. Their persuasive capacity warrants caution in deployment and evaluation protocols.

title: Robust Canonicalization through Bootstrapped Data Re-Alignment
summary:
Fine-grained visual classification (FGVC) tasks, such as insect and bird
identification, demand sensitivity to subtle visual cues while remaining robust
to spatial transformations. A key challenge is handling geometric biases and
noise, such as different orientations and scales of objects. Existing remedies
rely on heavy data augmentation, which demands powerful models, or on
equivariant architectures, which constrain expressivity and add cost.
Canonicalization offers an alternative by shielding such biases from the
downstream model. In practice, such functions are often obtained using
canonicalization priors, which assume aligned training data. Unfortunately,
real-world datasets never fulfill this assumption, causing the obtained
canonicalizer to be brittle. We propose a bootstrapping algorithm that
iteratively re-aligns training samples by progressively reducing variance and
recovering the alignment assumption. We establish convergence guarantees under
mild conditions for arbitrary compact groups, and show on four FGVC benchmarks
that our method consistently outperforms equivariant, and canonicalization
baselines while performing on par with augmentation.

AI.tldr: Bootstrapped canonicalization for fine-grained visual classification: iteratively re-align images to remove geometric biases, with convergence guarantees for compact groups; matches strong augmentation and beats equivariant/canonicalization baselines on four datasets.
AI.motivation: FGVC needs sensitivity to subtle cues yet robustness to pose/scale changes. Heavy augmentation requires large models; equivariant architectures restrict expressivity and add cost. Canonicalizers can help but are brittle because real training data are not perfectly aligned, violating common priors.
AI.method: Introduce an iterative bootstrapping algorithm that estimates canonical transformations and re-aligns training samples, progressively reducing pose variance and restoring the alignment assumption. The approach is formulated for arbitrary compact transformation groups and comes with convergence guarantees under mild conditions.
AI.result: Across four FGVC benchmarks, the method consistently outperforms equivariant and canonicalization baselines and achieves performance comparable to strong data augmentation, demonstrating improved robustness to geometric noise.
AI.conclusion: Iterative data re-alignment provides a practical, theory-backed alternative to heavy augmentation and rigid equivariance for FGVC, mitigating geometric biases while preserving model expressivity and generalizing across compact groups.

title: Looking to Learn: Token-wise Dynamic Gating for Low-Resource Vision-Language Modelling
comment: Accepted to the EMNLP 2025 BabyLM Workshop
summary:
Training vision-language models on cognitively-plausible amounts of data
requires rethinking how models integrate multimodal information. Within the
constraints of the Vision track for the BabyLM Challenge 2025, we propose a
lightweight decoder-based architecture with (1) token-wise dynamic gating for
adaptive fusion of linguistic and visual cues, (2) feature modulation and
channel attention to maximise the utility of limited visual information and (3)
auxiliary contrastive objectives for visual grounding. Evaluation on five
benchmarks (BLiMP, BLiMP Supplement, EWoK, Winoground and VQA) shows
competitive or superior performance to multimodal baselines. More notably, our
dynamic gate discovers interpretable patterns without explicit supervision,
favouring visual cues for content words and linguistic cues for function words.
While we identify limitations in the Challenge constraints, such as the
information bottleneck created by global image embeddings and training
instability from the dataset split, our findings establish dynamic gating as a
powerful tool for efficient multimodal learning, offering both interpretability
and performance even under severe constraints.

AI.tldr: Proposes a lightweight decoder-only vision–language model with token-wise dynamic gating, feature modulation/channel attention, and auxiliary contrastive grounding, achieving competitive-to-superior results on BLiMP, BLiMP Supplement, EWoK, Winoground, and VQA under BabyLM Vision constraints. The gate yields interpretable patterns (visual for content words, linguistic for function words); limitations include global image embedding bottlenecks and training instability from the dataset split.
AI.motivation: Make multimodal models sample-efficient and cognitively plausible by learning to integrate visual and linguistic information under strict data and architectural constraints (BabyLM Vision track), while retaining interpretability.
AI.method: A lightweight decoder-based architecture that (1) uses token-wise dynamic gating to adaptively fuse visual and textual signals, (2) applies feature modulation and channel attention to maximize limited visual information, and (3) incorporates auxiliary contrastive objectives to improve visual grounding. Operates with global image embeddings due to challenge constraints.
AI.result: On five benchmarks (BLiMP, BLiMP Supplement, EWoK, Winoground, VQA), the model is competitive or better than multimodal baselines. The gating mechanism discovers interpretable behavior without supervision, preferring visual cues for content words and linguistic cues for function words.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic gating is an effective, interpretable mechanism for efficient multimodal learning under severe data constraints, though performance is limited by the use of global image embeddings and training instability from dataset splits. The approach offers a promising path toward data-efficient VLMs.

title: The Price of Thought: A Multilingual Analysis of Reasoning, Performance, and Cost of Negotiation in Large Language Models
summary:
Negotiation is a fundamental challenge for AI agents, as it requires an
ability to reason strategically, model opponents, and balance cooperation with
competition. We conduct the first comprehensive study systematically evaluating
the effect of (LLM-)reasoning on the negotiation abilities of both commercial
and open-weight LLMs, and do this across three languages. Using a self-play
setup across three diverse dialogue games, we analyse trade-offs between
performance and cost, the language consistency of reasoning processes, and the
nature of strategic adaptation exhibited by models. Our findings show that
enabling reasoning-that is, scaling test time compute-significantly improves
negotiation outcomes by enhancing collaboration and helping models overcome
task complexities, but comes at a substantial computational cost: reasoning
improves GPT-5's performance by 31.4 % while increasing its cost by nearly 400
%. Most critically, we uncover a significant multilingual reasoning
distinction: open-weight models consistently switch to English for their
internal reasoning steps, even when negotiating in German or Italian (and thus
possibly impacting potential explainability gains through the disclosure of
reasoning traces), while leading commercial models maintain language
consistency between their reasoning and final output.

AI.tldr: Reasoning at test time substantially improves LLM negotiation performance across languages and games but incurs large computational costs; open-weight models often “think” in English even when negotiating in other languages, whereas commercial models keep reasoning-language consistent.
AI.motivation: Negotiation requires strategic reasoning, opponent modeling, and balancing cooperation vs. competition. The authors aim to quantify how enabling explicit reasoning affects negotiation quality, its cost–performance trade-off, cross-language consistency of reasoning, and models’ strategic adaptation—an area lacking a comprehensive, multilingual evaluation.
AI.method: Self-play evaluations on three diverse dialogue negotiation games across three languages (English, German, Italian). Compare commercial and open-weight LLMs with and without explicit (scaled) test-time reasoning. Measure negotiation outcomes, compute cost, language used in internal reasoning traces, and evidence of strategic adaptation.
AI.result: Enabling reasoning significantly boosts outcomes by fostering collaboration and handling task complexity (e.g., GPT-5 +31.4% performance) but increases compute cost sharply (~4×). Open-weight models frequently switch internal reasoning to English even when the dialogue is in German or Italian, while leading commercial models preserve reasoning-language consistency.
AI.conclusion: Test-time reasoning is effective but expensive; practitioners face a clear cost–quality trade-off. The multilingual inconsistency in open-weight models’ internal reasoning challenges explainability and transparency, whereas commercial models avoid this mismatch. Future work should target efficient, language-consistent reasoning techniques.

title: InstructUDrag: Joint Text Instructions and Object Dragging for Interactive Image Editing
summary:
Text-to-image diffusion models have shown great potential for image editing,
with techniques such as text-based and object-dragging methods emerging as key
approaches. However, each of these methods has inherent limitations: text-based
methods struggle with precise object positioning, while object dragging methods
are confined to static relocation. To address these issues, we propose
InstructUDrag, a diffusion-based framework that combines text instructions with
object dragging, enabling simultaneous object dragging and text-based image
editing. Our framework treats object dragging as an image reconstruction
process, divided into two synergistic branches. The moving-reconstruction
branch utilizes energy-based gradient guidance to move objects accurately,
refining cross-attention maps to enhance relocation precision. The text-driven
editing branch shares gradient signals with the reconstruction branch, ensuring
consistent transformations and allowing fine-grained control over object
attributes. We also employ DDPM inversion and inject prior information into
noise maps to preserve the structure of moved objects. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that InstructUDrag facilitates flexible, high-fidelity image
editing, offering both precision in object relocation and semantic control over
image content.

AI.tldr: InstructUDrag is a diffusion-based image editing framework that unifies text instructions with object dragging, enabling precise object relocation and simultaneous semantic edits while preserving object structure.
AI.motivation: Text-only editing poorly controls object position, while drag-only methods are limited to static relocation without semantic changes. There is a need for a method that combines accurate spatial control with fine-grained, text-driven attribute editing in a single workflow.
AI.method: Treat object dragging as image reconstruction in a dual-branch diffusion framework. A moving-reconstruction branch uses energy-based gradient guidance and refines cross-attention maps to accurately move objects. A text-driven editing branch shares gradients with the reconstruction branch to ensure consistent transformations and fine-grained attribute control. DDPM inversion and prior injection into noise maps preserve the structure of moved objects during editing.
AI.result: Experiments show flexible, high-fidelity edits that achieve accurate object relocation combined with controllable, text-driven semantic changes.
AI.conclusion: By coupling energy-guided relocation with text-conditioned editing and structure-preserving inversion, InstructUDrag overcomes the positioning limits of text-only methods and the semantic rigidity of drag-only methods, enabling precise and coherent image edits.

title: AutoMLGen: Navigating Fine-Grained Optimization for Coding Agents
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have shown impressive performance in general
programming tasks. However, in Machine Learning Engineering (MLE) scenarios
such as AutoML and Kaggle competitions, achieving high performance depends
heavily on expert intervention and repeated adjustments rather than simply
generating correct code. When applied directly to these tasks, LLMs often lack
fine-grained domain priors, and existing MLE approaches that use linear or
tree-structured searches limit knowledge transfer to adjacent hierarchical
links. As a result, they cannot leverage past full trajectories or share
information across branches, limiting self-evolving ability and search space
diversity. To address these limitations, we introduce AutoMLGen, an LLM-based
coding agent that integrates a domain knowledge base for high-quality prior
guidance and Monte Carlo Graph Search (MCGS) for efficient exploration. MCGS
retains the tree-guided exploration of MCTS while embedding a graph structure
into the expansion stage to enable dynamic path reorganization, historical
trajectory reuse, and multi-solution fusion to support both self-evolution and
collaborative learning. Combined with fine-grained operator sets, this design
improves stability and accelerates convergence. Evaluation on the MLE-Bench
shows that AutoMLGen achieves state-of-the-art performance in numerous
dimensions, such as the average medal rate and the valid submission rate, under
a 12-hour budget (half the standard runtime). The code is available at
https://github.com/Alpha-Innovator/InternAgent.

AI.tldr: AutoMLGen is an LLM-based coding agent for ML engineering that couples a curated domain knowledge base with a Monte Carlo Graph Search (MCGS) planner to reuse trajectories and share information across branches, yielding faster, more stable search and state-of-the-art results on MLE-Bench within a 12-hour budget.
AI.motivation: LLMs can write correct code but underperform in AutoML/Kaggle-like settings where high scores require iterative expert tuning. Existing linear or tree searches lack fine-grained domain priors and cannot reuse full historical trajectories or transfer knowledge across branches, limiting self-evolution and exploration diversity.
AI.method: Integrate a domain knowledge base to provide high-quality priors, and replace pure tree search with Monte Carlo Graph Search (MCGS): retain MCTS-style exploration but embed a graph during expansion to reorganize paths, reuse history, and fuse multiple solution branches. Use fine-grained operator sets to stabilize behavior and speed convergence.
AI.result: On MLE-Bench, AutoMLGen achieves state-of-the-art across several dimensions, notably average medal rate and valid submission rate, under a 12-hour time budget (half the standard runtime).
AI.conclusion: Graph-augmented search plus domain priors enables an LLM agent to self-evolve and collaborate across solution branches, improving stability, exploration efficiency, and end performance in MLE tasks. Empirical results on MLE-Bench support the approach’s effectiveness and practical efficiency.

title: Lossless Vocabulary Reduction for Auto-Regressive Language Models
summary:
Tokenization -- the process of decomposing a given text into a sequence of
subwords called tokens -- is one of the key components in the development of
language models. Particularly, auto-regressive language models generate texts
token by token, i.e., by predicting the next-token distribution given the
previous ones, and thus tokenization directly affects their efficiency in text
generation. Since each language model has their own vocabulary as a set of
possible tokens, they struggle to cooperate with each other at the level of
next-token distributions such as model ensemble. In this paper, we establish a
theoretical framework of lossless vocabulary reduction, which efficiently
converts a given auto-regressive language model into the one with an
arbitrarily small vocabulary without any loss in accuracy. As an application,
we demonstrate that language models with different tokenization can cooperate
with each other efficiently through their maximal common vocabulary.

AI.tldr: They propose a lossless vocabulary reduction framework that converts any autoregressive LM to use an arbitrarily small (e.g., shared) vocabulary, enabling exact cooperation across models with different tokenizations.
AI.motivation: Tokenization shapes generation efficiency in autoregressive LMs and prevents direct cooperation (e.g., ensembling) because models expose different next‑token vocabularies. A method is needed to harmonize vocabularies without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.method: A theoretical construction that transforms a given autoregressive LM into an equivalent model over a smaller vocabulary while preserving the full next‑token/string distributions. The framework also identifies a maximal common vocabulary to align multiple models. The conversion is designed to be computationally efficient and lossless.
AI.result: They prove the existence of lossless vocabulary reduction to arbitrarily small vocabularies and demonstrate that models with different tokenizations can interoperate efficiently by projecting to their maximal common vocabulary.
AI.conclusion: Tokenization can be decoupled from accuracy: one can reduce or standardize vocabularies and enable cross‑model cooperation (e.g., ensembling) without retraining or performance loss by operating on a shared, reduced vocabulary.

title: Fine-grained text-driven dual-human motion generation via dynamic hierarchical interaction
summary:
Human interaction is inherently dynamic and hierarchical, where the dynamic
refers to the motion changes with distance, and the hierarchy is from
individual to inter-individual and ultimately to overall motion. Exploiting
these properties is vital for dual-human motion generation, while existing
methods almost model human interaction temporally invariantly, ignoring
distance and hierarchy. To address it, we propose a fine-grained dual-human
motion generation method, namely FineDual, a tri-stage method to model the
dynamic hierarchical interaction from individual to inter-individual. The first
stage, Self-Learning Stage, divides the dual-human overall text into individual
texts through a Large Language Model, aligning text features and motion
features at the individual level. The second stage, Adaptive Adjustment Stage,
predicts interaction distance by an interaction distance predictor, modeling
human interactions dynamically at the inter-individual level by an
interaction-aware graph network. The last stage, Teacher-Guided Refinement
Stage, utilizes overall text features as guidance to refine motion features at
the overall level, generating fine-grained and high-quality dual-human motion.
Extensive quantitative and qualitative evaluations on dual-human motion
datasets demonstrate that our proposed FineDual outperforms existing
approaches, effectively modeling dynamic hierarchical human interaction.

AI.tldr: FineDual is a tri-stage framework for dual-human motion generation that explicitly models hierarchical (individual → inter-individual → overall) and distance-dependent dynamics, yielding finer and more realistic interactions than prior methods.
AI.motivation: Human interactions are hierarchical and distance-dependent over time, but most existing dual-human motion generators treat interactions as temporally invariant and ignore the hierarchy (individual, inter-individual, overall). This gap limits realism and controllability of generated two-person motions.
AI.method: Tri-stage pipeline: (1) Self-Learning Stage: Use a large language model to decompose an overall interaction description into per-person texts; align each individual’s text features with corresponding motion features. (2) Adaptive Adjustment Stage: Predict time-varying interaction distance via a distance predictor and model dynamic inter-person interactions using an interaction-aware graph network conditioned on the predicted distances. (3) Teacher-Guided Refinement Stage: Use overall (global) text features as guidance/teacher to refine the motion features jointly at the pair level, producing fine-grained dual-human motion.
AI.result: On dual-human motion datasets, FineDual achieves better quantitative metrics and qualitative realism than existing approaches, particularly in capturing dynamic distance changes and hierarchical interaction structure.
AI.conclusion: Modeling both hierarchy and dynamic distance across stages leads to higher-quality dual-human motion generation. Leveraging LLM-based text decomposition, distance-aware graph modeling, and global text-guided refinement effectively captures fine-grained, realistic two-person interactions.

title: CaRT: Teaching LLM Agents to Know When They Know Enough
summary:
Many tasks require learned models to strategically gather relevant
information over multiple rounds of interaction before actually acting on a
task. Strategic information gathering requires models to know not only how to
effectively acquire information, but also when to stop gathering information
and make a decision, in order to avoid overthinking or getting derailed when
acting. In this paper, we formalize this problem and introduce Counterfactuals
and Reasoning for Termination (CaRT), an approach for teaching LLMs when to
stop seeking information. To appropriately learn when to terminate, CaRT
fine-tunes LLMs using counterfactual pairs of trajectories, one where
termination is appropriate and a minimally modified version of the same
trajectory where it is not. It trains the LLM to explain the rationale for the
termination decision in either case via verbal reasoning, and imbues this
capability into the base LLM via fine-tuning. We instantiate CaRT in two
domains: interactive medical diagnosis and math problem solving. In both
domains, we find that CaRT improves the efficiency of information gathering and
task success rate compared to other fine-tuning methods.

AI.tldr: CaRT fine-tunes LLMs with counterfactual trajectory pairs and verbal rationales to teach when to stop gathering information, improving efficiency and success in interactive diagnosis and math problem solving versus other fine-tuning methods.
AI.motivation: Many real-world tasks require multi-step information gathering and, crucially, knowing when to stop to avoid overthinking or derailment—something current LLMs struggle with. The work aims to formalize and address the termination decision in interactive reasoning tasks.
AI.method: Introduce Counterfactuals and Reasoning for Termination (CaRT): create paired trajectories of the same interaction, one where stopping is correct and a minimally edited variant where it is not; train the LLM to both decide termination and explain the rationale via verbal reasoning; fine-tune to imbue this capability into the base model. Evaluated in interactive medical diagnosis and math problem solving.
AI.result: Across both domains, CaRT leads to more efficient information gathering and higher task success rates compared to alternative fine-tuning baselines.
AI.conclusion: Counterfactual, explanation-driven fine-tuning is an effective way to teach LLMs when to terminate information seeking, reducing overthinking and improving outcomes across domains.

title: Evaluating LLM-Generated Legal Explanations for Regulatory Compliance in Social Media Influencer Marketing
comment:
Accepted for publication at the Natural Legal Language Processing
  Workshop (NLLP) 2025, co-located with EMNLP
summary:
The rise of influencer marketing has blurred boundaries between organic
content and sponsored content, making the enforcement of legal rules relating
to transparency challenging. Effective regulation requires applying legal
knowledge with a clear purpose and reason, yet current detection methods of
undisclosed sponsored content generally lack legal grounding or operate as
opaque "black boxes". Using 1,143 Instagram posts, we compare gpt-5-nano and
gemini-2.5-flash-lite under three prompting strategies with controlled levels
of legal knowledge provided. Both models perform strongly in classifying
content as sponsored or not (F1 up to 0.93), though performance drops by over
10 points on ambiguous cases. We further develop a taxonomy of reasoning
errors, showing frequent citation omissions (28.57%), unclear references
(20.71%), and hidden ads exhibiting the highest miscue rate (28.57%). While
adding regulatory text to the prompt improves explanation quality, it does not
consistently improve detection accuracy. The contribution of this paper is
threefold. First, it makes a novel addition to regulatory compliance technology
by providing a taxonomy of common errors in LLM-generated legal reasoning to
evaluate whether automated moderation is not only accurate but also legally
robust, thereby advancing the transparent detection of influencer marketing
content. Second, it features an original dataset of LLM explanations annotated
by two students who were trained in influencer marketing law. Third, it
combines quantitative and qualitative evaluation strategies for LLM
explanations and critically reflects on how these findings can support
advertising regulatory bodies in automating moderation processes on a solid
legal foundation.

AI.tldr: Evaluates small LLMs for legally robust detection of sponsored Instagram posts, finding strong but brittle accuracy; offers an error taxonomy and annotated explanations showing that adding regulatory text improves reasoning quality more than raw detection accuracy.
AI.motivation: Transparency rules for influencer marketing are hard to enforce because sponsored content blends with organic posts. Existing detectors are either legally ungrounded or opaque, so regulators need methods that are both accurate and capable of legally sound, explainable reasoning.
AI.method: Using 1,143 Instagram posts, the authors compare two compact LLMs (gpt-5-nano, gemini-2.5-flash-lite) across three prompting strategies that vary how much legal/regulatory text is provided. They assess classification (sponsored vs not) and analyze explanation quality via a taxonomy of legal reasoning errors. Explanations are annotated by two students trained in influencer marketing law; both quantitative and qualitative evaluations are performed.
AI.result: Both models reach strong overall classification (F1 up to 0.93) but drop by >10 points on ambiguous cases. Common reasoning errors include citation omissions (28.57%), unclear references (20.71%), and high miscues on hidden ads (28.57%). Supplying regulatory text improves explanation quality but does not reliably increase detection accuracy.
AI.conclusion: LLMs can aid moderation of influencer marketing but remain fragile on ambiguous/hidden ads and often lack legally rigorous reasoning. The provided error taxonomy, annotated explanation dataset, and mixed-method evaluation support more transparent, legally grounded automation for regulators, while highlighting the need to reduce citation gaps and ambiguity-related failures.

title: Adaptive Gradient Calibration for Single-Positive Multi-Label Learning in Remote Sensing Image Scene Classification
summary:
Multi-label classification (MLC) offers a more comprehensive semantic
understanding of Remote Sensing (RS) imagery compared to traditional
single-label classification (SLC). However, obtaining complete annotations for
MLC is particularly challenging due to the complexity and high cost of the
labeling process. As a practical alternative, single-positive multi-label
learning (SPML) has emerged, where each image is annotated with only one
relevant label, and the model is expected to recover the full set of labels.
While scalable, SPML introduces significant supervision ambiguity, demanding
specialized solutions for model training. Although various SPML methods have
been proposed in the computer vision domain, research in the RS context remains
limited. To bridge this gap, we propose Adaptive Gradient Calibration (AdaGC),
a novel and generalizable SPML framework tailored to RS imagery. AdaGC adopts a
gradient calibration (GC) mechanism combined with Mixup and a dual exponential
moving average (EMA) module for robust pseudo-label generation. To maximize
AdaGC's effectiveness, we introduce a simple yet theoretically grounded
indicator to adaptively trigger GC after an initial warm-up stage based on
training dynamics, thereby guaranteeing the effectiveness of GC in mitigating
overfitting to label noise. Extensive experiments on two benchmark RS datasets
under two distinct label noise types demonstrate that AdaGC achieves
state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance while maintaining strong robustness across
diverse settings.

AI.tldr: Proposes AdaGC, an adaptive gradient-calibration framework for single-positive multi-label learning in remote sensing, combining Mixup and a dual-EMA pseudo-labeling scheme with an adaptive trigger, achieving SOTA and robust performance under different label-noise types on two benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Remote sensing imagery benefits from multi-label classification, but full annotations are expensive. SPML reduces labeling cost by providing only one positive label per image, yet it introduces severe supervision ambiguity and label-noise overfitting. Existing SPML work in computer vision does not adequately address RS-specific challenges, motivating a tailored, robust approach.
AI.method: AdaGC integrates: (1) gradient calibration (GC) to correct misleading gradients caused by missing/ambiguous labels; (2) Mixup for augmentation; (3) a dual exponential moving average (EMA) module to produce stable pseudo-labels; and (4) a simple, theory-backed indicator that monitors training dynamics and adaptively triggers GC after a warm-up period to avoid premature or noisy calibration.
AI.result: Across two RS benchmarks and two types of label noise, AdaGC attains state-of-the-art performance and maintains strong robustness across diverse experimental settings.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive Gradient Calibration effectively mitigates SPML supervision ambiguity and label-noise overfitting in RS. Its adaptive trigger and dual-EMA pseudo-labeling make it generalizable and stable, yielding SOTA accuracy and robustness while reducing annotation burden.

title: FlowSearch: Advancing deep research with dynamic structured knowledge flow
summary:
Deep research is an inherently challenging task that demands both breadth and
depth of thinking. It involves navigating diverse knowledge spaces and
reasoning over complex, multi-step dependencies, which presents substantial
challenges for agentic systems. To address this, we propose FlowSearch, a
multi-agent framework that actively constructs and evolves a dynamic structured
knowledge flow to drive subtask execution and reasoning. FlowSearch is capable
of strategically planning and expanding the knowledge flow to enable parallel
exploration and hierarchical task decomposition, while also adjusting the
knowledge flow in real time based on feedback from intermediate reasoning
outcomes and insights. FlowSearch achieves state-of-the-art performance on both
general and scientific benchmarks, including GAIA, HLE, GPQA and TRQA,
demonstrating its effectiveness in multi-disciplinary research scenarios and
its potential to advance scientific discovery. The code is available at
https://github.com/Alpha-Innovator/InternAgent.

AI.tldr: FlowSearch is a multi-agent system that builds and adaptively updates a structured "knowledge flow" to coordinate parallel, hierarchical reasoning for complex research tasks, achieving state-of-the-art results on GAIA, HLE, GPQA, and TRQA.
AI.motivation: Deep research requires both breadth and depth, involving multi-step dependencies across diverse knowledge spaces. Existing agentic systems struggle to plan, decompose, and integrate such complex reasoning effectively.
AI.method: Introduce FlowSearch, a multi-agent framework that constructs a dynamic, structured knowledge flow. It plans and expands this flow to enable parallel exploration and hierarchical task decomposition, and it continually revises the flow in real time using feedback from intermediate reasoning outcomes.
AI.result: Demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on general and scientific benchmarks (GAIA, HLE, GPQA, TRQA), indicating robustness across multi-disciplinary research scenarios. The implementation is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: By actively managing and evolving a structured knowledge flow, FlowSearch improves complex, multi-step research capabilities and shows potential to accelerate scientific discovery; code release supports reproducibility and adoption.

title: Interpreting LLM-as-a-Judge Policies via Verifiable Global Explanations
summary:
Using LLMs to evaluate text, that is, LLM-as-a-judge, is increasingly being
used at scale to augment or even replace human annotations. As such, it is
imperative that we understand the potential biases and risks of doing so. In
this work, we propose an approach for extracting high-level concept-based
global policies from LLM-as-a-Judge. Our approach consists of two algorithms:
1) CLoVE (Contrastive Local Verifiable Explanations), which generates
verifiable, concept-based, contrastive local explanations and 2) GloVE (Global
Verifiable Explanations), which uses iterative clustering, summarization and
verification to condense local rules into a global policy. We evaluate GloVE on
seven standard benchmarking datasets for content harm detection. We find that
the extracted global policies are highly faithful to decisions of the
LLM-as-a-Judge. Additionally, we evaluated the robustness of global policies to
text perturbations and adversarial attacks. Finally, we conducted a user study
to evaluate user understanding and satisfaction with global policies.

AI.tldr: They introduce CLoVE and GloVE to distill verifiable, concept-based local and global decision rules from LLM-as-a-judge, showing high faithfulness, robustness to perturbations/adversaries, and good user satisfaction on harm-detection benchmarks.
AI.motivation: LLM-as-a-judge is increasingly used to replace human annotations, but its opaque criteria can embed biases and risks. The authors aim to surface, understand, and audit the high-level policies that govern such judgments in a verifiable, human-interpretable way.
AI.method: Two-step framework: (1) CLoVE creates contrastive, concept-based local explanations that are verifiable (e.g., by perturbing inputs to test concept influence); (2) GloVE clusters and summarizes these local rules iteratively, verifying them to form a concise global policy capturing the LLM judge’s behavior. They evaluate on seven content-harm detection datasets, test robustness to text perturbations and adversarial attacks, and run a user study for interpretability/usability.
AI.result: Extracted global policies closely match (high faithfulness to) LLM-as-a-judge decisions; show robustness under perturbations and adversarial attacks; and are rated by users as understandable and satisfactory.
AI.conclusion: Concept-based, verifiable rule extraction can reliably summarize and audit LLM-judge behavior at scale, improving transparency and robustness for content harm assessment and potentially other evaluation tasks.

title: One Stone with Two Birds: A Null-Text-Null Frequency-Aware Diffusion Models for Text-Guided Image Inpainting
summary:
Text-guided image inpainting aims at reconstructing the masked regions as per
text prompts, where the longstanding challenges lie in the preservation for
unmasked regions, while achieving the semantics consistency between unmasked
and inpainted masked regions. Previous arts failed to address both of them,
always with either of them to be remedied. Such facts, as we observed, stem
from the entanglement of the hybrid (e.g., mid-and-low) frequency bands that
encode varied image properties, which exhibit different robustness to text
prompts during the denoising process. In this paper, we propose a
null-text-null frequency-aware diffusion models, dubbed \textbf{NTN-Diff}, for
text-guided image inpainting, by decomposing the semantics consistency across
masked and unmasked regions into the consistencies as per each frequency band,
while preserving the unmasked regions, to circumvent two challenges in a row.
Based on the diffusion process, we further divide the denoising process into
early (high-level noise) and late (low-level noise) stages, where the
mid-and-low frequency bands are disentangled during the denoising process. As
observed, the stable mid-frequency band is progressively denoised to be
semantically aligned during text-guided denoising process, which, meanwhile,
serves as the guidance to the null-text denoising process to denoise
low-frequency band for the masked regions, followed by a subsequent text-guided
denoising process at late stage, to achieve the semantics consistency for
mid-and-low frequency bands across masked and unmasked regions, while preserve
the unmasked regions. Extensive experiments validate the superiority of
NTN-Diff over the state-of-the-art diffusion models to text-guided diffusion
models. Our code can be accessed from https://github.com/htyjers/NTN-Diff.

AI.tldr: NTN-Diff is a frequency-aware, staged diffusion inpainting method that uses text-guided mid-frequency denoising to steer a null-text low-frequency reconstruction, then refines with late-stage text guidance—preserving unmasked regions while enforcing semantic consistency across masked/unmasked areas, outperforming prior text-guided models.
AI.motivation: Text-guided image inpainting struggles to simultaneously (1) keep unmasked content unchanged and (2) ensure semantic consistency between generated (masked) and original (unmasked) regions. The authors argue this stems from entanglement of frequency bands with different sensitivity to text prompts during denoising.
AI.method: Decompose consistency by frequency bands and split the diffusion process into early (high-noise) and late (low-noise) stages. During early denoising, the mid-frequency band is text-guided to achieve semantic alignment; this stable mid-frequency signal then guides a null-text denoising pass for the low-frequency content in masked regions. A subsequent late-stage text-guided denoising enforces final semantic consistency while preserving unmasked areas.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, NTN-Diff outperforms state-of-the-art text-guided diffusion inpainting methods; specific metrics aren’t listed in the abstract, and code is provided at the linked repository.
AI.conclusion: Frequency-aware disentanglement plus staged text/null-text guidance addresses both fidelity of unmasked regions and cross-region semantic alignment. The approach is empirically superior to SOTA baselines for text-guided inpainting.

title: Agent Learning via Early Experience
summary:
A long-term goal of language agents is to learn and improve through their own
experience, ultimately outperforming humans in complex, real-world tasks.
However, training agents from experience data with reinforcement learning
remains difficult in many environments, which either lack verifiable rewards
(e.g., websites) or require inefficient long-horizon rollouts (e.g., multi-turn
tool use). As a result, most current agents rely on supervised fine-tuning on
expert data, which is challenging to scale and generalizes poorly. This
limitation stems from the nature of expert demonstrations: they capture only a
narrow range of scenarios and expose the agent to limited environment
diversity. We address this limitation with a middle-ground paradigm we call
early experience: interaction data generated by the agent's own actions, where
the resulting future states serve as supervision without reward signals. Within
this paradigm we study two strategies of using such data: (1) Implicit world
modeling, which uses collected states to ground the policy in environment
dynamics; and (2) Self-reflection, where the agent learns from its suboptimal
actions to improve reasoning and decision-making. We evaluate across eight
diverse environments and multiple model families. Our approaches consistently
improve effectiveness and out-of-domain generalization, highlighting the value
of early experience. Moreover, in environments with verifiable rewards, our
results provide promising signals that early experience offers a strong
foundation for subsequent reinforcement learning, positioning it as a practical
bridge between imitation learning and fully experience-driven agents.

AI.tldr: Proposes “early experience,” a middle ground between imitation learning and RL: train language agents on their own interaction data without reward signals, via implicit world modeling and self-reflection, yielding better effectiveness and out-of-domain generalization and serving as a strong prelude to RL.
AI.motivation: RL on language agents is hard where rewards are unverifiable or sparse/long-horizon; supervised fine-tuning on expert demos does not scale and generalizes poorly because demos cover narrow scenarios and limited environment diversity.
AI.method: Collect agent-generated interaction trajectories (“early experience”) and use resulting future states as supervision. Two strategies: (1) Implicit world modeling—ground the policy in environment dynamics using collected states; (2) Self-reflection—learn from suboptimal actions to improve reasoning/decision-making. Evaluate across eight diverse environments and multiple model families.
AI.result: Across eight environments, both strategies consistently improve task effectiveness and out-of-domain generalization. In settings with verifiable rewards, early experience provides strong signals and a solid initialization for subsequent RL.
AI.conclusion: Early experience is a practical bridge between imitation learning and fully experience-driven agents, improving generalization without explicit rewards and bootstrapping later RL.

title: Mitigating Judgment Preference Bias in Large Language Models through Group-Based Polling
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) as automatic evaluators, commonly referred to as
LLM-as-a-Judge, have also attracted growing attention. This approach plays a
vital role in aligning LLMs with human judgments, providing accurate and
reliable assessments. However, LLM-based judgment models often exhibit judgment
preference bias during the evaluation phase, tending to favor responses
generated by themselves, undermining the reliability of their judgments. This
paper introduces the Group-Based Polling Optimization (Genii), an unsupervised
multi-agent collaborative optimization framework that mitigates the inherent
judgment preference bias of judgment models. Specifically, Genii integrates
various LLM-based judgment models into a multi-agent system and simulates the
interactive client-server polling mechanism to optimize each client agent
unsupervisedly. Our experiments demonstrate that Genii outperforms supervised
models trained on annotated judgment data, while requiring no human-labeled
annotations. Genii consistently improves performance across different client
agents during the polling, even when weaker models act as server agents.
Further analysis reveals that Genii effectively mitigates judgment preference
bias of LLM-based judgment models, demonstrating its effectiveness. All codes
are available at https://github.com/NEUIR/Genii.

AI.tldr: Genii is an unsupervised, multi-agent polling framework that reduces self-preference bias in LLM-as-a-Judge and outperforms supervised judgment models without requiring human labels.
AI.motivation: LLM-based evaluators are crucial for aligning models with human judgments but often favor their own model-generated answers, undermining evaluation reliability.
AI.method: Combine diverse LLM-based judgment models into a multi-agent system and run an interactive client–server polling process that unsupervisedly optimizes each client agent, using group-based collaboration to attenuate individual model biases.
AI.result: Across experiments, Genii surpasses supervised baselines trained on annotated judgment data, consistently improves multiple client agents during polling, remains effective even when weaker models serve as servers, and measurably reduces judgment preference bias.
AI.conclusion: An unsupervised multi-agent polling approach can mitigate preference bias in LLM judges while improving accuracy and robustness without labeled data; code is publicly available for replication.

title: A Multimodal Depth-Aware Method For Embodied Reference Understanding
summary:
Embodied Reference Understanding requires identifying a target object in a
visual scene based on both language instructions and pointing cues. While prior
works have shown progress in open-vocabulary object detection, they often fail
in ambiguous scenarios where multiple candidate objects exist in the scene. To
address these challenges, we propose a novel ERU framework that jointly
leverages LLM-based data augmentation, depth-map modality, and a depth-aware
decision module. This design enables robust integration of linguistic and
embodied cues, improving disambiguation in complex or cluttered environments.
Experimental results on two datasets demonstrate that our approach
significantly outperforms existing baselines, achieving more accurate and
reliable referent detection.

AI.tldr: Proposes an ERU framework that fuses language, pointing, and depth via LLM-augmented training and a depth-aware decision module, yielding state-of-the-art disambiguation and referent detection on two datasets.
AI.motivation: Open-vocabulary detectors struggle when multiple plausible objects exist; disambiguating referents in cluttered scenes requires better integration of linguistic instructions and embodied (pointing) cues, with 3D awareness to resolve spatial ambiguity.
AI.method: A joint ERU pipeline combining: (1) LLM-based data augmentation to diversify language/pointing expressions; (2) explicit depth-map modality to inject geometric context; and (3) a depth-aware decision module that fuses linguistic and embodied signals with depth to choose the target object.
AI.result: Across two datasets, the approach significantly outperforms strong baselines, delivering higher accuracy and reliability in referent detection, particularly in complex or cluttered scenes with multiple candidates.
AI.conclusion: Integrating LLM-augmented training, depth sensing, and depth-aware fusion improves embodied reference disambiguation. The framework achieves superior performance and robustness and suggests depth-guided, multimodal reasoning is key for ERU.

title: How to Teach Large Multimodal Models New Skills
comment:
In submission. Code is available at
  https://github.com/jessemelpolio/LMM_CL
summary:
How can we teach large multimodal models (LMMs) new skills without erasing
prior abilities? We study sequential fine-tuning on five target skills while
monitoring general ability on eight held-out benchmarks across three model
families. We observe that apparent "forgetting" on held-out tasks after narrow
fine-tuning can partly recover at later stages. We trace this behavior to a
measurable shift in the output token distribution, manifested through a simple
counting-bias probe that co-varies with forgetting. Guided by this picture, we
identify two simple, robust tuning recipes that learn strongly while limiting
drift: (i) updating only the self-attention projection layers, and (ii)
updating only the MLP Gate&Up while freezing the Down projection. Across models
and tasks, these choices deliver strong target gains while largely preserving
held-out performance. Code is available at
https://github.com/jessemelpolio/LMM_CL

AI.tldr: Sequential fine-tuning of LMMs causes apparent forgetting driven by output-distribution drift; probing this drift (counting bias) explains recoveries, and constraining updates to specific submodules (self-attention projections or MLP Gate&Up) learns new skills while largely preserving prior abilities.
AI.motivation: Enable LMMs to acquire new skills over time without catastrophic forgetting of general abilities. Existing narrow fine-tuning often hurts held-out performance; the authors seek a simple, robust approach that works across model families and tasks, and a mechanistic indicator of forgetting.
AI.method: Fine-tune three LMM families sequentially on five target skills while tracking eight held-out benchmarks. Analyze forgetting and partial recovery, and relate it to a measurable shift in output token distribution via a counting-bias probe. Propose and test two constrained-update recipes: (i) update only self-attention projection layers; (ii) update only MLP Gate&Up while freezing the Down projection. Compare target-skill gains and held-out performance.
AI.result: Narrow fine-tuning induces apparent forgetting that can partially recover later; the counting-bias probe co-varies with forgetting, indicating output-distribution drift. The two constrained-update recipes achieve strong gains on target skills while substantially preserving performance on held-out benchmarks across models and tasks.
AI.conclusion: Apparent forgetting in sequential LMM fine-tuning reflects controllable output-distribution drift. Limiting parameter updates to specific attention or MLP submodules curbs drift, enabling effective continual skill learning with minimal degradation of prior abilities; the recipes are simple, robust, and broadly applicable.

title: AI Knowledge Assist: An Automated Approach for the Creation of Knowledge Bases for Conversational AI Agents
comment: Accepted to the EMNLP 2025 Industry Track
summary:
The utilization of conversational AI systems by leveraging Retrieval
Augmented Generation (RAG) techniques to solve customer problems has been on
the rise with the rapid progress of Large Language Models (LLMs). However, the
absence of a company-specific dedicated knowledge base is a major barrier to
the integration of conversational AI systems in contact centers. To this end,
we introduce AI Knowledge Assist, a system that extracts knowledge in the form
of question-answer (QA) pairs from historical customer-agent conversations to
automatically build a knowledge base. Fine-tuning a lightweight LLM on internal
data demonstrates state-of-the-art performance, outperforming larger
closed-source LLMs. More specifically, empirical evaluation on 20 companies
demonstrates that the proposed AI Knowledge Assist system that leverages the
LLaMA-3.1-8B model eliminates the cold-start gap in contact centers by
achieving above 90% accuracy in answering information-seeking questions. This
enables immediate deployment of RAG-powered chatbots.

AI.tldr: They present AI Knowledge Assist, which auto-builds company-specific knowledge bases by extracting QA pairs from historical customer–agent conversations, enabling immediate deployment of high-accuracy RAG chatbots.
AI.motivation: Contact centers lack dedicated, up-to-date knowledge bases, creating a cold-start barrier for deploying RAG-powered conversational AI. Manual KB creation is slow and costly; existing large closed models may be overkill or inaccessible.
AI.method: Mine historical customer–agent logs to extract question–answer pairs, assemble them into a KB, and fine-tune a lightweight open model (LLaMA‑3.1‑8B) on internal data. Use the resulting KB and model within a RAG pipeline; compare against larger closed-source LLMs across multiple companies.
AI.result: Across 20 companies, the system achieves >90% accuracy on information-seeking questions and outperforms larger closed-source LLMs, effectively removing the cold-start gap for contact centers.
AI.conclusion: Automatically deriving a KB from past conversations and fine-tuning a compact open LLM can deliver state-of-the-art, production-ready performance for contact centers, enabling cost-effective and immediate RAG chatbot deployment.

title: Learning Neural Exposure Fields for View Synthesis
comment:
Accepted to NeurIPS 2025. Project page available at
  https://www.m-niemeyer.github.io/nexf/index.html
summary:
Recent advances in neural scene representations have led to unprecedented
quality in 3D reconstruction and view synthesis. Despite achieving high-quality
results for common benchmarks with curated data, outputs often degrade for data
that contain per image variations such as strong exposure changes, present,
e.g., in most scenes with indoor and outdoor areas or rooms with windows. In
this paper, we introduce Neural Exposure Fields (NExF), a novel technique for
robustly reconstructing 3D scenes with high quality and 3D-consistent
appearance from challenging real-world captures. In the core, we propose to
learn a neural field predicting an optimal exposure value per 3D point,
enabling us to optimize exposure along with the neural scene representation.
While capture devices such as cameras select optimal exposure per image/pixel,
we generalize this concept and perform optimization in 3D instead. This enables
accurate view synthesis in high dynamic range scenarios, bypassing the need of
post-processing steps or multi-exposure captures. Our contributions include a
novel neural representation for exposure prediction, a system for joint
optimization of the scene representation and the exposure field via a novel
neural conditioning mechanism, and demonstrated superior performance on
challenging real-world data. We find that our approach trains faster than prior
works and produces state-of-the-art results on several benchmarks improving by
over 55% over best-performing baselines.

AI.tldr: NExF adds a learned per-3D-point exposure field to neural scene representations, enabling HDR-consistent view synthesis from challenging captures and outperforming prior methods (>55% on benchmarks) while training faster.
AI.motivation: Neural scene methods produce high quality on curated data but fail when images exhibit strong per-frame exposure variations (e.g., indoor/outdoor transitions, windows). Cameras choose exposure per image/pixel; this mismatch causes inconsistent appearance and degraded reconstructions. A mechanism is needed to handle HDR and exposure variability consistently in 3D.
AI.method: Learn a neural exposure field that predicts an optimal exposure value for each 3D point. Jointly optimize this exposure field with the neural scene representation using a new conditioning mechanism so that rendering accounts for per-point exposure during training and inference. This generalizes exposure selection from 2D (per image/pixel) to 3D, avoiding multi-exposure captures or post-processing.
AI.result: On challenging real-world data and several benchmarks, NExF achieves state-of-the-art quality with over 55% improvement versus the best prior baselines and converges faster. It produces accurate, 3D-consistent appearance in high dynamic range scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Optimizing exposure in 3D, rather than per image, resolves inconsistencies from exposure variation and yields robust, high-quality reconstructions and view synthesis without extra capture or post-processing, establishing a new SOTA and faster training.

title: DACIP-RC: Domain Adaptive Continual Instruction Pre-Training via Reading Comprehension on Business Conversations
comment:
Accepted to the EMNLP 2025 Industry Track. Equal contribution from
  the first four authors
summary:
The rapid advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs) have enabled their
adoption in real-world industrial scenarios for various natural language
processing tasks. However, the high inference cost of large-scale LLMs makes
their deployment impractical, necessitating the use of smaller models. Despite
their efficiency, smaller LLMs lack robust zero-shot instruction-following
capabilities across diverse domains, limiting their adaptability to dynamic
user requirements. Traditional fine-tuning approaches exacerbate this issue by
inducing catastrophic forgetting, reducing the model's generalization ability
for unseen tasks. In this paper, we propose Domain Adaptive Continual
Instruction Pre-Training via Reading Comprehension (DACIP-RC), a continual
pre-training technique that enhances smaller LLMs' domain adaptability for
business conversational tasks. Unlike conventional pre-training approaches that
rely on next-token prediction, DACIP-RC generates diverse task instructions and
responses via reading comprehension on conversation transcripts, enabling
better instruction generalization. Our empirical evaluations demonstrate that
DACIP-RC significantly improves zero-shot generalization across a wide range of
business conversational tasks, including meeting summarization, action item
generation, and call purpose identification. To the best of our knowledge, this
is the first work to apply instruction pre-training on business conversational
data, providing insights into how industries can leverage proprietary datasets
for domain adaptation.

AI.tldr: Introduces DACIP-RC, a continual instruction pre-training approach that uses reading comprehension over business conversation transcripts to create diverse instruction–response pairs, markedly boosting small LLMs’ zero-shot performance on conversational business tasks while mitigating catastrophic forgetting.
AI.motivation: Large LLMs are costly to deploy; smaller LLMs are efficient but weak at zero-shot instruction following across domains. Standard fine-tuning worsens generalization via catastrophic forgetting. There’s a need to adapt smaller LLMs to evolving, domain-specific business tasks using proprietary data.
AI.method: Domain Adaptive Continual Instruction Pre-Training via Reading Comprehension (DACIP-RC): instead of next-token prediction, it generates varied task instructions and responses by performing reading comprehension on conversation transcripts. This continual pre-training aims to expand instruction-following capability and maintain prior knowledge for business conversational domains.
AI.result: Empirical studies show significant gains in zero-shot generalization on multiple business conversational tasks (meeting summarization, action item extraction, call purpose detection) compared to conventional approaches.
AI.conclusion: DACIP-RC enhances domain adaptability of small LLMs for business dialogue tasks without the typical forgetting seen in fine-tuning. It is claimed as the first to apply instruction pre-training on business conversational data, offering a pathway for industries to leverage proprietary datasets for domain adaptation.

title: LTCA: Long-range Temporal Context Attention for Referring Video Object Segmentation
summary:
Referring Video Segmentation (RVOS) aims to segment objects in videos given
linguistic expressions. The key to solving RVOS is to extract long-range
temporal context information from the interactions of expressions and videos to
depict the dynamic attributes of each object. Previous works either adopt
attention across all the frames or stack dense local attention to achieve a
global view of temporal context. However, they fail to strike a good balance
between locality and globality, and the computation complexity significantly
increases with the increase of video length. In this paper, we propose an
effective long-range temporal context attention (LTCA) mechanism to aggregate
global context information into object features. Specifically, we aggregate the
global context information from two aspects. Firstly, we stack sparse local
attentions to balance the locality and globality. We design a dilated window
attention across frames to aggregate local context information and perform such
attention in a stack of layers to enable a global view. Further, we enable each
query to attend to a small group of keys randomly selected from a global pool
to enhance the globality. Secondly, we design a global query to interact with
all the other queries to directly encode the global context information.
Experiments show our method achieves new state-of-the-art on four referring
video segmentation benchmarks. Notably, our method shows an improvement of
11.3% and 8.3% on the MeViS valu and val datasets respectively.

AI.tldr: They propose LTCA, an efficient long-range temporal attention module for referring video object segmentation that balances local and global context via stacked dilated window attention, random global key sampling, and a global query token, achieving state-of-the-art results with large gains on MeViS.
AI.motivation: RVOS needs long-range temporal reasoning over video conditioned on language. Existing methods either use full attention across frames (computationally expensive) or dense local attention stacks (limited global view and still costly as videos grow). The paper aims to capture dynamic object attributes with a better locality–globality trade-off and lower complexity as video length increases.
AI.method: Long-Range Temporal Context Attention (LTCA): (1) Stack sparse local attentions using dilated window attention across frames to expand receptive field over layers; augment each query with attention to a small, randomly sampled set of keys from a global pool to inject global context efficiently. (2) Introduce a dedicated global query that interacts with all queries to directly encode and distribute global context. The aggregated global context is fused into object features for language-guided segmentation.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on four RVOS benchmarks. On MeViS, LTCA improves performance by 11.3% and 8.3% on the valu and val splits, respectively (metrics unspecified in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Efficiently aggregating long-range temporal context with a balanced local/global attention design yields superior RVOS accuracy while mitigating the quadratic cost of full-frame attention. LTCA provides a scalable mechanism that generalizes across benchmarks and significantly boosts performance on MeViS.

title: Beyond Over-Refusal: Scenario-Based Diagnostics and Post-Hoc Mitigation for Exaggerated Refusals in LLMs
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) frequently produce false refusals, declining
benign requests that contain terms resembling unsafe queries. We address this
challenge by introducing two comprehensive benchmarks: the Exaggerated Safety
Benchmark (XSB) for single-turn prompts, annotated with "Focus" keywords that
identify refusal-inducing triggers, and the Multi-turn Scenario-based
Exaggerated Safety Benchmark (MS-XSB), which systematically evaluates refusal
calibration in realistic, context-rich dialog settings. Our benchmarks reveal
that exaggerated refusals persist across diverse recent LLMs and are especially
pronounced in complex, multi-turn scenarios. To mitigate these failures, we
leverage post-hoc explanation methods to identify refusal triggers and deploy
three lightweight, model-agnostic approaches, ignore-word instructions, prompt
rephrasing, and attention steering, at inference time, all without retraining
or parameter access. Experiments on four instruction-tuned Llama models
demonstrate that these strategies substantially improve compliance on safe
prompts while maintaining robust safety protections. Our findings establish a
reproducible framework for diagnosing and mitigating exaggerated refusals,
highlighting practical pathways to safer and more helpful LLM deployments.

AI.tldr: LLMs often over-refuse safe queries that contain sensitive-looking terms. This work introduces two benchmarks to diagnose the issue and proposes lightweight, inference-time fixes that reduce false refusals without weakening safety.
AI.motivation: Current safety tuning can lead models to decline benign requests when they detect safety-adjacent tokens, harming usability and trust. The field lacks standardized, realistically contextualized evaluations and practical mitigation tactics that don’t require retraining or parameter access.
AI.method: 1) Build two benchmarks: XSB (single-turn, with annotated “Focus” trigger keywords) and MS-XSB (multi-turn, scenario-based) to measure refusal calibration. 2) Use post-hoc explanation to surface refusal triggers. 3) Apply three model-agnostic, inference-time interventions—ignore-word instructions, prompt rephrasing, and attention steering—without retraining or internal weights access. Evaluate on four instruction-tuned Llama models.
AI.result: Benchmarks show exaggerated refusals are prevalent across modern LLMs, especially in complex multi-turn dialogs. The three interventions significantly increase compliance on safe prompts while maintaining strong safety safeguards on unsafe ones, as demonstrated on four Llama variants.
AI.conclusion: The paper offers a reproducible framework for diagnosing and mitigating exaggerated refusals, pairing robust evaluation (single- and multi-turn) with practical, lightweight fixes. This advances safer yet more helpful LLM behavior and suggests deployable paths without model retraining.

title: Unlocking 3D Affordance Segmentation with 2D Semantic Knowledge
summary:
Affordance segmentation aims to parse 3D objects into functionally distinct
parts, bridging recognition and interaction for applications in robotic
manipulation, embodied AI, and AR. While recent studies leverage visual or
textual prompts to guide this process, they often rely on point cloud encoders
as generic feature extractors, overlooking the intrinsic challenges of 3D data
such as sparsity, noise, and geometric ambiguity. As a result, 3D features
learned in isolation frequently lack clear and semantically consistent
functional boundaries. To address this bottleneck, we propose a
semantic-grounded learning paradigm that transfers rich semantic knowledge from
large-scale 2D Vision Foundation Models (VFMs) into the 3D domain.
Specifically, We introduce Cross-Modal Affinity Transfer (CMAT), a pre-training
strategy that aligns a 3D encoder with lifted 2D semantics and jointly
optimizes reconstruction, affinity, and diversity to yield semantically
organized representations. Building on this backbone, we further design the
Cross-modal Affordance Segmentation Transformer (CAST), which integrates
multi-modal prompts with CMAT-pretrained features to generate precise,
prompt-aware segmentation maps. Extensive experiments on standard benchmarks
demonstrate that our framework establishes new state-of-the-art results for 3D
affordance segmentation.

AI.tldr: They pretrain a 3D encoder by transferring rich 2D semantic knowledge (from VFMs) via a cross-modal affinity objective (CMAT), then use a transformer (CAST) that fuses multi-modal prompts with the pretrained 3D features to produce precise, prompt-aware affordance segmentations, achieving SOTA on benchmarks.
AI.motivation: 3D affordance segmentation suffers from point cloud sparsity, noise, and geometric ambiguity. Generic 3D encoders used as feature extractors often yield semantically inconsistent boundaries. Leveraging the strong semantics of large 2D VFMs could ground 3D features and improve functional part parsing.
AI.method: CMAT pretraining aligns a 3D encoder with semantics lifted from 2D VFMs, jointly optimizing reconstruction, cross-modal affinity, and feature diversity to produce semantically organized 3D representations. On top, CAST (a transformer) integrates multi-modal prompts with CMAT-pretrained features to generate prompt-aware affordance segmentation maps.
AI.result: On standard 3D affordance segmentation benchmarks, the approach establishes new state-of-the-art performance (details not provided in abstract).
AI.conclusion: Semantic grounding via cross-modal transfer from 2D VFMs enables clearer, more consistent 3D affordance boundaries. The CMAT+CAST pipeline effectively leverages prompts and yields improved, precise affordance segmentation outcomes.

title: ARM2: Adaptive Reasoning Model with Vision Understanding and Executable Code
summary:
Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) often suffer from the ``over-thinking''
problem, generating unnecessarily long reasoning on simple tasks. Some
strategies have been proposed to mitigate this issue, such as length penalties
or routing mechanisms, but they are typically heuristic and task-specific,
lacking a general framework for adaptive reasoning. In this paper, we present
ARM2, a unified model that adaptively balances reasoning performance and
efficiency across multiple formats through a reinforcement learning framework
augmented with length-aware optimization. Beyond conventional natural language
inference, ARM2 integrates vision understanding, extending its applicability to
multimodal. Moreover, ARM2 integrates executable code into reasoning, enabling
substantial reductions in token cost while preserving task performance compared
to long CoT. Experiments demonstrate that ARM2 achieves performance on par with
traditional reasoning models trained with GRPO, while reducing token usage by
over 70% on average. We further conduct extensive analyses to validate the
effectiveness of ARM2 and the soundness of its design.

AI.tldr: ARM2 is a unified, reinforcement learning–trained adaptive reasoning model that optimizes both accuracy and brevity, works across text and vision, and can invoke executable code—cutting token usage by >70% while matching GRPO-trained baselines.
AI.motivation: Large Reasoning Models tend to over‑think, producing unnecessarily long chains of thought on simple tasks. Existing fixes (length penalties, routers) are heuristic and task‑specific, lacking a general, principled way to trade off reasoning depth and efficiency across modalities.
AI.method: ARM2 uses a reinforcement learning framework augmented with length‑aware optimization: the reward jointly accounts for task performance and token cost. The model is unified across modalities (language and vision) and can incorporate executable code within its reasoning to replace verbose natural language steps when beneficial.
AI.result: Across evaluations, ARM2 attains performance on par with GRPO‑trained reasoning models while reducing token usage by over 70% on average. Incorporating code maintains task accuracy compared to long chain‑of‑thought reasoning but with much lower token cost. Extensive analyses support these findings.
AI.conclusion: A general, adaptive approach to reasoning that balances efficiency and accuracy is feasible. ARM2 offers a unified, multimodal framework that curbs over‑thinking, preserves performance, and substantially lowers token costs, suggesting a practical path for scalable, efficient reasoning systems.

title: LinVideo: A Post-Training Framework towards O(n) Attention in Efficient Video Generation
comment: Code will be released upon acceptance
summary:
Video diffusion models (DMs) have enabled high-quality video synthesis.
However, their computation costs scale quadratically with sequence length
because self-attention has quadratic complexity. While linear attention lowers
the cost, fully replacing quadratic attention requires expensive pretraining
due to the limited expressiveness of linear attention and the complexity of
spatiotemporal modeling in video generation. In this paper, we present
LinVideo, an efficient data-free post-training framework that replaces a target
number of self-attention modules with linear attention while preserving the
original model's performance. First, we observe a significant disparity in the
replaceability of different layers. Instead of manual or heuristic choices, we
frame layer selection as a binary classification problem and propose selective
transfer, which automatically and progressively converts layers to linear
attention with minimal performance impact. Additionally, to overcome the
ineffectiveness and inefficiency of existing objectives for this transfer
process, we introduce an anytime distribution matching (ADM) objective that
aligns the distributions of samples across any timestep along the sampling
trajectory. This objective is efficient and recovers model performance.
Extensive experiments show that our method achieves a 1.25-2.00x speedup while
preserving generation quality, and our 4-step distilled model further delivers
a 15.92x latency reduction with minimal visual quality drop.

AI.tldr: LinVideo is a data-free post-training framework that selectively replaces self-attention layers in video diffusion models with linear attention using an anytime distribution matching objective, preserving quality while accelerating inference by 1.25–2.00× (up to 15.92× with 4-step distillation).
AI.motivation: Video diffusion models suffer quadratic compute/memory growth from self-attention over long spatiotemporal sequences. Fully switching to linear attention typically degrades performance or requires costly pretraining due to limited expressiveness and the difficulty of spatiotemporal modeling. A practical, low-cost way to gain linear attention efficiency while retaining original model quality is needed.
AI.method: Two key components: (1) Selective transfer—treat each attention layer’s replaceability as a binary classification problem and progressively convert only the most replaceable layers from quadratic to linear attention, avoiding manual heuristics; (2) Anytime Distribution Matching (ADM)—a data-free objective that aligns the student’s sample distributions to the teacher’s at any timestep along the diffusion sampling trajectory, improving efficiency and recovery of generation quality. The framework post-trains a target model without original training data.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, LinVideo achieves 1.25–2.00× speedup while preserving generation quality; with an additional 4-step distillation, latency is reduced by 15.92× with only minimal visual quality degradation.
AI.conclusion: Selective, data-free replacement of self-attention with linear attention, guided by ADM, provides a practical path to faster video diffusion without retraining from scratch, maintaining high visual quality and substantially reducing latency.

title: METRICALARGS: A Taxonomy for Studying Metrical Poetry with LLMs
summary:
Prior NLP work studying poetry has focused primarily on automatic poem
generation and summarization. Many languages have well-studied traditions of
poetic meter which enforce constraints on a poem in terms of syllable and
