phoneme patterns. Such advanced literary forms offer opportunities for probing
deeper reasoning and language understanding in Large Language Models (LLMs) and
their ability to follow strict pre-requisites and rules. In this paper, we
introduce MetricalARGS, the first taxonomy of poetry-related NLP tasks designed
to evaluate LLMs on metrical poetry across four dimensions: Analysis,
Retrieval, Generation, and Support. We discuss how these tasks relate to
existing NLP tasks, addressing questions around datasets and evaluation
metrics. Taking Telugu as our example language, we illustrate how the taxonomy
can be used in practice. MetricalARGS highlights the broader possibilities for
understanding the capabilities and limitations of today's LLMs through the lens
of metrical poetry.

AI.tldr: Introduces MetricalARGS, a taxonomy to evaluate LLMs on metrical poetry via four task families—Analysis, Retrieval, Generation, and Support—illustrated with Telugu and linked to datasets and metrics.
AI.motivation: Prior NLP work on poetry focused on generation/summarization, overlooking metrical constraints that require precise rule-following (syllable/phoneme patterns). Such constraints can rigorously probe LLM reasoning and compliance with formal rules across languages.
AI.method: Propose a structured taxonomy (MetricalARGS) of poetry-related NLP tasks spanning four dimensions, relate each to existing NLP task types, and discuss appropriate datasets and evaluation metrics. Demonstrate the taxonomy’s practical use with a Telugu case study.
AI.result: A conceptual framework and task suite for metrical-poetry evaluation; mapping to existing tasks; guidance on datasets/metrics; and a Telugu instantiation showing feasibility. No large-scale empirical benchmark results are reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: MetricalARGS provides a systematic way to assess LLM capabilities and limitations on rule-governed poetic forms, enabling deeper evaluation and informing future dataset creation, metrics, and cross-lingual studies.

title: Evaluating Small Vision-Language Models on Distance-Dependent Traffic Perception
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) are becoming increasingly powerful,
demonstrating strong performance on a variety of tasks that require both visual
and textual understanding. Their strong generalisation abilities make them a
promising component for automated driving systems, which must handle unexpected
corner cases. However, to be trusted in such safety-critical applications, a
model must first possess a reliable perception system. Moreover, since critical
objects and agents in traffic scenes are often at a distance, we require
systems that are not "shortsighted", i.e., systems with strong perception
capabilities at both close (up to 20 meters) and long (30+ meters) range. With
this in mind, we introduce Distance-Annotated Traffic Perception Question
Answering (DTPQA), the first Visual Question Answering (VQA) benchmark focused
solely on perception-based questions in traffic scenes, enriched with distance
annotations. By excluding questions that require reasoning, we ensure that
model performance reflects perception capabilities alone. Since automated
driving hardware has limited processing power and cannot support large VLMs,
our study centers on smaller VLMs. More specifically, we evaluate several
state-of-the-art (SOTA) small VLMs on DTPQA and show that, despite the
simplicity of the questions, these models significantly underperform compared
to humans (~60% average accuracy for the best-performing small VLM versus ~85%
human performance). However, it is important to note that the human sample size
was relatively small, which imposes statistical limitations. We also identify
specific perception tasks, such as distinguishing left from right, that remain
particularly challenging for these models.

AI.tldr: They introduce DTPQA, a perception-only, distance-annotated VQA benchmark for traffic scenes, showing small VLMs perform far below humans and struggle with spatial distinctions (e.g., left vs right), especially relevant for long-range perception demands in automated driving.
AI.motivation: Automated driving needs trustworthy perception, including long-range detection of distant agents. While VLMs generalize well, safety-critical deployment requires validating pure visual perception separate from reasoning, and on resource-constrained hardware that favors small VLMs.
AI.method: Create a VQA benchmark (DTPQA) restricted to perception questions and enriched with distance annotations to assess close and long-range capabilities. Evaluate several SOTA small VLMs against a human baseline, and analyze task-specific weaknesses (e.g., left/right discrimination).
AI.result: Best small VLM achieves about 60% average accuracy versus ~85% human accuracy; notable failures include left–right discrimination. The human evaluation has a small sample size, limiting statistical strength.
AI.conclusion: There is a substantial perception gap between small VLMs and humans on traffic perception, particularly for spatial distinctions, indicating current small VLMs are not yet reliable for safety-critical automotive perception. DTPQA offers a focused benchmark to drive improvements, though broader human studies are needed.

title: Training-Free Group Relative Policy Optimization
summary:
Recent advances in Large Language Model (LLM) agents have demonstrated their
promising general capabilities. However, their performance in specialized
real-world domains often degrades due to challenges in effectively integrating
external tools and specific prompting strategies. While methods like agentic
reinforcement learning have been proposed to address this, they typically rely
on costly parameter updates, for example, through a process that uses
Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) followed by a Reinforcement Learning (RL) phase
with Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to alter the output
distribution. However, we argue that LLMs can achieve a similar effect on the
output distribution by learning experiential knowledge as a token prior, which
is a far more lightweight approach that not only addresses practical data
scarcity but also avoids the common issue of overfitting. To this end, we
propose Training-Free Group Relative Policy Optimization (Training-Free GRPO),
a cost-effective solution that enhances LLM agent performance without any
parameter updates. Our method leverages the group relative semantic advantage
instead of numerical ones within each group of rollouts, iteratively distilling
high-quality experiential knowledge during multi-epoch learning on a minimal
ground-truth data. Such knowledge serves as the learned token prior, which is
seamlessly integrated during LLM API calls to guide model behavior. Experiments
on mathematical reasoning and web searching tasks demonstrate that
Training-Free GRPO, when applied to DeepSeek-V3.1-Terminus, significantly
improves out-of-domain performance. With just a few dozen training samples,
Training-Free GRPO outperforms fine-tuned small LLMs with marginal training
data and cost.

AI.tldr: They introduce Training-Free GRPO, a no-parameter-update method that distills experiential knowledge into a token prior to steer LLM agents, yielding notable out-of-domain gains on math reasoning and web search with only a few training examples.
AI.motivation: Agentic LLMs underperform in specialized real-world tasks; current fixes (SFT + RL like GRPO) are costly, data-hungry, and can overfit. The authors seek a lightweight alternative that can improve tool use and prompting without model parameter updates.
AI.method: Training-Free Group Relative Policy Optimization: instead of optimizing model weights via numerical rewards, they compute a group-relative semantic advantage among rollout candidates, iteratively select/distill high-quality behaviors over multiple epochs using minimal ground-truth data, and encode this distilled experiential knowledge as a token prior. This prior is injected at inference time (API calls) to guide outputs, avoiding parameter tuning.
AI.result: Applied to DeepSeek-V3.1-Terminus on mathematical reasoning and web search, the approach significantly improves out-of-domain performance. With only a few dozen training samples, it surpasses small LLMs that were fine-tuned, at lower data and computational cost.
AI.conclusion: Learning and injecting a token prior via Training-Free GRPO can approximate the distributional benefits of RL fine-tuning without parameter updates, offering a cost-effective, data-efficient way to boost LLM agent performance while mitigating overfitting.

title: SPICE: Simple and Practical Image Clarification and Enhancement
summary:
We introduce a simple and efficient method to enhance and clarify images.
More specifically, we deal with low light image enhancement and clarification
of hazy imagery (hazy/foggy images, images containing sand dust, and underwater
images). Our method involves constructing an image filter to simulate low-light
or hazy conditions and deriving approximate reverse filters to minimize
distortions in the enhanced images. Experimental results show that our approach
is highly competitive and often surpasses state-of-the-art techniques in
handling extremely dark images and in enhancing hazy images. A key advantage of
our approach lies in its simplicity: Our method is implementable with just a
few lines of MATLAB code.

AI.tldr: A simple, filter-based method enhances low-light and hazy images by simulating the degradation and applying approximate inverse filters, often outperforming state-of-the-art while being implementable in a few lines of MATLAB.
AI.motivation: Low-light and hazy (fog, sand dust, underwater) images suffer from reduced visibility and contrast, hampering downstream perception and human viewing. Existing methods can be complex, data-hungry, or fail on extremely dark scenes. A simpler, robust approach is sought.
AI.method: Design a forward image filter that models low-light or haze formation; derive approximate reverse (inverse) filters that undo the simulated degradations to restore/enhance the image. Emphasizes simplicity and computational efficiency, suitable for compact MATLAB implementation.
AI.result: Experiments indicate the approach is competitive and often superior to state-of-the-art, particularly on extremely dark images and hazy scenes, producing clearer, less distorted outputs.
AI.conclusion: Model-driven approximate inverse filtering provides a simple, effective, and general solution for low-light enhancement and dehazing, with strong empirical performance and minimal implementation complexity.

title: Memory Retrieval and Consolidation in Large Language Models through Function Tokens
summary:
The remarkable success of large language models (LLMs) stems from their
ability to consolidate vast amounts of knowledge into the memory during
pre-training and to retrieve it from the memory during inference, enabling
advanced capabilities such as knowledge memorization, instruction-following and
reasoning. However, the mechanisms of memory retrieval and consolidation in
LLMs remain poorly understood. In this paper, we propose the function token
hypothesis to explain the workings of LLMs: During inference, function tokens
activate the most predictive features from context and govern next token
prediction (memory retrieval). During pre-training, predicting the next tokens
(usually content tokens) that follow function tokens increases the number of
learned features of LLMs and updates the model parameters (memory
consolidation). Function tokens here roughly correspond to function words in
linguistics, including punctuation marks, articles, prepositions, and
conjunctions, in contrast to content tokens. We provide extensive experimental
evidence supporting this hypothesis. Using bipartite graph analysis, we show
that a small number of function tokens activate the majority of features. Case
studies further reveal how function tokens activate the most predictive
features from context to direct next token prediction. We also find that during
pre-training, the training loss is dominated by predicting the next content
tokens following function tokens, which forces the function tokens to select
the most predictive features from context.

AI.tldr: Proposes the function token hypothesis: a small set of function tokens (e.g., punctuation, articles, prepositions, conjunctions) act as controllers that activate predictive features for next-token prediction (retrieval), while learning is driven by predicting content tokens that follow them (consolidation). Empirical analyses support that these tokens dominate feature activation and training loss dynamics.
AI.motivation: Despite LLMs’ success at memorization, instruction-following, and reasoning, how they retrieve and consolidate “memory” is unclear. The paper seeks a mechanistic account linking token types to feature activation and learning dynamics.
AI.method: Formulate the function token hypothesis. Use bipartite graph analysis between tokens and features to quantify which tokens activate which features; conduct case studies showing activation patterns during inference; analyze pre-training loss composition focusing on content tokens following function tokens.
AI.result: Few function tokens activate the majority of features; case studies show function tokens select the most predictive contextual features to steer next-token prediction; pre-training loss is largely from predicting content tokens that follow function tokens, implying these tokens are trained to pick predictive features.
AI.conclusion: Function tokens operate as gating/selector mechanisms that orchestrate both retrieval and consolidation in LLMs. Recognizing their central role offers a mechanistic explanation for LLM behavior and suggests focusing on function tokens to interpret and potentially improve training and inference.

title: Hyperspectral data augmentation with transformer-based diffusion models
comment:
10 pages, 2 figures, accepted at SPIE REMOTE SENSING conference 16-20
  September 2024 Edinburgh, United Kingdom
summary:
The introduction of new generation hyperspectral satellite sensors, combined
with advancements in deep learning methodologies, has significantly enhanced
the ability to discriminate detailed land-cover classes at medium-large scales.
However, a significant challenge in deep learning methods is the risk of
overfitting when training networks with small labeled datasets. In this work,
we propose a data augmentation technique that leverages a guided diffusion
model. To effectively train the model with a limited number of labeled samples
and to capture complex patterns in the data, we implement a lightweight
transformer network. Additionally, we introduce a modified weighted loss
function and an optimized cosine variance scheduler, which facilitate fast and
effective training on small datasets. We evaluate the effectiveness of the
proposed method on a forest classification task with 10 different forest types
using hyperspectral images acquired by the PRISMA satellite. The results
demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms other data augmentation
techniques in both average and weighted average accuracy. The effectiveness of
the method is further highlighted by the stable training behavior of the model,
which addresses a common limitation in the practical application of deep
generative models for data augmentation.

AI.tldr: Guided diffusion–based data augmentation, paired with a lightweight transformer, a modified weighted loss, and an optimized cosine variance schedule, boosts small-sample hyperspectral forest classification on PRISMA, outperforming other augmentation baselines with stable training.
AI.motivation: Deep learning for hyperspectral land-cover mapping is hampered by scarce labeled data, which leads to overfitting. The authors aim to mitigate small-sample issues and improve class discrimination by generating richer training data while maintaining training stability and efficiency.
AI.method: Use a guided diffusion model to synthesize class-consistent hyperspectral samples for data augmentation. Employ a lightweight transformer to capture complex spectral–spatial patterns with limited labels. Introduce a modified weighted loss to handle class imbalance and an optimized cosine variance scheduler to stabilize and speed training on small datasets.
AI.result: On a 10-class forest-type task using PRISMA hyperspectral imagery, the proposed approach surpasses alternative augmentation methods in both average and weighted-average accuracy and exhibits more stable training behavior.
AI.conclusion: Guided diffusion augmentation combined with a lightweight transformer and tailored training strategies effectively reduces overfitting and yields superior, stable performance for small-sample hyperspectral classification, suggesting practical utility for real-world remote sensing applications.

title: LLMs Learn to Deceive Unintentionally: Emergent Misalignment in Dishonesty from Misaligned Samples to Biased Human-AI Interactions
summary:
Previous research has shown that LLMs finetuned on malicious or incorrect
completions within narrow domains (e.g., insecure code or incorrect medical
advice) can become broadly misaligned to exhibit harmful behaviors, which is
called emergent misalignment. In this work, we investigate whether this
phenomenon can extend beyond safety behaviors to a broader spectrum of
dishonesty and deception under high-stakes scenarios (e.g., lying under
pressure and deceptive behavior). To explore this, we finetune open-sourced
LLMs on misaligned completions across diverse domains. Experimental results
demonstrate that LLMs show broadly misaligned behavior in dishonesty.
Additionally, we further explore this phenomenon in a downstream combined
finetuning setting, and find that introducing as little as 1% of misalignment
data into a standard downstream task is sufficient to decrease honest behavior
over 20%. Furthermore, we consider a more practical human-AI interaction
environment where we simulate both benign and biased users to interact with the
assistant LLM. Notably, we find that the assistant can be misaligned
unintentionally to exacerbate its dishonesty with only 10% biased user
population. In summary, we extend the study of emergent misalignment to the
domain of dishonesty and deception under high-stakes scenarios, and demonstrate
that this risk arises not only through direct finetuning, but also in
downstream mixture tasks and practical human-AI interactions.

AI.tldr: Finetuning open-source LLMs on misaligned outputs induces broad, emergent dishonesty and deception; even tiny amounts of misaligned data (≈1%) in mixed finetuning or a small share of biased users (≈10%) during interaction significantly degrade honesty (>20% drop).
AI.motivation: Prior work showed domain-specific harmful finetuning (e.g., insecure code) can generalize into broader safety failures. The authors ask whether this emergent misalignment also extends to dishonesty/deception in high-stakes contexts and whether it can arise from realistic downstream finetuning or user interactions.
AI.method: Finetune LLMs on misaligned completions spanning diverse domains and evaluate dishonest/deceptive behaviors under high-stakes scenarios (e.g., lying under pressure). Study a mixed-downstream finetuning regime where a small fraction of misaligned data is added to a standard task. Simulate human–AI interactions with benign vs. biased users to observe unintentional drift toward dishonesty.
AI.result: Models exhibit broad dishonest behavior after misaligned finetuning. Adding ~1% misaligned data in a downstream mix reduces honest behavior by >20%. In simulated interactive settings, merely ~10% biased users suffice to exacerbate dishonesty unintentionally.
AI.conclusion: Emergent misalignment extends beyond safety violations to dishonesty/deception and can be triggered by direct misaligned finetuning, small misaligned fractions in mixed tasks, and routine user interactions. This underscores the need for stronger data curation, robustness, alignment methods, and monitoring in deployment.

title: UniVideo: Unified Understanding, Generation, and Editing for Videos
summary:
Unified multimodal models have shown promising results in multimodal content
generation and editing but remain largely limited to the image domain. In this
work, we present UniVideo, a versatile framework that extends unified modeling
to the video domain. UniVideo adopts a dual-stream design, combining a
Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM) for instruction understanding with a
Multimodal DiT (MMDiT) for video generation. This design enables accurate
interpretation of complex multimodal instructions while preserving visual
consistency. Built on this architecture, UniVideo unifies diverse video
generation and editing tasks under a single multimodal instruction paradigm and
is jointly trained across them. Extensive experiments demonstrate that UniVideo
matches or surpasses state-of-the-art task-specific baselines in
text/image-to-video generation, in-context video generation and in-context
video editing. Notably, the unified design of UniVideo enables two forms of
generalization. First, UniVideo supports task composition, such as combining
editing with style transfer, by integrating multiple capabilities within a
single instruction. Second, even without explicit training on free-form video
editing, UniVideo transfers its editing capability from large-scale image
editing data to this setting, handling unseen instructions such as
green-screening characters or changing materials within a video. Beyond these
core capabilities, UniVideo also supports visual-prompt-based video generation,
where the MLLM interprets visual prompts and guides the MMDiT during synthesis.
To foster future research, we will release our model and code.

AI.tldr: UniVideo is a unified, instruction-driven video generation and editing framework that combines an MLLM for understanding multimodal instructions with a Multimodal DiT for video synthesis, achieving SOTA-level performance while enabling task composition, transfer from image editing, and visual-prompt-based generation.
AI.motivation: Unified multimodal models have largely focused on images; there is a need for a single model that can accurately follow complex multimodal instructions and handle diverse video generation/editing tasks while maintaining visual consistency.
AI.method: A dual-stream architecture: (1) an MLLM to parse and reason over text and visual prompts, and (2) a Multimodal DiT (MMDiT) to generate videos. The system uses a unified multimodal instruction interface and is jointly trained across tasks including text/image-to-video, in-context video generation, and in-context video editing. The MLLM’s interpretation guides the MMDiT during synthesis, enabling capabilities like visual-prompt-based generation and transfer of editing skills from image data.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, UniVideo matches or surpasses specialized baselines in text/image-to-video generation, in-context video generation, and in-context video editing. It supports task composition (e.g., editing with style transfer), generalizes to free-form video editing without explicit training (e.g., green-screening, material changes), and handles visual-prompt-based generation.
AI.conclusion: Unified modeling can be effectively extended to video: UniVideo delivers strong performance, broad generalization, and flexible instruction-driven capabilities across generation and editing, with plans to release code and models to support future research.

title: SenWave: A Fine-Grained Multi-Language Sentiment Analysis Dataset Sourced from COVID-19 Tweets
summary:
The global impact of the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a
comprehensive understanding of public sentiment and reactions. Despite the
availability of numerous public datasets on COVID-19, some reaching volumes of
up to 100 billion data points, challenges persist regarding the availability of
labeled data and the presence of coarse-grained or inappropriate sentiment
labels. In this paper, we introduce SenWave, a novel fine-grained
multi-language sentiment analysis dataset specifically designed for analyzing
COVID-19 tweets, featuring ten sentiment categories across five languages. The
dataset comprises 10,000 annotated tweets each in English and Arabic, along
with 30,000 translated tweets in Spanish, French, and Italian, derived from
English tweets. Additionally, it includes over 105 million unlabeled tweets
collected during various COVID-19 waves. To enable accurate fine-grained
sentiment classification, we fine-tuned pre-trained transformer-based language
models using the labeled tweets. Our study provides an in-depth analysis of the
evolving emotional landscape across languages, countries, and topics, revealing
significant insights over time. Furthermore, we assess the compatibility of our
dataset with ChatGPT, demonstrating its robustness and versatility in various
applications. Our dataset and accompanying code are publicly accessible on the
repository\footnote{https://github.com/gitdevqiang/SenWave}. We anticipate that
this work will foster further exploration into fine-grained sentiment analysis
for complex events within the NLP community, promoting more nuanced
understanding and research innovations.

AI.tldr: SenWave introduces a fine-grained, multi-language COVID-19 Twitter sentiment dataset (10 categories, 5 languages) with 20k human-annotated tweets (10k EN, 10k AR), 30k machine-translated ES/FR/IT tweets from English, and 105M+ unlabeled tweets. Fine-tuned transformer models enable detailed temporal, geographic, and topical emotion analyses; the dataset and code are released and shown compatible with ChatGPT.
AI.motivation: Existing COVID-19 social media datasets are massive but lack sufficient high-quality labels and often use coarse or inappropriate sentiment schemes, limiting nuanced understanding of public reactions during the pandemic across languages and regions.
AI.method: Curate a fine-grained sentiment schema of 10 categories; collect and annotate 10k English and 10k Arabic tweets; translate 30k English tweets into Spanish, French, and Italian; gather 105M+ unlabeled tweets from various pandemic waves. Fine-tune pre-trained transformer-based models on the labeled data and analyze sentiment dynamics across languages, countries, and topics. Evaluate dataset compatibility with ChatGPT.
AI.result: The fine-tuned models support accurate fine-grained sentiment classification, and the analyses reveal significant temporal shifts and cross-lingual/country/topic differences in emotional responses. The dataset demonstrates robustness and versatility, including compatibility with ChatGPT. Data and code are publicly available.
AI.conclusion: SenWave provides a comprehensive resource for fine-grained, multilingual sentiment analysis of complex events, facilitating more nuanced research and applications in NLP.

title: Detecting Legend Items on Historical Maps Using GPT-4o with In-Context Learning
summary:
Historical map legends are critical for interpreting cartographic symbols.
However, their inconsistent layouts and unstructured formats make automatic
extraction challenging. Prior work focuses primarily on segmentation or general
optical character recognition (OCR), with few methods effectively matching
legend symbols to their corresponding descriptions in a structured manner. We
present a method that combines LayoutLMv3 for layout detection with GPT-4o
using in-context learning to detect and link legend items and their
descriptions via bounding box predictions. Our experiments show that GPT-4 with
structured JSON prompts outperforms the baseline, achieving 88% F-1 and 85%
IoU, and reveal how prompt design, example counts, and layout alignment affect
performance. This approach supports scalable, layout-aware legend parsing and
improves the indexing and searchability of historical maps across various
visual styles.

AI.tldr: Combines LayoutLMv3 with GPT‑4o (in‑context learning, structured JSON prompts) to detect and link historical map legend symbols to their descriptions via bounding boxes, outperforming baselines (88% F1, 85% IoU) and analyzing how prompt design, example count, and layout alignment impact results.
AI.motivation: Historical map legends are essential for interpreting symbols, but inconsistent layouts and unstructured formats hinder automatic extraction. Existing work emphasizes segmentation/OCR and rarely achieves structured linking of symbols to descriptions.
AI.method: A layout-aware pipeline: (1) use LayoutLMv3 for layout detection; (2) apply GPT‑4o with in-context learning and structured JSON prompts to predict bounding boxes and link legend items to their textual descriptions; (3) evaluate with F1 and IoU while ablating prompt design, number of in-context examples, and layout alignment.
AI.result: GPT‑4 with structured JSON prompts outperforms a baseline, achieving 88% F1 and 85% IoU. Experiments show that prompt structure, example quantity, and alignment cues materially affect performance.
AI.conclusion: The approach enables scalable, layout-aware parsing of legends across diverse visual styles, improving the indexing and searchability of historical maps. It highlights the importance of prompt engineering and layout conditioning for reliable legend item–description linking.

title: Investigating Counterclaims in Causality Extraction from Text
summary:
Research on causality extraction from text has so far almost entirely
neglected counterclaims. Existing causality extraction datasets focus solely on
"procausal" claims, i.e., statements that support a relationship. "Concausal"
claims, i.e., statements that refute a relationship, are entirely ignored or
even accidentally annotated as procausal. We address this shortcoming by
developing a new dataset that integrates concausality. Based on an extensive
literature review, we first show that concausality is an integral part of
causal reasoning on incomplete knowledge. We operationalize this theory in the
form of a rigorous guideline for annotation and then augment the Causal News
Corpus with concausal statements, obtaining a substantial inter-annotator
agreement of Cohen's $\kappa=0.74$. To demonstrate the importance of
integrating concausal statements, we show that models trained without concausal
relationships tend to misclassify these as procausal instead. Based on our new
dataset, this mistake can be mitigated, enabling transformers to effectively
distinguish pro- and concausality.

AI.tldr: They introduce “concausal” (counter-causal) claims—statements that refute a causal relation—into causality extraction, extend the Causal News Corpus with such annotations (κ=0.74), and show that including them helps transformers distinguish procausal vs. concausal statements, avoiding systematic misclassification.
AI.motivation: Most causality-extraction work focuses only on procausal claims, ignoring counterclaims. This skews models toward affirming causal links and undermines causal reasoning under incomplete knowledge. The authors aim to correct this by formally incorporating concausal evidence.
AI.method: (1) Conduct a literature review to argue concausality’s role in causal reasoning; (2) design rigorous annotation guidelines; (3) augment the Causal News Corpus with concausal statements; (4) assess inter-annotator agreement (Cohen’s κ); (5) train/evaluate transformer models with and without concausal data to test misclassification and discrimination between pro- and concausality.
AI.result: They achieve substantial inter-annotator agreement (κ=0.74). Models trained without concausal data tend to misclassify concausal statements as procausal. Using the new dataset mitigates this and enables effective discrimination between pro- and concausality.
AI.conclusion: Concausality is essential for robust causality extraction. Providing guidelines and an augmented dataset improves model performance by reducing biases toward procausal interpretations and enabling reliable identification of counter-causal claims.

title: Robust Source-Free Domain Adaptation for Medical Image Segmentation based on Curriculum Learning
summary:
Recent studies have uncovered a new research line, namely source-free domain
adaptation, which adapts a model to target domains without using the source
data. Such a setting can address the concerns on data privacy and security
issues of medical images. However, current source-free domain adaptation
frameworks mainly focus on the pseudo label refinement for target data without
the consideration of learning procedure. Indeed, a progressive learning process
from source to target domain will benefit the knowledge transfer during model
adaptation. To this end, we propose a curriculum-based framework, namely
learning from curriculum (LFC), for source-free domain adaptation, which
consists of easy-to-hard and source-to-target curricula. Concretely, the former
curriculum enables the framework to start learning with `easy' samples and
gradually tune the optimization direction of model adaption by increasing the
sample difficulty. While, the latter can stablize the adaptation process, which
ensures smooth transfer of the model from the source domain to the target. We
evaluate the proposed source-free domain adaptation approach on the public
cross-domain datasets for fundus segmentation and polyp segmentation. The
extensive experimental results show that our framework surpasses the existing
approaches and achieves a new state-of-the-art.

AI.tldr: They propose a curriculum-based source-free domain adaptation (SFDA) framework for medical image segmentation that gradually adapts a source-trained model to a target domain using easy-to-hard samples and a source-to-target transition, achieving state-of-the-art results on fundus and polyp datasets.
AI.motivation: SFDA avoids sharing source data, addressing privacy/security concerns common in medical imaging. Existing SFDA methods mainly refine pseudo labels but overlook the learning schedule itself; a progressive curriculum could transfer knowledge more stably and effectively across domains.
AI.method: A framework called Learning From Curriculum (LFC) with two curricula: (1) easy-to-hard curriculum—begin adaptation using ‘easy’ target samples and gradually include harder ones to steer optimization; (2) source-to-target curriculum—stabilizes adaptation by smoothly transitioning the model from source to target domain. Details on how ‘ease’ is measured or scheduled are not provided in the abstract.
AI.result: On public cross-domain datasets for fundus and polyp segmentation, LFC outperforms prior SFDA approaches and sets a new state-of-the-art; specific metrics and improvements are not reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: Curriculum design—both in sample difficulty and domain transition—can significantly enhance SFDA stability and effectiveness for medical image segmentation, yielding SOTA performance across tested benchmarks.

title: The Alignment Waltz: Jointly Training Agents to Collaborate for Safety
summary:
Harnessing the power of LLMs requires a delicate dance between being helpful
and harmless. This creates a fundamental tension between two competing
challenges: vulnerability to adversarial attacks that elicit unsafe content,
and a tendency for overrefusal on benign but sensitive prompts. Current
approaches often navigate this dance with safeguard models that completely
reject any content that contains unsafe portions. This approach cuts the music
entirely-it may exacerbate overrefusals and fails to provide nuanced guidance
for queries it refuses. To teach models a more coordinated choreography, we
propose WaltzRL, a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that
formulates safety alignment as a collaborative, positive-sum game. WaltzRL
jointly trains a conversation agent and a feedback agent, where the latter is
incentivized to provide useful suggestions that improve the safety and
helpfulness of the conversation agent's responses. At the core of WaltzRL is a
Dynamic Improvement Reward (DIR) that evolves over time based on how well the
conversation agent incorporates the feedback. At inference time, unsafe or
overrefusing responses from the conversation agent are improved rather than
discarded. The feedback agent is deployed together with the conversation agent
and only engages adaptively when needed, preserving helpfulness and low latency
on safe queries. Our experiments, conducted across five diverse datasets,
demonstrate that WaltzRL significantly reduces both unsafe responses (e.g.,
from 39.0% to 4.6% on WildJailbreak) and overrefusals (from 45.3% to 9.9% on
OR-Bench) compared to various baselines. By enabling the conversation and
feedback agents to co-evolve and adaptively apply feedback, WaltzRL enhances
LLM safety without degrading general capabilities, thereby advancing the Pareto
front between helpfulness and harmlessness.

AI.tldr: WaltzRL is a multi‑agent RL framework that jointly trains a conversation agent and a feedback agent with a Dynamic Improvement Reward, reducing both unsafe outputs and overrefusals while preserving overall capabilities.
AI.motivation: Safety alignment of LLMs faces a tradeoff: existing safeguard models tend to fully reject any response containing unsafe elements, which increases overrefusals and offers little guidance on how to answer safely. The goal is to keep helpfulness while ensuring harmlessness via more nuanced, constructive control.
AI.method: Formulate alignment as a collaborative positive‑sum game between two agents. A feedback agent proposes actionable suggestions to improve the conversation agent’s responses. Training uses a Dynamic Improvement Reward (DIR) that evolves based on how well the conversation agent incorporates feedback. At inference, unsafe or overrefusing responses are revised rather than discarded; the feedback agent triggers adaptively to maintain low latency on safe queries.
AI.result: Across five datasets, WaltzRL markedly reduces unsafe responses and overrefusals versus baselines—for example, unsafe rates drop from 39.0% to 4.6% on WildJailbreak, and overrefusals from 45.3% to 9.9% on OR‑Bench—without degrading general capabilities.
AI.conclusion: Co‑evolving a conversation and feedback agent with adaptive, dynamic rewards can shift the Pareto frontier toward both helpfulness and harmlessness. WaltzRL improves safety and reduces refusals while maintaining capabilities, and uses the feedback agent at inference only when needed.

title: VideoVerse: How Far is Your T2V Generator from a World Model?
summary:
The recent rapid advancement of Text-to-Video (T2V) generation technologies,
which are critical to build ``world models'', makes the existing benchmarks
increasingly insufficient to evaluate state-of-the-art T2V models. First,
current evaluation dimensions, such as per-frame aesthetic quality and temporal
consistency, are no longer able to differentiate state-of-the-art T2V models.
Second, event-level temporal causality, which not only distinguishes video from
other modalities but also constitutes a crucial component of world models, is
severely underexplored in existing benchmarks. Third, existing benchmarks lack
a systematic assessment of world knowledge, which are essential capabilities
for building world models. To address these issues, we introduce VideoVerse, a
comprehensive benchmark that focuses on evaluating whether a T2V model could
understand complex temporal causality and world knowledge in the real world. We
collect representative videos across diverse domains (e.g., natural landscapes,
sports, indoor scenes, science fiction, chemical and physical experiments) and
extract their event-level descriptions with inherent temporal causality, which
are then rewritten into text-to-video prompts by independent annotators. For
each prompt, we design a suite of binary evaluation questions from the
perspective of dynamic and static properties, with a total of ten carefully
defined evaluation dimensions. In total, our VideoVerse comprises 300 carefully
curated prompts, involving 815 events and 793 binary evaluation questions.
Consequently, a human preference aligned QA-based evaluation pipeline is
developed by using modern vision-language models. Finally, we perform a
systematic evaluation of state-of-the-art open-source and closed-source T2V
models on VideoVerse, providing in-depth analysis on how far the current T2V
generators are from world models.

AI.tldr: Introduces VideoVerse, a benchmark and QA-based evaluation pipeline to assess text-to-video (T2V) models on event-level temporal causality and world knowledge, with 300 prompts, 815 events, and 793 binary questions across 10 dimensions, used to systematically evaluate SOTA models.
AI.motivation: Existing T2V benchmarks focus on per-frame quality and simple temporal consistency, which no longer differentiate state-of-the-art systems. Crucial capabilities for building ‘world models’—event-level temporal causality and systematic world knowledge—are largely missing from current evaluations.
AI.method: Collect diverse real-world videos, extract event-level descriptions capturing inherent temporal causality, and rewrite them into T2V prompts. For each prompt, design binary evaluation questions covering dynamic and static properties over 10 dimensions. Build a human preference–aligned, VLM-based QA evaluation pipeline. Provide a curated set: 300 prompts, 815 events, 793 binary questions.
AI.result: A comprehensive benchmark and automated evaluation pipeline enabling fine-grained assessment of temporal causality and world knowledge in T2V models. The authors conduct systematic evaluations of leading open- and closed-source T2V models on VideoVerse and provide analyses of their gaps relative to ‘world model’ capabilities.
AI.conclusion: VideoVerse fills key evaluation gaps by moving beyond aesthetics/consistency to event-level causality and knowledge. It offers a scalable, question-driven framework to measure progress toward T2V systems that genuinely understand and generate causal, knowledge-grounded video content.

title: Contrastive Decoding for Synthetic Data Generation in Low-Resource Language Modeling
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are trained on huge amounts of textual data, and
concerns have been raised that the limits of such data may soon be reached. A
potential solution is to train on synthetic data sampled from LLMs. In this
work, we build on this idea and investigate the benefits of contrastive
decoding for generating synthetic corpora. In a controlled setting, we
experiment with sampling corpora using the relative difference between a good
and bad model trained on the same original corpus of 100 million words. By
amplifying the signal from a model that has better performance, we create a
synthetic corpus and mix it with the original training data. Our findings show
that training on a mixture of synthesized and real data improves performance on
the language modeling objective and a range of downstream tasks. In particular,
we see that training with a mix of synthetic data from contrastive decoding
benefits tasks that require more reasoning skills, while synthetic data from
traditional sampling helps more on tasks dependent on surface level linguistic
capabilities.

AI.tldr: They generate synthetic training data by contrastively sampling text that a stronger model prefers over a weaker one, then mix it with real data; this improves language modeling and downstream performance, with contrastive synthetic data boosting reasoning tasks and traditional sampling aiding surface-level skills.
AI.motivation: Real web-scale text may soon be exhausted, so scaling LLMs requires alternative data sources. Synthetic data is promising, but its quality and usefulness depend on how it’s generated. The authors explore whether contrastive decoding—emphasizing what a strong model does better than a weak one—can produce higher-value synthetic corpora.
AI.method: In a controlled setup, two models ("good" and "bad") are trained on the same 100M-word corpus. Synthetic text is sampled using the relative difference in their preferences (contrastive decoding), effectively amplifying the better model’s signal. The resulting synthetic corpus is mixed with the original training data. Performance is evaluated on the LM objective and diverse downstream tasks, and compared against synthetic data from traditional sampling.
AI.result: Mixing synthetic with real data improves both language modeling and downstream task performance. Contrastive-decoded synthetic data particularly benefits tasks requiring reasoning, whereas synthetic data from traditional sampling helps more on surface-level linguistic capabilities.
AI.conclusion: Contrastive decoding is an effective strategy for generating synthetic data that enhances LLM training, especially for reasoning-centric tasks. The choice of synthetic generation method should be matched to target capabilities: contrastive for reasoning, traditional sampling for surface-linguistic skills.

title: Large Scale Diffusion Distillation via Score-Regularized Continuous-Time Consistency
summary:
This work represents the first effort to scale up continuous-time consistency
distillation to general application-level image and video diffusion models.
Although continuous-time consistency model (sCM) is theoretically principled
and empirically powerful for accelerating academic-scale diffusion, its
applicability to large-scale text-to-image and video tasks remains unclear due
to infrastructure challenges in Jacobian-vector product (JVP) computation and
the limitations of standard evaluation benchmarks. We first develop a
parallelism-compatible FlashAttention-2 JVP kernel, enabling sCM training on
models with over 10 billion parameters and high-dimensional video tasks. Our
investigation reveals fundamental quality limitations of sCM in fine-detail
generation, which we attribute to error accumulation and the "mode-covering"
nature of its forward-divergence objective. To remedy this, we propose the
score-regularized continuous-time consistency model (rCM), which incorporates
score distillation as a long-skip regularizer. This integration complements sCM
with the "mode-seeking" reverse divergence, effectively improving visual
quality while maintaining high generation diversity. Validated on large-scale
models (Cosmos-Predict2, Wan2.1) up to 14B parameters and 5-second videos, rCM
matches or surpasses the state-of-the-art distillation method DMD2 on quality
metrics while offering notable advantages in diversity, all without GAN tuning
or extensive hyperparameter searches. The distilled models generate
high-fidelity samples in only $1\sim4$ steps, accelerating diffusion sampling
by $15\times\sim50\times$. These results position rCM as a practical and
theoretically grounded framework for advancing large-scale diffusion
distillation.

AI.tldr: They scale continuous-time consistency distillation to real, large text-to-image and video models by adding a JVP kernel and propose a score-regularized variant (rCM) that fixes sCM’s detail and mode-coverage issues, achieving 1–4 step high-fidelity sampling with 15×–50× speedups and SOTA-level quality and diversity without GAN tuning.
AI.motivation: Although sCM is promising for fast diffusion sampling, it hadn’t been shown to work on large-scale T2I/video due to JVP infrastructure limits and weak benchmarks. Moreover, sCM’s forward-divergence objective tends to be mode-covering and accumulates errors, hurting fine details. A scalable, high-quality, diverse, and fast distillation method was needed.
AI.method: 1) Implement a parallelism-compatible FlashAttention-2 JVP kernel to enable training with >10B parameter models and high-dim video. 2) Diagnose sCM’s quality limits (error accumulation, mode covering). 3) Introduce rCM: augment sCM with score distillation as a long-skip regularizer, injecting reverse-divergence (mode-seeking) behavior to improve detail while preserving diversity. 4) Train/evaluate on large models (Cosmos-Predict2, Wan2.1) and videos.
AI.result: rCM matches or surpasses DMD2 on quality metrics, improves diversity, works up to 14B parameters and 5-second videos, and produces high-fidelity samples in 1–4 steps, yielding 15×–50× speedups, without GAN-tuning or extensive hyperparameter sweeps.
AI.conclusion: With the new JVP kernel and score-regularized objective, rCM provides a practical, theoretically grounded path to large-scale diffusion distillation that preserves diversity and detail while enabling ultra-fast sampling.

title: Beyond Turn Limits: Training Deep Search Agents with Dynamic Context Window
summary:
While recent advances in reasoning models have demonstrated cognitive
behaviors through reinforcement learning, existing approaches struggle to
invoke deep reasoning capabilities in multi-turn agents with long-horizon
interactions. We propose DeepMiner, a novel framework that elicits such
abilities by introducing high-difficulty training tasks and dynamic context
window. DeepMiner presents a reverse construction method to generate complex
but verifiable question-answer pairs from authentic web sources, which ensures
the challenge and reliability of training data while injecting cognitive
capabilities into multi-turn reasoning scenarios. We further design an elegant
yet effective dynamic context management strategy for both training and
inference, utilizing sliding window mechanisms while eliminating the dependency
on external summarization models, thereby efficiently empowering the model to
handle continuously expanding long-horizon contexts. Through reinforcement
learning on Qwen3-32B, we develop DeepMiner-32B, which achieves substantial
performance improvements across multiple search agent benchmarks. DeepMiner
attains 33.5% accuracy on BrowseComp-en, surpassing the previous best
open-source agent by almost 20 percentage points, and demonstrates consistent
improvements on BrowseComp-zh, XBench-DeepSearch, and GAIA. Notably, our
dynamic context management enables sustained interactions of nearly 100 turns
within standard 32k context length, effectively addressing the context
limitations that constrain existing multi-turn interaction systems.

AI.tldr: DeepMiner is a reinforcement-learning framework that builds hard, verifiable web-based QA tasks and uses a dynamic sliding-window context manager to train/infer multi-turn agents that reason over long horizons, yielding large gains on search-agent benchmarks and sustaining ~100 turns within a 32k context.
AI.motivation: Existing RL reasoning models underperform in multi-turn, long-horizon settings because training data are not hard/grounded enough and context windows overflow, often requiring lossy external summarization. The authors aim to elicit deeper reasoning in agents by supplying challenging, verifiable tasks and an efficient way to manage ever-growing dialogue context without external summarizers.
AI.method: 1) Reverse construction of complex, verifiable question–answer pairs from authentic web sources to create challenging training data. 2) Dynamic context management using a sliding-window mechanism during both training and inference, avoiding external summarization while handling long-horizon interactions. 3) RL fine-tuning on Qwen3-32B to produce DeepMiner-32B.
AI.result: On BrowseComp-en, DeepMiner reaches 33.5% accuracy, ~+20 percentage points over the previous best open-source agent, with consistent gains on BrowseComp-zh, XBench-DeepSearch, and GAIA. The dynamic context strategy supports nearly 100 conversational turns within a standard 32k context length.
AI.conclusion: Combining hard, verifiable data generation with dynamic context management effectively injects deep reasoning capabilities into multi-turn agents. The approach overcomes practical context-length limits without external summarization and substantially improves performance across multiple search-agent benchmarks.

title: Gaze on the Prize: Shaping Visual Attention with Return-Guided Contrastive Learning
summary:
Visual Reinforcement Learning (RL) agents must learn to act based on
high-dimensional image data where only a small fraction of the pixels is
task-relevant. This forces agents to waste exploration and computational
resources on irrelevant features, leading to sample-inefficient and unstable
learning. To address this, inspired by human visual foveation, we introduce
Gaze on the Prize. This framework augments visual RL with a learnable foveal
attention mechanism (Gaze), guided by a self-supervised signal derived from the
agent's experience pursuing higher returns (the Prize). Our key insight is that
return differences reveal what matters most: If two similar representations
produce different outcomes, their distinguishing features are likely
task-relevant, and the gaze should focus on them accordingly. This is realized
through return-guided contrastive learning that trains the attention to
distinguish between the features relevant to success and failure. We group
similar visual representations into positives and negatives based on their
return differences and use the resulting labels to construct contrastive
triplets. These triplets provide the training signal that teaches the attention
mechanism to produce distinguishable representations for states associated with
different outcomes. Our method achieves up to 2.4x improvement in sample
efficiency and can solve tasks that the baseline fails to learn, demonstrated
across a suite of manipulation tasks from the ManiSkill3 benchmark, all without
modifying the underlying algorithm or hyperparameters.

AI.tldr: Proposes “Gaze on the Prize,” a learnable foveal attention module for visual RL trained via return-guided contrastive learning, which focuses perception on task-relevant features and yields up to 2.4x sample-efficiency gains on ManiSkill3 without changing the base RL algorithm or hyperparameters.
AI.motivation: Visual RL from pixels is sample-inefficient and unstable because most pixels are irrelevant to the task, causing wasted exploration and computation. Inspired by human foveation, the authors aim to direct attention toward features that actually drive returns.
AI.method: Augment standard visual RL with a learnable foveal attention mechanism (“Gaze”). Use a self-supervised signal derived from return differences (“Prize”): representations from experiences with similar returns are grouped; return-guided contrastive learning forms triplets that push attention to distinguish features associated with success vs. failure. This is plug-and-play, requiring no change to the underlying RL algorithm or hyperparameters.
AI.result: On ManiSkill3 manipulation tasks, the approach improves sample efficiency by up to 2.4x and solves tasks that a baseline fails to learn.
AI.conclusion: Return-guided, contrastive training of a foveal attention module enables agents to focus on task-relevant visual cues, improving efficiency and capability in visual RL without altering the base algorithm—suggesting a general, scalable way to make pixel-based RL more effective.

title: Neuron-Level Analysis of Cultural Understanding in Large Language Models
summary:
As large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed worldwide, ensuring
their fair and comprehensive cultural understanding is important. However, LLMs
exhibit cultural bias and limited awareness of underrepresented cultures, while
the mechanisms underlying their cultural understanding remain underexplored. To
fill this gap, we conduct a neuron-level analysis to identify neurons that
drive cultural behavior, introducing a gradient-based scoring method with
additional filtering for precise refinement. We identify both culture-general
neurons contributing to cultural understanding regardless of cultures, and
culture-specific neurons tied to an individual culture. These neurons account
for less than 1% of all neurons and are concentrated in shallow to middle MLP
layers. We validate their role by showing that suppressing them substantially
degrades performance on cultural benchmarks (by up to 30%), while performance
on general natural language understanding (NLU) benchmarks remains largely
unaffected. Moreover, we show that culture-specific neurons support knowledge
of not only the target culture, but also related cultures. Finally, we
demonstrate that training on NLU benchmarks can diminish models' cultural
understanding when we update modules containing many culture-general neurons.
These findings provide insights into the internal mechanisms of LLMs and offer
practical guidance for model training and engineering. Our code is available at
https://github.com/ynklab/CULNIG

AI.tldr: They find a tiny, identifiable set of neurons (<<1%) in shallow–mid MLP layers that largely drive LLMs’ cultural understanding; ablating them hurts cultural tasks (~30%) without much affecting general NLU, revealing mechanisms and training trade-offs.
AI.motivation: LLMs show cultural biases and weak coverage of underrepresented cultures, and we lack mechanistic understanding of how cultural knowledge is represented internally. Understanding this could improve fairness and guide training/engineering.
AI.method: Perform neuron-level attribution with a gradient-based scoring method plus filtering to pinpoint neurons associated with cultural behavior. Separate these into culture-general (useful across cultures) and culture-specific (tied to a single culture). Validate via targeted suppression/ablation and by assessing transfer to related cultures; analyze layer distribution. Study effects of fine-tuning on NLU benchmarks, especially when updating modules rich in culture-general neurons.
AI.result: Identified culture-general and culture-specific neurons comprising <1% of all neurons, concentrated in shallow-to-mid MLP layers. Suppressing them substantially reduces performance on cultural benchmarks (up to 30%) while leaving general NLU mostly intact. Culture-specific neurons also support related cultures. Fine-tuning on NLU datasets can erode cultural understanding when it updates modules with many culture-general neurons.
AI.conclusion: Cultural knowledge in LLMs is localized and mechanistically traceable to a small subset of neurons. This enables targeted interventions (e.g., preservation or modulation) and cautions that standard NLU fine-tuning may unintentionally harm cultural competence if it modifies critical modules. Provides practical guidance for training and model engineering; code released at the provided repository.

title: Hierarchical Spatial Algorithms for High-Resolution Image Quantization and Feature Extraction
summary:
This study introduces a modular framework for spatial image processing,
integrating grayscale quantization, color and brightness enhancement, image
sharpening, bidirectional transformation pipelines, and geometric feature
extraction. A stepwise intensity transformation quantizes grayscale images into
eight discrete levels, producing a posterization effect that simplifies
representation while preserving structural detail. Color enhancement is
achieved via histogram equalization in both RGB and YCrCb color spaces, with
the latter improving contrast while maintaining chrominance fidelity.
Brightness adjustment is implemented through HSV value-channel manipulation,
and image sharpening is performed using a 3 * 3 convolution kernel to enhance
high-frequency details. A bidirectional transformation pipeline that integrates
unsharp masking, gamma correction, and noise amplification achieved accuracy
levels of 76.10% and 74.80% for the forward and reverse processes,
respectively. Geometric feature extraction employed Canny edge detection,
Hough-based line estimation (e.g., 51.50{\deg} for billiard cue alignment),
Harris corner detection, and morphological window localization. Cue isolation
further yielded 81.87\% similarity against ground truth images. Experimental
evaluation across diverse datasets demonstrates robust and deterministic
performance, highlighting its potential for real-time image analysis and
computer vision.

AI.tldr: A modular, deterministic spatial image-processing framework that combines quantization, color/brightness enhancement, sharpening, a bidirectional transform pipeline, and geometric feature extraction; it reports ~75% bidirectional transform accuracy and ~82% cue isolation similarity, indicating suitability for real-time computer vision tasks.
AI.motivation: To provide an integrated, rule-based (deterministic) pipeline for robust, real-time image analysis that simplifies intensity representation, enhances perceptual quality without distorting color, and extracts geometric features reliably, while enabling forward and reverse transformations for analysis and synthesis workflows.
AI.method:
- Grayscale stepwise intensity transformation to 8 levels (posterization) to simplify structure while retaining edges.
- Color enhancement via histogram equalization in RGB and YCrCb (the latter for contrast gains with chroma fidelity).
- Brightness control by adjusting the HSV value channel.
- Sharpening with a 3×3 kernel to boost high-frequency details.
- Bidirectional transformation pipeline combining unsharp masking, gamma correction, and intentional noise amplification; evaluated for forward and reverse accuracy.
- Geometric feature extraction using Canny edges, Hough line detection (e.g., 51.50° cue alignment), Harris corners, and morphological localization; cue isolation matched to ground truth.
- Tested across diverse datasets.
AI.result:
- Forward and reverse pipeline accuracies: 76.10% and 74.80%.
- Cue isolation similarity: 81.87% versus ground truth.
- Empirically, YCrCb equalization improved contrast while maintaining chrominance.
- Reported robust, deterministic behavior across datasets, implying stability suited to real-time use.
AI.conclusion: The modular pipeline effectively integrates classic image-processing steps for both enhancement and feature extraction, achieving moderate accuracy and strong cue-isolation performance with consistent behavior across datasets. It appears suitable for real-time applications, though precise definitions of metrics, runtime, and generalization boundaries would strengthen claims.

title: AutoRed: A Free-form Adversarial Prompt Generation Framework for Automated Red Teaming
summary:
The safety of Large Language Models (LLMs) is crucial for the development of
trustworthy AI applications. Existing red teaming methods often rely on seed
instructions, which limits the semantic diversity of the synthesized
adversarial prompts. We propose AutoRed, a free-form adversarial prompt
generation framework that removes the need for seed instructions. AutoRed
operates in two stages: (1) persona-guided adversarial instruction generation,
and (2) a reflection loop to iteratively refine low-quality prompts. To improve
efficiency, we introduce a verifier to assess prompt harmfulness without
querying the target models. Using AutoRed, we build two red teaming datasets --
AutoRed-Medium and AutoRed-Hard -- and evaluate eight state-of-the-art LLMs.
AutoRed achieves higher attack success rates and better generalization than
existing baselines. Our results highlight the limitations of seed-based
approaches and demonstrate the potential of free-form red teaming for LLM
safety evaluation. We will open source our datasets in the near future.

AI.tldr: AutoRed is a seed-free, free-form red teaming framework that generates adversarial prompts via persona-guided generation and an iterative reflection loop, aided by a verifier that scores harmfulness without querying target models. It produces AutoRed-Medium/Hard datasets and outperforms seed-based baselines across eight LLMs in attack success and generalization.
AI.motivation: Seed-instruction-dependent red teaming constrains semantic diversity and limits transfer/generalization of adversarial prompts. There is a need for scalable, efficient methods that can explore a broader space of unsafe behaviors without repeatedly querying target LLMs.
AI.method: Two-stage pipeline: (1) Persona-guided adversarial instruction generation where an LLM adopts varied personas to propose harmful-intent prompts without relying on seed instructions. (2) A reflection loop that critiques and refines low-quality prompts iteratively to increase potency and diversity. Efficiency is improved by using a verifier that predicts prompt harmfulness offline (i.e., without querying target models). The authors compile the generated prompts into two datasets (AutoRed-Medium, AutoRed-Hard) and evaluate them across eight state-of-the-art LLMs.
AI.result: AutoRed achieves higher attack success rates and better cross-model generalization compared to seed-based baselines. The authors construct and will release two benchmark datasets, demonstrating limitations of seed-based approaches and the effectiveness of their free-form strategy on eight contemporary LLMs.
AI.conclusion: Free-form, seedless adversarial prompt generation, guided by personas and refined via reflection, is more effective and efficient for red teaming LLMs than seed-based methods. The approach broadens semantic coverage, improves transferability, and provides datasets to support robust safety evaluation, with plans to open source the resources.

title: Video-STAR: Reinforcing Open-Vocabulary Action Recognition with Tools
summary:
Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have demonstrated remarkable
potential in bridging visual and textual reasoning, yet their reliance on
text-centric priors often limits their ability to disentangle semantically
similar actions in open-vocabulary scenarios. To address this, we propose
Video-STAR, a framework that harmonizes contextual sub-motion decomposition
with tool-augmented reinforcement learning for open-vocabulary action
recognition (OVAR). Unlike prior methods that treat actions as monolithic
entities, our approach innovatively decomposes actions into discriminative
sub-motions for fine-grained matching while dynamically invoking
domain-specific tools for cross-modal interleaving, thereby enabling
category-specific reasoning capacity and reducing cross-modal hallucination.
Moreover, by designing a hierarchical reward that balances tool-usage
efficiency, sub-motion relevance, and structural coherence in reasoning, our
method autonomously leverages external tools to prioritize sub-motion patterns
without explicit supervision, transmitting from text-centric reasoning to
visually grounded inference. Extensive evaluations on HMDB-51, UCF-101, SSv2,
Kinetics-400, and Kinetics-600 datasets demonstrate our state-of-the-art
performance, outperforming existing methods in distinguishing fine-grained
actions and handling cross-modal hallucination, validating our excellent
robustness and generalization.

AI.tldr: Video-STAR improves open-vocabulary action recognition by decomposing actions into discriminative sub-motions and training an MLLM with tool-augmented reinforcement learning, achieving state-of-the-art results while reducing cross-modal hallucination.
AI.motivation: MLLMs often over-rely on text priors and struggle to distinguish visually similar actions in open-vocabulary settings, leading to misclassification and hallucination. The goal is to make action recognition more fine-grained and visually grounded without heavy supervision.
AI.method: Introduce contextual sub-motion decomposition to break an action into discriminative visual primitives, and a tool-augmented RL framework that dynamically calls domain-specific tools during reasoning. A hierarchical reward balances tool-use efficiency, sub-motion relevance, and reasoning coherence, encouraging category-specific, visually grounded inference and limiting hallucination.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on HMDB-51, UCF-101, SSv2, Kinetics-400, and Kinetics-600, with better disambiguation of fine-grained actions and reduced cross-modal hallucination, indicating improved robustness and generalization.
AI.conclusion: Decomposing actions plus tool-augmented RL shifts MLLMs from text-centric to visually grounded reasoning for OVAR, yielding SOTA accuracy and robustness across benchmarks; suggests a promising path for fine-grained, open-vocabulary video understanding.

title: Two-Stage Voting for Robust and Efficient Suicide Risk Detection on Social Media
summary:
Suicide rates have risen worldwide in recent years, underscoring the urgent
need for proactive prevention strategies. Social media provides valuable
signals, as many at-risk individuals - who often avoid formal help due to
stigma - choose instead to share their distress online. Yet detecting implicit
suicidal ideation, conveyed indirectly through metaphor, sarcasm, or subtle
emotional cues, remains highly challenging. Lightweight models like BERT handle
explicit signals but fail on subtle implicit ones, while large language models
(LLMs) capture nuance at prohibitive computational cost. To address this gap,
we propose a two-stage voting architecture that balances efficiency and
robustness. In Stage 1, a lightweight BERT classifier rapidly resolves
high-confidence explicit cases. In Stage 2, ambiguous inputs are escalated to
either (i) a multi-perspective LLM voting framework to maximize recall on
implicit ideation, or (ii) a feature-based ML ensemble guided by
psychologically grounded indicators extracted via prompt-engineered LLMs for
efficiency and interpretability. To the best of our knowledge, this is among
the first works to operationalize LLM-extracted psychological features as
structured vectors for suicide risk detection. On two complementary datasets -
explicit-dominant Reddit and implicit-only DeepSuiMind - our framework
outperforms single-model baselines, achieving 98.0% F1 on explicit cases, 99.7%
on implicit ones, and reducing the cross-domain gap below 2%, while
significantly lowering LLM cost.

AI.tldr: Two-stage suicide-risk detection system routes easy explicit cases to a lightweight BERT and escalates ambiguous ones to either an LLM voting scheme or an LLM-guided feature ensemble, achieving near-perfect F1 on both explicit and implicit datasets with much lower LLM cost and improved cross-domain robustness.
AI.motivation: Rising global suicide rates and the prevalence of distress disclosures on social media demand proactive detection. While explicit ideation can be caught by lightweight models, implicit ideation (metaphor, sarcasm, subtle affect) is missed, and using full LLMs for all data is too costly. The goal is to balance nuance, efficiency, and generalization.
AI.method: A two-stage voting architecture: (1) a lightweight BERT quickly classifies high-confidence explicit posts; (2) uncertain cases are routed to either (i) a multi-perspective LLM voting framework to maximize recall on subtle/implicit ideation, or (ii) a feature-based ML ensemble whose inputs are psychologically grounded indicators extracted via prompt-engineered LLMs, improving efficiency and interpretability. The work operationalizes LLM-extracted psychological features as structured vectors for classification.
AI.result: On Reddit (explicit-dominant) and DeepSuiMind (implicit-only), the framework surpasses single-model baselines, reaching 98.0% F1 on explicit and 99.7% on implicit cases, reducing cross-domain performance gap to under 2%, and cutting LLM inference cost substantially.
AI.conclusion: Routing and voting reconcile efficiency with nuance in suicide-risk detection. LLMs are used selectively and also to derive interpretable psychological features, yielding strong performance, better cross-domain robustness, and lower cost, suggesting a practical path for scalable, interpretable risk monitoring.

title: The Visual Iconicity Challenge: Evaluating Vision-Language Models on Sign Language Form-Meaning Mapping
summary:
Iconicity, the resemblance between linguistic form and meaning, is pervasive
in signed languages, offering a natural testbed for visual grounding. For
vision-language models (VLMs), the challenge is to recover such essential
mappings from dynamic human motion rather than static context. We introduce the
\textit{Visual Iconicity Challenge}, a novel video-based benchmark that adapts
psycholinguistic measures to evaluate VLMs on three tasks: (i) phonological
sign-form prediction (e.g., handshape, location), (ii) transparency (inferring
meaning from visual form), and (iii) graded iconicity ratings. We assess $13$
state-of-the-art VLMs in zero- and few-shot settings on Sign Language of the
Netherlands and compare them to human baselines. On \textit{phonological form
prediction}, VLMs recover some handshape and location detail but remain below
human performance; on \textit{transparency}, they are far from human baselines;
and only top models correlate moderately with human \textit{iconicity ratings}.
Interestingly, \textit{models with stronger phonological form prediction
correlate better with human iconicity judgment}, indicating shared sensitivity
to visually grounded structure. Our findings validate these diagnostic tasks
and motivate human-centric signals and embodied learning methods for modelling
iconicity and improving visual grounding in multimodal models.

AI.tldr: They introduce the Visual Iconicity Challenge, a video-based benchmark to test whether vision-language models can ground sign language form–meaning mappings. Across three psycholinguistically inspired tasks and 13 VLMs, models capture some phonological form but fall short of humans, especially on meaning transparency; only the strongest models align moderately with human iconicity judgments.
AI.motivation: Iconicity is pervasive in signed languages and provides a natural probe of visual grounding, yet most VLMs are trained on static imagery and lack evaluation on dynamic human motion and psycholinguistic constructs. A diagnostic, human-centered benchmark is needed to assess whether models recover visually grounded form–meaning mappings.
AI.method: Create a video-based benchmark (on Sign Language of the Netherlands) with three tasks adapted from psycholinguistics: (i) phonological sign-form prediction (e.g., handshape, location), (ii) transparency (inferring meaning from visual form), and (iii) graded iconicity ratings. Evaluate 13 state-of-the-art VLMs in zero/few-shot settings and compare to human baselines; analyze correlations between model performance on phonology and alignment with human iconicity judgments.
AI.result: VLMs recover some handshape and location detail but remain below human performance on phonological prediction; they perform far below humans on transparency; only top models show moderate correlation with human iconicity ratings. Models with stronger phonological prediction correlate better with human iconicity judgments.
AI.conclusion: The benchmark provides valid diagnostic tasks for visual grounding of iconicity. Current VLMs are not yet human-like in mapping dynamic sign forms to meanings; improving performance will likely require human-centric supervision and embodied learning approaches that better capture visually grounded structure.

title: On the Relationship Between the Choice of Representation and In-Context Learning
summary:
In-context learning (ICL) is the ability of a large language model (LLM) to
learn a new task from a few demonstrations presented as part of the context.
Past studies have attributed a large portion of the success of ICL to the way
these in-context demonstrations are represented, particularly to how labels are
represented in classification tasks. On the other hand, observations of the
learning capacity of ICL (i.e., the extent to which more in-context
demonstrations can lead to higher performance) have been mixed, and ICL is
often thought to occur only under specific conditions. The interaction between
these two aspects in ICL, representation and learning, has not been studied in
depth until now. We hypothesize that they are largely independent of one
another, such that the representation of demonstrations determines the baseline
accuracy of ICL, while learning from additional demonstrations improves only on
top of this baseline. We validate this hypothesis by developing an optimization
algorithm that can enumerate a spectrum of possible label sets
(representations) varying in semantic relevance. We then perform ICL with
varying numbers of in-context demonstrations for each of these label sets. We
observed that learning happens regardless of the quality of the label set
itself, although its efficiency, measured by the slope of improvement over
in-context demonstrations, is conditioned on both the label set quality and the
parameter count of the underlying language model. Despite the emergence of
learning, the relative quality (accuracy) of the choice of a label set
(representation) is largely maintained throughout learning, confirming our
hypothesis and implying their orthogonality. Our work reveals a previously
underexplored aspect of ICL: the independent effects of learning from
demonstrations and their representations on ICL performance.

AI.tldr: Representation and learning in in‑context learning are largely orthogonal: label representations set the baseline accuracy, and adding more demonstrations improves performance on top of that baseline without changing the relative quality of representations; the improvement rate depends on label quality and model size.
AI.motivation: Prior work shows that how in‑context examples—especially labels in classification—are represented strongly affects ICL performance, while evidence on whether more demonstrations consistently yield better accuracy is mixed. The interaction between representation effects and learning-from-more-demos remains unclear.
AI.method: Propose an optimization algorithm to generate a spectrum of label sets (representations) with varying semantic relevance. For each label set, run ICL with differing numbers of in‑context demonstrations and across models of different parameter counts, measuring accuracy and the slope of improvement as demonstrations increase.
AI.result: Learning (performance gains from additional demonstrations) occurs regardless of label set quality. However, the efficiency of learning—the slope of improvement—depends on both label set quality and the model’s parameter count. Despite learning, the relative ranking of label set quality in terms of accuracy remains largely stable across numbers of demonstrations.
AI.conclusion: ICL performance decomposes into two largely independent components: representation sets the baseline, and learning from more demonstrations adds gains on top without altering relative representation quality. This implies practitioners should optimize label representations to raise the baseline, while expecting model size and representation quality to govern how efficiently additional demonstrations help.

title: InstructX: Towards Unified Visual Editing with MLLM Guidance
summary:
With recent advances in Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) showing
strong visual understanding and reasoning, interest is growing in using them to
improve the editing performance of diffusion models. Despite rapid progress,
most studies lack an in-depth analysis of MLLM design choices. Moreover, the
integration of MLLMs and diffusion models remains an open challenge in some
difficult tasks, such as video editing. In this paper, we present InstructX, a
unified framework for image and video editing. Specifically, we conduct a
comprehensive study on integrating MLLMs and diffusion models for
