title: MultiCOIN: Multi-Modal COntrollable Video INbetweening
summary:
Video inbetweening creates smooth and natural transitions between two image
frames, making it an indispensable tool for video editing and long-form video
synthesis. Existing works in this domain are unable to generate large, complex,
or intricate motions. In particular, they cannot accommodate the versatility of
user intents and generally lack fine control over the details of intermediate
frames, leading to misalignment with the creative mind. To fill these gaps, we
introduce \modelname{}, a video inbetweening framework that allows multi-modal
controls, including depth transition and layering, motion trajectories, text
prompts, and target regions for movement localization, while achieving a
balance between flexibility, ease of use, and precision for fine-grained video
interpolation. To achieve this, we adopt the Diffusion Transformer (DiT)
architecture as our video generative model, due to its proven capability to
generate high-quality long videos. To ensure compatibility between DiT and our
multi-modal controls, we map all motion controls into a common sparse and
user-friendly point-based representation as the video/noise input. Further, to
respect the variety of controls which operate at varying levels of granularity
and influence, we separate content controls and motion controls into two
branches to encode the required features before guiding the denoising process,
resulting in two generators, one for motion and the other for content. Finally,
we propose a stage-wise training strategy to ensure that our model learns the
multi-modal controls smoothly. Extensive qualitative and quantitative
experiments demonstrate that multi-modal controls enable a more dynamic,
customizable, and contextually accurate visual narrative.

AI.tldr: They propose a DiT-based video inbetweening framework with rich multi‑modal controls (depth/layering, motion trajectories, text prompts, and region targets). By mapping controls to a common sparse point representation, separating motion and content into two generators, and using stage‑wise training, it produces fine‑grained, high‑quality transitions with complex motions.
AI.motivation: Current inbetweening methods struggle with large/complex motions and offer limited, coarse user control, leading to misalignment with creative intent. The goal is to provide precise, versatile, and easy-to-use control over intermediate frames.
AI.method: Adopt a Diffusion Transformer as the video generator; unify diverse controls via a sparse point-based representation fed as video/noise input; split conditioning into motion vs. content branches with dedicated generators guiding denoising; train with a stage‑wise schedule to progressively learn multi‑modal controls.
AI.result: Extensive qualitative and quantitative evaluations indicate the approach enables more dynamic, customizable, and contextually accurate interpolations, handling complex motions better than prior work.
AI.conclusion: A controllable, creator-aligned video inbetweening system that balances flexibility and precision through multi‑modal control unification, dual-branch (motion/content) conditioning, and staged training, improving fidelity and control of intermediate frames.

title: ResAD: Normalized Residual Trajectory Modeling for End-to-End Autonomous Driving
summary:
End-to-end autonomous driving (E2EAD) systems, which learn to predict future
trajectories directly from sensor data, are fundamentally challenged by the
inherent spatio-temporal imbalance of trajectory data. This imbalance creates a
significant optimization burden, causing models to learn spurious correlations
instead of causal inference, while also prioritizing uncertain, distant
predictions, thereby compromising immediate safety. To address these issues, we
propose ResAD, a novel Normalized Residual Trajectory Modeling framework.
Instead of predicting the future trajectory directly, our approach reframes the
learning task to predict the residual deviation from a deterministic inertial
reference. The inertial reference serves as a counterfactual, forcing the model
to move beyond simple pattern recognition and instead identify the underlying
causal factors (e.g., traffic rules, obstacles) that necessitate deviations
from a default, inertially-guided path. To deal with the optimization imbalance
caused by uncertain, long-term horizons, ResAD further incorporates Point-wise
Normalization of the predicted residual. It re-weights the optimization
objective, preventing large-magnitude errors associated with distant, uncertain
waypoints from dominating the learning signal. Extensive experiments validate
the effectiveness of our framework. On the NAVSIM benchmark, ResAD achieves a
state-of-the-art PDMS of 88.6 using a vanilla diffusion policy with only two
denoising steps, demonstrating that our approach significantly simplifies the
learning task and improves model performance. The code will be released to
facilitate further research.

AI.tldr: ResAD reframes E2E autonomous driving trajectory prediction as learning normalized residuals from a simple inertial reference, mitigating spatio-temporal imbalance and emphasizing causal deviations; it attains SOTA PDMS 88.6 on NAVSIM with a lightweight diffusion policy (2 denoising steps).
AI.motivation: Direct trajectory prediction from raw sensors suffers from spatio-temporal data imbalance: models overfit spurious correlations, overweight uncertain long-horizon waypoints, and underemphasize near-term safety-critical decisions.
AI.method: Normalized Residual Trajectory Modeling: predict the residual from a deterministic inertial reference trajectory used as a counterfactual. Apply point-wise normalization to reweight errors along the horizon so large, uncertain long-term deviations do not dominate the loss. Implemented with a vanilla diffusion policy requiring only two denoising steps.
AI.result: On the NAVSIM benchmark, ResAD achieves state-of-the-art PDMS of 88.6 using a simple diffusion policy with only two denoising steps, indicating improved efficiency and performance.
AI.conclusion: Residual, counterfactual-guided modeling plus point-wise normalization simplifies optimization, promotes causally grounded decisions (e.g., adhering to rules, avoiding obstacles), and improves immediate safety and overall performance; code will be released.

title: NaViL: Rethinking Scaling Properties of Native Multimodal Large Language Models under Data Constraints
comment:
Accepted by NeurIPS 2025. 22 pages, link:
  https://github.com/OpenGVLab/NaViL
summary:
Compositional training has been the de-facto paradigm in existing Multimodal
Large Language Models (MLLMs), where pre-trained vision encoders are connected
with pre-trained LLMs through continuous multimodal pre-training. However, the
multimodal scaling property of this paradigm remains difficult to explore due
to the separated training. In this paper, we focus on the native training of
MLLMs in an end-to-end manner and systematically study its design space and
scaling property under a practical setting, i.e., data constraint. Through
careful study of various choices in MLLM, we obtain the optimal
meta-architecture that best balances performance and training cost. After that,
we further explore the scaling properties of the native MLLM and indicate the
positively correlated scaling relationship between visual encoders and LLMs.
Based on these findings, we propose a native MLLM called NaViL, combined with a
simple and cost-effective recipe. Experimental results on 14 multimodal
benchmarks confirm the competitive performance of NaViL against existing MLLMs.
Besides that, our findings and results provide in-depth insights for the future
study of native MLLMs.

AI.tldr: They propose training multimodal LLMs natively end-to-end (instead of composing pretrained vision encoders with LLMs), systematically explore the design/scaling space under data constraints, and introduce NaViL, a simple, cost-effective model that is competitive on 14 benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Compositional pipelines (pretrained vision encoder + pretrained LLM + multimodal pretraining) make it hard to study multimodal scaling because components are trained separately. The authors want to understand how to best scale and design MLLMs when trained end-to-end, especially under practical data limits.
AI.method: Conduct a systematic, end-to-end (“native”) training study: ablate architectural and training choices to find an optimal meta-architecture balancing performance and cost; analyze scaling by jointly varying visual encoder and LLM sizes under a fixed data budget; derive a simple recipe and instantiate it as NaViL.
AI.result: They find a positive, coupled scaling relationship between vision encoder and LLM capacity; identify an optimal meta-architecture for cost–performance; and show NaViL achieves competitive results across 14 multimodal benchmarks while being simple and cost-effective.
AI.conclusion: End-to-end native training is a viable, efficient alternative to compositional MLLMs. Co-scaling vision and language modules yields better performance, and the proposed NaViL, built on these insights, matches strong baselines with lower complexity, offering guidance for future native MLLM designs.

title: D$^2$GS: Depth-and-Density Guided Gaussian Splatting for Stable and Accurate Sparse-View Reconstruction
summary:
Recent advances in 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) enable real-time,
high-fidelity novel view synthesis (NVS) with explicit 3D representations.
However, performance degradation and instability remain significant under
sparse-view conditions. In this work, we identify two key failure modes under
sparse-view conditions: overfitting in regions with excessive Gaussian density
near the camera, and underfitting in distant areas with insufficient Gaussian
coverage. To address these challenges, we propose a unified framework D$^2$GS,
comprising two key components: a Depth-and-Density Guided Dropout strategy that
suppresses overfitting by adaptively masking redundant Gaussians based on
density and depth, and a Distance-Aware Fidelity Enhancement module that
improves reconstruction quality in under-fitted far-field areas through
targeted supervision. Moreover, we introduce a new evaluation metric to
quantify the stability of learned Gaussian distributions, providing insights
into the robustness of the sparse-view 3DGS. Extensive experiments on multiple
datasets demonstrate that our method significantly improves both visual quality
and robustness under sparse view conditions. The project page can be found at:
https://insta360-research-team.github.io/DDGS-website/.

AI.tldr: D^2GS strengthens sparse-view 3D Gaussian Splatting by tackling two failure modes—near-camera overfitting and far-field underfitting—via depth/density-guided dropout and distance-aware fidelity supervision, plus a new stability metric, yielding better visual quality and robustness.
AI.motivation: Although 3DGS enables real-time, high-fidelity novel view synthesis, its performance degrades and becomes unstable when only a few views are available. The authors aim to diagnose the root causes of this instability and design targeted mechanisms that both prevent overfitting and improve coverage where supervision is weak, while also quantifying model stability.
AI.method: A unified framework, D^2GS, with two components: (1) Depth-and-Density Guided Dropout adaptively masks redundant Gaussians by jointly considering their spatial depth and local density, mitigating near-camera overfitting; (2) Distance-Aware Fidelity Enhancement provides targeted supervision to far-field regions to alleviate underfitting. Additionally, they introduce a stability metric to evaluate the reliability of learned Gaussian distributions under sparse views.
AI.result: Across multiple datasets, D^2GS significantly improves visual quality and robustness for sparse-view NVS compared to standard 3DGS, as validated by experiments and the proposed stability metric. A project page is provided for resources and demos.
AI.conclusion: By explicitly handling both overfitting (near camera) and underfitting (far field) within a single framework and offering a stability metric, D^2GS makes sparse-view 3DGS more reliable and accurate, advancing practical NVS when capture is limited.

title: MATRIX: Multimodal Agent Tuning for Robust Tool-Use Reasoning
summary:
Vision language models (VLMs) are increasingly deployed as controllers with
access to external tools for complex reasoning and decision-making, yet their
effectiveness remains limited by the scarcity of high-quality multimodal
trajectories and the cost of manual annotation. We address this challenge with
a vision-centric agent tuning framework that automatically synthesizes
multimodal trajectories, generates step-wise preference pairs, and trains a VLM
controller for robust tool-use reasoning. Our pipeline first constructs
M-TRACE, a large-scale dataset of 28.5K multimodal tasks with 177K verified
trajectories, enabling imitation-based trajectory tuning. Building on this, we
develop MATRIX Agent, a controller finetuned on M-TRACE for step-wise tool
reasoning. To achieve finer alignment, we further introduce Pref-X, a set of
11K automatically generated preference pairs, and optimize MATRIX on it via
step-wise preference learning. Across three benchmarks, Agent-X, GTA, and GAIA,
MATRIX consistently surpasses both open- and closed-source VLMs, demonstrating
scalable and effective multimodal tool use. Our data and code is avaliable at
https://github.com/mbzuai-oryx/MATRIX.

AI.tldr: They build a large multimodal trajectory dataset (M-TRACE) and a VLM controller (MATRIX) trained via imitation plus step-wise preference learning (Pref-X), yielding state-of-the-art multimodal tool-use performance across benchmarks.
AI.motivation: VLM-based tool-use agents underperform due to the scarcity and expense of high-quality, step-wise multimodal trajectories and annotations needed for reliable reasoning and control.
AI.method: 1) Automatically synthesize and verify multimodal trajectories; 2) Release M-TRACE (28.5K tasks, 177K verified trajectories) for imitation-based tuning; 3) Finetune a VLM controller (MATRIX) for step-wise tool reasoning; 4) Generate Pref-X (11K auto preference pairs) and apply step-wise preference learning for finer alignment.
AI.result: MATRIX consistently outperforms strong open- and closed-source VLMs on Agent-X, GTA, and GAIA benchmarks, demonstrating improved, scalable multimodal tool-use reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Vision-centric agent tuning that combines large-scale synthetic/verified trajectories with step-wise preference optimization produces a robust VLM controller for tool use; resources are released for reproducibility and further research.

title: ReSplat: Learning Recurrent Gaussian Splats
summary:
While feed-forward Gaussian splatting models provide computational efficiency
and effectively handle sparse input settings, their performance is
fundamentally limited by the reliance on a single forward pass during
inference. We propose ReSplat, a feed-forward recurrent Gaussian splatting
model that iteratively refines 3D Gaussians without explicitly computing
gradients. Our key insight is that the Gaussian splatting rendering error
serves as a rich feedback signal, guiding the recurrent network to learn
effective Gaussian updates. This feedback signal naturally adapts to unseen
data distributions at test time, enabling robust generalization. To initialize
the recurrent process, we introduce a compact reconstruction model that
operates in a $16 \times$ subsampled space, producing $16 \times$ fewer
Gaussians than previous per-pixel Gaussian models. This substantially reduces
computational overhead and allows for efficient Gaussian updates. Extensive
experiments across varying of input views (2, 8, 16), resolutions ($256 \times
256$ to $540 \times 960$), and datasets (DL3DV and RealEstate10K) demonstrate
that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance while significantly
reducing the number of Gaussians and improving the rendering speed. Our project
page is at https://haofeixu.github.io/resplat/.

AI.tldr: ReSplat is a recurrent, feed-forward Gaussian splatting method that uses rendering error as a feedback signal to iteratively refine 3D Gaussians without gradients, achieving state-of-the-art quality with far fewer Gaussians and faster rendering.
AI.motivation: Standard feed-forward Gaussian splatting is efficient and works with sparse inputs, but its single-pass inference caps reconstruction quality and generalization, especially on unseen data. The authors seek an approach that preserves efficiency while enabling iterative refinement without costly gradient-based optimization.
AI.method: Introduce ReSplat, a recurrent network that repeatedly updates 3D Gaussians using the renderer’s image-space error as a rich feedback signal. The recurrence adapts at test time to unseen distributions. The process is initialized by a compact reconstruction model operating in a 16× subsampled space, producing 16× fewer Gaussians than per-pixel models, which reduces compute and enables efficient iterative updates—without explicit gradient computation.
AI.result: Across 2, 8, and 16 input views, resolutions from 256×256 to 540×960, and datasets (DL3DV, RealEstate10K), ReSplat attains state-of-the-art reconstruction quality while using significantly fewer Gaussians and rendering faster than prior feed-forward per-pixel Gaussian approaches.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging rendering error as feedback in a recurrent feed-forward framework yields efficient, gradient-free iterative refinement that improves quality, reduces Gaussian count, and accelerates rendering, offering robust generalization to unseen data.
